Elevated plasma viral load in stage 3 was found to correlate with decreased cTfh-mediated B cell IgG production, indicating a role for increased viremia in cTfh impairment and dysfunctional humoral response. Phenotypic perturbations were also evident in the mature B cell compartment, most notably a decrease in resting memory B cells in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2, coinciding with higher viremia. Our coculture assay also suggested that intrinsic memory B cell defects could contribute to the impaired response despite at a lower level. Overall, cTfh-mediated B cell responses are significantly altered in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2, coinciding with increased inflammation and a reduction in memory B cells. These data suggest that early ART for acutely HIV infected individuals could preserve immune dysregulation while preserving cTfh function and B cell memory.
 Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease that affects over 200 million people worldwide. The current treatment for schistosomiasis is praziquantel, which has several non-optimal features. To develop next generation anthelmintics, it is important to identify new drug targets. One approach is to profile flatworm G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), which are a class of receptors that are targeted by over a quarter of current human therapeutics. In this study, the authors pharmacologically profiled a schistosome serotonergic GPCR (Sm . 5HTR) that has been implicated as a downstream modulator of PZQ efficacy. They used a miniaturized screening assay that is compatible with high content screening and employs a split luciferase-based biosensor sensitive to cellular cAMP levels. The authors identified new ligands and compound series selective for Sm . 5HTR, and demonstrated conservation of an unusual antagonist-evoked inactivation mechanism for Sm . 5HTR. These findings suggest that Sm . 5HTR is a promising target for the development of next generation anthelmintics.
 The primordial organization of the metazoan body is achieved during gastrulation by the establishment of the germ layers. Adhesion differences between ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm cells could in principle be sufficient to maintain germ layer integrity and prevent intermixing. However, in organisms as diverse as fly, fish, or amphibian, the ectoderm-mesoderm boundary not only keeps these germ layers separated but the ectoderm also serves as substratum for mesoderm migration, and the boundary must be compatible with repeated cell attachment and detachment. We show that localized detachment resulting from contact-induced signals at the boundary is at the core of ectoderm-mesoderm segregation. Cells alternate between adhesion and detachment, and detachment requires ephrinB/EphB signaling. Multiple ephrinB ligands and EphB receptors are expressed on each side of the boundary, and tissue separation depends on forward signaling across the boundary in both directions, involving partially redundant ligands and receptors and activation of Rac and RhoA. This mechanism differs from a simple differential adhesion process of germ layer formation. Instead, it involves localized responses to signals exchanged at the tissue boundary and an attachment/detachment cycle which allows for cell migration across a cellular substratum.
 Autism Spectrum Disorder ( ASD ) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by social communication and interaction difficulties, as well as restricted and repetitive behaviors and interests.  While the underlying causes of ASD are still unknown, it is believed to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors.  One potential contributor to ASD is dysfunction in the folate-dependent one-carbon metabolism and transsulfuration pathways.  In this study, the authors analyzed metabolite concentrations of these pathways in blood samples from 83 participants with ASD and 76 age-matched neurotypical peers.  Using Fisher Discriminant Analysis, the authors were able to distinguish participants with ASD from neurotypical peers with 96.1% accuracy.  Additionally, kernel partial least squares was used to predict adaptive behavior, as measured by the Vineland Adaptive Behavior Composite score, with an R2 of 0.45 after cross-validation.  These results suggest that dysfunction in the folate-dependent one-carbon metabolism and transsulfuration pathways may be associated with ASD and could potentially be used as biomarkers for diagnosis and severity prediction.  Overall, this study provides strong evidence for the association between these pathways and ASD and highlights the potential for using multivariate statistical analysis to extract important information from complex biochemical data sets.
 Leishmaniasis is a neglected tropical disease that affects millions of people worldwide. In Brazil, the disease is endemic and has been increasing in incidence over the past decade. To better understand the spatial and temporal patterns of leishmaniasis in Brazil, we used Bayesian geostatistical negative binomial models to analyze reported incidence data of cutaneous and visceral leishmaniasis from 2001 to 2010. We identified precipitation and socioeconomic proxies as important risk factors for both types of leishmaniasis. Our risk maps predicted the highest numbers of infected people in the states of Minas Gerais and Pará for visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis, respectively. These maps can be used to prioritize intervention areas and optimize resource allocation for control and elimination efforts.
 Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral disease that is rapidly spreading across the world. Infection with any of the four dengue viral serotypes can cause a range of symptoms, from mild viral illness to severe plasma leakage and shock. Recent studies have shown that adults are increasingly affected by dengue, with unusual complications such as acute liver failure, encephalopathy, myocarditis, and acute renal failure. In this study, we compared the clinical and laboratory features, management, and outcomes of 647 adults and 881 children with confirmed dengue who were hospitalized at a single hospital in southern Vietnam. We found that adults had more severe signs of vascular leakage and shock, while bleeding manifestations and organ involvement were more common in children. Additionally, adults experienced significantly more severe thrombocytopenia. Secondary infection but not serotype was independently associated with greater thrombocytopenia, although with a smaller effect than age-group. The effect of age-group on platelet count was also apparent in the values obtained several weeks after recovery, indicating that healthy adults have intrinsically lower counts compared to children. Our study highlights the distinctions between adults and children in the pattern of complications seen in association with dengue infection, and these depend partly on intrinsic age-dependent physiological differences. This knowledge is important to inform research on disease pathogenesis and to encourage development of management guidelines that are appropriate to the age-groups at risk.
 In this study, we found that a novel mutation in the CCR5 gene of sooty mangabeys (SM) results in a lack of surface expression and coreceptor function. Despite this, SM are susceptible to natural and experimental infection with SIVsmm and exhibit robust viral replication. This is the first clear evidence for in vivo alternative coreceptor use by SIVsmm in its natural hosts. Our data suggests that cell targeting and tropism in SM is linked to expression and use of both CCR5 and additional alternative entry pathways. This is the third example of convergent evolution resulting in nonfunctional mutant CCR5 alleles among primate species.
MEF2 is a family of transcriptional regulators involved in the control of pleiotropic responses during development and adult life. In this study, we have explored the transcriptional landscape and the epigenetic modifications under the control of these TFs in relation to the tumorigenic process using leiomyosarcomas (LMS) as a model. We have shown that MEF2 can support both pro-oncogenic or tumor suppressive activities depending on the interaction with co-activators or co-repressors partners. In LMS, this two-faced trait of MEF2 is relevant for tumor aggressiveness. Class IIa HDACs are overexpressed in 22% of LMS, where high levels of MEF2, HDAC4 and HDAC9 inversely correlate with overall survival. The knock out of HDAC9 suppresses the transformed phenotype of LMS cells by restoring the transcriptional proficiency of some MEF2-target loci. HDAC9 coordinates also the demethylation of H3K4me3 at the promoters of MEF2-target genes. Moreover, we have shown that class IIa HDACs do not bind all the regulative elements bound by MEF2. Hence, in a cell MEF2-target genes actively transcribed and strongly repressed can coexist. These repressed MEF2-targets are poised in terms of chromatin signature. Overall our results candidate class IIa HDACs and HDAC9 in particular, as druggable targets for a therapeutic intervention in LMS.
2D crystalline films of hydrophobins are important for fungal growth and have many industrial applications. We used protein docking, molecular dynamics simulation, and electron cryo-microscopy to study the surface structure of films composed of two class II hydrophobins, HFBI and HFBII, produced by Trichoderma reesei. Our results suggest a unit cell composed of six proteins with P6 symmetry, but our cryo-EM results show a structure with only P3 symmetry. We also found a possible metastable structure with P3 symmetry and a smaller lattice size. Our results provide insight into the structure and properties of hydrophobin films and may have implications for their industrial applications.
 We have identified Threonyl tRNA synthetase ( ThrRS ) as a potential drug target in Leishmania donovani, the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis. We have characterized the enzyme activity of LdThrRS and found it to be essential for the survival of L. donovani. Borrelidin, a known inhibitor of ThrRS, was found to have antileishmanial activity and inhibited the aminoacylation activity of LdThrRS. Our study provides a platform for further exploration of LdThrRS as a potential target for drug discovery against visceral leishmaniasis.
 We have defined a multi-motif PAMP signature of non-self recognition by RIG-I that includes a 5′-ppp with poly-uridine sequence composition and length. This HCV PAMP motif drives potent RIG-I signaling to induce the innate immune response to infection. Our studies define a basis of non-self discrimination by RIG-I and offer insights into the antiviral therapeutic potential of targeted RIG-I signaling activation.
 Eosinophils are known to play a role in host defense and allergy, but recent studies have shown that they also have important functions in metabolism and tissue regeneration. In this study, the authors investigated the role of eosinophils in the growth of Trichinella spiralis larvae in skeletal muscle. They found that IL-4 and eosinophils are necessary for normal larval growth and that eosinophils from IL-4 competent mice are sufficient to support growth. The eosinophil-mediated effect operates in the absence of adaptive immunity. Following invasion by newborn larvae, host gene expression in skeletal muscle was compatible with a regenerative response and a shift in the source of energy in infected tissue. The presence of eosinophils suppressed local inflammation while also influencing nutrient homeostasis in muscle. These findings suggest that eosinophils promote larval growth by an IL-4 dependent mechanism that limits local interferon-driven responses that otherwise alter nutrient metabolism in infected muscle.
 In this study, the authors report a quantitative genome-wide analysis of DNA replication kinetics in several human cell types. They found that DNA replication origins are spaced at 40 kb intervals and fire as small clusters whose synchrony increases during S phase. Replication fork velocity remains constant and narrowly distributed through S phase. However, multi-scale analysis of a genome-wide replication timing profile shows a broad distribution of replication timing gradients with practically no regions larger than 100 kb replicating at less than 2 kb/min. Therefore, HeLa cells lack large regions of unidirectional fork progression. The authors suggest that origins fire independently of each other but under the control of long-range chromatin structure, or that replication forks progressing from early origins stimulate initiation in nearby unreplicated DNA. These findings shed a new light on the replication timing program of mammalian genomes and provide a general model for their replication kinetics.
 Our nervous system is able to recognize objects despite changes in contextual variables such as perspective or lighting conditions. This ability is thought to be due to the fact that object identities typically vary more slowly in time than contextual variables or noise. In this study, we explore how this "temporal stability" or "slowness" approach can be implemented within the limits of biologically realistic spike-based learning rules. We first show that slow feature analysis (SFA), an algorithm based on slowness, can be implemented in linear continuous model neurons using a modified Hebbian learning rule. We then show analytically that for linear Poisson neurons, slowness learning can be implemented by spike-timing–dependent plasticity (STDP) with a specific learning window. By studying the learning dynamics of STDP, we show that for functional interpretations of STDP, it is not the learning window alone that is relevant but rather the convolution of the learning window with the postsynaptic potential. We then derive STDP learning windows that implement slow feature analysis and the "trace rule." The resulting learning windows are compatible with physiological data both in shape and timescale. Moreover, our analysis shows that the learning window can be split into two functionally different components that are sensitive to reversible and irreversible aspects of the input statistics, respectively. The theory indicates that irreversible input statistics are not in favor of stable weight distributions but may generate oscillatory weight dynamics. Our analysis offers a novel interpretation for the functional role of STDP in physiological neurons.
 We have discovered a new phenomenon in heterogeneous tumors called cooperative adaptation to therapy (CAT), where cancer cells induce co-resistant phenotypes in neighboring cancer cells when exposed to cancer therapy. We used CRISPR/Cas9 to engineer phenotypically diverse non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells by conferring mutations in Dicer1, a type III cytoplasmic endoribonuclease involved in small non-coding RNA genesis. We monitored three-dimensional growth dynamics of fluorescently-labeled mutant and/or wild-type cells individually or in co-culture using a substrate-free NanoCulture system under unstimulated or drug pressure conditions. By integrating mathematical modeling with flow cytometry, we characterized the growth patterns of mono- and co-cultures using a mathematical model of intra- and interspecies competition. We found that the combination of WT and mutants in co-cultures allowed for beneficial growth in previously drug sensitive cells despite drug pressure via induction of cell state transitions described by a cooperative game theoretic change in the fitness values. Finally, we used an ex vivo human tumor model that predicts clinical response through drug sensitivity analyses and determined that cellular and morphologic heterogeneity correlates to prognostic failure of multiple clinically-approved and off-label drugs in individual NSCLC patient samples. Together, these findings present a new paradox in drug resistance implicating non-genetic cooperation among tumor cells to thwart drug pressure, suggesting that profiling for druggable targets alone may be insufficient to assign effective therapy.
Rickettsioses are a group of bacterial infections that are transmitted by ticks and other arthropods. They are common in sub-Saharan Africa, but the burden of disease, risk factors, and transmission are not well understood. In this study, we used data from a population-based cohort study in Mbeya, Tanzania to estimate the seroprevalence of IgG antibodies against Spotted Fever Group (SFG) rickettsiae and to assess socioeconomic and environmental risk factors. We found that SFG-seropositivity was 67.9% and that it was associated with age, warmer temperatures, male gender, and low population density. At higher elevations, higher cattle density was associated with higher seroprevalence. These findings suggest that SFG rickettsial infection is common in the more rural population of Mbeya Region and that spread is further limited by temperature and higher elevation. Examination of the contribution of SFG to febrile illnesses seems warranted in a prospective study to estimate the disease burden in the population. This will also allow determination of the causative pathogens.
 Fatty acids play a crucial role in many physiological processes, including the formation of membranes and energy storage. In this study, we uncover a role for the monounsaturated fatty acid oleate in the innate immune response of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. From an RNAi screen for regulators of innate immune defense genes, we identified the two stearoyl-coenzyme A desaturases that synthesize oleate in C . elegans. We show that the synthesis of oleate is necessary for the pathogen-mediated induction of immune defense genes. Accordingly, C . elegans deficient in oleate production are hypersusceptible to infection with diverse human pathogens, which can be rescued by the addition of exogenous oleate. However, oleate is not sufficient to drive protective immune activation. Together, these data add to the known health-promoting effects of monounsaturated fatty acids and suggest an ancient link between nutrient stores, metabolism, and host susceptibility to bacterial infection.
 The study presents a new class of antibiotics that target riboswitches, which are regulatory elements that control gene expression in response to specific metabolite binding. The study focuses on guanine riboswitches, which are involved in the regulation of transport and biosynthesis of purine metabolites. The study shows that a pyrimidine compound, PC1, binds to guanine riboswitches and exhibits bactericidal activity against a subgroup of bacterial species, including well-known nosocomial pathogens. The study also shows that PC1 targets a different metabolic pathway and that it is effective against multiple drug-resistant strains. The study uses a mouse model to show a direct correlation between the administration of PC1 and the reduction of Staphylococcus aureus infection in mammary glands. The study establishes the possibility of using existing structural knowledge to design novel guanine riboswitch-targeting antibiotics as powerful and selective antimicrobial compounds.
 We used virtual reality to study how gaze informs the construction of mental space during wayfinding in macaque monkeys. We found that hippocampal cells in monkeys encode the animal's logical situation within a set of actions leading to the goal, and that this encoding is influenced by the target of gaze. Our findings suggest that counterparts of rodent place cells in primates embody multidimensional, task-situated knowledge pertaining to the target of gaze, therein supporting self-awareness in the construction of space.
 We present a computational analysis of the spatial gene expression patterns at the mid-hindbrain boundary ( MHB ) of the mouse embryo. We use a Boolean approach to infer regulatory interactions between the genes Otx2 , Gbx2 , Fgf8 , Wnt1 , En1/En2 , and Pax2/5 . Our analysis predicts that Fgf8 and Wnt1 signaling are dependent on each other for stable maintenance, but Fgf8 is not sufficient to ectopically induce Wnt1 expression. We validate this prediction experimentally by performing a time-course analysis of Wnt1 expression after Fgf8-bead implantation into mouse anterior neural plate/tube explants. Our analysis clarifies epistatic relationships at the MHB, especially between the two key patterning molecules Fgf8 and Wnt1. We also construct spatial models that are able to explain the stable maintenance of the characteristic gene expression patterns at the MHB. These patterns are the result of a refinement and sharpening of initially blurred expression domains. Our models are competent to simulate this process and reproduce the phenotypes of various loss-of-function experiments even in a correct spatio-temporal order. We conclude with a robustness analysis of our models.
 Theileria annulata is a parasite that causes a disease called tropical theileriosis in cattle. The parasite transforms host cells, causing them to divide uncontrollably. The parasite interacts with host cell microtubules (MTs) to ensure its distribution between daughter cells during cell division. We found that a protein called p104, which is expressed on the surface of the parasite, binds to a protein called EB1, which is a key regulator of MT dynamics. This interaction is mediated by a specific motif in p104. Our findings provide new insight into the mode of interaction between Theileria and the host cell cytoskeleton.
DNA damage is a common occurrence during normal cell division, and cells have developed mechanisms to repair such damage. One such mechanism is homologous recombination (HR), which involves the exchange of genetic information between two homologous DNA molecules. In this study, the authors found that a protein called Pif1 plays a crucial role in HR by promoting the exchange of genetic information between two homologous DNA molecules. They also found that Pif1 is phosphorylated in response to DNA damage, and this phosphorylation is important for its function in HR. The authors propose a model whereby the passage of HR forks through telomeres promotes telomere lengthening. This study provides important insights into the mechanisms of HR and its role in maintaining genome stability.
 Onchocerciasis is a debilitating disease caused by the filarial nematode Onchocerca volvulus . It is a major public health concern in many parts of the world, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. The current diagnostic tools for onchocerciasis are not ideal, as they are invasive, time-consuming, and lack sensitivity. In this study, we investigated the use of luciferase immunoprecipitation systems (LIPS) as a more rapid, specific, and standardized diagnostic assay for onchocerciasis. Four recombinantly produced Onchocerca volvulus antigens were tested by LIPS on a large cohort of blinded sera comprised of both uninfected controls and patients with a proven parasitic infection including Onchocerca volvulus (Ov), Wuchereria bancrofti (Wb), Loa loa (Ll), Strongyloides stercoralis (Ss), and with other potentially cross-reactive infections. In addition to testing all four Ov antigens separately, a mixture that tested all four antigens simultaneously was evaluated in the standard 2-hour incubation format as well as in a 15-minute rapid LIPS format. Antibody responses to the four different Ov antigens allowed for unequivocal differentiation between Ov-infected and uninfected control sera with 100% sensitivity and 100% specificity. Analysis of the antibody titers to each of these four antigens in individual Ov-infected sera revealed that they were markedly different and did not correlate (rS = –0.11 to 0.58; P = 0.001 to 0.89) to each other. Compared to Ov-infected sera, patients infected with Wb, Ll, Ss, and other conditions had markedly lower geometric mean antibody titers to each of the Ov 4 antigens (P<0.0002 for each antigen). The simplified method of using a mixture of the 4 Ov antigens simultaneously in the standard format or a quick 15-minute format (QLIPS) showed 100% sensitivity and specificity in distinguishing the Ov-infected sera from the uninfected control sera. Finally, the QLIPS format had the best performance with 100% sensitivity and specificity values of 76%, 84%, and 93% for distinguishing Ov from Wb, Ll, and Ss-infected sera, respectively. The multi-antigen LIPS assay can be used as a rapid, high throughput, and specific tool to not only to diagnose individual Ov infections but also as a sensitive and potentially point-of-care method for early detection of recrudescent infections in areas under control and for mapping new areas of transmission of Ov infection.
 The Encyclopedia of DNA Elements (ENCODE) Project is a large-scale effort to identify and characterize functional elements in the human genome. The project involves multiple technologies and approaches, including chromatin immunoprecipitation, DNA methylation analysis, and RNA sequencing. The ENCODE Consortium, comprising 27 institutions, is working to generate high-quality data and develop novel algorithms to facilitate analysis. The data and derived results are made available through a freely accessible database. The project has identified several classes of functional elements, including genes, transcripts, and transcriptional regulatory regions, as well as DNA binding proteins that interact with regulatory regions in the genome. The ENCODE Project has also developed standards to ensure high-quality, reproducible data and has placed an emphasis on data quality, including ongoing development and application of standards for data reproducibility and the collection of associated experimental information. The Consortium has prioritized the analysis of selected sets of cell types, including two widely studied immortalized cell lines, an EBV-immortalized B-lymphoblastoid line, and the H1 human embryonic stem cell line, as well as more than 100 cell types that are being analyzed in selected assays. The ENCODE Project aims to provide the scientific and medical communities with high-quality, comprehensive annotations of candidate functional elements in the human genome, which will enable the interpretation of the human genome and improve health.
 Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) is a common human virus that causes infectious mononucleosis and is associated with various cancers. EBV evades the host immune system by downregulating its antigen expression during the latent phase of infection and by producing immune evasion proteins during the replicative phase. In this study, the authors identified a new immune evasion protein, gp150, which is expressed during the late phase of infection and interferes with antigen presentation by HLA I, II, and CD1d molecules. The authors provide evidence that gp150 shields the recognition of these surface molecules in a glycan-dependent manner. This represents a novel immune evasion mechanism in herpesviruses.
 The translocated actin recruiting phosphoprotein ( Tarp ) is a conserved protein among all pathogenic chlamydial species . Previous studies have identified the actin binding and proline rich domains of Tarp as essential for Tarp-mediated actin nucleation . In this study, we examined the actin binding domains of Tarp orthologs from different chlamydial species and found that they all promote actin nucleation. We also generated a peptide antiserum specific for the Tarp actin binding domain and found that it inhibited actin polymerization in vitro and chlamydial entry in vivo. Our findings suggest that Tarp-mediated actin polymerization is a conserved feature among diverse chlamydial species and plays an important role in bacterial entry.
 Schistosomiasis japonica is a zoonosis with a number of mammalian species acting as reservoir hosts, including water buffaloes which can contribute up to 75% to human transmission in the People's Republic of China. Determining prevalence and intensity of Schistosoma japonicum in mammalian hosts is important for calculating transmission rates and determining environmental contamination. A new procedure, the formalin–ethyl acetate sedimentation-digestion (FEA–SD) technique, for increased visualization of S. japonicum eggs in bovine feces is described. The procedure involves filtration, sedimentation, potassium hydroxide digestion and centrifugation steps prior to microscopy. Bulk debris, including the dense cellulosic material present in bovine feces, often obscures schistosome eggs with the result that prevalence and infection intensity based on direct visualization cannot be made accurately. This technique removes nearly 70% of debris from the fecal samples and renders the remaining debris translucent. It allows improved microscopic visualization of S. japonicum eggs and provides an accurate quantitative method for the estimation of infection in bovines and other ruminant reservoir hosts. The FEA-SD technique could be of considerable value if applied as a surveillance tool for animal reservoirs of S. japonicum, particularly in areas with low to high infection intensity, or where, following control efforts, there is suspected elimination of schistosomiasis japonica.
 Osteogenesis Imperfecta ( OI ) is a genetic disorder characterized by low bone mass, bone deformities, and joint laxity. It is caused by mutations in genes that encode proteins involved in the synthesis and processing of collagen, the main component of bone. In particular, mutations in the genes encoding cartilage associated protein ( CRTAP ) and prolyl 3-hydroxylase 1 ( P3H1 ) have been identified as the first causes of recessive OI. These proteins, together with cyclophilin B ( encoded by PPIB ), form a complex that 3-hydroxylates a single proline residue on the α1 ( I ) chain ( Pro986 ) and has cis/trans isomerase ( PPIase ) activity essential for proper collagen folding. Recent data suggest that prolyl 3-hydroxylation of Pro986 is not required for the structural stability of collagen; however, the absence of this post-translational modification may disrupt protein-protein interactions integral for proper collagen folding and lead to collagen over-modification. To distinguish between these functions, we generated knock-in mice carrying a single amino acid substitution in the catalytic site of P3h1 ( Lepre1H662A ). This substitution abolished P3h1 activity but retained ability to form a complex with Crtap and thus the collagen chaperone function. Knock-in mice showed absence of prolyl 3-hydroxylation at Pro986 of the α1 ( I ) and α1 ( II ) collagen chains but no significant over-modification at other collagen residues. They were normal in appearance, had no growth defects and normal cartilage growth plate histology but showed decreased trabecular bone mass. This new mouse model recapitulates elements of the bone phenotype of OI but not the cartilage and growth phenotypes caused by loss of the prolyl 3-hydroxylation complex. Our observations suggest differential tissue consequences due to selective inactivation of P3H1 hydroxylase activity versus complete ablation of the prolyl 3-hydroxylation complex.
 The P-element is a type of transposable element that was horizontally transferred from a distantly related species into Drosophila melanogaster . Despite causing ‘hybrid dysgenesis’ , a syndrome of abnormal phenotypes that include sterility , the P-element spread globally in the course of a few decades in D . melanogaster . Until recently , its sister species , including D . simulans , remained P-element free . Here , we find a hybrid dysgenesis-like phenotype in the offspring of crosses between D . simulans strains collected in different years; a survey of 181 strains shows that around 20% of strains induce hybrid dysgenesis . Using genomic and transcriptomic data , we show that this dysgenesis-inducing phenotype is associated with the invasion of the P-element . To characterize this invasion temporally and geographically , we survey 631 D . simulans strains collected on three continents and over 27 years for the presence of the P-element . We find that the D . simulans P-element invasion occurred rapidly and nearly simultaneously in the regions surveyed , with strains containing P-elements being rare in 2006 and common by 2014 . Importantly , as evidenced by their resistance to the hybrid dysgenesis phenotype , strains collected from the latter phase of this invasion have adapted to suppress the worst effects of the P-element .
 We report on the adaptation of a rhodamine B marking technique for male Aedes aegypti to allow for rapid assessment of competitiveness ( mating success ) during field releases. Rhodamine B marking is a potentially useful evaluation method for male-based sterile insect technique ( SIT ) control strategies as well as a viable body marking technique for male-based mark-release-recapture experiments without the negative side-effects of traditional marking methods. We report on a series of experiments with the goals of determining optimal feeding regimes for ideal body and seminal fluid marking, as well as any potential impacts of rhodamine B feeding on male survival and male mating competitiveness. We conclude by presenting results from proof-of-principle field releases.
 Superantigens are a family of toxins produced by certain bacteria that can cause severe inflammatory responses and even death in humans. These toxins bind directly to T cells and major histocompatibility complex II (MHC-II) molecules on antigen-presenting cells, bypassing the need for conventional antigen presentation. This allows superantigens to activate a large number of T cells, resulting in massive cytokine production and inflammation. In this study, we found that superantigens must bind directly to the dimer interface of CD28, a costimulatory receptor expressed on T cells, to elicit inflammatory cytokine gene expression and toxicity. We also found that preventing access of superantigens to CD28 is sufficient to block their lethality. Our findings suggest that CD28 is a critical receptor target for superantigen toxins and reveal a novel role for CD28 in pathogen recognition.
 The Wnt/β-catenin pathway is important for the development and maintenance of pluripotent stem cells. In this study, the authors found that the Wnt/β-catenin pathway controls the cell cycle of mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs) by regulating the expression of cell cycle inhibitors. They showed that the Wnt/β-catenin pathway induces the expression of negative regulators of the cell cycle, such as p16Ink4a and p19Arf, leading to a reduction in cell proliferation and an increase in the number of cells in G1. The authors also found that the Wnt/β-catenin pathway regulates the expression of pluripotency genes, but not differentiation genes. They showed that the Wnt/β-catenin pathway recruits the transcription factor Tcf1 to the promoters of cell cycle genes, such as the Ink4/Arf locus, leading to an increased expression of negative regulators of the cell cycle. The authors concluded that the Wnt/β-catenin pathway controls the cell cycle of mESCs by regulating the expression of cell cycle inhibitors.
Dengue virus (DENV) is a major public health problem in tropical countries, causing a broad spectrum of clinical manifestations from asymptomatic to severe and even fatal features. In this study, we aimed to characterize the activation of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) in dengue patients and their function under DENV-2 stimulation in vitro. We found that pDCs of mild dengue patients exhibit significantly higher frequencies of membrane TRAIL compared to severe cases or healthy controls. Plasma levels of IFN-α and soluble TRAIL are increased in mild compared to severe dengue patients, positively correlating with pDC activation. In vitro experiments showed that DENV-2 induced mTRAIL relocalization and IFN-α production by pDC. Furthermore, we found that pDC effect on viral load reduction was mainly dependent on IFN-α production. Thus, we propose that TRAIL-expressing pDCs may have an important role in the outcome of disease.
 The immune response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ) infection is complex and involves various cytokines, including tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ). TNF plays a major role in host defense against Mtb in both active and latent phases of infection. TNF-neutralizing drugs used to treat inflammatory disorders have been reported to increase the risk of tuberculosis ( TB ), in accordance with animal studies. The present study takes a computational approach toward characterizing the role of TNF in protection against the tubercle bacillus in both active and latent infection. We extend our previous mathematical models to investigate the roles and production of soluble ( sTNF ) and transmembrane TNF ( tmTNF ). We analyze effects of anti-TNF therapy in virtual clinical trials ( VCTs ) by simulating two of the most commonly used therapies, anti-TNF antibody and TNF receptor fusion, predicting mechanisms that explain observed differences in TB reactivation rates. The major findings from this study are that bioavailability of TNF following anti-TNF therapy is the primary factor for causing reactivation of latent infection and that sTNF—even at very low levels—is essential for control of infection. Using a mathematical model, it is possible to distinguish mechanisms of action of the anti-TNF treatments and gain insights into the role of TNF in TB control and pathology. Our study suggests that a TNF-modulating agent could be developed that could balance the requirement for reduction of inflammation with the necessity to maintain resistance to infection and microbial diseases. Alternatively, the dose and timing of anti-TNF therapy could be modified. Anti-TNF therapy will likely lead to numerous incidents of primary TB if used in areas where exposure is likely.
1000 Genomes Project revealed 208 retroduplication variations (RDVs) in human genomes. In this study, we investigated the variation in loss of ancestral (shared with other primates) retrocopies among different human populations. We also examined retrocopy expression levels using RNA-Seq data and detected 193 RDVs. Most of these RDVs resulted from retrocopy deletion. We experimentally confirmed the expression of 11 ancestral retrogenes that underwent deletion in certain individuals. The frequency of their deletion, with the exception of one retrogene, is very low. The expression, conservation and low rate of deletion of the remaining 10 retrocopies may suggest some functionality. We also searched for differences in retrocopy expression levels between populations and found 9 retrogenes that undergo statistically significant differential expression.
 Neurocysticercosis ( NCC ) is a disease caused by the larval stage of the parasitic helminth Taenia solium, which infects the central nervous system ( CNS ) of humans and pigs. The inflammatory response to cysticerci varies depending on their location and the extent of the parasite's degeneration. This study compared the inflammatory response to cysticerci located in the parenchyma, meninges, or both tissues in naturally infected pigs. The results showed that cysticerci located in the parenchyma elicited a significantly greater inflammatory response after anthelmintic treatment compared to those located in the meninges or both tissues. The study suggests that the suboptimal inflammatory response to cysticidal drugs may be the reason subarachnoid NCC is generally refractory to treatment compared to parenchymal NCC.
Yaws is a re-emerging endemic treponemal infection caused by Treponema pallidum ssp. pertenue. Azithromycin is the cornerstone of the WHO yaws eradication campaign. However, there is a possibility that resistance may have emerged in T. pallidum pertenue or that alternative infections may be responsible for some of the reported cases. We conducted a cross-sectional survey in thirty communities in two districts of Ghana where MDA for trachoma had previously been conducted. Children aged 5–17 years with ulcerative lesions compatible with yaws were enrolled. Samples for treponemal serology and lesion PCR were collected from all children. We found no evidence of ongoing transmission of yaws in these communities. H. ducreyi was associated with a proportion of skin lesions, but the majority of lesions remain unexplained. Integration of diagnostic testing into both pre and post-MDA surveillance systems is required to better inform yaws control programmes.
 We have shown that two FDA-approved drugs, tofacitinib and ruxolitinib, can block the seeding and maintenance of the HIV reservoir in vitro. These drugs target the Jak-STAT pathway, which is involved in regulating homeostasis of memory T cells, the major hub of the HIV reservoir. We have also shown that these drugs can block viral production from infected cells and inhibit γ-C receptor cytokine (IL-2, IL-7, and IL-15)-induced viral reactivation from latent stores. These results suggest that dysregulation of the Jak-STAT pathway is associated with HIV persistence and that Jak inhibitors may be integrated into future curative strategies.
 Baculoviruses are large DNA viruses that infect arthropods, mainly insects from the orders Lepidoptera, Diptera, and Hymenoptera. During their replication cycle, they produce two distinct morphological forms, the occlusion-derived virus that is responsible for transmission of the infection between insects and the budded virus that is responsible for spreading the infection within one insect host. In this study, we used microarray analysis to determine genes differentially expressed in S. exigua cells challenged with the species-specific baculovirus SeMNPV as well as with a generalist baculovirus, AcMNPV. We found that, in contrast to the host transcriptional shut-off that is expected during baculovirus infection, S. exigua cells showed a balanced number of up- and down-regulated genes during the first 36 hours following the infection. Many immune-related genes, including pattern recognition proteins, genes involved in signalling and immune pathways, as well as immune effectors and genes coding for proteins involved in the melanization cascade were found to be down-regulated after baculovirus infection. The down-regulation of immune-related genes was confirmed in the larval gut. We also observed an increase in the gut bacterial load following baculovirus infection. We hypothesize this to be a consequence of viral infection. Subsequent experiments on virus performance in the presence and absence of gut microbiota revealed that gut bacteria enhanced baculovirus virulence, pathogenicity, and dispersion. We discuss the host immune response processes and pathways affected by baculoviruses, as well as the role of gut microbiota in viral infection.
 We have identified a novel gene that controls entry into the second meiotic division in Arabidopsis thaliana . By combining a mutation in this gene with two others that affect key meiotic processes, we created a genotype called MiMe in which meiosis is totally replaced by mitosis . The obtained plants produce functional diploid gametes that are genetically identical to their mother . This is an important step towards understanding and engineering apomixis .
 The current study is the first large-scale assessment of the contribution of tissue-specific information to gene prioritization. By integrating tissue-specific gene expression data with protein interaction information, the authors construct tissue-specific protein-protein interaction networks for 60 tissues and investigate their prioritization power. They find that tissue-specific PPI networks considerably improve the prioritization results compared to those obtained using a generic PPI network. Furthermore, they allow predicting novel disease-tissue associations, pointing to sub-clinical tissue effects that may escape early detection. The authors conclude that incorporating tissue-specific information into the prioritization process is likely to yield more accurate results.
 Insecticide resistance is a major concern in the fight against malaria, a disease that kills over 400,000 people each year. Insecticide resistance occurs when mosquitoes develop mutations that allow them to survive exposure to insecticides. This can happen when insecticides are used in the same way over and over again. To combat this, researchers have developed a model to help determine the best way to use insecticides to minimize the spread of resistance. The model takes into account the exposure of males and females to different concentrations of insecticides and the selection pressures and dominance values of different concentrations. The model was used to investigate the relative merits of sequential use of insecticides versus their deployment as a mixture. The results showed that both strategies can last more than 500 mosquito generations, but in those runs where resistance had spread to high levels by 500 generations, 56% favoured sequential use and 44% favoured mixtures. Mixtures are favoured when insecticide effectiveness ( their ability to kill homozygous susceptible genotypes ) is high and exposure ( the proportion of mosquitoes that encounter the insecticide ) is low. If insecticides do not reliably kill homozygous sensitive genotypes, it is likely that sequential deployment will be a more robust strategy. The model provides a flexible framework for investigating the spread of insecticide resistance in vector populations and identifying vector control strategies most likely to minimize the spread of insecticide resistance.
 Blood-sucking insects, such as triatomines, have evolved complex mechanisms to counteract host responses during feeding. These mechanisms include the release of bioactive molecules from their saliva, which can have therapeutic potential. In this study, next-generation sequencing and mass spectrometry were used to investigate the salivary transcriptome of Rhodnius neglectus, a kissing bug that acts as a vector of Chagas disease. The study identified 73 putative secretory proteins, including lipocalins, serine protease inhibitors, and antigen-5. The data presented in this study can improve our understanding of hematophagy and the complex interplay among vectors and their vertebrate hosts, and aid in the development of new therapeutic molecules.
In this study, we used transcriptional profiling to identify genes that are differentially expressed in response to different bacterial environments in the soil nematode Caenorhabditis elegans . We then used mutations to inactivate these genes and showed that many of them contribute to lifespan and/or fitness in a given bacterial environment . We also found that the degree of differential gene expression between two bacterial environments predicted the magnitude of the effect of the loss of gene function on life history traits in those environments . Our results suggest that examination of differential gene expression in different environments can be informative about the relative contributions to function, at least for life history traits.
 The blastocyst is a critical stage in mammalian embryo development where the inner cell mass ( ICM ) and trophoectoderm ( TE ) are formed. The ICM gives rise to the embryo proper, while the TE forms the placenta. The formation of these structures is a dynamic process that involves cell movements, cell-cell interactions, and gene expression. In this study, the authors developed a computational model to investigate the mechanisms underlying the formation of the ICM and TE. The model incorporates stochastic effects, such as gene expression noise, and takes into account the physical structure of the embryo. The authors used quantitative imaging data to test the predictions of the model and found that noise-mediated plasticity plays a critical role in organizing the blastocyst. The authors also found that asymmetries in gene expression noise can promote plasticity while ameliorating the potentially detrimental effects of stochasticity. These results suggest that noise has a crucial role in maintaining cellular plasticity and organizing the blastocyst.
 The immune system is a complex network of cells and molecules that work together to protect the body from foreign invaders. One of the key players in this network are antibodies, which are proteins that bind to specific molecules on the surface of pathogens and help to neutralize them. The ability of antibodies to bind to a wide range of different molecules is thought to be due to their inherent flexibility, which allows them to adapt to different binding partners. In this study, the authors used computational methods to design antibodies that could bind to multiple different molecules at once. They found that the antibodies they designed were more flexible than mature antibodies, and that this flexibility was important for their ability to bind to multiple different molecules. The authors suggest that this flexibility is an important feature of antibodies that allows them to adapt to a wide range of different pathogens.
The study of locust behavior has been a topic of interest for many years, as these insects can form destructive swarms that can devastate crops and vegetation. In this study, the authors developed a mathematical model to describe the phase change of locusts from solitary to gregarious behavior. They found that the phase change is driven by the interactions between locusts and that the critical density at which the phase change occurs depends on the behavioral parameters of the individual locusts. The authors also found that the final ratio of gregarious to solitary locusts is determined by the behavioral parameters of the individual locusts. Their model also exhibits population-level hysteresis, which has implications for locust management.
 Viral membrane fusion is a critical step in the entry of enveloped viruses into host cells. The fusion process is driven by conformational changes of viral envelope glycoproteins, which are triggered by specific stimuli such as acidic pH or receptor interactions. Here, we used tick-borne encephalitis virus (TBEV) as a model to study the fusion process of class II flaviviruses. We found that exposure of TBEV virions to alkaline pH traps the particles in an intermediate conformation in which the E dimers dissociate and interact with target membranes via the fusion peptide without proceeding to the merger of the membranes. Further treatment to low pH leads to fusion, suggesting that these monomers correspond to an as-yet-elusive intermediate required to convert the prefusion dimer into the postfusion trimer. Our data provide important new insights into the dynamic process of viral membrane fusion.
 The rapid and accelerating loss of biodiversity is a significant ecological challenge. Present-day rates of extinction are several orders of magnitude greater than background rates and are projected to increase further if current trends continue. In vertebrates, species traits such as body size, fecundity, and geographic range are important predictors of vulnerability. However, our knowledge of plant extinctions and vulnerabilities is lagging. Here, we disentangle the underlying drivers of extinction risk in plants, focusing on the Cape of South Africa, a global biodiversity hotspot. By comparing Red List data for the British and South African floras, we demonstrate that the taxonomic distribution of extinction risk differs significantly between regions, inconsistent with a simple trait-based model of extinction. Using a comprehensive phylogenetic tree for the Cape, we reveal a phylogenetic signal in the distribution of plant extinction risks but show that the most threatened species cluster within short branches at the tips of the phylogeny—opposite to trends in mammals. From analyzing the distribution of threatened species across 11 exemplar clades, we suggest that mode of speciation best explains the unusual phylogenetic structure of extinction risks in plants of the Cape. Our results have important implications for conservation priorities and cast doubts on the utility of current Red List criteria for plants in regions such as the Cape, where speciation has been rapid, if our aim is to maximize the preservation of the tree-of-life.
 The innate immune system is the first line of defense against pathogens. Dectin-1 is a pattern recognition receptor that recognizes fungal β-glucan and plays a crucial role in anti-fungal immunity. In this study, two new interactors of Dectin-1, Bruton's Tyrosine Kinase (BTK) and Vav1, were identified in macrophages. BTK and Vav1 are recruited to phagocytic cups containing C . albicans yeasts or hyphae but are absent from mature phagosomes. BTK and Vav1 localize to cuff regions surrounding the hyphae, while Dectin-1 lines the full length of the phagosome. BTK and Vav1 colocalize with the lipid PI ( 3 , 4 , 5 ) P3 and F-actin at the phagocytic cup, but not with diacylglycerol ( DAG ) which marks more mature phagosomal membranes. Using a selective BTK inhibitor, it was shown that BTK contributes to DAG synthesis at the phagocytic cup and the subsequent recruitment of PKCε. BTK- or Vav1-deficient peritoneal macrophages display a defect in both zymosan and C . albicans phagocytosis. Bone marrow-derived macrophages that lack BTK or Vav1 show reduced uptake of C . albicans, comparable to Dectin1-deficient cells. BTK- or Vav1-deficient mice are more susceptible to systemic C . albicans infection than wild type mice. This work identifies an important role for BTK and Vav1 in immune responses against C . albicans.
 Rift Valley fever ( RVF ) is a vector-borne disease affecting ruminants and humans . Madagascar was heavily affected by RVF in 2008–2009 , with evidence of a large and heterogeneous spread of the disease . The identification of at-risk environments is essential to optimize the available resources by targeting RVF surveillance in Madagascar . Herein , the objectives of our study were: ( i ) to identify the environmental factors and areas favorable to RVFV transmission to both cattle and human and ( ii ) to identify human behaviors favoring human infections in Malagasy contexts . First , we characterized the environments of Malagasy communes using a Multiple Factor Analysis ( MFA ) . Then , we analyzed cattle and human serological data collected at national level using Generalized Linear Mixed Models , with the individual serological status ( cattle or human ) as the response , and MFA factors , as well as other potential risk factors ( cattle density , human behavior ) as explanatory variables. Cattle and human seroprevalence rates were positively associated to humid environments ( p<0 . 001 ) . Areas with high cattle density were at risk ( p<0 . 01; OR = 2 . 6 ) . Furthermore , our analysis showed that frequent contact with raw milk contributed to explain human infection ( OR = 1 . 6 ) . Finally , our study highlighted the eastern-coast , western and north-western parts as high-risk areas for RVF transmission in cattle . Our integrated approach analyzing environmental , cattle and human datasets allow us to bring new insight on RVF transmission patterns in Madagascar . The association between cattle seroprevalence , humid environments and high cattle density suggests that concomitant vectorial and direct transmissions are critical to maintain RVF enzootic transmission . Additionally , in the at-risk humid environment of the western , north-western and the eastern-coast areas , suitable to Culex and Anopheles mosquitoes , vectorial transmission probably occurs in both cattle and human . The relative contribution of vectorial or direct transmissions could be further assessed by mathematic modelling .
 Prions are self-propagating protein conformations that can be transmitted between non-identical proteins. Transmission barriers are attributed to sequence differences in prion proteins, but their underlying mechanisms are not clear. We used a yeast Rnq1/[PIN+]-based experimental system to explore the nature of transmission barriers. We found that Rnq1 encompasses multiple prion determinants that can independently drive amyloid formation in vitro and transmit the [PIN+] prion state in vivo. Subsequent analysis of [PIN+] transmission between Rnq1 fragments with different sets of prion determinants established that (i) one common QN-rich region is required and usually sufficient for the transmission; (ii) despite identical sequences of the common QNs, such transmissions are impeded by barriers of different strength. Existence of transmission barriers in the absence of amino acid mismatches in transmitting regions indicates that in complex prion domains multiple prion determinants act cooperatively to attain the final prion conformation, and reveals transmission barriers determined by this cooperative fold.
 We present a novel deep learning framework for population genetic inference. Our method is able to separate the global nature of demography from the local nature of selection, without sequential steps for these two factors. We apply our method to 197 African Drosophila melanogaster genomes from Zambia to infer both their overall demography and regions of their genome under selection. We find many regions of the genome that have experienced hard sweeps, and fewer under selection on standing variation or balancing selection. Interestingly, we find that soft sweeps and balancing selection occur more frequently closer to the centromere of each chromosome. In addition, our demographic inference suggests that previously estimated bottlenecks for African Drosophila melanogaster are too extreme. Our deep learning method is a powerful tool for population genetic inference and learning informative features of data.
HPV oncogenes E6/E7 are known to cause genomic instability and increase sensitivity to DNA crosslinking agents. In this study, we found that HPV E6/E7 attenuate the FA DNA crosslink repair pathway by inhibiting the completion of the repair process. E6/E7 impaired FancD2 colocalization with double-strand breaks, which subsequently hindered the recruitment of the downstream protein Rad51 to DSB in E6 cells. Further, E6 expression caused delayed FancD2 deubiquitination, an important process for effective ICL repair. E6 mediated p53 degradation did not hamper the cell cycle specific process of FancD2 modifications but abrogated repair by disrupting FancD2 deubiquitination. These findings uncover unique mechanisms by which HPV oncogenes contribute to genomic instability and the response to cisplatin therapies.
 Onchocerciasis is a disease caused by the parasite Onchocerca volvulus and transmitted by black flies. In Mexico, the Southern Chiapas focus was the largest onchocerciasis focus in Latin America. Since 1998, the focus has undergone semi-annual mass treatment with ivermectin. In 2003, 50 communities shifted from twice to four times a year, and 113 communities were added to the quarterly treatment regimen in 2009. In-depth epidemiological and entomological assessments were conducted in six sentinel communities and three extra-sentinel communities. None of the 67,924 Simulium ochraceum s. l. collected from this focus during the dry season of 2011 were found to contain parasite DNA when tested by polymerase chain reaction-enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (PCR-ELISA), resulting in an upper bound of the 95% confidence interval (95%-ULCI) of the infective rate in the vectors of 0.06/2,000 flies examined. Serological assays testing for Onchocerca volvulus exposure conducted on 4,230 children 5 years of age and under (of a total population of 10,280 in this age group) revealed that 2/4,230 individuals were exposed to O. volvulus (0.05%; one sided 95% confidence interval=0.08%). The in-depth epidemiological and entomological findings from the Southern Chiapas focus meet the criteria for interruption of transmission developed by the international community.
 Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive bacterium that causes foodborne illnesses in humans. It is able to survive in soil and can become an intracellular pathogen following ingestion by mammals. The bacterium uses a number of virulence factors to gain entry into host cells, escape from host cell vacuoles, replicate within the cytosol, and spread to infect adjacent cells. The central virulence regulatory protein, PrfA, is a transcriptional activator that regulates the expression of many virulence genes. PrfA activation occurs following bacterial entry into host cells, but the identity of the small molecule cofactor that triggers PrfA activation has not yet been determined. In this study, the authors have identified a lipoprotein, PplA, that is secreted by L. monocytogenes and that shares homology with a peptide pheromone-encoding lipoprotein in E. faecalis. The authors have shown that PplA is required for L. monocytogenes virulence and that it may help the bacterium sense its presence within the confines of the host cell vacuole, stimulating the expression of virulence genes.
 Vibrio cholerae is a bacterium that causes cholera, a severe diarrheal disease. To survive in the harsh environment of the human intestine, V. cholerae has developed a number of adaptations, including the ability to cope with oxidative stress. In this study, we used a genetic approach to identify genes that are important for V. cholerae to survive in the host intestine. We found that a gene called mutS is important for V. cholerae to survive in the host intestine, especially in the presence of oxidative stress. MutS is involved in a process called mismatch repair, which helps to repair errors that occur during DNA replication. We also found that mutations in genes that produce an enzyme called catalase, which helps to break down hydrogen peroxide, and genes that produce a type of protein called rugose variants, which help V. cholerae to form biofilms, are important for V. cholerae to survive in the host intestine. These findings suggest that V. cholerae uses a combination of adaptations to survive in the host intestine, and that these adaptations are important for the bacterium to cause disease.
 Mlh1-Mlh3 is a protein complex that plays a role in both meiosis and mismatch repair (MMR). In meiosis, Mlh1-Mlh3 is involved in the resolution of double Holliday junctions (dHJs) into crossovers (COs) and noncrossovers (NCOs). In MMR, Mlh1-Mlh3 is involved in the recognition and repair of mismatched DNA.  To understand the function of Mlh1-Mlh3 in both meiosis and MMR, the authors analyzed 60 new mlh3 alleles in baker’s yeast. They found that five alleles specifically disrupted MMR, while one (mlh3-32) specifically disrupted meiotic crossing over. The authors also constructed whole genome recombination maps for wild-type and MMR+ crossover- , MMR- crossover+ , endonuclease defective and null mlh3 mutants in an S288c/YJM789 hybrid background.  The authors observed an increase in the number of noncrossover events in all of the mlh3 mutants, consistent with recombination intermediates being resolved through alternative recombination pathways. They also found that Mlh1-Mlh3 is an endonuclease that nicks circular duplex DNA in vitro, and that Mlh1-mlh3-32 (MMR+ crossover-) is defective in endonuclease activity.  The authors suggest that the defects seen in their mutants can be explained by a weakening of protein-protein interactions, which can be tolerated in meiosis but not MMR. They also provide new insights into how defective meiotic components can alter the fate of meiotic recombination intermediates.  Overall, the authors provide a structure-function map of Mlh3 that reveals the importance of protein-protein interactions in regulating Mlh1-Mlh3’s enzymatic activity. They also illustrate how defective meiotic components can alter the fate of meiotic recombination intermediates, providing new insights for how meiotic recombination pathways are regulated.
 Antibiotic resistance is a growing concern for public health. The emergence of resistance often leads to a switch to new drugs and the discontinuation of older ones. However, this can result in the persistence of resistance indefinitely. Here, we show that host contact structure, in particular heterogeneity in the number of contacts, plays an important role in the reversion dynamics. Host contact structure acts both during the phase of intense treatment, leading to non-random distributions of the resistant strain among the infected population, and after the discontinuation of the drug, by affecting the competition dynamics resulting in a mitigation of fitness advantages. As a consequence, we observe both a lower rate of reversion and a lower probability that reversion to sensitivity on the population level occurs after treatment is stopped. Our simulations show that the impact of heterogeneity in the host population is maximal in the biologically most plausible parameter range, namely when fitness costs of resistance are small.
 Autism spectrum disorders ( ASDs ) are complex neurodevelopmental diseases that are caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Recent studies have identified large structural variants, such as copy number variants ( CNVs ), that are associated with ASD. However, the mechanisms by which these variants contribute to ASD are not well understood. In this study, we used Drosophila as a model organism to investigate the effects of CNVs on neurological phenotypes. We found that dosage changes in unique Drosophila orthologues of genes affected by CNVs in humans with ASD led to synaptic and circadian defects. We also found that pairwise dosage changes in orthologues of genes affected by the same CNV led to synergistic effects on synaptic and circadian phenotypes. These findings suggest that the combination of genetic variants, rather than individual variants, may contribute to the development of ASD.
 Experimental cerebral malaria ( ECM ) is a severe neurological syndrome caused by infection with the parasite Plasmodium berghei ANKA ( Pb ANKA ) in susceptible mice. The pathogenic role of CD8+ T cells in ECM has been well established, but the mechanisms through which they mediate their pathogenic activity during malaria infection remain poorly understood. In this study, we used intravital two-photon microscopy and detailed ex vivo flow cytometric analysis to investigate the behavior of brain-infiltrating CD8+ T cells during ECM. We found that CD8+ T cells accumulated perivascularly within the meninges of mice with ECM, forming cognate interactions with CX3CR1-bearing antigen presenting cells. However, apoptosis was a rare event in relation to the extensive vascular leakage observed during ECM. Our results support a model where CD8+ T cells mediate ECM via direct recognition of cognate antigen on target cells without the need for additional in situ secondary activation in the brain by professional antigen presenting cells and without causing apoptosis. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms through which CD8+ T cells cause ECM and may aid the development of improved therapeutic options to treat the condition.
Tungiasis is a parasitic disease caused by the sand flea Tunga penetrans. It is a neglected tropical disease that mainly affects people living in precarious conditions in tropical and subtropical countries. The study aimed to determine the burden of tungiasis in Vihiga County in Kenya. The overall prevalence of tungiasis was found to be 21.5%. The study identified factors that contribute to the occurrence of tungiasis, including low economic status, earthen floor, lack of toilet facilities, age of participant, no regular use of closed footwear, and common resting place inside the house. The findings suggest a need to design cost-effective and easily accessible control strategies for tungiasis.
 The Arabidopsis root tip contains a central xylem axis flanked by intervening procambial cells. The xylem axis consists of two cell types, protoxylem and metaxylem, with protoxylem cells positioned at the margins of the axis and maturing earlier than metaxylem cells in the center. The correct positioning and specification of protoxylem cells depend on a mutual feedback between auxin and cytokinins mediated by the PIN class of auxin efflux transporters and AHP6, an inhibitor of cytokinin signaling. In this work, we implemented a parsimonious computational model of auxin transport that considers hormonal regulation of auxin transporters within a spatial context, explicitly taking into account cell shape and polarity and the presence of cell walls. Our analysis reveals that an informative spatial pattern in cytokinin levels generated by diffusion is a theoretically unlikely scenario. Furthermore, our model shows that such a pattern is not required for correct and robust auxin patterning. Instead, auxin-dependent modifications of cytokinin response, rather than variations in cytokinin levels, allow for the necessary feedbacks, which can amplify and stabilize the auxin maximum. Our simulations demonstrate the importance of hormonal regulation of auxin efflux for pattern robustness. We predict and experimentally verify a role of AUX1 and LAX1/2 auxin influx transporters in this process. Furthermore, we show that polar localization of PIN1 generates an auxin flux circuit that not only stabilizes the accumulation of auxin within the xylem axis but also provides a mechanism for auxin to accumulate specifically in the xylem-pole pericycle cells, an important early step in lateral root initiation. The model also revealed that pericycle cells on opposite xylem poles compete for auxin accumulation, consistent with the observation that lateral roots are not initiated opposite to each other.
 The study investigates the role of a transcription factor, cAMP response element-binding protein B (CREB-B), in the neuropeptide F (NPF) /nitric oxide (NO) signaling pathway that regulates phase-related locomotor plasticity in the migratory locust, Locusta migratoria. The study finds that CREB-B directly activates brain NOS expression by interacting with NOS promoter region. The phosphorylation of CREB-B at serine 110 site changes in response to population density variation and is negatively controlled by NPF2. The involvement of CREB-B in NPF2-regulated locomotor plasticity is further validated by RNAi experiment and behavioral assay. Furthermore, the study reveals that protein kinase A mediates the regulatory effects of NPF2 on CREB-B phosphorylation and NOS transcription. These findings highlight a precise signal cascade underlying environment-induced behavioral plasticity.
 The earliest stages of development in most metazoans are driven by maternally deposited proteins and mRNAs, with widespread transcriptional activation of the zygotic genome occurring hours after fertilization, at a period known as the maternal-to-zygotic transition (MZT). In Drosophila, the MZT is preceded by the transcription of a small number of genes that initiate sex determination, patterning, and other early developmental processes; and the zinc-finger protein Zelda (ZLD) plays a key role in their transcriptional activation. To better understand the mechanisms of ZLD activation and the range of its targets, we used chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-Seq) to map regions bound by ZLD before (mitotic cycle 8), during (mitotic cycle 13), and after (late mitotic cycle 14) the MZT. Although only a handful of genes are transcribed prior to mitotic cycle 10, we identified thousands of regions bound by ZLD in cycle 8 embryos, most of which remain bound through mitotic cycle 14. As expected, early ZLD-bound regions include the promoters and enhancers of genes transcribed at this early stage. However, we also observed ZLD bound at cycle 8 to the promoters of roughly a thousand genes whose first transcription does not occur until the MZT and to virtually all of the thousands of known and presumed enhancers bound at cycle 14 by transcription factors that regulate patterned gene activation during the MZT. The association between early ZLD binding and MZT activity is so strong that ZLD binding alone can be used to identify active promoters and regulatory sequences with high specificity and selectivity. This strong early association of ZLD with regions not active until the MZT suggests that ZLD is not only required for the earliest wave of transcription but also plays a major role in activating the genome at the MZT.
24-hour circadian rhythms are essential for many biological processes in living organisms. Protein-protein interactions (PPIs) are crucial for the regulation of these rhythms. However, the timing of these interactions is largely unknown. In this study, we used a yeast-two-hybrid approach to identify 109 novel PPIs among circadian clock proteins. We found that protein phosphatase 1 (PPP1) interacts with CLOCK/BMAL1, resulting in BMAL1 destabilization. We constructed a dynamic circadian PPI network using circadian expression data and found that interacting proteins are expressed at similar times, likely restricting regulatory interactions to specific phases. We also predict that circadian PPIs dynamically connect many important cellular processes, contributing to temporal organization of cellular physiology. Our data provide a valuable resource of circadian PPIs within hepatocytes that are important for keeping the pace of the molecular clockwork and for the control of cellular physiology.
 Nematode polyprotein allergens ( NPAs ) are unusual lipid-binding proteins found in nematodes. They are synthesized as large, tandemly repetitive polyproteins that are post-translationally cleaved into multiple copies of small lipid-binding proteins. NPAs are probably central to transport and distribution of small hydrophobic compounds between the tissues of nematodes and may play key roles in nutrient scavenging, immunomodulation, and IgE antibody-based responses in infection. In the present study, the solution structure of ABA-1A, the most common repeating unit of the NPA of Ascaris suum, was determined by protein nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The protein adopts a novel seven-helical fold comprising a long central helix that participates in two hollow four-helical bundles on either side. Discrete hydrophobic ligand-binding pockets are found in the N-terminal and C-terminal bundles, and the amino acid sidechains affected by ligand (fatty acid) binding were identified. Recombinant ABA-1A contains tightly-bound ligand (s) of bacterial culture origin in one of its binding sites. This is the first mature, post-translationally processed, unit of a naturally-occurring tandemly-repetitive polyprotein to be structurally characterized from any source and it belongs to a new structural class. NPAs have no counterparts in vertebrates, so represent potential targets for drug or immunological intervention. The nature of the (as yet) unidentified bacterial ligand(s) may be pertinent to this, as will our characterization of the unusual binding sites.
 Ciguatera is a type of fish poisoning that occurs throughout the tropics, particularly in vulnerable island communities such as the developing Pacific Island Countries and Territories ( PICTs ). After consuming ciguatoxin-contaminated fish, people report a range of acute neurologic, gastrointestinal, and cardiac symptoms, with some experiencing chronic neurologic symptoms lasting weeks to months. Unfortunately, the true extent of illness and its impact on human communities and ecosystem health are still poorly understood. A questionnaire was emailed to the Health and Fisheries Authorities of the PICTs to quantify the extent of ciguatera. The data were analyzed using t-test, incidence rate ratios, ranked correlation, and regression analysis. There were 39,677 reported cases from 17 PICTs, with a mean annual incidence of 194 cases per 100,000 people across the region from 1998–2008 compared to the reported annual incidence of 104/100,000 from 1973–1983. There has been a 60% increase in the annual incidence of ciguatera between the two time periods based on PICTs that reported for both time periods. Taking into account under-reporting, in the last 35 years an estimated 500,000 Pacific islanders might have suffered from ciguatera. This level of incidence exceeds prior ciguatera estimates locally and globally, and raises the status of ciguatera to an acute and chronic illness with major public health significance. To address this significant public health problem, which is expected to increase in parallel with environmental change, well-funded multidisciplinary research teams are needed to translate research advances into practical management solutions.
Chagas disease is a parasitic infection caused by Trypanosoma cruzi that affects millions of people worldwide. The disease is characterized by a chronic phase that can last for decades and lead to severe complications such as cardiomyopathy. The immune response during the chronic phase of Chagas disease is impaired, and the CD4+CD8+ T cell population is expanded. In this study, we analyzed the production of cytokines and cytotoxic molecules by CD4+CD8+ T cells before and after benznidazole treatment. We also studied the expression and co-expression of inhibitory receptors in these patients after treatment. Our results showed that benznidazole treatment reduced the frequency of CD4+CD8+ T cells and decreased the ratio of CD4+CD8low/CD4+CD8high subpopulations. Additionally, the co-expression level of the inhibitory receptor was reduced after treatment simultaneously with the enhancement of the multifunctional capacity of CD4+CD8+ T cells. After treatment, an increase in the frequency of T . cruzi antigen-specific CD4+CD8+ T cells expressing IL-2 and TNF-α was also observed. These findings suggest that benznidazole treatment partially reverses the exhaustion process caused by T . cruzi infection in these cells with an improvement in the functional response of the T . cruzi antigen-specific CD4+CD8+ T cells.
 Phosphoinositides are important lipid signals in plant development and stress response. However, multiple isoforms of the phosphoinositide biosynthetic genes make it difficult to understand the roles of each enzyme in phosphoinositide metabolism. Here, we report that phosphoinositide-specific phospholipase C2 (AtPLC2) is the primary phosphoinositide metabolic enzyme in Arabidopsis thaliana. AtPLC2 is involved in seedling growth and ER stress response. Our results reveal the primary enzyme in phosphoinositide metabolism and its involvement in seedling growth and ER stress response.
 This study challenges the reductionist assumption that causation occurs at the micro level and excludes the emergence of macro-level causation. The authors use a principled, well-defined measure of intrinsic cause-effect power, integrated information ( Φ ), to show that a macro level can "beat" the micro level in terms of cause-effect power. The authors demonstrate this by analyzing a simple logic gate system and coarse-graining ( nearly ) identical elements into groups and averaging over their states. They then repeat the analysis at the macro level by grouping subsets of those micro elements inside black boxes. The authors use the interventional and counterfactual causal framework of integrated information theory to quantify intrinsic cause-effect power and system mechanisms at the micro level and all possible black-boxed macro levels. They demonstrate that the Φ value of systems of black-box macro elements can increase when going from finer to coarser spatiotemporal grains and lead to emergent cause-effect properties at macro scales.
