The authors use the Boolean network model of the fission yeast cell cycle as an example to demonstrate this.
 Reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) are produced in the mitochondrial respiratory chain ( RC ) and are important for cell survival and adaptation to the environment . However, ROS can also damage cells under certain conditions. To understand the mechanisms of ROS production in the RC, we developed a rule-based model that accounts for electron transport in the whole RC coupled to proton translocation, transmembrane electrochemical potential generation, TCA cycle reactions, and substrate transport to mitochondria. The model fits respiratory electron fluxes measured in rat brain mitochondria fueled by succinate or pyruvate and malate, and the dynamics of NAD+ reduction by reverse electron transport from succinate through complex I. Our analysis revealed an association of ROS production with levels of specific radicals of individual electron transporters and their combinations in species of complexes I and III. The phenomenon of bistability, previously revealed as a property of complex III, remains valid for the whole RC. The conditions for switching to a state with a high content of free radicals in complex III were predicted based on theoretical analysis and were confirmed experimentally. These findings provide a new insight into the mechanisms of ROS production in the RC.
Intracellular transport is a vital process that enables the movement of cargo along microtubules. This process is carried out by motor proteins, which are responsible for converting chemical energy into mechanical energy. The transport of cargo by motor proteins is a complex process that involves multiple motor proteins working together. In this article, we report the effects of mutations in motor proteins on the transport of cargo by multiple motor proteins. We found that mutations in motor proteins can lead to an increase in the expected run-length of cargo transport. We also developed a semi-analytical method to analyze the transport of cargo by multiple motor proteins. Our method is easily implementable and can be used to model the transport of cargo by multiple motor proteins of different types.
 We studied learning in terms of behavioral strategies on a 2-choice operant cue discrimination task in two groups of mice, a group with a genetic modification associated with severe learning deficits, namely, a selective knockout (KO) of the Cacna1c gene coding for the α subunit of Cav1.2 L-type high-voltage-dependent calcium channels (Cav1.2NesCre), and matched controls with intact gene expression (Cav1.2fl/fl). Calcium influx through voltage-dependent calcium channels is essential for synaptic plasticity and other cellular adaptations thought to underlie instrumental learning. The CACNA1C gene has also been implicated in the pathophysiology of psychiatric disease, rendering it an important target for understanding learning mechanisms not only in normal but also psychiatric conditions. By studying the detailed pattern of behavioral responses and rewards received across the learning process, combined with analyses based on behavioral (reinforcement) learning models, we found that Cav1.2NesCre mice did not simply exhibit a general learning deficit but rather relied on different behavioral strategies than Cav1.2fl/fl mice. Our results suggest that a selective functional ablation of the Cacna1c gene can modulate the learning process in a specific way, highlighting that much more mechanistic insight could be gained by examining response patterns in terms of a larger repertoire of potential behavioral strategies. The results may also have clinical implications for treating psychiatric disorders.
Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are responsible for spreading many arboviruses, including dengue and Zika. Wolbachia bacteria are being used to control these viruses by reducing the mosquito population. However, the effectiveness of Wolbachia infections depends on environmental conditions, particularly temperature. We found that wMel and wMelPop-CLA infections were not effective at high temperatures, while wAlbB infections were effective at all temperatures. These findings have implications for the success of Wolbachia interventions in different environments.
 Adenoviruses are important human pathogens that have been developed as vectors for gene therapies and genetic vaccines . Previous studies indicated that human infections with adenoviruses are self-limiting in immunocompetent hosts with evidence of some persistence in adenoid tissue . We sought to better understand the natural history of adenovirus infections in various non-human primates and discovered that healthy populations of great apes ( chimpanzees , bonobos , gorillas , and orangutans ) and macaques shed substantial quantities of infectious adenoviruses in stool . Shedding in stools from asymptomatic humans was found to be much less frequent , comparable to frequencies reported before . We purified and fully sequenced 30 novel adenoviruses from apes and 3 novel adenoviruses from macaques . Analyses of the new ape adenovirus sequences ( as well as the 4 chimpanzee adenovirus sequences we have previously reported ) together with 22 complete adenovirus genomes available from GenBank revealed that ( a ) the ape adenoviruses could clearly be classified into species corresponding to human adenovirus species B , C , and E , ( b ) there was evidence for intraspecies recombination between adenoviruses , and ( c ) the high degree of phylogenetic relatedness of adenoviruses across their various primate hosts provided evidence for cross species transmission events to have occurred in the natural history of B and E viruses . The high degree of asymptomatic shedding of live adenovirus in non-human primates and evidence for zoonotic transmissions warrants caution for primate handling and housing . Furthermore , the presence of persistent and/or latent adenovirus infections in the gut should be considered in the design and interpretation of human and non-human primate studies with adenovirus vectors .
 The nucleosome is the fundamental unit of chromatin, the complex of DNA and proteins that makes up the genetic material of eukaryotic cells. The nucleosome is composed of a core of eight histone proteins and about 147 base pairs of DNA, which are wrapped around the histone core about 1.75 times. The DNA in the nucleosome is not static, but can unwrap and rewrap in response to various cellular processes. In this study, we used molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the energetics of unwrapping the outer superhelical turn of nucleosomal DNA. We found that unwrapping costs about 11.5 kcal/mol, and that the unwrapping occurs asymmetrically, with one end of the DNA unwrapping first and then the other end. These results provide insight into the dynamics of nucleosomes and their role in regulating gene expression.
 Lysosomes are important organelles in the cell that help break down waste and damaged cell parts. They are sensitive to oxidative stress, which can damage their membranes. ApoD is a protein that helps protect lysosomes from oxidative stress. It is found in the blood and is overexpressed in the brain during aging and neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, the authors found that ApoD is endocytosed and targeted to a subset of vulnerable lysosomes in a stress-dependent manner. It is functionally stable in this acidic environment and helps maintain lysosomal pH gradients and membrane integrity. The authors also found that ApoD is involved in two lysosomal-dependent biological processes, myelin phagocytosis and optimization of neurodegeneration-triggered autophagy. These findings suggest that ApoD plays an important role in protecting lysosomes and maintaining cellular function.
 The study focuses on the life cycle and behavior of Phlebotomus orientalis Parrot ( Diptera: Psychodidae ) in laboratory colonies. The study compares two P . orientalis colonies originating from different sites in Ethiopia: a non-endemic site in the lowlands - Melka Werer ( MW ) , and an endemic focus of human visceral leishmaniasis in the highlands - Addis Zemen ( AZ ) . The study reports marked differences in life-cycle parameters between the two colonies, including distinct requirements for larval food and humidity during pupation. However, analyses using Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA ( RAPD ) PCR and DNA sequencing of cytB and COI mitochondrial genes did not reveal any genetic differences. F1 hybrids developed successfully with higher fecundity than the parental colonies. Susceptibility of P . orientalis to Leishmania donovani was studied by experimental infections. Even the lowest infective dose tested ( 2×103 per ml ) was sufficient for successful establishment of L . donovani infections in about 50% of the P . orientalis females. Both MW and AZ colonies of P . orientalis were highly susceptible to Ethiopian L . donovani strains. The development of L . donovani was similar in both P . orientalis colonies; hence, the absence of visceral leishmaniasis in non-endemic area Melka Werer cannot be attributed to different susceptibility of local P . orientalis populations to L . donovani. The study provides important information regarding the life cycle and behavior of P . orientalis in laboratory colonies, which is essential for the major goal of the work: experimental infections and comparison of susceptibility of both colonies to infections with L . donovani.
 Schistosomiasis is a serious public health problem in China, with an estimated 30,000 cases of advanced schistosomiasis japonica in 2008 . However, the disability weight (DW) for advanced schistosomiasis japonica has not been included in the Global Burden of Disease (GBD) study. Therefore, a patient-based quality-of-life evaluation was performed for advanced schistosomiasis japonica. Of 506 candidates, 215 cases were confirmed as advanced schistosomiasis japonica and evaluated. Most patients reported impairments in at least one health dimension, such as pain or discomfort, usual activities, and anxiety or depression. The overall DW was 0.447, and age-specific DWs ranged from 0.378 among individuals aged 30-44 years to 0.510 among the elderly aged ≥60 years. DWs were positively associated with loss of work capacity, psychological abnormality, ascites, and active hepatitis B virus, while splenectomy and high albumin were protective factors for quality of life. These patient-preference disability estimates could provide updated data for a revision of the GBD, as well as for evidence-based decision-making in China's national schistosomiasis control program.
 This study used national census data from 1999 to estimate population vulnerability and disability in Kenya's 7 tsetse belts, known as sleeping sickness areas. The study found that residents and recent migrants of working age living in tsetse-infested areas were more likely to have disability than those living outside of these areas. The study also found that living in poverty and tsetse-infested areas increased the likelihood of disability. The study suggests that incorporating reports on disability from the national census is a promising surveillance tool that may enhance future HAT surveillance programs in sub-Saharan Africa. The combined burdens of HAT and AAT and the opportunity costs of agricultural production in AAT areas are likely contributors to disability within tsetse-infested areas. Future research will assess changes in the spatial relationships between high tsetse infestation and human disability following the release of the Kenya 2009 census at the local level.
 Hexamethylene bisacetamide ( HMBA ) is a potent inducer of cell differentiation and HIV production in chronically infected cells . However , its mechanism of action remains poorly defined . In this study , we demonstrate that HMBA activates transiently the PI3K/Akt pathway , which leads to the phosphorylation of HEXIM1 and the subsequent release of active positive transcription elongation factor b ( P-TEFb ) from its transcriptionally inactive complex with HEXIM1 and 7SK small nuclear RNA ( snRNA ) . As a result , P-TEFb is recruited to the HIV promoter to stimulate transcription elongation and viral production . Despite the continuous presence of HMBA , the released P-TEFb reassembles rapidly with 7SK snRNA and HEXIM1 . In contrast , a mutant HEXIM1 protein that cannot be phosphorylated and released from P-TEFb and 7SK snRNA via the PI3K/Akt pathway antagonizes this HMBA-mediated induction of viral production . Thus , our studies reveal how HIV transcription is induced by HMBA and suggest how modifications in the equilibrium between active and inactive P-TEFb could contribute to cell differentiation .
 Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania parasites and transmitted by sand flies. The disease can manifest in different forms, including cutaneous, mucocutaneous, and visceral leishmaniasis. The severity of the disease is influenced by various factors, including the parasite species, host genetic factors, and the presence of viruses that infect the parasites. In this study, the authors investigated the role of Leishmania RNA virus (LRV) in the pathogenesis of leishmaniasis. They found that LRV is present in various Leishmania species and that its presence is associated with the development of mucocutaneous and disseminated forms of the disease. The authors also developed a new method for detecting LRV in parasites, which could be used for diagnosing leishmaniasis in the field.
 Enteropathogenic and enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli ( EPEC and EHEC ) are closely related pathogens that attach tightly to intestinal epithelial cells, efface microvilli, and promote cytoskeletal rearrangements into protrusions called actin pedestals. In this study, the authors characterized the colonization properties of EPEC and EHEC during infection of polarized epithelial cells. They found that EPEC and EHEC both formed distinct bacterial communities, or “macrocolonies,” that encompassed multiple host cells. Tir and EspFU, as well as the host Arp2/3 complex, were all critical for the expansion of macrocolonies over time. Unexpectedly, EspFU accelerated the formation of larger macrocolonies compared to EPEC Tir, as EspFU-mediated actin assembly drove faster bacterial motility to cell junctions, where bacteria formed a secondary pedestal on a neighboring cell and divided, allowing one of the daughters to disengage and infect the second cell. Collectively, these data reveal that EspFU enhances epithelial colonization by increasing actin-based motility and promoting an efficient method of cell-to-cell transmission.
 Extracellular vesicles ( EVs ) are small, membrane-bound particles released by cells that play important roles in cell-to-cell communication. EVs have been found in many pathogenic organisms, including helminths, and may be involved in the pathogenesis of diseases. However, the optimal method for isolating EVs from helminths is not known. In this study, the authors compared two methods for isolating EVs from the liver fluke Fasciola hepatica: differential centrifugation ( DC ) and size exclusion chromatography ( SEC ). They found that SEC produced smaller and less diverse EVs, with a higher EV purity to free excretory-secretory protein ( ESP ) yield, a less diverse EV proteome, and different EV gene enrichment profiles compared to DC. The authors suggest that SEC may be the better method for isolating EVs from helminths for downstream analysis and application development.
 We present a reverse-engineering approach to study post-transcriptional regulation in pattern formation. We use detailed quantitative datasets of gap gene mRNA and protein expression to solve and fit a model of post-transcriptional regulation, and establish its structural and practical identifiability. Our results demonstrate that post-transcriptional regulation is not required for patterning in this system, but is necessary for proper control of protein levels. Our work demonstrates that the uniqueness and specificity of a fitted model can be rigorously determined in the context of spatio-temporal pattern formation, greatly increasing the potential of reverse engineering for the study of development and other similarly complex biological processes.
 Rotavirus is a major cause of diarrhea worldwide, particularly in children under the age of five. The virus is highly infectious and causes severe damage to the small intestine. However, the mechanisms underlying the age-dependent susceptibility to rotavirus infection are not well understood. In this study, the authors investigated the role of the innate immune system in the age-dependent susceptibility to rotavirus infection using an oral mouse infection model. They found that the expression of the innate immune receptor for viral dsRNA, Toll-like receptor (TLR) 3, was low in the epithelium of suckling mice but strongly increased during the postnatal period, inversely correlating with rotavirus susceptibility, viral shedding, and histological damage. Adult mice deficient in TLR3 or the adaptor molecule Trif exerted significantly higher viral shedding and decreased epithelial expression of proinflammatory and antiviral genes as compared to wild-type animals. In contrast, neonatal mice deficient in TLR3 or Trif did not display impaired cell stimulation or enhanced rotavirus susceptibility. Using chimeric mice, the authors detected a major contribution of the non-hematopoietic cell compartment in the Trif-mediated antiviral host response in adult animals. Finally, the authors found a significant age-dependent increase of TLR3 expression in human small intestinal biopsies. These findings suggest that upregulation of TLR3 expression during infancy might contribute to the age-dependent susceptibility to rotavirus infection.
 The study aimed to analyze whole-exome sequencing data from 1,039 autism spectrum disorder ( ASD ) cases and 870 controls from the NIMH repository. The data came from two centers using different methods to produce sequence and to call variants from it. The study found that gene-based tests, such as SKAT, have better power when the data is combined using mega-analysis rather than meta-analysis. The study also found that principal component-based analyses were sufficient to control for ancestry and produce test statistics with appropriate distributions. After quality control and controlling for ancestry, the study found no clear-cut associations, including associations in known ASD genes. The study concludes that rare variants affecting risk are not clustering in a small number of genes.
 Mycetoma is a chronic infectious disease that affects the lower extremities and is caused by fungi. The most common causative agent is Madurella mycetomatis, which forms grains in the tissue. Chitin is a component of the fungal cell wall and is thought to be embedded in the grain. Chitinases are part of the innate immune system and their activity is upregulated in response to chitin. Polymorphisms in the genes encoding for chitinases have been described that result in decreased chitinase activity. In this study, we investigated the association between these polymorphisms and the incidence of mycetoma caused by M. mycetomatis in a Sudanese population. We found that a polymorphism resulting in decreased chitotriosidase activity was associated with increased odds of mycetoma. No association was found for the polymorphisms in the genes for AMCase. These results suggest that decreased chitinase activity may increase susceptibility towards fungal infections, including mycetoma.
 Herpes simplex virus ( HSV ) is a common human virus that causes cold sores and can lead to more serious complications such as encephalitis. HSV has two phases of infection: acute and latent. During the acute phase, the virus replicates and spreads throughout the body. During the latent phase, the virus remains dormant in the body but can reactivate and cause another episode of infection. Recent studies have shown that lytic genes, which are normally only expressed during the acute phase, can be transcribed during the latent phase. However, direct evidence of lytic protein expression during latency has been difficult to find. In this study, the authors used a highly sensitive Cre-marking model to show that lytic and latent phases are less clearly defined than previously thought. They found that around half of the HSV spread leading to latently infected sites occurred beyond the initial acute infection and that lytic promoters can drive protein expression during latency. These findings suggest that the distinction between acute and latent phases of HSV infection may not be as clear-cut as previously thought.
 Prion diseases are a group of neurodegenerative diseases that affect humans and animals. They are caused by the misfolding of a protein called prion protein, which leads to the formation of aggregates that spread throughout the brain. In this study, the authors compared the cell specificity of prion protein aggregates at early preclinical times post-infection using three mouse scrapie strains that differ in brain regional pathology. They found that the pattern of cell specificity of prion protein aggregates varied among the strains, with strain 22L being mainly associated with astroglia, while strain ME7 was mainly associated with neurons and neuropil. In thalamus and cortex, strain RML was similar to 22L, but in substantia nigra, RML was similar to ME7. The authors also studied the expression of 90 genes involved in neuroinflammation and found that despite the cellular differences in prion protein aggregates, the pattern of upregulated genes was similar for all three strains. Interestingly, the profile of upregulated genes in scrapie differed markedly from that seen in two acute viral CNS diseases. The authors suggest that their findings may have practical relevance for understanding the pathogenesis of prion diseases and for developing common strategies of therapeutic intervention against the seeded polymerization events.
 The physical organization of chromosomes is crucial for regulating gene expression and cell function. In this study, the authors developed a coarse-grained model for self-avoiding polymers on a lattice that accounts for the polymer entanglement length and the volumic density. They show that their simulation scheme not only captures the steady-state structural and dynamical properties of the system but also tracks the same dynamics at different coarse-graining. This strategy allows a strong power-law gain in numerical efficiency and offers a systematic way to define reliable coarse-grained null models for chromosomes. The authors use their formalism to investigate in detail the time evolution of the 3D organization of chromosome 3R (20 Mbp) in drosophila during one cell cycle (20 hours). They show that a combination of their coarse-graining strategy with a one-parameter block copolymer model integrating epigenomic-driven interactions quantitatively reproduce experimental data at the chromosome-scale and predict that chromatin motion is very dynamic during the cell cycle.
 The study aimed to understand the genetic architecture and causal mechanisms of cell type specificity of eQTLs. The authors performed an eQTL analysis in three parts: first, they identified eQTLs from eleven studies on seven cell types; then, they integrated eQTL data with cis-regulatory element (CRE) data from the ENCODE project; finally, they built a set of classifiers to predict the cell type specificity of eQTLs. The cell type specificity of eQTLs is associated with eQTL SNP overlap with hundreds of cell type specific CRE classes, including enhancer, promoter, and repressive chromatin marks, regions of open chromatin, and many classes of DNA binding proteins. These associations provide insight into the molecular mechanisms generating the cell type specificity of eQTLs and the mode of regulation of corresponding eQTLs. Using a random forest classifier with cell specific CRE-SNP overlap as features, the authors demonstrated the feasibility of predicting the cell type specificity of eQTLs. They then demonstrated that CREs from a trait-associated cell type can be used to annotate GWAS associations in the absence of eQTL data for that cell type. The authors anticipate that such integrative, predictive modeling of cell specificity will improve our ability to understand the mechanistic basis of human complex phenotypic variation.
 HIV-1 envelope proteins (Envs) are the target of broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (bN-mAbs) that recognize epitopes consisting of both amino acid and glycan residues. These bN-mAbs require early intermediates in the N-linked glycosylation pathway for binding. However, cell lines suitable for biopharmaceutical production that limit N-linked glycosylation to mannose-5 (Man5) or earlier intermediates are not readily available. The authors report the development of a stable suspension-adapted Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cell line that limits glycosylation to Man5 and earlier intermediates. This cell line was created using the clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat (CRISPR)/CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9) gene editing system and contains a mutation that inactivates the gene encoding Mannosyl (Alpha-1,3)-Glycoprotein Beta-1,2-N-Acetylglucosaminyltransferase (MGAT1). Monomeric gp120s produced in the MGAT1− CHO cell line exhibit improved binding to prototypic glycan-dependent bN-mAbs directed to the V1/V2 domain (e.g., PG9) and the V3 stem (e.g., PGT128 and 10–1074) while preserving the structure of the important glycan-independent epitopes (e.g., VRC01). The ability of the MGAT1− CHO cell line to limit glycosylation to early intermediates in the N-linked glycosylation pathway without impairing the doubling time or ability to grow at high cell densities suggests that it will be a useful substrate for the biopharmaceutical production of HIV-1 vaccine immunogens.
 Parasitic nematodes are responsible for devastating diseases that affect millions of people worldwide. One promising target for therapeutic inhibitor discovery is trehalose-6-phosphate phosphatase ( T6PP ) from Brugia malayi . In this study, the authors determined the X-ray crystal structure of T6PP from B . malayi and found that it has a stabilizing N-terminal MIT-like domain and a catalytic C-terminal C2B-type HAD phosphatase fold. Structure-guided mutagenesis and kinetic analyses using a designed competitive inhibitor identified five residues important for binding and catalysis. The model of the T6PP-trehalose 6-phosphate complex indicates a substrate-binding mode wherein shape complementarity and van der Waals interactions drive recognition. The authors suggest that high-affinity inhibitors will be bi-dentate, taking advantage of substrate-like binding to the phosphoryl-binding pocket while simultaneously utilizing non-native binding to the trehalose pocket. The conservation of the key residues that enforce the shape of the substrate pocket in T6PP enzymes suggests that development of broad-range anthelmintic and antibacterial therapeutics employing this platform may be possible.
 In this study, we present a novel computational framework that incorporates whole, realistic tumors extracted ex vivo to efficiently simulate vascular blood flow and interstitial fluid transport in silico for validation against in vivo biomedical imaging. Our model couples Poiseuille and Darcy descriptions of vascular and interstitial flow, respectively, and incorporates spatially heterogeneous blood vessel lumen and interstitial permeabilities to generate accurate predictions of tumor fluid dynamics. We detail the application of our framework to an orthotopic murine glioma (GL261) and a human colorectal carcinoma xenograft (LS147T), and perform sensitivity analysis to gain an understanding of the key biological mechanisms that determine tumor fluid transport. Finally, we mimic vascular normalization by modifying parameters such as vascular and interstitial permeabilities, and show that incorporating realistic vasculatures is key to modelling the contrasting fluid dynamic response between tumor samples. Contrary to literature, we show that reducing tumor interstitial fluid pressure is not essential to increase interstitial perfusion and that therapies should seek to develop an interstitial fluid pressure gradient. We also hypothesise that stabilising vessel diameters and permeabilities are not key responses following vascular normalization and that therapy may alter interstitial hydraulic conductivity. Consequently, we suggest that normalizing the interstitial microenvironment may provide a more effective means to increase interstitial perfusion within tumors.
 HIV spreads efficiently both in a cell-free state and from cell to cell, but the relative importance of these two transmission modes in natural infection has not yet been resolved. Here we report on neutralizing antibody activity during cell-cell transmission using specifically tailored experimental strategies that enable unambiguous discrimination between the two transmission routes. We demonstrate that the activity of neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) and entry inhibitors during cell-cell transmission varies depending on their mode of action. While gp41 directed agents remain active, CD4 binding site (CD4bs) directed inhibitors, including the potent neutralizing mAb VRC01, dramatically lose potency during cell-cell contacts. This implies that CD4bs mAbs act preferentially through blocking free virus transmission, while still allowing HIV to spread through cell-cell contacts. Thus providing a plausible explanation for how HIV maintains infectivity and rapidly escapes potent and broadly active CD4bs directed antibody responses in vivo.
 Attention has many effects on neural responses, including modifying firing rates and receptive field structure. Several existing models suggest that these effects arise from selective modulation of neural inputs. However, anatomical and physiological observations suggest that attentional modulation targets higher levels of the visual system, such as V4 or MT, rather than input areas, such as V1. Here we propose a simple mechanism that explains how a top-down attentional modulation falling on higher visual areas can produce the observed effects of attention on neural responses. Our model requires only the existence of modulatory feedback connections between areas and short-range lateral inhibition within each area. Feedback connections redistribute the top-down modulation to lower areas, which in turn alters the inputs of other higher-area cells, including those that did not receive the initial modulation. This produces firing rate modulations and receptive field shifts. Simultaneously, short-range lateral inhibition between neighboring cells produce competitive effects that are automatically scaled to receptive field size in any given area. Our model reproduces the observed attentional effects on response rates (response gain, input gain, biased competition automatically scaled to receptive field size) and receptive field structure (shifts and resizing of receptive fields both spatially and in complex feature space), without modifying model parameters. Our model also makes the novel prediction that attentional effects on response curves should shift from response gain to contrast gain as the spatial focus of attention drifts away from the studied cell.
The posterior signaling center (PSC) is a small group of specialized cells that controls hemocyte (blood cell) homeostasis in the lymph gland, the hematopoietic organ of Drosophila larvae. This role of the PSC is very reminiscent of the "niche," the microenvironment of hematopoietic stem cells in vertebrates. In this study, the authors identified a short type I cytokine-related receptor, CG14225/Latran, that is required for switching off JAK/STAT signaling in hematopoietic prohemocytes. This is a prerequisite for massive differentiation of lamellocytes upon wasp parasitisation. The authors propose that this sequence of events culminates in the complete inhibition of residual JAK/STAT signaling by Latran. This is the first in vivo example of a role for a nonsignaling receptor in controlling a dedicated immune response, and raises the question of whether short, nonsignaling receptors also control specific aspects of vertebrate cellular immunity.
 We have investigated patterns of recombination that occur over 120 day long experimental infections of tomato plants with two begomoviruses, Tomato yellow leaf curl virus and Tomato leaf curl Comoros virus. We show that patterns of sequence exchange between these viruses can be extraordinarily complex and present clear evidence that factors such as local degrees of sequence similarity but not genomic secondary structure strongly influence where recombination breakpoints occur. We also find that over-all patterns of recombination are strongly influenced by selection against individual recombinants displaying disrupted intra-genomic interactions such as those required for proper protein and nucleic acid folding. We further demonstrate that recombination patterns can be used to identify the various ways in which recombination can disrupt intra-genome interactions and indirectly visualise long-range intra-genome interaction networks.
 Nucleosomes are the basic units of eukaryotic chromatin and have been shown to influence the evolution of eukaryotic genomes. However, the relationship between nucleosome positioning and sequence evolution is not well understood. In this study, we compared nucleosome-associated substitution patterns in humans and the model archaeon Haloferax volcanii. We found that despite differences in nucleosome structure and composition, the patterns of substitutions around nucleosomes were remarkably similar between the two species. We also found that these patterns were not consistent with mutation or purifying selection acting on static nucleosomes. Instead, we propose that nucleosome repositioning in response to substitutions is a major factor in shaping nucleosome-associated substitution patterns. This finding highlights the importance of considering the direction of causality between genetic and epigenetic change when assessing selection and mutation biases in the context of chromatin architecture.
 The native state of proteins is characterized by an ensemble of conformers in dynamics equilibrium. Ligands interacting with the proteins select the best conformer in terms of affinity, shifting the conformational equilibrium. Intramolecular vibrational dynamics associated to each conformation should guarantee conformational transitions. We present a novel procedure to identify key positions sustaining the conformational diversity associated to ligand binding. We find a negative correlation between the effects of mutations on these normal mode subspaces associated to ligand-binding and position-specific evolutionary conservations obtained from multiple sequence-structure alignments. Positions whose mutations are found to alter the most these subspaces are defined as key positions, that is, dynamically important residues that mediate the ligand-binding conformational change. These positions are shown to be evolutionary conserved, mostly buried aliphatic residues localized in regular structural regions of the protein like β-sheets and α-helix.
 Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ) is a bacterium that causes tuberculosis ( TB ) in humans. Mtb can survive for a long time in the body and is able to adapt to different environments. Mtb can use different carbon sources to survive, including fatty acids, lipids, glucose, and glycolytic 3-carbon compounds. Mtb also uses CO2 as a carbon source. Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate aldolase ( FBA ) is an enzyme that is important for glycolysis and gluconeogenesis. FBA is essential for Mtb to grow in vitro, but it is not clear why. In this study, the authors used a genetic switch to control the expression of FBA in Mtb. They found that FBA is essential for Mtb to grow in vivo, but it is not essential in vitro if the bacteria are grown on a mixture of glucose and butyrate. The authors also found that Mtb can use butyrate as a carbon source if it is able to co-catabolize glucose. These findings suggest that FBA is important for Mtb to survive in the body, but it is not essential for Mtb to survive in vitro.
2-Cys peroxiredoxins are ubiquitous peroxidases that play various functions in cells. In Leishmania and related trypanosomatids, which lack catalase and selenium-glutathione peroxidases, the discovery of this family of enzymes provided the molecular basis for peroxide removal in these organisms. In this study, the functional relevance of one of such enzymes, the mitochondrial 2-Cys peroxiredoxin (mTXNPx), was investigated along the Leishmania infantum life cycle. mTXNPx null mutants (mtxnpx−) produced by a gene replacement strategy were found unable to thrive in a murine model of infection. Unexpectedly, however, the avirulent phenotype of mtxnpx− was not due to lack of the peroxidase activity of mTXNPx as these behaved like controls when exposed to oxidants added exogenously or generated by macrophages during phagocytosis ex vivo. In line with this, mtxnpx− were also avirulent when inoculated into murine hosts unable to mount an effective oxidative phagocyte response. Definitive conclusion that the peroxidase activity of mTXNPx is not required for parasite survival in mice was obtained by showing that a peroxidase-inactive version of this protein was competent in rescuing the non-infective phenotype of mtxnpx−. A novel function is thus proposed for mTXNPx, that of a molecular chaperone, which may explain the impaired infectivity of the null mutants. This premise is based on the observation that the enzyme is able to suppress the thermal aggregation of citrate synthase in vitro. Also, mtxnpx− were more sensitive than controls to a temperature shift from 25°C to 37°C, a phenotype reminiscent of organisms lacking specific chaperone genes. Collectively, the findings reported here change the paradigm which regards all trypanosomatid 2-Cys peroxiredoxins as peroxide-eliminating devices. Moreover, they demonstrate, for the first time, that these 2-Cys peroxiredoxins can be determinant for pathogenicity independently of their peroxidase activity.
Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection that can cause a range of symptoms, including fever, cough, and fatigue. It is most common in people with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS. The current standard for diagnosing histoplasmosis is through blood or bone marrow cultures, which can take several weeks to grow. A new test, called the Histoplasma urine antigen (HUAg) test, has been developed that can diagnose histoplasmosis more quickly. However, the accuracy of this test has not been well studied in people with HIV/AIDS. In this study, researchers evaluated the accuracy of the HUAg test in diagnosing histoplasmosis in people with HIV/AIDS in Mexico. They found that the test was not very accurate, with a sensitivity of only 67% and a specificity of 97%. This means that the test may miss some cases of histoplasmosis and may also give false positives. The researchers suggest that the HUAg test may be useful for starting antifungal treatment early, but that a culture-based approach is still necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
1.8 million children die from diarrhea annually, and millions more suffer multiple episodes of nonfatal diarrhea. On average, in up to 40% of cases, no etiologic agent can be identified. Metagenomic sequencing has enabled systematic and unbiased characterization of microbial populations, including viruses. In this study, we characterized the eukaryotic viral communities present in diarrhea specimens from 12 children by employing a strategy of “micro-mass sequencing” that entails minimal starting sample quantity ( <100 mg stool ), minimal sample purification, and limited sequencing ( 384 reads per sample ). Using this methodology, we detected known enteric viruses as well as multiple sequences from putatively novel viruses with only limited sequence similarity to viruses in GenBank. Our results suggest that metagenomic investigation of the viral diversity found in human diarrhea has the potential to define the spectrum of viruses present in stool during episodes of acute diarrhea and to assess whether these agents play a causal role in human diarrhea.
2014-2016 saw two major arbovirus outbreaks worldwide, dengue and Zika. The Dominican Republic was affected by both, with 17,324 dengue cases in 2015 and 5,235 Zika cases in 2016. This study used retrospective disease surveillance data to identify and describe the transmission dynamics of both viruses, including associated cases of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). The study found that Zika infections were more widely dispersed among the population than dengue, with higher attack rates among females. The reproductive number (R0) of Zika was also higher among females. The study also compared the age and sex-adjusted distributions of both Zika and dengue outbreaks and calculated the reproductive number (R0) of each outbreak. The findings suggest that community awareness campaigns, through influencing short-term health seeking behavior, remain the most plausible mechanism behind increased reporting among women of reproductive age. Media campaigns and screening are therefore recommended for women of reproductive age during Zika outbreaks. Future research should focus on clinical Zika outcomes among dengue seropositive individuals.
 Poly ( ADP-ribose ) polymerases ( PARPs ) are enzymes that catalyze the transfer of multiple poly ( ADP-ribose ) units onto target proteins. PARP1 is the founding and most characterized member of the PARP family in humans. In Arabidopsis, PARP2 rather than PARP1 makes the greatest contribution to PARP activity and organismal viability in response to genotoxic stresses. PARP2 carries SAP DNA binding motifs rather than the zinc finger domains common in plant and animal PARP1 proteins. PARP2 also makes stronger contributions than PARP1 to plant immune responses. For poly ( ADP-ribose ) glycohydrolase ( PARG ) enzymes, Arabidopsis PARG1 and not PARG2 is the major contributor to poly ( ADP-ribose ) removal from acceptor proteins. PARP1 and PARP2 interact with each other and with PARG1 and PARG2. PARP1 and PARG1 are localized to the nucleus while PARP2 and PARG2 are localized to the cytoplasm. Overall, the study suggests that PARP2 and PARG1 are the major contributors to poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ation in Arabidopsis.
 The PHR proteins are a group of intracellular signaling molecules that regulate synapse formation and axon termination. The C . elegans PHR protein, RPM-1, is a ubiquitin ligase that inhibits the DLK-1 and MLK-1 MAP kinase pathways. We have identified several kinases that are likely to form a new MAP kinase pathway that suppresses synapse formation defects in the mechanosensory neurons of rpm-1 mutants, but not axon termination defects. This pathway includes MIG-15 (MAP4K), NSY-1 (MAP3K), JKK-1 (MAP2K), and JNK-1 (MAPK). Transgenic overexpression of kinases in the MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway is sufficient to impair synapse formation in wild-type animals. The MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway functions cell autonomously in the mechanosensory neurons and these kinases localize to presynaptic terminals, providing further evidence of a role in synapse development. Loss of MIG-15/JNK-1 signaling also suppresses defects in habituation to repeated mechanical stimuli in rpm-1 mutants, a behavioral deficit that is likely to arise from impaired glutamatergic synapse formation. Interestingly, habituation results are consistent with the MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway functioning as a parallel opposing pathway to RPM-1. These findings indicate the MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway can restrict both glutamatergic synapse formation and short-term learning.
 The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has a well-studied system for determining the sex of an individual based on the activity of the transcription factor TRA-1. TRA-1 is controlled by a linear pathway that determines whether an individual will develop as a hermaphrodite or a male. However, TRA-1 is also a member of a complex called the Tip60 HAT complex, which has been shown to have a bipotential function in mammals. In this study, the authors show that the Tip60 HAT complex also has a bipotential function in C. elegans. They found that the Tip60 HAT complex works with TRA-1 to activate the expression of male-specific genes, while also repressing the expression of female-specific genes. The authors also found that the Tip60 HAT complex works in parallel with the linear pathway to control the sex-determination process. They conclude that the Tip60 HAT complex is a key component of the bipotential switch that controls sex-determination in C. elegans.
ΦDM, ΦE, and ΦAR are three new measures of integrated information that overcome the limitations of previous measures. ΦDM is defined for discrete Markov systems, but ΦE and ΦAR are defined for continuous or discrete stochastic systems, Markovian or otherwise. ΦE and ΦAR are easy to apply in practice, and ΦE is equivalent to ΦDM for Gaussian systems. These measures provide new opportunities for examining information integration in real and model systems, and carry implications for relations between integrated information, consciousness, and other neurocognitive processes. However, our findings pose challenges for theories that ascribe physical meaning to the measured quantities.
 The persistent spread of Rhodesian human African trypanosomiasis ( HAT ) in Uganda has raised concerns of a potential overlap with the Gambian form of the disease . Recent research has aimed to increase the evidence base for targeting control measures by focusing on the environmental and climatic factors that control the spatial distribution of the disease . One recent study used simple logistic regression methods to explore the relationship between prevalence of Rhodesian HAT and several social , environmental and climatic variables in two of the most recently affected districts of Uganda , and suggested the disease had spread into the study area due to the movement of infected , untreated livestock from endemic areas . Here we extend this study to account for spatial autocorrelation , incorporate uncertainty in input data and model parameters and undertake predictive mapping for risk of high HAT prevalence in future . Using a spatial analysis in which a generalised linear geostatistical model is used in a Bayesian framework to account explicitly for spatial autocorrelation and incorporate uncertainty in input data and model parameters we are able to demonstrate a more rigorous analytical approach , potentially resulting in more accurate parameter and significance estimates and increased predictive accuracy , thereby allowing an assessment of the validity of the livestock movement hypothesis given more robust parameter estimation and appropriate assessment of covariate effects . Analysis strongly supports the theory that Rhodesian HAT was imported to the study area via the movement of untreated , infected livestock from endemic areas . The confounding effect of health care accessibility on the spatial distribution of Rhodesian HAT and the linkages between the disease's distribution and minimum land surface temperature have also been confirmed via the application of these methods . Predictive mapping indicates an increased risk of high HAT prevalence in the future in areas surrounding livestock markets , demonstrating the importance of livestock trading for continuing disease spread . Adherence to government policy to treat livestock at the point of sale is essential to prevent the spread of sleeping sickness in Uganda .
 The study of the stability of ecosystems has been a longstanding question in ecology. The consensus that complexity begets stability was challenged in the 1970s, and the assumption that there exists a feasible equilibrium was not tested until recently. The authors of this study found that equilibrium feasibility vanishes in species-rich systems. They also found that weak interactions increase stability in structured systems, while strong interactions decrease stability in unstructured systems. The authors suggest that a general understanding of ecosystem dynamics requires focusing on the interplay between interaction strength and network architecture.
 Q fever is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium Coxiella burnetii. It is widespread, with a near global distribution. In Africa, there is evidence of endemicity in cattle, small ruminants, and humans, with seroprevalence ranging from 7% to 33% in sheep, 4% to 55% in cattle, and 1% to 32% in humans. However, there are significant gaps in our understanding of the epidemiology of this pathogen, particularly in resource-poor settings. This study aimed to provide a One Health assessment of Q fever epidemiology in parts of Western and Nyanza Provinces, Western Kenya, in cattle and humans. A cross-sectional survey was conducted, and serum samples from 2049 humans and 955 cattle in 416 homesteads were analyzed for C . burnetii antibodies. Questionnaires covering demographic, socio-economic, and husbandry information were also administered. These data were linked to environmental datasets based on geographical locations. Correlation and spatial-cross correlation analyses were applied to assess the potential link between cattle and human seroprevalence. Multilevel regression analysis was used to assess the relationships between a range of socio-economic, demographic, and environmental factors and sero-positivity in both humans and animals. The overall sero-prevalence of C . burnetii was 2.5% in humans and 10.5% in cattle, but we found no evidence of correlation between cattle and human seroprevalence either within households or when incorporating spatial proximity to other households in the survey. Multilevel modelling indicated the importance of several factors for exposure to the organism, including cattle obtained from market, those residing in areas with lower precipitation levels, younger age group in humans, variations between ethnic groups, and frequent livestock contact (specifically grazing and dealing with abortion material). These results illustrate endemicity of C . burnetii in western Kenya, although prevalence is relatively low. The analysis indicates that while environmental factors may play a role in cattle exposure patterns, human exposure patterns are likely to be driven more strongly by livestock contacts. The implication of livestock markets in cattle exposure risks suggests these may be a suitable target for interventions.
 Schistosomiasis is a major neglected tropical disease affecting over 200 million people worldwide. The draft genome sequences of three schistosome species are now available, highlighting the need for functional genomic approaches to identify the role and importance of schistosome genes. Retrovirus-mediated transgenesis is an established functional genomics approach for model species, but vertical transmission of integrated transgenes has not been reported in schistosomes. Vasa is a germ cell-specific marker that has been studied widely in other species. Here, we identified three vasa-like genes in S. mansoni and examined their developmental expression. We found specific expression in the schistosome ovary and strikingly elevated expression in the developing egg. Since Vasa is a reliable germ cell marker in other flatworms, we anticipate that reporter transgenes vectored by an integration competent vector such as MLV and driven by a vasa promoter might be of use to monitor transgene integration into schistosome germ cells.
 Heart valve disease is a major clinical problem worldwide . Cardiac valve development and homeostasis need to be precisely controlled . Hippo signaling is essential for organ development and tissue homeostasis , while its role in valve formation and morphology maintenance remains unknown . VGLL4 is a transcription cofactor in vertebrates and we found it was mainly expressed in valve interstitial cells at the post-EMT stage and was maintained till the adult stage . Tissue specific knockout of VGLL4 in different cell lineages revealed that only loss of VGLL4 in endothelial cell lineage led to valve malformation with expanded expression of YAP targets . We further semi-knockout YAP in VGLL4 ablated hearts , and found hyper proliferation of arterial valve interstitial cells was significantly constrained . These findings suggest that VGLL4 is important for valve development and manipulation of Hippo components would be a potential therapy for preventing the progression of congenital valve disease .
Soft selective sweeps are a type of evolutionary process in which a beneficial mutation arises and spreads in a population, but not to fixation. This process is different from a hard sweep, in which a beneficial mutation reaches fixation in a population. Recent studies have claimed that soft selective sweeps are pervasive across organisms of very different effective population size and mutation rate, including humans, Drosophila, and HIV. However, others have evaluated the relevance of these models to natural populations and the identifiability of the models relative to other known population-level processes, arguing that soft sweeps are likely to be rare. In this study, we carefully evaluated three recent studies and their underlying methodologies. Using population genetic theory and extensive simulation, we found that all three examples are prone to extremely high false-positive rates, incorrectly identifying soft sweeps under both hard sweep and neutral models. Furthermore, we demonstrated that well-fit demographic histories combined with rare hard sweeps serve as the more parsimonious explanation. These findings represent a necessary response to the growing tendency of invoking parameter-heavy, assumption-laden models of pervasive positive selection and neglecting best practices regarding the construction of proper demographic null models.
 Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vector for dengue fever, causing 50–100 million infections per year. Female mosquitoes are known to be inhibited from host-seeking behavior for three days following a blood meal by a humoral factor. Head Peptide-I is a candidate peptide mediating this suppression, but the mechanism by which this peptide alters mosquito behavior and the receptor through which it signals are unknown. In this study, we identified eight Neuropeptide Y-Like Receptors ( NPYLRs ) in the Ae . aegypti genome and screened each in a cell-based calcium imaging assay for sensitivity against a panel of peptide ligands. We found that NPYLR1 responded to Head Peptide-I as well as short Neuropeptide-F peptides ( sNPFs ). Two NPYLR1 homologues identified in the genome of the Lyme disease vector, Ixodes scapularis, were also sensitive to Head Peptide-I. Injection of synthetic Head Peptide-I and sNPF-3 inhibited host-seeking behavior in non-blood-fed female mosquitoes, whereas control injections of buffer or inactive Head Peptide-I [Cys10] had no effect. To ask if NPYLR1 is necessary for blood-feeding-induced host-seeking inhibition, we used zinc-finger nucleases to generate five independent npylr1 null mutant strains and tested them for behavioral abnormalities. We found that npylr1 mutants displayed normal behavior in locomotion, egg laying, sugar feeding, blood feeding, host seeking, and inhibition of host seeking after a blood meal. In this work, we deorphanized four Ae . aegypti NPYLRs and identified NPYLR1 as a candidate sNPF receptor that is also sensitive to Head Peptide-I. Yet npylr1 alone is not required for host-seeking inhibition and we conclude that other signaling mechanisms must exist for this important behavioral regulation that function even after removal of NPYLR1 activity.
 Schistosomiasis is a water-borne disease caused by parasitic flatworms. The study aimed to identify areas with suitable conditions for schistosomiasis transmission in Akure North Local Government Area of Ondo State, Nigeria. The study used multicriteria evaluation (MCE) and spatial analysis to determine the risk of schistosomiasis in the study area. The results showed that 82% of the area falls under the high and very high risk category. The study also revealed that environmental factors such as temperature, drainage, elevation, rainfall, slope, and land use/land cover can be used to identify and predict the transmission of schistosomiasis. The study suggests that environmental factors can be used in identifying and predicting the transmission of schistosomiasis as well as effective monitoring of disease risk in newly established rural and agricultural communities.
 Streptococcus pneumoniae ( pneumococcal ) meningitis is a common bacterial infection of the brain that causes long-term disabilities in half of the patients. The cholesterol-dependent cytolysin pneumolysin ( PLY ) is a key factor in the neuropathogenic potential of the pneumococci. Here, we demonstrate selective synaptic loss within the superficial layers of the frontal neocortex of post-mortem brain samples from individuals with pneumococcal meningitis. We also observed this effect in mice with pneumococcal meningitis only when the bacteria expressed the pore-forming cholesterol-dependent cytolysin PLY. Exposure of acute mouse brain slices to only PLY at disease-relevant, non-lytic concentrations caused permanent dendritic swelling, dendritic spine elimination, and synaptic loss. The NMDA glutamate receptor antagonists MK801 and D-AP5 reduced this pathology. Pneumolysin increased glutamate levels within the mouse brain slices. In mouse astrocytes, pneumolysin initiated the release of glutamate in a calcium-dependent manner. We propose that pneumolysin plays a significant synapto- and dendritotoxic role in pneumococcal meningitis by initiating glutamate release from astrocytes, leading to subsequent glutamate-dependent synaptic damage. We outline for the first time the occurrence of synaptic pathology in pneumococcal meningitis and demonstrate that a bacterial cytolysin can dysregulate the control of glutamate in the brain, inducing excitotoxic damage.
 Human papillomaviruses ( HPVs ) are DNA viruses associated with major human cancers . To develop new means to prevent HPV infections, such as vaccines and microbicides, it is important to understand the infectious life cycle of HPVs . HPVs must first establish their infection within the basal layer of stratified epithelium, but why this is the case has not been understood. In this study, we used chemical biology approaches to reveal that cell cycle progression through mitosis is critical for HPV infection. We learned that the recipient cell must enter M phase for successful onset of transcription of the HPV encapsidated genes. These findings provide one reason why HPVs initially establish infections in the basal compartment of stratified epithelia, where cells are progressing through the cell cycle. These results also have potentially important implications for HPV control.
 Penicillium marneffei is a fungus that causes systemic mycosis in humans and animals. It is a dimorphic fungus that grows as mycelia at 25°C and yeast cells at 37°C. We used high-throughput sequencing technology to identify small RNAs in P. marneffei. We found that small RNAs were more abundantly expressed in mycelial than yeast phase. We also identified 24 potential milRNA candidates and two genes encoding putative Dicer-like proteins and an Argonaute-like protein. Northern blot analysis confirmed the differential expression of two milRNAs in mycelial phase, which was dependent on dcl-2 but not dcl-1 or qde-2. Our findings provide evidence for the existence of milRNAs in thermal dimorphic fungi and differential expression of milRNAs during different growth phases.
 Zika virus ( ZIKV ) is a mosquito-borne virus that has been spreading rapidly in the Pacific region since 2013. Several mosquito species, including Aedes aegypti and Aedes polynesiensis, have been implicated as potential vectors of ZIKV. In this study, we evaluated the vector competence of field populations of Ae . aegypti and Ae . polynesiensis from different Pacific islands for a ZIKV strain that circulated in the region during the 2013–2017 outbreak. We found that the infection rates were heterogeneous between the Ae . aegypti populations, but the dissemination rates were moderate and more homogenous between these populations. For Ae . polynesiensis, infection rates were less heterogeneous between the two populations tested. The transmission rate and efficiency results revealed a low vector competence for ZIKV of the different Aedes vector populations under study. Our results indicate a low ZIKV transmission by Ae . aegypti and Ae . polynesiensis tested from the Pacific region. These results suggest the importance of other factors, such as vector density, mosquito lifespan, and the large immunologically naive fraction of the population, that may have contributed to the rapid spread of ZIKV in the Pacific region during the 2013–2017 outbreak.
 The long non-coding RNA ( lncRNA ) Xist is a master regulator of X-chromosome inactivation in mammalian cells . To study the structure of Xist in cells , we developed Targeted Structure-Seq , which combines chemical probing of RNA structure in cells with target-specific massively parallel sequencing . By enriching for signals from the RNA of interest , Targeted Structure-Seq achieves high coverage of the target RNA with relatively few sequencing reads , thus providing a targeted and scalable approach to analyze RNA conformation in cells . We use this approach to probe the full-length Xist lncRNA to develop new models for functional elements within Xist , including the repeat A element in the 5’-end of Xist . This analysis also identified new structural elements in Xist that are evolutionarily conserved , including a new element proximal to the C repeats that is important for Xist function . , Introduction:  One of the earliest discoveries of a mammalian long non-coding RNA ( lncRNA ) with a well-defined role in gene regulation is the ∼18 kb Xist lncRNA ( NR_001463 . 3 ) [1 , 2] . Xist drives chromosome-wide repression of one of the two female X-chromosomes during mammalian development in order to balance gene dosage between males ( XY ) and females ( XX ) [3–6] . During early development in female embryos , Xist transcription is up-regulated on the future inactive X-chromosome . Xist spreads by a two-step mechanism [7] to eventually coat the majority of the X-chromosome [3–6 , 8] . Xist directs dramatic and mitotically stable changes on the inactive X chromosome , including DNA methylation , histone methylation , and changes in histone variant incorporation . Despite the relatively long history of studying Xist compared to other lncRNAs , surprisingly little is known about the in vivo conformations of Xist or its molecular mechanism [9] . Xist has at least two partially separable functions: silencing of transcription , and spreading on the X chromosome . These functions map to different features within the RNA [10] . The most notable feature of the Xist RNA is a set of diverse regions that include distinct repeat sequences , denoted A-F ( Fig 1A ) , several of which show conservation across species [1 , 2] . Each of these repetitive elements have a different arrangement; for example , the C-repeat region ( 3098-4712 nt ) is composed of 14 copies of a ∼120 nt monomer , while the A-repeat region , located near the 5’ terminus ( 308-733 nt ) , is composed of 7 . 5 repeats of a ∼25 nt monomer consensus sequence connected by poorly conserved , 17-49 nt U-rich linker sequences . The A-repeat region is the most well-studied structural element in Xist , and is necessary and sufficient to cause transcriptional silencing in mouse and human [10 , 11] . This motif has been reported to interact with various protein factors including the polycomb repressive complex 2 ( PRC2 ) [12 , 13] and the ASF/SF2 splicing factors [14] . While deletion analyses have uncovered evidence for other functional elements , the regions of Xist required for spreading and recruitment of other protein factors are still poorly defined [10] . Nonetheless , it is noteworthy that short antisense peptide nucleic acid ( PNA ) and locked nucleic acid ( LNA ) oligonucleotides targeting the repeat C region of Xist can cause release of Xist from the chromosome without RNA degradation . [15 , 16] These findings support the notion that the C repeat region of Xist is involved in maintaining the association of the RNA with the chromatin . It remains largely unclear how many functional elements will be found within Xist , where they are located , and how they are structured . Understanding the cellular functions of RNA features within Xist would be greatly facilitated by knowing their in vivo conformations . RNA elements , similar to peptide motifs , can fold into thermodynamically stable structures to fulfill their regulatory roles . Our ability to predict RNA secondary structure using minimal free energy is limited by the size
 Genetic variants have been identified for many complex diseases, but it is controversial whether risk prediction based on genomic profiles will be useful clinically. In this study, a novel unifying statistical framework was developed to evaluate the performance of genetic risk prediction models. The framework connects a large variety of predictive indices together, including the area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve, the mean risk difference between cases and non-cases, the net reclassification improvement, the proportion of cases explained by a specific percentile of population at the highest risk, the variance of predicted risks, and the risk at any percentile. The results from simulations match very well with the theoretical estimates. The methodology was applied to nine complex diseases, evaluating the predictive power of genetic tests based on known susceptibility variants for each trait. The results suggest that genetic tests may be useful in risk prediction for some complex diseases, but not for others.
 The study aimed to evaluate the accuracy of a new rapid diagnostic test (RDT) for human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) in comparison with an RDT produced using native antigens and the card agglutination test for trypanosomiasis (CATT). The new RDT, SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0, was found to be more sensitive than CATT and as specific as the SD BIOLINE HAT. Combining two or three tests resulted in a markedly increased sensitivity, although some decrease in specificity was observed. The study suggests that using two or more tests could enhance the sensitivity of diagnostic algorithms for HAT, although further investigation of the practicality and cost-effectiveness of such algorithms is needed.
 Chagas disease is a neglected tropical disease that affects millions of people in Latin America. In Guatemala, the disease has been effectively controlled in most of the country, but some areas still have persistent infestation. We carried out three cross-sectional surveys in Comapa, Guatemala, to evaluate the impact of vector control activities on infestation and seroprevalence. After multiple rounds of indoor residual insecticide spraying, infestation decreased significantly, but seroprevalence in women of child-bearing age remains high. Our findings suggest that sustained vector control efforts are needed to reach the goal of Chagas disease elimination in Guatemala.
 The bacterium Citrobacter rodentium is a natural mouse pathogen that causes attaching and effacing ( A/E ) lesions . It shares a common virulence strategy with the clinically significant human A/E pathogens enteropathogenic E . coli ( EPEC ) and enterohaemorrhagic E . coli ( EHEC ) and is widely used to model this route of pathogenesis . We previously reported the complete genome sequence of C . rodentium ICC168 , where we found that the genome displayed many characteristics of a newly evolved pathogen . In this study , through PFGE , sequencing of isolates showing variation , whole genome transcriptome analysis and examination of the mobile genetic elements , we found that , consistent with our previous hypothesis , the genome of C . rodentium is unstable as a result of repeat-mediated , large-scale genome recombination and because of active transposition of mobile genetic elements such as the prophages . We sequenced an additional C . rodentium strain , EX-33 , to reveal that the reference strain ICC168 is representative of the species and that most of the inactivating mutations were common to both isolates and likely to have occurred early on in the evolution of this pathogen . We draw parallels with the evolution of other bacterial pathogens and conclude that C . rodentium is a recently evolved pathogen that may have emerged alongside the development of inbred mice as a model for human disease .
 Stochastic fluctuations in gene expression give rise to distributions of protein levels across cell populations. Despite a mounting number of theoretical models explaining stochasticity in protein expression, we lack a robust, efficient, and assumption-free approach for inferring the molecular mechanisms that underlie the shape of protein distributions. Here we propose a method for inferring sets of biochemical rate constants that govern chromatin modification, transcription, translation, and RNA and protein degradation from stochasticity in protein expression. We asked whether the rates of these underlying processes can be estimated accurately from protein expression distributions, in the absence of any limiting assumptions. To do this, we (1) derived analytical solutions for the first four moments of the protein distribution, (2) found that these four moments completely capture the shape of protein distributions, and (3) developed an efficient algorithm for inferring gene expression rate constants from the moments of protein distributions. Using this algorithm, we find that most protein distributions are consistent with a large number of different biochemical rate constant sets. Despite this degeneracy, the solution space of rate constants almost always informs on underlying mechanism. For example, we distinguish between regimes where transcriptional bursting occurs from regimes reflecting constitutive transcript production. Our method agrees with the current standard approach, and in the restrictive regime where the standard method operates, also identifies all of the underlying rate constants. Even without making any assumptions, we obtain estimates of individual biochemical rate constants or meaningful ratios of rate constants in 91% of tested cases. In some cases, our method identified all of the underlying rate constants. The framework developed here will be a powerful tool for deducing the contributions of particular molecular mechanisms to specific patterns of gene expression.
 Monkeypox virus (MPXV) is a rare but emerging zoonotic disease that causes a rash and fever in humans. It is endemic in Central and West Africa and has been reported in the United States. There is no specific treatment for MPXV, and the smallpox vaccine has been shown to be effective but not without side effects. In this study, researchers used recombinant bovine herpesvirus 4 (BoHV-4) vectors to express different MPXV glycoproteins in mice. They found that all three vectors were safe and effective in protecting mice against a lethal MPXV challenge. This study suggests that BoHV-4-based vectors could be a promising platform for developing vaccines against MPXV and other emerging diseases.
5’-3’ decay is the major mRNA decay pathway in many eukaryotes, including trypanosomes. After deadenylation, mRNAs are decapped by the nudix hydrolase DCP2 of the decapping complex and finally degraded by the 5’-3’ exoribonuclease. Uniquely, trypanosomes lack homologues to all subunits of the decapping complex, while deadenylation and 5’-3’ degradation are conserved. Here, the author shows that the parasites use an ApaH-like phosphatase ( ALPH1 ) as their major mRNA decapping enzyme. ALPH1 is a novel trypanosome stress granule protein and is involved in mRNA binding. A fraction of ALPH1 co-localises exclusively with the 5’-3’ exoribonuclease XRNA to a special granule at the posterior pole of the cell, indicating a connection between the two enzymes. RNAi depletion of ALPH1 is lethal and causes a massive increase in total mRNAs that are deadenylated but have not yet started 5’-3’ decay. These data suggest that ALPH1 acts downstream of deadenylation and upstream of mRNA degradation, consistent with a function in mRNA decapping. In vitro experiments show that recombinant, N-terminally truncated ALHP1 protein, but not a catalytically inactive mutant, sensitises the capped trypanosome spliced leader RNA to yeast Xrn1, but only if an RNA 5’ polyphosphatase is included. This indicates that the decapping mechanism of ALPH1 differs from the decapping mechanism of Dcp2 by leaving more than one phosphate group at the mRNA’s 5’ end. This is the first reported function of a eukaryotic ApaH-like phosphatase, a bacterial-derived class of enzymes present in all phylogenetic super-groups of the eukaryotic kingdom. The substrates of eukaryotic ApaH-like phosphatases are unknown. However, the substrate of the related bacterial enzyme ApaH, diadenosine tetraphosphate, is highly reminiscent of a eukaryotic mRNA cap.
β-cells are responsible for producing insulin, a hormone that regulates blood sugar levels. In diabetes, the body loses its ability to produce enough insulin, leading to high blood sugar levels. Scientists have found that new β-cells can be made from other types of cells in the pancreas. They have also found that a gene called Arx is important for this process. By inhibiting the expression of Arx in adult α-cells, the scientists were able to convert them into β-like cells. These new β-like cells were able to produce insulin and regulate blood sugar levels. This discovery could lead to new treatments for diabetes.
 The initiation of DNA replication is tightly regulated in eukaryotic cells to ensure that it occurs only once per cell cycle. However, re-initiation of DNA replication can lead to genomic alterations, which can contribute to cancer. To understand how re-initiation is regulated, researchers have identified a number of mechanisms that prevent re-initiation of DNA replication. However, these mechanisms are not sufficient to prevent re-initiation entirely. In this study, researchers have identified novel genetic elements that are necessary for preferential re-initiation of two origins and sufficient to confer preferential re-initiation on heterologous origins when the control of re-initiation is partially deregulated. These elements do not enhance the S phase timing or efficiency of adjacent origins and thus are specifically acting as re-initiation promoters (RIPs). The researchers have mapped the two RIPs to ∼60 bp AT rich sequences that act in a distance- and sequence-dependent manner. During the induction of re-replication, Mcm2-7 reassociates both with origins that preferentially re-initiate and origins that do not, suggesting that the RIP elements can overcome a block to re-initiation imposed after Mcm2-7 associates with origins. These findings identify a local level of control in the block to re-initiation and reveal a complex genomic landscape of re-replication potential that is revealed when global mechanisms preventing re-initiation are compromised. Hence, if re-replication does contribute to genomic alterations, as has been speculated for cancer cells, some regions of the genome may be more susceptible to these alterations than others.
170 HIV-1 patients with amebiasis were analyzed retrospectively. The clinical presentation of amebiasis was similar to that described in normal hosts. High fever, leukocytosis, and high CRP were associated with extraluminal amebic diseases. Two patients died from amebic colitis, and three patients died from causes unrelated to amebiasis. Treatment with metronidazole or tinidazole was successful in 165 cases. Luminal treatment was provided to 83 patients following metronidazole or tinidazole treatment. However, amebiasis recurred in 6 of these patients, a frequency similar to that seen in patients who did not receive luminal treatment. Various genotypes of E. histolytica were identified in 14 patients but there was no correlation between genotype and clinical features. The outcome of metronidazole and tinidazole treatment of uncomplicated amebiasis was excellent even in HIV-1-infected individuals. Luminal treatment following metronidazole or tinidazole treatment does not reduce recurrence of amebiasis in high risk populations probably due to amebic re-infection.
 The study aimed to assess the impact of adding vector control to case detection and treatment on the incidence of Gambian sleeping sickness in the Mandoul area of Chad . The study found that the deployment of tiny targets, which attract and kill tsetse, significantly reduced the number of tsetse caught in traps and the incidence of sleeping sickness in the Mandoul area . The study also used mathematical modeling to estimate the impact of vector control on the incidence of sleeping sickness and found that vector control was responsible for 70.4% of the reduction in reported cases between 2013 and 2015. The study suggests that the combination of vector control and medical interventions could lead to the elimination of Gambian sleeping sickness as a public health problem in the Mandoul area by 2018.
 Strongyloidiasis is a parasitic infection caused by the nematode Strongyloides stercoralis. It is a soil-transmitted helminthiasis that is endemic in tropical and subtropical regions, but has also been reported in temperate climates. The parasite can persist in the human host for decades without the need for exogenous reinfection. Imported strongyloidiasis is increasingly being diagnosed in non-endemic areas, such as Spain, due to increased migration and international travel. The aim of this study was to describe the epidemiological, clinical, and microbiological characteristics of patients with imported strongyloidiasis in Spain. The study included 1245 cases from the +REDIVI Spanish Collaborative Network from 2009 to 2017. Most of the patients were immigrants from South America, and detection of larvae in stool samples was observed in 21.9% of the cases. Eosinophilia was present in 82.2% of cases. Treatment with ivermectin was the most strongly associated factor to achieve the cure. Given the long latency of the infection and the risk of developing a severe presentation, screening of S . stercoralis infection should be mandatory in patients coming from or had traveled to endemic areas, especially in those with immunosuppressant conditions.
 Vaccines are an important tool for preventing infectious diseases. The inoculum dose, or the amount of antigen or live attenuated pathogen used in a vaccine, is an important consideration in vaccine design. Higher doses generally lead to better immune stimulation but may also cause more severe side effects and reduce population coverage in the presence of vaccine shortages. Determining the optimal inoculum dose is an important component of rational vaccine design.
