A combination of mathematical models and experimental data can help determine the impact of inoculum dose on important outcomes such as immune protection and morbidity. We illustrate this concept by fitting a mathematical model to data from influenza A virus (IAV) infection of mice and human parainfluenza virus (HPIV) infection of cotton rats at different inoculum doses. We use the model to map inoculum dose to the level of immune protection and morbidity and explore how such a framework might be used to determine an optimal inoculum dose. Our findings illustrate that the impact of inoculum dose on immune protection and morbidity can depend on the specific pathogen and that both protection and morbidity do not necessarily increase monotonically with increasing inoculum dose. Once vaccine design goals are specified with required levels of protection and acceptable levels of morbidity, our proposed framework can help in the rational design of vaccines and determination of the optimal amount of inoculum.
 The development of multicellular organisms is a complex process that involves the coordination of various cellular functions. One important aspect of this process is the control of gene expression, which can be influenced by various factors such as cell-to-cell communication and environmental conditions. In this study, the authors investigated the role of noise in gene expression during the development of a multicellular organism. They used the filamentous cyanobacterium Anabaena as a model organism and studied the expression of the HetR transcription factor, which is essential for heterocyst differentiation. The authors found that noise in gene expression plays a crucial role in the development of Anabaena filaments and that cell-to-cell communication is important for controlling this noise. They also identified specific proteins that are involved in this process. Overall, this study provides important insights into the mechanisms that control gene expression during the development of multicellular organisms.
 Japanese encephalitis virus ( JEV ) is a zoonotic flavivirus that causes encephalitis in humans and reproductive disorders in pigs in the Asian pacific region . The genome of JEV is single-stranded positive-sense RNA consisting of a short 5’ untranslated region , a single open reading frame , and a longer 3’ untranslated region . The single open reading frame encodes a polyprotein that is subsequently cleaved by both cellular and viral proteases into three structural proteins ( capsid ( C ) , pre-membrane/membrane ( PrM ) , and envelope ( E ) ) and seven nonstructural proteins ( NS ) ( NS1 , NS2A , NS2B , NS3 , NS4A , NS4B and NS5 ) . The JEV enzootic transmission cycle is maintained in nature by several species of mosquito vectors and vertebrate hosts . JEV is transmitted predominantly by Culex mosquitoes , but several other genera may participate in certain circumstances [4] . Mosquitoes transmit JEV from a viremic vertebrate to a susceptible vertebrate including humans , birds , pigs and other mammals by bite . After infection by JEV-infected mosquitoes , many domestic and wild bird species demonstrate varying degrees of viremia . Some of which , including young domestic ducklings and chicks , as well as ardeid wading birds develop a level of viremia sufficient to infect mosquitoes and are thus considered the amplifying hosts for JEV transmission [4–6] . Among mammal species susceptible to JEV infection , pigs are the only mammals responsible for JEV transmission , because JEV-infected pigs develop a level of viremia that remains high enough to infect mosquitoes for up to 4 days [4] . JEV is phylogenetically divided into five genotypes ( genotype I to V ) based on the nucleotide sequence of the E gene [7 , 8] . Genotype III ( GIII ) has historically been the main causative agent of Japanese encephalitis ( JE ) and was the dominant genotype throughout most of Asia from 1935 through the 1990s . Genotype I ( GI ) was isolated in Cambodia in 1967 and remained undetectable until 1977 when a new isolate was collected in China . Notably , molecular epidemiological surveillance of JEV isolates collected during the last 20 years revealed that GIII has been gradually replaced by GI , showing a genotype shift with GI as the dominant genotype in Asian countries [9–10] . Previous analysis of the differences between the two genotypes at genetic and epidemiological levels suggested that GI displaced GIII probably by achieving a replication cycle that is more efficient but more restricted in its host range [11] . This hypothesis was partially supported by an observation that a GI isolate has significantly higher infectivity titers in mosquito C6/36 cells than two GIII isolates [10] . We therefore evaluated the prevalence of GI and GIII infection in pigs in China and used seven recently-isolated JEV strains including three GI strains and four GIII strains to compare their replication efficiency in vitro and in vivo , with the aim of gaining insight into the reasons for the JEV genotype shift .
The study of biofilm formation in Candida albicans, a fungal pathogen, is important for understanding its pathobiology. A network of transcription factors regulates biofilm formation, but their functional interactions are not well understood. To address this, the authors used a systematic genetic interaction approach based on generating all possible double heterozygous mutants of the network genes and quantitatively analyzing the genetic interactions between them. The network is highly susceptible to genetic perturbation, with all six network heterozygous mutants showing alterations in biofilm formation. The network shows properties of a small-world network that is highly efficient but not robust. The authors also found that expression of Rob1 is dependent on both auto-regulation and cooperative interactions with other network TFs. Finally, the heterozygous Ndt80 deletion mutant is hyperfilamentous under both biofilm and hyphae-inducing conditions in a Tec1-dependent manner. These findings provide new insights into the functions of individual TFs as well as into the role of the overall network topology in its function.
 Asparagine ( Asn ) is an important amino acid that is synthesized by asparagine synthetase ( AS ) from aspartate in an ATP-dependent manner using ammonia or glutamine as a nitrogen source . In this study, we have characterized the asparagine synthetase A ( LiAS-A ) from Leishmania infantum , a parasite that causes visceral leishmaniasis in humans. We have shown that LiAS-A is able to use both ammonia and glutamine as nitrogen donors, and that it is not essential for parasite survival, growth, or infectivity in normal in vitro and in vivo conditions. Therefore, we exclude AS-A as a suitable drug target against L . infantum parasites.
 Toxocariasis is a parasitic infection caused by Toxocara canis or Toxocara cati, the common roundworms of dogs and cats, respectively. It is one of the most prevalent helminthiasis worldwide, with a seroprevalence ranging from 35 to 42% in Western countries and from 60 to 90% in tropical settings. Toxocara larvae can migrate to any organ, including the central nervous system, leading to neurotoxocariasis. Several studies have suggested a possible role of toxocariasis in the incidence of epilepsy. A systematic review and meta-analysis of all the available data found a positive association between Toxocara spp. seropositivity and epilepsy. However, this association is still debated. To gain further insight on the association between human toxocariasis and epilepsy, we updated our previous research. Our findings suggest that the association between toxocariasis and epilepsy is still positive, even after considering new studies. These findings highlight the importance of further research to understand the physiopathological mechanisms of toxocariasis-associated epileptogenesis.
 The DNA damage response ( DDR ) is a critical cellular process that helps maintain genomic stability and prevent tumor development. In this study, we describe a new pathway that regulates the DDR through the interaction of ATM, a protein that plays a key role in the DDR, and miR-335, a microRNA that targets CtIP, a protein involved in DNA end resection during homologous recombination repair. We show that ATM-dependent downregulation of miR-335 expression is important for the DDR and that this new pathway is dysfunctional in two patient-derived lymphoblastoid cell lines with constitutive miR-335 overexpression. We also demonstrate that suppressing miR-335 can rescue the radiosensitive cellular phenotype of these patient-derived cell lines. Our findings suggest that miR-335 may be a new target for therapeutic intervention in patients with DDR defects.
 In this study, we investigated the role of mentalizing in learning in the context of social interactions. We asked participants to play repeated games against artificial ( Bayesian ) mentalizing agents, which differed in their sophistication. We found that participants won against the artificial ( sophisticated ) mentalizing agents in the social framing of the task, and lost in the non-social framing. Moreover, we found that participants' choice sequences were best explained by sophisticated mentalizing Bayesian learning models only in the social framing. This study is the first demonstration of the added-value of mentalizing on learning in the context of repeated social interactions. Our results show that we would not be able to decipher intentional behaviour without a priori attributing mental states to others.
 The study proposes an efficient algorithm to implement the estimation of Gaussian graphical model ( GGM ) and obtain p-value and confidence interval for each edge in the graph, based on a recent proposal by Ren et al. . The algorithm is faster by several orders of magnitude than the current implemented algorithm for Ren et al. without losing any accuracy. The algorithm is applied to two real data sets: transcriptomic data from a study of childhood asthma and proteomic data from a study of Alzheimer’s disease. The resulting networks reveal interesting interactions and the differential networks between cases and controls show functional relevance to the diseases. The algorithm has been implemented in an R package named “FastGGM”.
 The striatum is a key brain structure involved in movement and learning. It receives input from the cerebral cortex and sends output to the basal ganglia. The striatum is composed of medium spiny neurons (MSNs) that inhibit each other through local connections. Studies have shown that MSNs display large variations in firing rate on slow timescales, which are thought to be driven by cortical inputs. However, recent work suggests that striatal activity may also be generated internally by the MSN network. In this study, we investigate how striatal activity interacts with cortical driving and how this activity depends on network parameters. We find that striatal activity is optimized in a marginally stable transition regime that occurs at striatally relevant connectivities and synaptic strengths. We discuss how these properties may be utilized in temporally delayed reinforcement learning tasks.
 In this study, we investigated the role of the yeast Rab GTPase Sec4p in coupling polarized exocytosis with endocytosis. We found that Sec4p localizes to nascent sites of endocytosis and promotes actin polymerization, which triggers compensatory endocytosis. Our results suggest that Sec4p overrides a limiting step in actin patch formation and directly couples transport cycles to and from the cell cortex. This study provides new insights into the mechanisms underlying the regulation of polarized growth in yeast.
 Acetaminophen (APAP) is a widely used pain reliever, but it can cause liver damage in some people. The mechanism of APAP-induced liver injury in mice is not fully understood, but it is believed to involve the formation of a toxic metabolite called NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine) within hepatocytes. The formation of NAPQI is thought to be zonated, meaning that it occurs more frequently in certain regions of the liver. In this study, the authors used computer simulations to test different hypotheses about how APAP-induced liver injury occurs in mice. They found that a hypothesis that combines two different zonation patterns was able to explain the observed liver damage in mice. This finding could help researchers better understand how APAP-induced liver injury occurs in mice and potentially lead to new treatments for this condition.
 The study aimed to quantify the parasite burden in children congenitally infected with Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, at three different diagnostic controls during one-year follow-up after delivery. The parasite burden was estimated by quantitative PCR in 51 children, grouped according to the results of one-year follow-up diagnosis. The results showed that the parasite burden in some children was below the detection limit of the INP micromethod. The study highlights the need for more sensitive parasitological methods to ensure an early diagnosis of T . cruzi congenital infection.
 The paper proposes a biophysical model of Escherichia coli that predicts growth rate and an effective cellular composition from an effective, coarse-grained representation of its genome. The model assumes that E . coli is in a state of balanced exponential steady-state growth, growing in a temporally and spatially constant environment, rich in resources. The model is applied to a series of past measurements where the growth rate and rRNA-to-protein ratio have been measured for seven E . coli strains with an rRNA operon copy number ranging from one to seven (the wild-type copy number). These experiments show that growth rate markedly decreases for strains with fewer than six copies. Using the model, we were able to reproduce these measurements. The model that best fits these data suggests that the volume fraction of macromolecules inside E . coli is not fixed when the rRNA operon copy number is varied. Moreover, the model predicts that increasing the copy number beyond seven results in a cytoplasm densely packed with ribosomes and proteins. Assuming that under such overcrowded conditions prolonged diffusion times tend to weaken binding affinities, the model predicts that growth rate will not increase substantially beyond the wild-type growth rate. The model therefore suggests that changing the rRNA operon copy number of wild-type E . coli cells growing in a constant rich environment does not substantially increase their growth rate. Other observations regarding strains with an altered rRNA operon copy number, such as nucleoid compaction and the rRNA operon feedback response, appear to be qualitatively consistent with this model. In addition, we discuss possible design principles suggested by the model and propose further experiments to test its validity.
 The MYB transcription factor family is involved in many biological processes, including metabolism, development, and responses to biotic and abiotic stresses. RADIALIS-LIKE SANT/MYB 1 (RSM1) is a MYB-related subfamily member that plays roles in plant development, stress responses, and plant hormone signaling. However, the molecular mechanisms of RSM1 action in response to abiotic stresses remain obscure. In this study, we show that down-regulation or up-regulation of RSM1 expression alters the sensitivity of seed germination and cotyledon greening to abscisic acid (ABA), NaCl, and mannitol in Arabidopsis. The expression of RSM1 is dynamically regulated by ABA and NaCl. Transcription factors ELONGATED HYPOCOTYL 5 (HY5) and HY5 HOMOLOG (HYH) regulate RSM1 expression via binding to the RSM1 promoter. Genetic analyses reveal that RSM1 mediates multiple functions of HY5 in responses of seed germination, post-germination development to ABA and abiotic stresses, and seedling tolerance to salinity. RSM1 and HY5/HYH may function as a regulatory module in responses to ABA and abiotic stresses. RSM1 binds to the promoter of ABA INSENSITIVE 5 (ABI5) and stimulates HY5 binding to the ABI5 promoter. However, no evidence was found in the dual-luciferase transient expression assay to support that RSM enhances the activation of ABI5 expression by HY. In summary, HY5/HYH and RSM1 may converge on the ABI5 promoter and independently or somehow dependently regulate ABI5 expression and ABI5-downstream ABA and abiotic stress-responsive genes, thereby improving the adaption of plants to the environment.
 Mitochondrial complex I is a large and complex enzyme that links the electron transfer from NADH to ubiquinone to the pumping of four protons from the matrix into the intermembrane space. In humans, defects in complex I are involved in a wide range of degenerative disorders. Recent progress in X-ray structural analysis of prokaryotic and eukaryotic complex I confirmed that the redox reactions are confined entirely to the hydrophilic peripheral arm of the L-shaped molecule and take place at a remarkable distance from the membrane domain. While this implies that the proton pumping within the membrane arm of complex I is driven indirectly via long-range conformational coupling, the molecular mechanism and the number, identity, and localization of the pump-sites remain unclear. Here, we report that upon deletion of the gene for a small accessory subunit of the Yarrowia complex I, a stable subcomplex (nb8mΔ) is formed that lacks the distal part of the membrane domain as revealed by single particle analysis. The analysis of the subunit composition of holo and subcomplex by three complementary proteomic approaches revealed that two (ND4 and ND5) of the three subunits with homology to bacterial Mrp-type Na+/H+ antiporters that have been discussed as prime candidates for harbouring the proton pumps were missing in nb8mΔ. Nevertheless, nb8mΔ still pumps protons at half the stoichiometry of the complete enzyme. Our results provide evidence that the membrane arm of complex I harbours two functionally distinct pump modules that are connected in series by the long helical transmission element recently identified by X-ray structural analysis.
 Fever is a regulated increase of body temperature that occurs in response to infection. Fever has been shown to play a role in modulating immune responses to infection, but the potential of febrile temperatures in regulating antigen binding affinity to antibodies has not been explored. In this study, we investigated the effect of temperature on the binding affinity of two antibody-antigen complexes from two different fever-inducing infectious diseases. We used selected malarial and dengue antigens against specific monoclonal antibodies, and observed a marked increase in the affinity of these antibody-antigen complexes at 40°C compared to physiological or pathophysiological temperatures. We also observed a notable decrease in affinity at 42°C, possibly due to protein unfolding. These results suggest that fever may play a positive and adaptive role in vivo by enhancing protein-protein affinity for samples with limited availability.
 The actomyosin cortex is a thin layer of cross-linked actin filaments and myosin motors that lies just beneath the plasma membrane of animal cells. It is responsible for cellular deformation and flow. The production and dissipation of contractile stress in the actomyosin cortex are essential for these processes. In this study, we developed a computational model of a cross-linked network with active motors based on minimal requirements for production and dissipation of contractile stress. We characterized how the production and dissipation of network stress depend on cross-link dynamics and filament turnover, and how these dependencies combine to determine overall rates of cortical flow. Our analysis revealed that filament turnover is required to maintain active stress against external resistance and steady state flow in response to external stress. We also found that effective viscosity increases with filament lifetime up to a characteristic time τc, and then becomes independent of filament lifetime and sharply dependent on crosslink dynamics. These results provide a framework for understanding how animal cells tune cortical flow through local control of network remodeling.
 The study aimed to identify the genetic loci responsible for seedling sensitivity to high sugar levels in Arabidopsis thaliana. A quantitative trait locus ( QTL ) analysis was performed using a Col/C24 F2 population. A glucose and fructose-sensing QTL, GSQ11, was identified and mapped to the ANAC060 gene. The Col ANAC060 allele confers sugar insensitivity and is dominant over the sugar-sensitive C24 allele. The truncated Col ANAC060 protein lacks the transmembrane domain and is constitutively located in the nucleus. The study suggests that the sugar-ABA signaling cascade induces ANAC060 expression, but the truncated Col ANAC060 protein attenuates ABA induction and ABA signaling, resulting in sugar insensitivity. The study provides insight into the sugar-ABA signaling cascade and the role of ANAC060 in sugar sensitivity.
 The bacterial second messenger c-di-GMP is involved in many cellular processes, including biofilm formation, motility, and virulence. The c-di-GMP levels are regulated by two classes of enzymes, diguanylate cyclases (DGCs) and phosphodiesterases (PDEs). In Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the HptB pathway controls biofilm formation and motility by involving both HsbD and the anti-anti-sigma factor HsbA. The rewiring of c-di-GMP signaling into the HptB cascade relies on the original interaction between HsbD and HsbA and on the control of HsbD dynamic localization at the cell poles. Our study provides insights into how c-di-GMP signaling can be orchestrated in bacteria to reach output specificity.
 In this study, we investigated how humans learn multiple visuomotor mappings when feedback for each is provided alternately. We found that participants could learn the associations between target shape and required visuomotor mapping and generalise to novel but similar conditions. We also developed a Bayesian learning model that predicted generalisation that is more consistent with categorisation ( i.e., use one mapping or the other ) and found that the model poses a possible mechanism for simultaneously learning multiple visuomotor mappings.
 The cerebellum is responsible for coordinating and fine-tuning motor movements. The inferior olivary nucleus ( IO ) provides one of the two main inputs to the cerebellum, the climbing fibers ( CFs ). Activation of CFs is believed to be related to timing of motor commands and/or motor learning. CF spikes lead to large all-or-none action potentials in cerebellar Purkinje cells, overriding any other ongoing activity and silencing these cells for a brief period of time afterwards. Previously reported results from in vitro studies suggested that the information encoded in the climbing fiber burst is related to the occurrence of the spike relative to the ongoing sub-threshold membrane potential oscillation of the olivary cell, i.e., that the phase of the oscillation is reflected in the size of the climbing fiber burst. We used a detailed three-compartmental model of an inferior olivary cell to further investigate the possible factors determining the size of the climbing fiber burst. Our findings suggest that the phase-dependency of the burst size is present but limited and that charge flow between soma and dendrite is a major determinant of the climbing fiber burst. From our findings it follows that phenomena such as cell ensemble synchrony can have a big effect on the climbing fiber burst size through dendrodendritic gap-junctional coupling between olivary cells.
 Iron is essential for life, but its redox properties can also be toxic. The liver plays a central role in regulating iron levels, and a computational model of human liver iron metabolism has been developed. The model includes core regulatory components and their kinetic properties, and has been validated by reproducing previously published physiological data. The model can be used to simulate the response to iron challenges and to identify potential drug targets for treating iron-related diseases.
 The nuclear pore complex ( NPC ) is a selective gateway for material transport across the nuclear envelope ( NE ) . The transport process is highly dynamic and fast, and involves the hydrophobic interactions between karyopherins ( kaps ) and FG-repeat domains . In this study, we developed a coarse-grained model of the NPC structure that mimics nucleocytoplasmic transport ( NCT ) . The model predicts that the first-passage time of a 15 nm cargo-complex is about 2 . 6±0 . 13 ms with an inverse Gaussian distribution for statistically adequate number of independent Brownian dynamics simulations . Moreover , the cargo-complex is primarily attached to the channel wall where it interacts with the FG-layer as it passes through the central channel . The kap-FG hydrophobic interaction is highly dynamic and fast , which ensures an efficient translocation through the NPC . Finally , as opposed to intact NPCs , cytoplasmic filaments-deficient NPCs show a high degree of permeability to inert cargos , implying the defining role of cytoplasmic filaments in the selectivity barrier . , Introduction:  The nuclear pore complex ( NPC ) is the exclusive gateway of material transport across the nuclear envelope ( NE ) . This selective gateway plays a critical role in regulating transcription and protecting the genetic material of eukaryotic cells; consequently , its structure is highly conserved from yeast to vertebrates . However , the mechanism of transport across the NPC remains elusive and proposed models thus far remain incomplete and sometimes contradictory even for normal ( wild-type ) NPC . The NPC is composed of about 30 distinct proteins collectively called nucleoporins ( nups ) . Individual nups are directly related to several human diseases including influenza , cancers such as leukemia and inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors , and less frequent diseases like triple-A syndrome and primary biliary cirrhosis [13] , [14] , [15] , [16] . Nups also play an important role in viral infections by providing docking sites for viral capsids , and also by blocking host cell mRNA export or inhibiting import of antiviral signals [17] . For a most recent comprehensive review about NPC-related disease see Jamali et al . , 2011 [18] . Along the same lines , Buehler et al . , 2010 , have recently reviewed the role of protein mechanics in disease conditions [19] . The total mass of the NPC is species-dependent and is about 44 MDa and 60 MDa in yeast and vertebrates , respectively [20] . The dimensions of the NPC also depend on the species . For example , yeast NPCs are 15% smaller than Xenopus NPCs [21] . The subunits of the NPC structure are cytoplasmic filaments , a cytoplasmic ring , a central channel that includes the spoke domains , a nuclear ring , and a nuclear basket that is composed of nuclear rods and a distal ring ( see Figure 2 for the detailed dimensions of Xenopus oocyte NPC ) . The NPC acts as a freeway for passive diffusion of molecules and ions smaller than ∼5 nm in diameter [22] , [23] , while actively controlling and facilitating the transport of larger cargos up to about 39–40 nm [7] , [24] by discriminating between inert and karyopherin-bound cargos . Karyopherins ( kaps ) are a family of soluble proteins by which different cargos are shuttled between the cytoplasm and nucleoplasm via a signaling process to form the cargo-complex . A single NPC can accommodate a remarkable rate of transport on the order of ∼1000 translocations/sec , corresponding to a mass flow of ∼100 MDa/sec [7] . Importantly , almost 30% of nups include natively unfolded domains of phenylalanine-glycine ( FG ) repeats , collectively termed FG-repeat domains [25] , [26] . It is believed that the key feature in nucleocytoplasmic transport ( NCT ) is the interaction of kap with these natively unfolded repeat domains , and thus , FG-repeats are the central players in all proposed models .  The nonhuman primate ( NHP ) model is often the best experimental model for testing interventions designed to block infection by human pathogens, such as HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria. However, significant ethical and economic constraints accompany such models, including a mandate to use as few animals as possible to achieve statistically significant and biologically meaningful results. In many NHP models, it is desirable to use a limiting infectious dose as a challenge, a dose which only infects a fraction of animals at each exposure. Such exposures are generally considered to be more physiological and therefore better mimic the potential clinical impact of vaccination or therapeutic intervention. To date, the most-used example of this is repeated mucosal challenge with SIV or SHIV for testing vaccines, microbicides, or peri-exposure prophylaxes. However, limiting-dose challenge models require careful titration of the infectious agent. Using a dose that is too high (and not physiological) may lead to a false negative effect of the intervention, whereas a dose that is too low will lead to insufficient infections within the time frame of the experiment to yield useful data, consequently using animals for no gain as well as wasting resources. Even a 2-fold error in the challenge dose can significantly impact the power of an experiment. The goal of the analyses presented here was to define a titration protocol that minimized animal use and procedures while estimating the AID50 to within 1.5-fold of the true value. While much of the discussion is based on NHP (and the SIV model), the protocol is generalizable to any pathogen and any animal model. A method for estimating infectious doses was published almost 80 years ago, based on the method by Reed and Muench, one would use as many as 48 animals to estimate the AID50. A seminal paper by Spouge used a Bayesian framework to define a method to estimate the AID50 (and its precision) for intravenous infection. However, the goal at that time was to define a minimal dose infecting all animals in an experiment (e.g., AID99) following intravenous infection (using a purely stochastic model of infection). Here, I model infection based in part on Michaelis-Menten kinetics, with the goal of defining a challenge dose that reproducibly infects a fraction of animals; the statistical analysis is similar to a Logit model from Spouge. From this, I define a parsimonious protocol to efficiently estimate the AID50 for a pathogen; this protocol will, on average, only use 15 animals.
 We studied the response of a first-order auditory interneuron ( AN2 ) in crickets to amplitude-modulated sound stimuli and found that adaptation shifts the stimulus–response curves toward higher stimulus intensities, with a time constant of 1.5 seconds for adaptation and recovery. The spike responses were thus reduced for low-intensity sounds. We then tested two competing hypotheses about the function of adaptation: infomax and selective coding. Infomax predicts that information conveyed about the entire signal range should be maximized, while selective coding predicts that “foreground” signals should be enhanced while “background” signals should be selectively suppressed. We tested how adaptation changes the input–response curve when presenting signals with two or three peaks in their amplitude distributions. By means of Bayesian data analysis, we quantified the shifts of the measured response curves and also found a slight reduction of their slopes. These decreases in slopes are smaller than those predicted by infomax, and the absolute response thresholds are higher. Most remarkably, and in contrast to the infomax principle, adaptation actually reduces the amount of encoded information when considering the whole range of input signals. Less information is transmitted about signals with lower intensity. The response curve changes are also not consistent with the selective coding hypothesis, because the amount of information conveyed about the loudest part of the signal does not increase as predicted but remains nearly constant.
 Prions are infectious particles that cause neurodegenerative diseases in humans and animals. Prions are composed of a misfolded form of a protein called PrPSc, which binds to and converts the normal form of the protein, PrPC, into PrPSc. In this study, the authors used a technique called serial protein misfolding cyclic amplification (sPMCA) to propagate PrPSc molecules in vitro. They found that PrPSc molecules lacking one or both of the polybasic domains (PBDs) of PrPC could still bind to and convert PrPC into PrPSc, but that these PrPSc molecules had diminished or absent biological infectivity. The authors suggest that the PBDs may be required for PrPSc to interact with PrPC in a way that generates infectivity. This study provides important insights into the mechanisms of prion propagation and infectivity.
 In this study, we developed an inverse reinforcement-learning ( IRL ) framework to identify an animal’s behavioral strategy from behavioral time-series data. We applied this framework to C . elegans thermotactic behavior, which involves two strategies: directed migration ( DM ) and isothermal migration ( IM ). We found that fed worms used both the absolute temperature and its temporal derivative, while starved worms used only the absolute temperature. We also found that the AFD neurons are fundamental for the DM exhibited by the fed worms. Our framework can reveal the most preferable/optimal state for the animals and how they reach that state, providing clues for understanding the computational principles in the nervous system.
 Haptophytes are a diverse group of eukaryotic algae that play an important role in aquatic ecosystems. They are responsible for a significant portion of global carbon sequestration and are known to produce harmful blooms. The draft genome sequence of Chrysochromulina tobin, a member of the Prymnesiophycidae subclass, has been sequenced and analyzed. The genome is small (59 Mb) and compact (40% protein coding), and encodes approximately 16,777 genes. Genes important to fatty acid synthesis, modification, and catabolism show distinct patterns of expression when monitored over a 24-hour light/dark cycle. The genome harbors the first hybrid polyketide synthase/non-ribosomal peptide synthase gene complex reported for an algal species, and encodes potential anti-microbial peptides and proteins involved in multidrug and toxic compound extrusion. A new haptophyte xanthorhodopsin was also identified, together with two “red” RuBisCO activases that are shared across many algal lineages. The Chrysochromulina tobin genome sequence provides new information on the evolutionary history, ecology, and economic importance of haptophytes.
 In this study, we investigated the role of the Rb, p53, and Brca1 pathways in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) using mouse models. We found that the combined inactivation of Rb and p53 pathways is sufficient to suppress the physiological cell death of mammary involution. Furthermore, concomitant inactivation of all three pathways in mammary epithelium has an additive effect on tumor latency and predisposes highly penetrant, metastatic adenocarcinomas. The tumors are poorly differentiated and have histologic features that are common among human Brca1-mutated tumors, including heterogeneous morphology, metaplasia, and necrosis. Gene expression analyses demonstrate that the tumors share attributes of both Basal-like and Claudin-low signatures, two molecular subtypes encompassed by the broader, triple-negative class defined by clinical markers. Our findings illustrate the compounding effect of acquiring multiple tumor suppressor mutations during tumor evolution and underscore the distinct requirements of each of these canonical tumor suppressor proteins.
Dengue fever is a major public health problem in many tropical and subtropical regions of the world. The primary vector of dengue virus is the mosquito Aedes aegypti. The abundance of Ae. aegypti is influenced by various factors, including the availability of larval development sites. In this study, we examined the relationship between the abundance of Ae. aegypti pupae and the density of larval development sites. We used data from 84,840 water-holding containers surveyed in rural Kamphaeng Phet, Thailand, over a four-year period. Our results showed that the abundance of Ae. aegypti pupae was positively associated with the density of larval development sites. We also found that the relationship between pupal abundance and larval density varied by container type. Our findings suggest that targeting the most productive containers could be an effective strategy for reducing the abundance of Ae. aegypti.
 In this study, we investigated the role of the Target of Rapamycin complex 2 (TORC2) in regulating developmental and behavioral responses to environmental cues in the bacterivorous nematode Caenorhabditis elegans . We found that TORC2 acts in the intestine to regulate neuronal expression of daf-7 and daf-28 genes, which are involved in food-dependent dauer formation and adult foraging behavior. Our results suggest that TORC2 plays a critical role in conveying internal nutrient state information to the nervous system, allowing animals to modulate both developmental and behavioral responses to environmental cues as a function of their metabolic state.
 Pluripotent stem cells are a remarkable model for the study of early development and hold promise as a source for cell replacement therapies. To successfully manipulate pluripotent stem cells in culture, it is important to understand the mechanisms by which they maintain their self-renewal and pluripotency. In this study, we used a combination of gene expression profiling, computational genomic analyses, and biochemical assays to systematically identify novel cis-regulatory sequences that control gene expression in pluripotent stem cells. We identified clusters of genes upregulated in ES cells and PGCs, which include several known markers of pluripotency. We developed a novel algorithm, CompMoby, which combines the strategies of comparative genomics with DNA sequence segmentation to identify sets of motifs in the upstream regions of coregulated genes. Using CompMoby, we identified motifs that are statistically overrepresented in genes upregulated in pluripotent cells and highly conserved across multiple mammalian species. We demonstrate that several of the predicted motifs are novel regulatory elements of gene expression in mouse and human ES cells. Finally, we show that the transcription factor NF-Y binds to one of the motifs, is differentially expressed during ES cell differentiation, and is required for ES cell proliferation. Our results suggest that this systematic approach can be broadly applied to understanding transcriptional networks in mammalian species.
 We have solved the crystal structure of a complex between a variant of vesicular stomatitis virus N lacking its 21 N-terminal residues ( NΔ21 ) and a peptide of 60 amino acids ( P60 ) encompassing the molecular recognition element ( MoRE ) of P that binds RNA-free N ( N0 ). The complex crystallized in a decameric circular form , which was solved at 3 . 0 Å resolution , reveals how the MoRE folds upon binding to N and competes with RNA binding and N polymerization . Small-angle X-ray scattering experiment and NMR spectroscopy on the soluble complex confirms the binding of the MoRE and indicates that its flanking regions remain flexible in the complex . The structure of this complex also suggests a mechanism for the initiation of viral RNA synthesis .
The gap junctions (GJs) in the fly visual system play a crucial role in encoding visual motion information. Our study shows that the presence of GJs enables the fly's visual system to efficiently encode the axis of rotation of the fly's ego motion. This encoding efficiency is near-optimal with respect to the physical limits of performance determined by the statistical structure of the visual input itself. The subpopulation of triplets of the vertical system cells, which are directly connected to downstream neurons, encodes motion more efficiently than the network as a whole. This efficient encoding of motion is behaviorally important, as the fly's survival depends on its ability to perform evasive maneuvers. Our study provides new insights into the functional role of GJs in sensory information processing and highlights the importance of considering specific network connectivity in understanding the computational principles implemented by neural circuitries.
 We have previously identified human P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1 ( PSGL-1 ) as a functional cellular receptor for EV71 infection in leukocytes . In this study, we investigated the role of post-translational modifications of PSGL-1 in the binding to EV71. We found that tyrosine sulfation of the N-terminal region of PSGL-1 facilitates PSGL-1–EV71 interaction and viral replication of EV71-PB in Jurkat T cells. To our knowledge, this is the second direct example of the involvement of tyrosine sulfation in specific virus-receptor interactions, a modification that mediates viral entry and replication in target cells.
Leishmaniasis is a serious global health problem that affects many people worldwide. The parasite is carried by the female phlebotomine sand fly and can infect a variety of mammalian species, including humans. Treatment with several agents is available, but drug toxicity and the emergence of resistant strains render available treatments ineffective in the long run. In this study, we tested the therapeutic efficacy of several mTOR inhibitors in controlling infection with Leishmania major. Rapamycin, GSK-2126458 and KU-0063794 were administered to BALB/c mice, which had received an intrafootpad injection of the parasite. Footpad swelling and parasite burden were assessed, and cytokine production by mouse splenocytes and phenotypic changes in draining lymph node cells were evaluated. Treatment with a clinically relevant dose of rapamycin or with GSK-2126458 dramatically lowered both the footpad swelling and the parasite load in the draining lymph node. Importantly, the employed dose of rapamycin did not kill the promastigotes in vitro as judged by 3- ( 4 , 5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl ) -2 , 5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide ( MTT ) assays and electron microscopy. Moreover, the IL-4 production capacity of splenocytes harvested from infected mice that were treated with rapamycin was significantly reduced. Consequently, the IFN-γ:IL-4 production ratio was elevated, suggesting a T helper-type 1 ( Th1 ) -skewed cytokine profile. Finally, the expression level of CD69 , an early activation marker, on splenic and lymph node CD4+ and CD8+ T cells was enhanced in rapamycin-treated mice. Taken together, our findings suggest that select mTOR inhibitors may be used in therapeutic settings for the management of leishmaniasis. We propose that the beneficial effects of such inhibitors stem from their immunomodulatory properties. Therefore, the adjuvanticity of mTOR inhibitors may also be considered in vaccination strategies against Leishmania species.
 Natural transformation is a process by which bacteria take up and incorporate foreign DNA into their genomes. This process is tightly controlled in many competent species, including Neisseria meningitidis, which preferentially takes up its own DNA. The protein ComP has been identified as the receptor for DNA uptake in Neisseria species. In this study, the authors show that ComP is essential for transformation in both the presence and absence of DUS, and that each base of the DUS sequence is important for efficient recognition by ComP. They also show that naturally occurring DUS variants in human Neisseria commensals are impaired for transformation of N. meningitidis. Finally, they show that a ComP homolog in one of these commensals can bind its cognate DUS and mediate DUS-enhanced transformation. These findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms of natural transformation in Neisseria species.
 Cytokinesis is the final stage of the eukaryotic cell cycle, when a mother cell separates into two daughter cells. In fungal cells, cytokinesis is mediated by a contractile actomyosin ring (CAR) that is conserved between fungal and animal cells. Fission yeast CAR is composed of many proteins besides F-actin and heavy and light chains of myosin II. Significant progress in identifying and characterizing the proteins that participate in CAR positioning, assembly, stabilization, and integrity has already been made. The septum of fission yeast is a three-layered polysaccharide structure made of a middle primary septum (PS) flanked by two secondary septa (SS), one on each side. Both the PS and SS are formed by essential β-glucans. The enzyme involved in their formation is the β (1,3) glucan synthase, composed of at least a regulatory and a catalytic subunit. Fission yeast contains four different catalytic subunits named Bgs1 to Bgs4. Bgs1 is responsible for the linear β (1,3) glucan necessary for PS formation; Bgs4 builds branched β (1,3) glucan, which is the most abundant polymer in the septum and cell wall. During cytokinesis, this polymer is required for connecting the CAR to the extracellular cell wall, for SS formation, for the correct PS structure, and to maintain the cell integrity during cell separation. A key protein for CAR positioning and function is the F-BAR domain-containing phosphoprotein Cdc15. Dephosphorylation of Cdc15 at mitotic entry induces a conformational switch in the protein that promotes oligomerization. Cdc15 also participates in endocytosis and it has recently been shown that it localizes to the Golgi where it helps in the delivery of Bgs1 to the plasma membrane during cytokinesis. Another F-BAR domain protein, Rga7, associates with Imp2 in a protein complex that coordinates the late stages of cytokinesis. Animal cell paxillin is a multi-domain scaffold protein that localizes to the intracellular surface of the plasma membrane in sites of cell adhesion to the extracellular matrix. Fission yeast Pxl1 is a component of the CAR that shares with other paxillins the Lin-11, Isl-1, Mec-3 (LIM) domains in its C-terminal half but presents a different N-terminal region, which is required for binding to the Cdc15 and Imp2 SH3 domains. Pxl1 also binds to the type II myosin Myo2 and is necessary for CAR integrity and proper constriction. In this work, the authors show that the functions of Pxl1 in the CAR and Bgs1 in the membrane are necessary for stable CAR anchorage. Additionally, cooperation between Pxl1 and Bgs1 is shown to be essential for CAR maintenance and septum formation, since cells without Bgs1 display CAR disassembly and cannot form septa when Pxl1 is absent or when the Pxl1 levels in the ring are reduced, as in the case of cells carrying the defective cdc15ΔSH3 allele.
 Glanders is a rare but serious disease caused by the bacterium Burkholderia mallei . It affects horses and camels and can be transmitted to humans. Glanders was recently reported in Bahrain, and the authors of this study used high-resolution genotyping and comparative whole genome sequencing to investigate the outbreak. They found that the samples from the outbreak in Bahrain separated into two distinct clusters, suggesting a complex epidemiological background and evidence for the involvement of multiple B . mallei strains. Additionally, the samples from Bahrain were more closely related to B . mallei isolated from horses in the United Arab Emirates in 2004 than other B . mallei, indicating repeated importation to the region from similar geographic sources. The close relationship of the Dubai/UAE B . mallei populations to each other may be indicative of a similar geographic origin that has yet to be identified for the infecting strains. The recent emergence of glanders in combination with worldwide horse trading might pose a new risk for human infections.
 Leishmaniasis is a complex disease caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania. It is a major public health problem in many tropical and subtropical regions of the world, with about 67,000 new cases reported each year. The severity of the disease depends on the parasite species, but species confirmation is not feasible in most cases. The World Health Organization recommends pentavalent antimonial derivatives (Glucantime or Sodium Stibogluconate) as first-line treatment for American cutaneous leishmaniasis (ACL) caused by Leishmania braziliensis. However, the cure rate of this treatment is about 75%, and the reasons for treatment failure are not well known. In this study, we characterized the clinical and parasitological features of patients with ACL that did not respond to Glucantime. We found that the main parasite species associated with lesions of patients that underwent treatment failure or relapse was L. braziliensis. We also found that parasites isolated from patients that underwent treatment failure showed a significant decrease in in vitro Glucantime susceptibility associated with previous administration of the medicament. Our results suggest that the indication of a second round of treatment in therapeutic failure of ACL caused by L. braziliensis with pentavalent antimonial derivatives is discussable.
 We report here the nearly complete genomic sequence of 20 different individuals , determined using “next-generation” sequencing technologies . We use these data to characterize the type of genetic variation carried by humans in a sample of this size , which is to our knowledge the largest set of unrelated genomic sequences that have been reported . We summarize different categories of variation in each genome , and in total across all 20 of the genomes , finding a surprising number of variants predicted to reduce or remove the proteins encoded by many different genes . This work provides important fundamental information about the scope of human genetic variation , and suggests ways to further explore the relationship between these genetic variants and human disease .
 The study presents a new approach to calculating the probability of a multiple sequence alignment given a phylogenetic tree and an evolutionary model that accounts for insertions and deletions in addition to substitutions. The approach is based on a non-reversible generative model of insertions and deletions, which is incorporated into an existing phylogenetic inference application. The study shows that the new approach improves accuracy relative to the usual approach of ignoring gaps, while retaining the computational efficiency of the Felsenstein peeling algorithm. The study uses standard benchmarking methods on simulated data and a new “concordance test” benchmark on real ribosomal RNA alignments to demonstrate the effectiveness of the new approach. The study concludes that the new approach is a valuable tool for phylogenetic inference and sequence analysis.
 Herpes simplex virus ( HSV ) is a common human pathogen that causes recurrent infections of the skin and mucous membranes. The initial infection is usually asymptomatic, but subsequent infections can cause painful blisters and lesions. The immune response to HSV is complex and involves both innate and adaptive immune cells. Dendritic cells ( DCs ) are key players in the immune response to HSV, as they are responsible for presenting HSV antigens to T cells. In this study, the authors used human skin explants and biopsies to investigate the interactions between HSV-infected Langerhans cells ( LCs ) and dermal DCs. They found that LCs containing HSV or HSV antigen interacted with BDCA3+ dermal DCs, which are equivalent to murine CD103+ dermal DCs. These interactions occurred in clusters of cells in the dermis and may play a key role in the immune response to HSV. The authors also found that LCs containing HSV or HSV antigen were taken up by BDCA3+ dermal DCs in vitro. These findings provide important insights into the immune response to HSV and may lead to new strategies for treating and preventing HSV infections.
 Leishmania spp. are intracellular parasites that infect macrophages and cause a variety of diseases in humans and animals. The parasites reside in a specialized organelle called the parasitophorous vacuole (PV), which is derived from the host cell's endolysosomal system. The PVs of Leishmania spp. are unique in that they can fuse with each other, allowing the parasites to grow and divide within the same vacuole. In this study, we used multidimensional imaging to study the biogenesis of Leishmania PVs in live macrophages. We found that the PVs of Leishmania major are small and tight-fitting, while the PVs of Leishmania amazonensis are large and loose. We also found that the PVs of Leishmania major undergo fission, while the PVs of Leishmania amazonensis undergo fusion. These findings provide new insights into the biogenesis and dynamics of Leishmania PVs, which may be useful for understanding the pathogenesis of Leishmania diseases.
 The study investigates the role of chromatin structure in regulating homology-directed repair (HDR) in chicken B cells. The authors found that the immunoglobulin Vλ pseudogene array is characterized by histone modifications associated with active chromatin. They also demonstrated that tethering the heterochromatin protein HP1 to the pseudo-Vλ donor array diminished histone acetylation within the pseudo-Vλ array and altered the outcome of Vλ diversification, so that nontemplated mutations rather than templated mutations predominated. These results suggest that chromatin structure regulates HDR and may contribute to maintaining genomic stability by preventing recombination between repetitive sequences.
The cerebellum is responsible for coordinating our movements and adapting to new situations. It is commonly thought that the cerebellum uses error information to guide motor learning, but a recent study on monkeys has challenged this idea. The study found that climbing fibers, which are thought to only transport information on instant errors, actually have a complex spike signature that lasts much longer than the error itself. This suggests that the climbing fiber system may play a more complex role in motor learning than previously thought.
 Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease characterized by the selective loss of motor neurons. The most common pathologic characteristic of ALS is the formation of cytoplasmic inclusions rich in the RNA/DNA binding protein TDP-43. Using a yeast model of ALS exhibiting TDP-43 dependent toxicity, we now show that TDP-43 overexpression dramatically alters cell shape and reduces ubiquitin dependent proteolysis of a reporter construct. Furthermore, we show that an excess of the Hsp40 chaperone, Sis1, reduced TDP-43’s effect on toxicity, cell shape and proteolysis. The strength of these effects was influenced by the presence of the endogenous yeast prion, [PIN+]. Although overexpression of Sis1 altered the TDP-43 aggregation pattern, we did not detect physical association of Sis1 with TDP-43, suggesting the possibility of indirect effects on TDP-43 aggregation. Furthermore, overexpression of the mammalian Sis1 homologue, DNAJB1, relieves TDP-43 mediated toxicity in primary rodent cortical neurons, suggesting that Sis1 and its homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS.
 Chagas disease is a major public health issue in many Latin American countries. The parasite Trypanosoma cruzi has six discrete typing units (DTUs), which are associated with different clinical manifestations of the disease. In this study, we used a multilocus conventional PCR and quantitative real time PCR (qPCR) approaches to perform the molecular typing and parasite load quantification directly from blood specimens of 65 chronic Chagas disease patients. We found that 35 patients presented positive amplification by real time qPCR, with 20 patients with the clinical indeterminate form and 15 patients with the cardiac form of the disease. The parasite load was significantly higher in patients over 70 years old. We were able to genotype the T. cruzi DTU in 28 patients (80%). Our results contribute to update the epidemiological knowledge of T. cruzi DTUs in Brazil and highlight the age of patient and infection by TcII as important features that lead to the observation of higher parasitemia levels.
Rabies is a deadly disease caused by a virus that affects humans and animals. It is most commonly transmitted by bites from infected animals, such as dogs and bats. In Guatemala, rabies is considered enzootic in bats, but little is known about the prevalence of rabies in different bat species. To address this knowledge gap, we conducted enhanced bat rabies surveillance in Guatemala between 2009 and 2011. We collected samples from 672 bats of 31 species and tested them for rabies virus (RABV) detection. We found that the prevalence of RABV detection among all collected bats was low (0.3%). However, we did detect RABV in the brains of two common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus). We also found RABV in oral swabs, lungs, and kidneys of both bats, and in all tissues except the liver of one bat. Sequencing of the nucleoprotein gene showed that both viruses were 100% identical, while sequencing of the glycoprotein gene revealed one non-synonymous substitution (302T, S). The two vampire bat RABV isolates in this study were phylogenetically related to viruses associated with vampire bats in the eastern states of Mexico and El Salvador. Additionally, we found that 7% of sera collected from 398 bats demonstrated RABV neutralizing antibody. Our results suggest that rabies is not widespread in Guatemalan bats, but that vampire bats may be a significant reservoir of rabies virus.
 The nuclear lamina is a protein structure that surrounds the nucleus of eukaryotic cells and plays a role in organizing the chromatin. In this study, the authors found that the nuclear lamina is important for the regulation of gene expression during herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. They found that the HSV genome is associated with increased heterochromatin in cells lacking the nuclear lamina protein lamin A/C. This suggests that the nuclear lamina may play a role in regulating the chromatin structure during HSV infection. The authors also found that the nuclear lamina is important for the targeting of the HSV genome to the nuclear periphery, which is thought to be important for the regulation of gene expression. Overall, this study provides new insights into the role of the nuclear lamina in regulating gene expression during HSV infection.
Mitochondria are organelles that produce energy for cells. They originated from proteobacteria and have a protein import system that is common to all forms of mitochondria. However, the protein import system in anaerobic mitochondria, such as hydrogenosomes, is not well understood. In this study, we analyzed the protein import system in hydrogenosomes of the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. We found that the hydrogenosomal protein import system, named TvTOM, is a highly divergent translocase that forms a triplet-pore complex. We also identified two receptors that are responsible for substrate binding. Our results suggest that the triplet-pore TOM complex was present in the last common eukaryotic ancestor and that receptors evolved independently in different eukaryotic lineages.
313 healthy individuals were studied to identify genetic variants affecting the expression of genes involved in immune response in CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. The analysis revealed that genetic control of gene expression in T cells is extensive and cell type-specific. Disease-associated variants were found to affect the expression of genes involved in immune response. A common missense variant in IL27 was identified, which affects the STAT1 and IRF1 pathway in CD4+ T cells. The study provides insights into the basic processes of gene expression regulation in T cells and advances our understanding of the pathways involved with disease susceptibility in the adaptive immune system.
 The Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has been struggling to eliminate Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) despite decades of efforts. Socio-cultural and economic factors are major barriers to HAT screening and treatment in the DRC. In this study, we conducted qualitative research in two provinces lagging behind in HAT elimination to better understand and address these barriers. We found that strong prohibitions associated with HAT treatment regimens are well-known by the community and lead some people to avoid HAT screening campaigns. These prohibitions were originally aimed at mitigating the severe adverse effects of the melarsoprol regimen but became obsolete with the new safer drugs. Correct health information regarding HAT treatment is essential, and health providers should address the perspective of the community in a constant dialogue to keep abreast of unintended transformations of meaning. Our findings can help improve the coverage of ongoing HAT screening and treatment activities in the DRC.
 The study aimed to estimate the incidence of visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in eastern Gedaref State, Sudan, where the disease is endemic. The study conducted a door-to-door survey in 45 villages and found that the incidence of VL was 7.9 cases per 1000 people per year. The study also found that the medical teams examined 551 individuals referred for a history of fever, and out of these, 16 were diagnosed with primary VL. The study concluded that VL represents a significant health burden in eastern Gedaref State, and active VL case detection had a very low yield in this specific setting with adequate access to care. The study recommends that other interventions, such as indoor residual spraying and bednet use, should be evaluated to control the disease.
The authors have developed a new method to measure the supercoiling of bacterial DNA in vivo. They used a "supercoil sensor" that contains a complete Lac operon flanked by directly repeated resolvase binding sites. By measuring the recombination efficiency of the sensor, they were able to determine the supercoiling density of the chromosome at different locations. They found that supercoiling density varies throughout the chromosome and that transcription plays a role in determining the supercoiling density. They also found that mutations in gyrase and topoisomerase IV cause significant changes in supercoiling density.
 Leishmania is a parasite that causes a range of diseases in humans and animals. It replicates within parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) that share many features with late endosomes/lysosomes. The size of these vacuoles varies depending on the species of Leishmania, with L. amazonensis causing large PVs that expand during infection. In this study, the authors found that the gene LYST/Beige, which regulates lysosome size, is upregulated during L. amazonensis infections. Mutations in this gene caused further PV expansion and enhanced parasite replication, while overexpression of LYST/Beige led to small PVs that did not sustain parasite growth. Treatment of cells with vacuolin-1, which expands PVs, reversed the phenotype of LYST/Beige over-expressing cells, expanding PVs and promoting parasite growth. In contrast, treatment with E-64d, which reduces PV size, inhibited L. amazonensis replication. Enlarged PVs appear to protect parasites from oxidative damage, since inhibition of nitric oxide synthase had no effect on L. amazonensis viability within large PVs, but enhanced their growth within LYST/Beige-induced small PVs. The authors conclude that the upregulation of LYST/Beige in infected cells functions as a host innate response to limit parasite growth, by reducing PV volume and inhibiting intracellular survival.
 The Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome ( AHDS ) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by severe intellectual disability, delayed development, and motor impairment. The disorder is caused by mutations in the monocarboxylate transporter 8 ( MCT8 ) gene, which encodes a protein that transports thyroid hormones across cell membranes. In order to better understand the mechanisms of AHDS, researchers have generated a zebrafish model of the disorder using the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing system. The zebrafish model exhibits similar neurological and behavioral deficiencies to those seen in human patients with AHDS, including reduced locomotor activity, altered response to light and dark transitions, and increased sleep time. These deficiencies are associated with altered expression of myelin-related genes and circuit-specific deficiencies in axon branching and synaptic density. The researchers also found that TH analogs can restore a portion of the neurological phenotypes in the zebrafish model. These findings suggest a potential mechanism for the disorder and a potential treatment option.
 We have shown that HCMV gB and gH/gL form a stable complex early after their synthesis and in the absence of other viral proteins. gB and gH/gL interact with each other regardless of whether they are able to mediate membrane fusion. gB-gH/gL complexes are incorporated into HCMV virions without receptor binding or membrane fusion. These data suggest a different model for how HCMV gB and gH/gL molecules interact and function compared with models for HSV-1 entry. Our data support the hypothesis that stable, preformed HCMV gB-gH/gL complexes are present in the virion envelope and that gB-gH/gL complexes might initiate membrane fusion between the virion envelope and cellular membranes.
 Mitochondrial DNA ( mtDNA ) is a maternally inherited high copy genome that is important for energy production in cells. Mutations in mtDNA can lead to a wide range of clinical disorders, and the segregation of these mutations in cells is influenced by a variety of factors. In this study, the authors used a heteroplasmic mouse model to investigate the mechanisms of mtDNA segregation in leukocytes. They found that Gimap3, an outer mitochondrial membrane GTPase, is a critical regulator of this process. Gimap3 is important for T cell development and survival, suggesting that leukocyte survival may be a key factor in the genetic regulation of mtDNA sequence variants and in modulating human mitochondrial diseases. The authors' findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of mtDNA segregation and may help to better understand the genetic regulation of mitochondrial diseases.
 Buruli ulcer ( BU ) is a rare bacterial infection that causes skin ulcers and can lead to severe disfigurement and disability. It is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans and is most common in tropical and subtropical regions of Africa, but has also been reported in other parts of the world. In Victoria, Australia, a sustained outbreak of BU occurred on the Bellarina peninsula between 2002 and 2012, with a mean incubation period of 4.5 months. Since then, a new endemic area has developed on the Mornington peninsula, and a retrospective review of 443 cases of BU notified in Victoria between 2013 and 2016 found that the mean incubation period for short-term visitors to endemic regions was 143 days ( 4.8 months ). This study provides valuable information for clinicians and public health officials to better understand the transmission of BU and to develop effective prevention strategies.

 Ophthalmo-acromelic syndrome (OAS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by eye malformations, most commonly bilateral anophthalmia, and post-axial oligosyndactyly. We have identified a locus for OAS on 14q24.2 and subsequently identified homozygous, predicted loss-of-function mutations in the SMOC1 gene in eight out of fourteen unrelated families with OAS. Whole mount in situ hybridization combined with optical projection tomography shows site- and stage-specific developmental expression of the orthologous mouse gene, Smoc1, in embryonic limb bud and craniofacial structures. The phenotype associated with homozygosity for a targeted “pre-conditional” gene-trap mouse mutation of Smoc1 also shows significant overlap with the human disease. We discuss the potential role for SMOC-1 in modulating BMP signaling during eye and limb development.
 The interferon system is a well-studied branch of the innate immune system that acts against viruses. Infection of vertebrate cells by many viruses provokes synthesis and secretion of interferons ( IFNs ) , which mediate induction of a cellular antiviral state that obstructs further viral spread. Type I IFNs ( α and β ) are produced by many cell types , while Type II IFN ( gamma ) is produced by immune cells . IFN-induced signaling pathways begin with IFN binding to IFN receptors at the cell surface . This results in signal transduction via the Jak/Stat pathway , which leads to activation of interferon-responsive genes and synthesis of effector proteins , including PKR , RNAseL , Mx , and many others ( reviewed in [1] , [2] , [3] , [4] ) . For HIV , previous studies have implicated IFNs in blocking both early and late stages of the HIV-1 lifecycle [5] , [6] , [7] , [8] , [9] , [10] . In many cell types , the inhibition of later steps in the life cycle following integration seems to be most potent ( reviewed in [2] ) . Although the effector mechanisms acting late have not been fully clarified , one report suggested that the IFN-inducible protein ISG15 interfered with the endosomal trafficking pathway used by HIV-1 to exit 293T cells by blocking the interaction of TSG101 with HIV-1 Gag [11] . Many tripartite motif ( TRIM ) proteins may function in innate immunity to restrict viral replication . TRIM5α from rhesus macaque ( RhTRIM5α ) blocks early replication steps of HIV-1 and other retroviruses ( reviewed in [12] ) ; in addition , one group has proposed that RhTRIM5α acts late during HIV replication as well [13] . The early target of RhTRIM5α is the capsid ( CA ) protein , which forms the protein shell of the viral core . Anti-HIV-1 activity has also been reported for other TRIM family members . TRIM1 has been shown to target the CA protein at an early stage pre-reverse transcription , TRIM22 has been suggested to affect HIV transcription and TRIM19 and TRIM32 have been suggested to affect trafficking of viral proteins ( reviewed in [14] ) . Recently , TRIM28 was shown to repress transcription from a retroviral promoter by binding to proviral DNA [15] . TRIM proteins contain a highly conserved RBCC motif comprised of a RING domain , one or two B-box domains , and a predicted coiled-coil region ( reviewed in [14] ) . The RING domain contains a specialized zinc finger [16] and has been shown to possess E3 ubiquitin ligase activity [17] , [18] , [19] , [20] , [21] , [22] . Little is known about the B-box domain , which is unique to TRIM proteins . The coiled-coil domain is believed to promote protein oligomerization [23] . Several TRIM proteins also contain a C-terminal SPRY domain that is proposed to be involved in protein-protein interactions and RNA binding [24] , [25] . Many TRIM family members are inducible by IFNs , providing candidate mediators of IFN inhibition . In an effort to identify TRIM proteins mediating anti-retroviral activity , we carried out transcriptional profiling of IFN-treated human osteosarcoma ( HOS ) cells and found that TRIM22 was the most up-regulated TRIM queried on the microarray used . HOS-CD4/CXCR4 cells were studied because they support robust HIV replication and show a strong antiviral response to IFNβ . Human TRIM22 ( also known as Staf-50 ) was previously identified from a search for IFN-regulated genes in Daudi cells . Over-expression of TRIM22 was reported to repress transcription from the HIV-1 LTR in a plasmid reporter system in COS-1 cells [26] . In a later study by another group , over-expression of TRIM22 was reported to inhibit HIV-1 replication in human macrophages and 293T cells and postulated
 We have shown that parasitic fig wasps may play a role in the maintenance of the mutualism between fig trees and their pollinator wasps. We found that parasitic wasps are more likely to parasitize pollinator offspring in the outer layers of ovules, which increases the fitness value of inner ovules to foundress pollinators. This means that parasitic wasps may be one of the selection pressures that have resulted in foundresses favoring inner ovules. Our findings suggest that parasitic fig wasps may make a contribution to the maintenance of the fig-pollinator mutualism.
 Plant height is a complex trait influenced by genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we used a Setaria recombinant inbred line population to assess the genetic architecture of plant height in response to different developmental queues, water availability, and planting density. We found that plant height is reduced under water limitation and high density planting and affected by growth environment. The results support a model where plant height is a heritable, polygenic trait and that the major genetic loci that influence plant height function independent of growth environment. The identity and contribution of loci that influence height change dynamically throughout development. The reduction of growth observed in water limited environments is a consequence of delayed progression through the genetic program that establishes plant height in Setaria. Alleles inherited from the weedy S . viridis parent act to increase plant height early, whereas a larger number of small effect alleles inherited from the domesticated S . italica parent collectively act to increase plant height later in development. This study provides a better understanding of the genetic architecture of plant height and its response to environmental factors.
 The wetlands of the Brazilian Pantanal are home to a diverse range of wildlife and mosquitoes, which makes them ideal for the transmission of zoonotic arboviruses. A recent study found evidence of various flaviviruses in horses in the Nhecolândia sub-region of Pantanal, including ILHV. To further investigate the circulation of ILHV in the region, we collected and tested adult mosquitoes for infectious virus and for flavivirus RNA detection. We found one pool of Aedes scapularis mosquitoes positive for ILHV by culture and real-time RT-PCR, indicating a minimum infection rate of 2.5 per 1000. Our findings confirm the circulation of ILHV in the Nhecolândia sub-region of Pantanal and highlight the importance of continued surveillance for arboviruses in this region.
Scabies is a common skin infection caused by the Sarcoptes scabiei mite. It is a major public health burden, particularly in developing countries. Current treatments with topical agents and/or oral ivermectin are insufficient and drug resistance is emerging. Moxidectin (MOX), with more advantageous pharmacological profiles, may be a promising alternative. Using a porcine scabies model, 12 pigs were randomly assigned to receive orally either MOX (0.3 mg/kg once) or IVM (0.2 mg/kg twice) or no treatment. We evaluated treatment efficacies by assessing mite count, clinical lesions, pruritus, and ELISA-determined anti-S. scabiei IgG antibodies reductions. Plasma and skin pharmacokinetic profiles were determined. At day 14 post-treatment, all four MOX-treated but only two IVM-treated pigs were mite-free. MOX efficacy was 100% and remained unchanged until study-end (D47) compared to 62% (range 26–100%) for IVM, with one IVM-treated pig remaining infected until D47. Clinical scabies lesions, pruritus, and anti-S. scabiei IgG antibodies had completely disappeared in all MOX-treated but only 75% of IVM-treated pigs. MOX persisted ~9 times longer than IVM in plasma and skin, thereby covering the mite’s entire life cycle and enabling long-lasting efficacy. Our data demonstrate that oral single-dose MOX was more effective than two consecutive IVM-doses, supporting MOX as a potential therapeutic approach for scabies.
β-lactam antibiotics target the final stages of peptidoglycan (PG) synthesis in bacteria, making them one of the most effective classes of antibiotics. However, the large number of proteins involved in PG synthesis makes it difficult to determine the specific role of each protein. Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive bacterial pathogen that has a minimal number of proteins involved in PG synthesis, making it a good model for studying this process. In this study, the authors constructed a S. aureus strain that encodes only two essential proteins involved in PG synthesis, PBP1 and PBP2. They found that this strain was capable of PG synthesis, but was highly susceptible to cell wall-targeting antibiotics and had decreased virulence in a Drosophila infection model. These results highlight the important roles of non-essential proteins in PG synthesis in natural environments, such as a host.
 Burkholderia pseudomallei is a bacterium that can cause a difficult-to-manage disease called melioidosis. Even with proper diagnosis and prompt treatment, the fatality rate for melioidosis patients can range from 10-40%. Surprisingly little is known about how B. pseudomallei infects, invades, and survives within its hosts, and virtually nothing is known about the contribution of critical nutrients such as iron to the bacterium's pathogenesis. In this study, we deleted the major siderophore malleobactin and pyochelin gene clusters in strain 1710b and revealed a residual siderophore activity that was unrelated to other known Burkholderia siderophores such as cepabactin and cepaciachelin, and not due to increased secretion of chelators such as citrate. Deletion of the two hemin uptake loci, hmu and hem, showed that Hmu is required for utilization of hemin and hemoglobin and that Hem cannot complement a Hmu deficiency. Prolonged incubation of a hmu hem mutant in hemoglobin-containing minimal medium yielded variants able to utilize hemoglobin and hemin. Lactoferrin utilization was dependent on malleobactin, but not pyochelin synthesis and/or uptake. A mba pch hmu hem quadruple mutant could use ferritin as an iron source and upon intranasal infection was lethal in an acute murine melioidosis model. These data suggest that B. pseudomallei may employ a novel ferritin-iron acquisition pathway as a means to sustain in vivo growth.
 Metabolic models are used to understand and predict cellular function. However, these models are often inconsistent and incomplete, making it difficult to use them for analysis. COMMGEN is a tool that automatically identifies and resolves inconsistencies between metabolic models, allowing for more accurate and comprehensive representations of metabolism. We tested COMMGEN on four organisms and found that the resulting consensus models were more coherent and predictive than the original models. COMMGEN is particularly useful for complex scenarios where manual curation is not feasible, such as eukaryotic organisms, microbial communities, and host-pathogen interactions.
 The human genome contains approximately 20,000 protein-coding genes, but scientists estimate that there are many more non-coding genes that do not encode proteins. These non-coding genes are thought to regulate the expression of protein-coding genes and play important roles in many biological processes. The ENCODE Project is a large-scale effort to identify and characterize these non-coding genes and their functions.
