The project has identified thousands of non-coding genes that are important for regulating gene expression and have potential roles in disease. The ENCODE Project has also developed new technologies and methods for studying non-coding genes, which will be useful for future research.
 In this study, we investigated the role of Topoisomerase II (Top2) in the resolution of heterochromatic DNA entanglements during meiosis I in Drosophila melanogaster females. We found that knockdown of Top2 by RNAi in the later stages of meiosis resulted in a specific defect in the separation of heterochromatic regions after spindle assembly. In Top2 RNAi-expressing oocytes, heterochromatic regions often failed to separate during prometaphase I and metaphase I. Additionally, we observed defects in biorientation and the inability of achiasmate chromosomes to move towards the spindle poles during prometaphase I. These data suggest that Topoisomerase II is involved in the resolution of heterochromatic DNA entanglements during meiosis I and that these entanglements must be resolved in order to complete meiosis.
Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is a serious zoonotic disease that affects humans and dogs. It is caused by the protozoan Leishmania infantum and transmitted by the bite of sand flies. The disease is endemic in many parts of the world, including Brazil. Current control measures for VL include early diagnosis and treatment of human cases, reduction of sand fly populations, serological surveys of dogs, and euthanasia of seropositive dogs. However, these measures have limitations and do not prevent the spread of the disease. In this study, we evaluated the effectiveness of community-wide use of deltamethrin-impregnated collars in dogs as a public health measure to control and prevent canine visceral leishmaniasis ( CVL ). We implemented an interventional study in two endemic areas in the district of Monte Gordo ( Bahia-Brazil ) : an intervention area, in which VL seronegative dogs were collared, and a control area in which only conventional CVL control measures were applied. We found that the use of deltamethrin-impregnated collars significantly reduced the seroprevalence of CVL in the intervention area, while the seroprevalence in the control area increased. Our results suggest that the use of deltamethrin-impregnated collars is an effective strategy for the control of CVL in endemic areas.
 X chromosomes are unusual in many ways, including their non-random gene content. We propose a new model to explain this bias: the "weak X" or "traffic jam" model. This model suggests that the X chromosome is not a tolerable environment for genes with very high maximal levels of expression, owing to transcriptional traffic jams. We test this model using data from The Encyclopedia of DNA Elements (ENCODE) and the Functional Annotation of the Mammalian Genome (FANTOM5) project. Our results show that the maximal expression of human X-linked genes is much lower than that of genes on autosomes, and that autosome-to-X retroposition events are associated with lower maximal expression of retrogenes on the X than seen for X-to-autosome retrogenes on autosomes. We also find that highly expressed tissue-specific genes are rare on the X and that broadly expressed genes on the X tend to be lowly expressed. These trends cannot be fully accounted for in terms of alternative models of biased expression. In conclusion, the notion that it is hard for genes on the Therian X to be highly expressed, owing to transcriptional traffic jams, provides a simple yet robustly supported rationale of many peculiar features of X’s gene content, gene expression, and evolution.
 Helicobacter pylori is a bacterium that lives in the stomach and is associated with gastric diseases. It is thought to have originated in Africa and has evolved into different populations over time. The authors investigated the prevalence and population structure of H . pylori in Baka Pygmies in Cameroon, a subgroup of Western Pygmies. They found that the prevalence of H . pylori infection in Baka Pygmies was much lower than in their agriculturalist neighbors. The authors also found that the H . pylori population in Baka Pygmies did not define a new population and that the Baka acquired their H . pylori infections from their agriculturalist neighbors. The authors suggest that the low prevalence of H . pylori infection in Baka Pygmies may be due to their small population size and other demographic factors.
 Dengue virus (DENV) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes dengue fever and dengue hemorrhagic fever. The DENV genome is a single-stranded RNA molecule that encodes for 11 proteins. One of these proteins, NS5, is the most highly conserved among the viral non-structural proteins and is responsible for capping, methylation, and replication of the flavivirus RNA genome. DENV2 NS5 localizes to the nucleus during infection, but the role of this localization is not clear. In this study, the authors used a combination of functional and structural analyses to determine the role of NS5 localization in DENV replication and pathogenesis. They found that the C-terminal 18 residues of NS5 are responsible for its nuclear localization and that mutations to this region affect its ability to replicate the viral RNA. The authors also found that the C-terminal region of NS5 plays an evolutionarily conserved role in RNA interactions that are critical for replication. Their findings suggest that the nuclear localization of NS5 may be important for DENV replication and pathogenesis.
 Neglected tropical diseases ( NTDs ) are a group of parasitic and bacterial infections that affect over 2 billion people worldwide. These diseases are often found in areas with poor sanitation and limited access to healthcare. The World Health Organization ( WHO ) has set targets for the control and elimination of several NTDs, but many countries lack the necessary data to plan and implement effective control programs. To address this issue, we developed an integrated mapping protocol ( Integrated Threshold Mapping ( ITM ) Methodology ) for lymphatic filariasis ( LF ), trachoma, schistosomiasis, and soil-transmitted helminths ( STH ). The ITM methodology is designed to be resource-efficient and aims to determine whether a threshold to trigger public health interventions has been reached in an implementation unit. The protocol relies on WHO-recommended indicators in disease-specific age groups and uses the district as the sampling frame for LF, trachoma, and STH, while the sub-district is used for schistosomiasis. We tested the ITM methodology in one district each in Mali and Senegal by comparing it to the standard WHO methodologies for each of the targeted diseases. Our results showed that the ITM methodology reached the same conclusions as the WHO methodologies regarding the initiation of public health interventions for trachoma, LF, and STH, but resulted in more targeted intervention recommendations for schistosomiasis. The ITM methodology was practical, feasible, and demonstrated an overall cost saving compared with the standard, non-integrated, WHO methodologies. This integrated mapping tool could facilitate the implementation of much-needed programs in endemic countries.
 In yeast, the protein Cdc14 is required for the exit from mitosis. It is anchored on nucleolar chromatin by the protein Cfi1/Net1 until early anaphase, when it is released into the nucleoplasm. Two redundant pathways promote Cdc14 release: the FEAR ( Cdc fourteen early release ) network and the MEN ( mitotic exit network ). Through genetic interactions, we report here a novel requirement for the ubiquitination of histone H2B by the Bre1 ubiquitin ligase in the cell cycle–dependent release of Cdc14 from nucleolar chromatin when the MEN is inactivated. This function for H2B ubiquitination is mediated by its activation of histone H3 methylation on lysines 4 and 79 ( meH3K4 and meH3K79 ) but, surprisingly, is not dependent on the histone deacetylase Sir2, which associates with Cdc14 on nucleolar chromatin as part of the RENT complex. We also observed a defect in Cdc14 release in cells lacking H3 lysine 36 methylation ( meH3K36 ) and in cells lacking an HDAC recruited by this modification. These histone modifications represent previously unappreciated factors required for the accessibility to and/or action on nucleolar chromatin of FEAR network components. The nonredundant role for these modifications in this context contrasts with the notion of a highly combinatorial code by which histone marks act to control biological processes.
 Gene expression programs are sets of co-expressed genes that orchestrate normal or pathological processes. The identification of these programs is a major challenge in computational biology, especially when using human expression data. We developed a new unsupervised computational framework, GeneProgram, that simultaneously organizes tissues into groups and genes into overlapping programs with consistent temporal behavior. Using synthetic and real gene expression data, we showed that GeneProgram outperformed several popular expression analysis methods. We applied GeneProgram to a compendium of 62 short time-series gene expression datasets exploring the responses of human cells to infectious agents or immune-modulating molecules. We discovered a set of biologically interpretable expression programs and characterized their functional breadth. These programs implicated surprising signaling pathways or receptor types in the response to infection. Our method is multipurpose and can be applied readily to novel compendia of biological data.
 The study aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying the adaptive features observed in innate cells, specifically NK cells. The authors found that only NKG2Chi NK cells, which are found in HCMV seropositive individuals, underwent epigenetic remodeling of the IFNG locus, leading to enhanced IFN-γ production. This suggests that NKG2Chi NK cells may represent a subset of NK cells with memory-like properties. The study provides important insights into the regulation of adaptive features in innate cells.
 The bacterium Legionella pneumophila causes Legionnaires' disease, a severe pneumonia. The bacterium is able to infect and replicate within a wide variety of eukaryotic cells, including human cells. The bacterium uses a type IV secretion system to translocate effector proteins into host cells, where they manipulate host cellular processes to promote bacterial replication. One such effector protein, LubX, is a U-box-type E3 ubiquitin ligase that translocates into host cells and polyubiquitinates a host kinase, Clk1. However, the function of this polyubiquitination is unknown. Interestingly, the expression and translocation of LubX is induced upon infection and the levels of LubX within host cells come to maximum at later stages of infection, compared to other L. pneumophila effectors. The gene encoding LubX is in close proximity to genes that encode several other type IV effectors, including VipD and SidH. Surprisingly, analyses of these effector proteins led to the identification of SidH as a target of LubX. LubX acts as a negative temporal regulator of SidH within host cells. This is the first example of a bacterial effector that targets and regulates a cognate effector within the host cells. The designation "metaeffector" is proposed for this class of bacterial effectors.
 HIV-1 is a highly variable virus that rapidly evolves in response to host immune responses. In this study, we analyzed the diversification of HIV-1 env coding sequences in 81 very early B subtype infections. We found evidence of adaptive evolution of HIV-1 and identified a subset of codon sites that diversified more rapidly than can be explained by a model of neutral evolution. These rapidly diversifying sites were either clustered and embedded in CTL epitopes or in a nucleotide context indicative of APOBEC-mediated G-to-A substitutions. We also examined the distribution, extent, and sequence context of insertions and deletions and provide evidence that the length variation seen in hypervariable loop regions of the envelope glycoprotein is a consequence of selection and not of mutational hotspots. Our results provide a detailed view of the process of diversification of HIV-1 following transmission and highlight the role of CTL escape and hypermutation in shaping viral evolution during the establishment of new infections.
 We introduce and analyze a minimal model of epigenetic silencing in budding yeast, built upon known biomolecular interactions in the system. Doing so, we identify the epigenetic marks essential for the bistability of epigenetic states. The model explicitly incorporates two key chromatin marks, H4K16 acetylation and H3K79 methylation, and explores whether the presence of multiple marks lead to a qualitatively different systems behavior. We find that having both modifications is important for the robustness of epigenetic silencing. Besides the silenced and transcriptionally active fate of chromatin, our model leads to a novel state with bivalent (i.e., both active and silencing) marks under certain perturbations (knock-out mutations, inhibition or enhancement of enzymatic activity). The design principles of the silencing system is systematically investigated and disparate experimental observations are assessed within a single theoretical framework. Specifically, we discuss the behavior of Sir protein recruitment, spreading and stability of silenced regions in commonly-studied mutants (e.g., sas2, dot1) illuminating the controversial role of Dot1 in the systems biology of yeast silencing.
 Severe acute malnutrition ( SAM ) is a major health problem in many developing countries, affecting millions of children. SAM can manifest as either oedematous or non-oedematous malnutrition, with oedematous malnutrition being the most severe form, also known as kwashiorkor. The pathogenesis of both types of malnutrition in children remains largely unknown, but recent studies have linked gut microbiota ( GM ) dysbiosis to oedematous malnutrition. In this study, we aimed to assess whether GM composition differs between Ugandan children suffering from either oedematous or non-oedematous malnutrition. We found that non-oedematous SAM children have lower GM diversity compared to oedematous SAM children, but no clear compositional differences were identified. Our results suggest that GM diversity may be a factor in the development of the two clinical phenotypes of SAM.
 Telomeres are the ends of chromosomes that protect them from degradation and fusion. Telomere length varies among individuals and is controlled by multiple loci. In a study of 112 wild-type Saccharomyces sensu stricto isolates, we found extensive telomere length variation in S. paradoxus isolates. This variation correlated with their geographic origin: European strains had extremely short telomeres, while American isolates had telomeres approximately three times as long. We used insertions of a URA3 gene near telomeres to accurately analyze individual telomere lengths and telomere position effect (TPE). Crossing the American and European strains resulted in F1 spores with a continuum of telomere lengths consistent with what would be predicted if many quantitative trait loci (QTLs) were involved in length maintenance. We detected transgressive segregation for both phenotypes. We validated by reciprocal hemizygosity that YKU80 and TLC1 are telomere-length QTLs in the two S. paradoxus subpopulations. Furthermore, we propose that sequence divergence within the Ku heterodimer generates negative epistasis within one of the allelic combinations, resulting in very short telomeres. Our study provides insights into the genetic mechanisms underlying telomere length variation in S. paradoxus.
 We have developed a new sequential sampling model ( SSM ) that accounts for the possibility of a decision not to decide. This is important because people often delay their decisions until they have more information, and this can affect the timing of their responses. We tested our model using data from two studies that involved participants making decisions about buying or rejecting stocks based on sequential information. We found that our model accurately predicted the timing of participants' responses, and that it was able to account for the fact that participants often delayed their decisions. We also used time-frequency analysis of EEG data to show that the decision not to decide was associated with an increase in oscillatory power in the beta band, which is a well-established neural marker of the active inhibition of motor responses. Finally, we tested our model experimentally in an adapted version of our task, and found that it accurately predicted the timing of participants' responses. Overall, our results show how computational modeling of decisions and response times can provide a deeper understanding of the hidden dynamics in cognition.
 Hereditary nasal parakeratosis ( HNPK ) is a skin disorder that affects the nasal planum of Labrador Retrievers . It is caused by a mutation in the SUV39H2 gene, which encodes a histone 3 lysine 9 ( H3K9 ) methyltransferase . This mutation causes a change in an evolutionarily conserved asparagine into a lysine in the catalytically active domain of the enzyme ( p . N324K ) . The HNPK phenotype is not caused by hyperproliferation, but rather delayed terminal differentiation of keratinocytes . Our data provide evidence that SUV39H2 is involved in the epigenetic regulation of keratinocyte differentiation ensuring proper stratification and tight sealing of the mammalian epidermis .
 Influenza A viruses ( IAVs ) are negative-strand RNA viruses with eight gene segments of various lengths . IAV subtypes are determined by the virus surface glycoproteins , hemagglutinin ( HA ) , and neuraminidase ( NA ) . IAVs with subtypes H1–H16 and N1–N9 have been identified . IAVs can cause infections in birds , marine mammals , land-based lower mammals ( e . g . , pigs , dogs , and horses ) , and humans . Wild birds maintain a large IAV genetic pool , which contributes to the appearance of new IAVs in humans , lower mammals , and domestic poultry . Pigs have both avian-like receptors ( α 2 , 3-linked sialic acid , SA2 , 3Gal ) and human-like receptors ( α 2 , 6-linked sialic acid , SA2 , 6Gal ) on the epithelial cells of their respiratory tissues , making them a proposed “mixing vessel” for generating pandemic IAV strains through genetic reassortment between avian and swine or human IAVs . In this study, we identified 30 distinct genotypes of reassortants recovered from nasal wash samples and respiratory tract tissues of a group of co-housed pigs ( influenza-seronegative , avian H1N1 IAV–infected , and swine H3N2 IAV–infected pigs ) . We found that reassortants from lower respiratory tracts had the largest variations in growth kinetics in respiratory tract epithelial cells , and the cold temperature in swine nasal cells seemed to select the type of reassortant viruses shed by the pigs . One reassortant in nasal wash samples was consistently identified in upper , middle , and lower respiratory tract tissues , and it was confirmed to be transmitted efficiently between pigs . Our findings suggest that during mixed infections of avian and swine IAVs , genetic reassortments are likely to occur in the lower respiratory track , and tissue tropism is an important factor selecting for a transmissible reassortant .
 Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease caused by the trematode Schistosoma mansoni. Infection during pregnancy may affect the immune response of the offspring to schistosome infection and schistosomiasis-associated morbidity. In a study in Uganda, we examined the effects of praziquantel treatment of S . mansoni during pregnancy on prevalence of S . mansoni infection and immune responsiveness among offspring at age five years. We found no evidence that maternal S . mansoni infection and its treatment during pregnancy influence prevalence and intensity of S . mansoni infection or effector immune response to S . mansoni infection among offspring at age five years. However, we observed effects on IL-10 responses to SWA, suggesting that maternal S . mansoni and its treatment during pregnancy may affect immunoregulatory responsiveness in childhood schistosomiasis. This might have implications for pathogenesis of the disease.
 Macrophages are important cells in the immune system that help fight infections. When macrophages are activated by inflammatory stimuli, they can internalize and destroy pathogens more efficiently. However, the exact mechanism by which macrophages are activated and how they internalize and destroy pathogens is not well understood. In this study, the authors found that inflammatory stimuli cause macrophages to switch from receptor-mediated phagocytosis to macropinocytosis, a non-saturable mode of uptake that allows the internalization of large amounts of cargo independent of any receptor usage. The authors also found that this switch is regulated by the phosphorylation of a protein called coronin 1, which is activated by protein kinase C. Together, these findings provide a new understanding of how macrophages are activated and how they internalize and destroy pathogens.
 The study aimed to assess knowledge, perceptions, and acceptance of tsetse baits (traps, targets) in villages where they had or had not been used previously. The study was conducted in 8 villages across Arua District in Uganda. The results showed that despite their proximity, acceptance of traps varied markedly between villages and was related to the duration of experience with tsetse control programs. The study highlights the importance of early engagements with communities and carefully designed sensitization campaigns to ensure acceptance of tsetse control interventions. The findings can be applied to other vector-borne and neglected tropical diseases.
 Recombination is a fundamental biological process that plays a crucial role in the evolution of species. In this study, we used high-resolution whole-genome recombination maps to investigate the evolutionary consequences of recombination in Drosophila melanogaster. We generated whole-genome CO and GC maps from eight crosses between natural strains of D. melanogaster. Our maps revealed extreme and highly punctuated variation in CO rates along chromosomes, with hot and coldspots. We also found extensive intra-specific variation in CO landscapes that is associated with hotspots at low frequency in our sample. GC rates are more uniformly distributed across the genome than CO rates and detectable in regions with reduced or absent CO. Our high-resolution whole-genome recombination maps provide a unique opportunity to evaluate the evolutionary consequences of recombination due to exposure to identical demographic and environmental factors. Our study highlights the importance of considering multiple layers of variation in recombination rates when analyzing population genetic data.
 DNA methylation is an important epigenetic modification that plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression. In Arabidopsis, DNA methylation is maintained by the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) pathway. The IDN2/RDM12 gene has been previously identified as a component of the RdDM machinery in Arabidopsis, but its function in the pathway remains unknown. In this study, we used affinity purification to identify two IDN2 paralogs, IDP1 and IDP2. We found that the previously uncharacterized IDN2 XH domain is required for the IDN2-IDP1/IDP2 complex formation as well as for IDN2 function. IDP1 is required for de novo DNA methylation, siRNA accumulation, and transcriptional gene silencing, whereas IDP2 has partially overlapping roles with IDP1. Unlike IDN2, IDP1 and IDP2 are incapable of binding double-stranded RNA, suggesting that their roles in the IDN2-IDP1/IDP2 complex are different from those of IDN2 in the IDN2-IDP1/IDP2 complex and that IDP1 and IDP2 are essential for the functioning of the complex in RdDM.
 Neutrophils are the first line of defense against invading pathogens and are rapidly recruited to the sites of Leishmania inoculation . During Leishmania braziliensis infection, depletion of inflammatory cells significantly increases the parasite load whereas co-inoculation of neutrophils plus L . braziliensis had an opposite effect . Moreover, the co-culture of infected macrophages and neutrophils also induced parasite killing leading us to ask how neutrophils alone respond to an L . braziliensis exposure . Herein we focused on understanding the interaction between neutrophils and L . braziliensis, exploring cell activation and apoptotic fate. Inoculation of serum-opsonized L . braziliensis promastigotes in mice induced neutrophil accumulation in vivo, peaking at 24 h. In vitro, exposure of thyoglycollate-elicited inflammatory or bone marrow neutrophils to L . braziliensis modulated the expression of surface molecules such as CD18 and CD62L, and induced the oxidative burst. Using mCherry-expressing L . braziliensis, we determined that such effects were mainly observed in infected and not in bystander cells. Neutrophil activation following contact with L . braziliensis was also confirmed by the release of TNF-α and neutrophil elastase. Lastly, neutrophils infected with L . braziliensis but not with L . major displayed markers of early apoptosis. We show that L . braziliensis induces neutrophil recruitment in vivo and that neutrophils exposed to the parasite in vitro respond through activation and release of inflammatory mediators. This outcome may impact on parasite elimination, particularly at the early stages of infection.
 Bovine tuberculosis ( bTB ) is a major problem for cattle farmers and governments worldwide. Vaccination is a promising tool to control bTB, but it is currently not used in any international control program because it interferes with the action of the tuberculin skin test, which is used to determine if animals, herds, and countries are officially bTB-free. New diagnostic tests that Differentiate Infected from Vaccinated Animals ( DIVA ) offer the potential to introduce vaccination within existing eradication programs. We use within-herd transmission models estimated from historical data from Great Britain ( GB ) to explore the feasibility of supplemental use of BCG vaccination. We find that the specificity of the DIVA test, rather than the sensitivity, is the greatest barrier to seeing a herd level benefit of vaccination. We estimate that a DIVA specificity of at least 99.85% and sensitivity of >40% is required to see a protective herd level benefit of vaccination with no increase in the risk of restrictions being imposed. Data from experimentally infected animals suggest that this target specificity could be achieved in vaccinates using a cocktail of three DIVA antigens while maintaining a sensitivity of 73.3% ( 95%CI: 61.9 , 82.9% ) relative to post-mortem detection. Using our models, we explore the range of the DIVA test characteristics necessary to see a protective herd level benefit of vaccination. We estimate that a DIVA specificity of at least 99.85% and sensitivity of >40% is required to see a protective herd level benefit of vaccination with no increase in the risk of missed infection. Data from experimentally infected animals suggest that this target specificity could be achieved in vaccinates using a cocktail of three DIVA antigens while maintaining a sensitivity of 73.3% ( 95%CI: 61.9 , 82.9% ) relative to post-mortem detection.
 Trichuriasis is a common parasitic infection that affects millions of people worldwide. Current treatments are limited and often fail to eradicate the infection. In this study, researchers screened a library of 480 small molecules for compounds that paralyze the adult stage of the parasite Trichuris muris in vitro. They identified a new class of molecules called dihydrobenzoxazepinones that are effective against both the adult and egg stages of T. muris. These molecules show promising selectivity for the parasite and could be developed into a new treatment for trichuriasis.
 We present a detailed analysis of the properties of protein interaction networks, focusing on the roles of hubs. We show that the idea of a date/party dichotomy for hubs is not supported by the data, and that the observed differences in network vulnerability to attacks on date and party hubs are largely due to a small number of particularly important hubs. We also find that there is no clear correlation between the location of a hub on a continuum of network topological characteristics and its expression co-expression with its interaction partners. However, we find that there is a relation between the functional linkage of proteins and the link (interaction) betweenness centrality of the proteins. We suggest that a framework incorporating a more nuanced notion of roles for both nodes and links might provide a better understanding of the organization of the interactome.
 We have developed a new method to estimate the genetic diversity of pathogens in infectious disease outbreaks. This method, called "transmission divergence," measures the number of mutations that have accumulated between pathogen genomes sampled from transmission pairs. We used this method to estimate the transmission divergence of ten major outbreak-causing pathogens, including Ebola virus, SARS coronavirus, and Clostridium difficile. We found that the transmission divergence of these pathogens is generally very low, with many outbreaks characterized by large numbers of genetically identical transmission pairs. This suggests that genetic sequence data may not provide much information about individual transmission events in these outbreaks. However, our results also highlight the importance of considering the specific characteristics of each pathogen when interpreting genetic sequence data in outbreak reconstruction.
 X chromosome inactivation ( XCI ) is a process in which one of the two X chromosomes is randomly silenced in female mammals to balance the dosage of X-linked genes. In this study, the authors used RNA-seq to analyze the allele-specific expression and chromatin structure of X-linked genes in mouse tissues and cells with skewed XCI. They found that few genes escape XCI in any of the mouse tissues examined, suggesting stringent silencing and escape controls. In contrast, an in vitro system represented by the embryonic-kidney-derived Patski cell line showed a higher density of escape genes. The authors also found that allele-specific RNA polymerase II occupancy and DNase I hypersensitivity at the promoter of genes on the Xi correlated well with levels of escape, consistent with an open chromatin structure at escape genes. They also found that allele-specific CTCF binding on the Xi clustered at escape genes and was denser in brain compared to the Patski cell line. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of XCI and its regulation in different tissues.
 VX-4 is a novel cysteine protease of P. vivax that has been characterized. It has dual substrate specificity depending on the surrounding micro-environmental pH. Its hydrolyzing activity against Z-Leu-Arg-MCA and Z-Phe-Arg-MCA was highest at acidic pH ( 5.5 ), whereas that against Z-Arg-Arg-MCA was maximal at neutral pH ( 6.5-7.5 ). VX-4 preferred positively charged amino acids and Gln at the P1 position, with less strict specificity at P3 and P4. P2 preferences depended on pH ( Leu at pH 5.5 and Arg at pH 7.5 ). Three amino acids that delineate the S2 pocket were substituted in VX-4 compared to VX-2 and VX-3 ( Ala90 , Gly157 and Glu180 ). Replacement of Glu180 abolished activity against Z-Arg-Arg-MCA at neutral pH, indicating the importance of this amino acid in the pH-dependent substrate preference. VX-4 was localized in the food vacuoles and cytoplasm of the erythrocytic stage of P. vivax. VX-4 showed maximal activity against actin at neutral pH, and that against P. vivax plasmepsin 4 and hemoglobin was detected at neutral/acidic and acidic pH, respectively. VX-4 demonstrates pH-dependent substrate switching, which might offer an efficient mechanism for the specific cleavage of different substrates in different intracellular environments. VX-4 might function as a hemoglobinase in the acidic parasite food vacuole, a maturase of P. vivax plasmepsin 4 at neutral or acidic pH, and a cytoskeleton-degrading protease in the neutral erythrocyte cytosol.
 Acetogens are microorganisms that can convert waste gases into multi-carbon commodities. The Wood-Ljungdahlii pathway (WLP) is the only known CO2-fixing pathway coupled to energy conservation. A new genome-scale model of metabolism and macromolecular synthesis (ME-model) has been developed for the model acetogen Clostridium ljungdahlii. The model captures all major central metabolic, amino acid, nucleotide, lipid, major cofactors, and vitamin synthesis pathways as well as pathways to synthesis RNA and protein molecules necessary to catalyze these reactions. The model accurately predicted secretion of acetate, ethanol, and glycerol during changing carbon and metal availability and revealed how protein allocation and media composition influence metabolic pathways and energy conservation in this model acetogen. The model provides new inroads for advanced engineering designs.
 In this study, we used a panel of human osteoblasts ( HObs ) to carry out a transcriptomic survey, similar to recent studies in lymphoblastoid cell lines ( LCLs ). We performed cis-association analysis with SNP genotypes to identify genetic variations of transcript isoforms, and our analysis indicates that differential expression of transcript isoforms in HObs is also partly controlled by cis-regulatory genetic variants. We examined the top SNPs from a GWAS of bone mineral density and found overlap with probeset associations observed in this study. Our approach to examining transcriptome variation in multiple tissue types is useful for detecting the proportion of genetic variation common to different cell types and for the identification of cell-specific isoform variants that may be functionally relevant. We selected one example ( FAM118A ) from the overlapping hits for follow-up fine-mapping studies, which revealed a novel transcript isoform with potential functional importance in bone biology.
Saccharomyces eubayanus is a non-S. cerevisiae parent of the lager-brewing hybrid S. pastorianus. In contrast to most S. cerevisiae and Frohberg-type S. pastorianus strains, S. eubayanus cannot utilize the α-tri-glucoside maltotriose, a major carbohydrate in brewer’s wort. In Saccharomyces yeasts, utilization of maltotriose is encoded by the subtelomeric MAL gene family, and requires transporters for maltotriose uptake. While S. eubayanus strain CBS 12357T harbors four SeMALT genes which enable uptake of the α-di-glucoside maltose, it lacks maltotriose transporter genes. In this study, we subjected laboratory evolution in carbon-limited chemostat cultures on maltotriose-enriched wort to S. eubayanus strain CBS 12357T. An evolved strain showed improved maltose and maltotriose fermentation in 7 L fermenter experiments on industrial wort. Whole-genome sequencing revealed a novel mosaic SeMALT413 gene, resulting from repeated gene introgressions by non-reciprocal translocation of at least three SeMALT genes. The predicted tertiary structure of SeMalT413 was comparable to the original SeMalT transporters, but overexpression of SeMalT413 sufficed to enable growth on maltotriose, indicating gene neofunctionalization had occurred. The mosaic structure of SeMalT413 resembles the structure of S. pastorianus maltotriose-transporter gene SpMTY1, which has high sequences identity to alternatingly S. cerevisiae MALx1, S. paradoxus MALx1 and S. eubayanus SeMALT3. Evolution of the maltotriose transporter landscape in hybrid S. pastorianus lager-brewing strains is therefore likely to have involved mechanisms similar to those observed in the present study.
 The variants of human influenza virus have caused substantial morbidity and mortality. In this study, we have established a positive correlation between the excess mortalities caused by viral strains of distinct antigenicity and their antigenic distances to their previous strains for each (sub) type of seasonal influenza viruses. Based on this relationship, we further developed a method to rapidly assess the mortality burden of influenza A (H1N1) virus by accurately predicting the antigenic distance between A (H1N1) strains. Rapid estimation of influenza mortality burden for new seasonal strains should help formulate a cost-effective response for influenza control and prevention.
 The Asian soybean rust fungus, Phakopsora pachyrhizi, is a major threat to soybean production worldwide. To understand how this fungus interacts with its host plant, we characterized a small, secreted cysteine-rich protein (SSCRP) called PpEC23. We found that PpEC23 suppresses plant immunity by interacting with a soybean transcription factor called GmSPL12l. This interaction leads to the suppression of basal defense responses and the hypersensitive response, a form of programmed cell death. Our findings provide new insights into how rust fungi manipulate host immune systems and suggest that PpEC23 could be a target for the development of new soybean rust resistance strategies.
 In this study, we identified the cell surface tyrosine kinase EphrinA2 receptor ( EphA2 ) as a chlamydial adherence and invasion receptor that induces PI3 kinase activation, promoting chlamydial replication. Interfering with binding of C . trachomatis serovar L2 ( Ctr ) to EphA2 , downregulation of EphA2 expression or inhibition of EphA2 activity significantly reduced Ctr infection. Ctr interacts with and activates EphA2 on the cell surface resulting in Ctr and receptor internalization. During chlamydial replication, EphA2 remains active accumulating around the inclusion and interacts with the p85 regulatory subunit of PI3K to support the activation of the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway that is required for normal chlamydial development. Overexpression of full length EphA2, but not the mutant form lacking the intracellular cytoplasmic domain, enhanced PI3K activation and Ctr infection. Despite the depletion of EphA2 from the cell surface, Ctr infection induces upregulation of EphA2 through the activation of the ERK pathway, which keeps the infected cell in an apoptosis-resistant state. The significance of EphA2 as an entry and intracellular signaling receptor was also observed with the urogenital C . trachomatis-serovar D. Our findings provide the first evidence for a host cell surface receptor that is exploited for invasion as well as for receptor-mediated intracellular signaling to facilitate chlamydial replication. In addition, the engagement of a cell surface receptor at the inclusion membrane is a new mechanism by which Chlamydia subverts the host cell and induces apoptosis resistance.
 Neurons have extensive dendritic trees that receive and process information from many synapses. The presence of active conductances in dendrites has been shown to be important for dendritic excitability, but the functional role of this excitability is not clear. Here, we propose that the main role of active dendritic conductances is to enhance the dynamic range of the neuron. We model a dendritic tree as a binary tree with many excitable branchlets and show that the average output of the model is a highly non-linear function of the afferent rate, with dynamic ranges above 50 dB. We predict that neurons with larger dendritic trees should have larger dynamic ranges and that blocking of active conductances should lead to a decrease in dynamic range. Our results suggest that dendritic spikes, which have been observed experimentally, could be responsible for a double-sigmoid response function in retinal ganglion cells. We propose that neurons have active dendrites because they need to work with a large stimulus range.
 The inference of regulatory interactions and quantitative models of gene regulation from time-series transcriptomics data has been extensively studied and applied to a range of problems in drug discovery, cancer research, and biotechnology. However, the commonly-made assumptions on the biological processes under study are often not valid. In this study, we systematically investigate the importance of these assumptions and possible corrections using a combination of models and experiments. We measure in real time and in vivo the activity of genes involved in the FliA-FlgM module of the E . coli motility network. From these data, we estimate protein concentrations and global physiological effects by means of kinetic models of gene expression. Our results indicate that correcting for the bias of commonly-made assumptions improves the quality of the models inferred from the data. Moreover, we show by simulation that these improvements are expected to be even stronger for systems in which protein concentrations have longer half-lives and the activity of the gene expression machinery varies more strongly across conditions than in the FliA-FlgM module. The approach proposed in this study is broadly applicable when using time-series transcriptome data to learn about the structure and dynamics of regulatory networks. In the case of the FliA-FlgM module, our results demonstrate the importance of global physiological effects and the active regulation of FliA and FlgM half-lives for the dynamics of FliA-dependent promoters.
 The study aimed to characterize the landscape distribution and spatio-temporal dynamics of Oligoryzomys fulvescens (O . fulvescens), an important mammalian reservoir in Central America. The study was conducted in the community of Agua Buena in Tonosí, Panama, between April 2006 and December 2009. The results showed that O . fulvescens typically was locally absent during the late transitional months of the season and re-established in subsequent years. These populations re-occurred in the same area during the first three years but subsequently re-established further south in the final year of the study. Spatial autocorrelation analyses indicated that local populations encompassed approximately 300–600 m. The borders between suitable and unsuitable habitats were sharply demarcated over short distances. Oligoryzomys fulvescens showed a well-defined spatial pattern that evolved over time, and led to a pattern of changing aggregation. These findings help explain the intermittent risk from pathogens transmitted by this species. The variation was associated with seasonality, as well as anthropogenic pressures that occurred with agricultural activities. These factors help define the characteristics of the occurrence, timing, intensity, and duration of synanthropic populations affected by human populations and consequently possible exposure that local human populations experience.
 Influenza viruses are a major threat to human health and are constantly evolving to evade pre-existing host immunity. To monitor genetic and antigenic changes, the World Health Organization runs a global surveillance program. Quantification of viral antigenic phenotypes is done with the hemagglutination inhibition ( HI ) assay, which measures the ability of an antiserum to inhibit the agglutination of red blood cells by a viral antigen. Antigenic cartography, involving multidimensional scaling of log-normalized HI titers, generates an accurate low-dimensional representation of the antigenic distances between antigen–antiserum pairs. However, computational methods for directly determining the antigenic impact of individual amino acid exchanges do not yet exist. We have developed a method for inferring ‘antigenic trees’ for the major viral surface protein hemagglutinin. In the antigenic tree, antigenic weights are assigned to all tree branches, allowing us to resolve the antigenic impact of the associated amino acid changes. Our technique predicted antigenic distances with comparable accuracy to antigenic cartography and identified both known and novel sites and amino acid changes with antigenic impact in the evolution of influenza A ( H3N2 ) viruses from 1968 to 2003. The technique can also be applied for inference of ‘phenotype trees’ and genotype–phenotype relationships from other types of pairwise phenotype distances.
 Human papillomavirus ( HPV ) is a common cause of cervical cancer. HPV infection occurs in the basal layer of the cervical epithelium and progresses to the upper layers as the cells differentiate. HPV replication and assembly occur in the nucleus of differentiated cells. HPV entry into host cells involves several steps, including binding to heparan sulfate proteoglycans ( HSPGs ), endocytosis, and transport to late endosomes or endolysosomes. The viral DNA ( vDNA ) and L2 dissociate from the capsid in endosomal compartments and move to the Golgi complex. After penetration into the cytosol, the vDNA moves complexed with L2 into the nucleus and eventually localizes to ND10 nuclear domains. However, it is unclear which entry step is influenced by cell cycle progression. In this study, a two-step, high-throughput RNAi silencing screen was used to identify host cell factors required during HPV16 infection. The results revealed a previously undetermined mechanism for import of the viral DNA into the nucleus. HPV16 requires nuclear envelope breakdown during mitosis for access of the vDNA to the nucleoplasm. The results accentuate the value of genes found by RNAi screens for investigation of viral infections. The list of cell functions required during HPV16 infection will provide a resource for future virus-host cell interaction studies.
 The fungus Pseudocercospora fijiensis causes Black Sigatoka disease in banana plants, which is a major threat to global banana production. The disease is managed by frequent fungicide applications, but this leads to the evolution of fungicide-resistant strains. To better understand the disease and develop new methods for disease management, the genomes of two isolates of P. fijiensis were sequenced and analyzed. The genomes were found to be highly expanded by LTR retrotransposons, making it the largest genome within the Dothideomycetes. The genomes of two closely related members of the Sigatoka disease complex, P. musae and P. eumusae, were also found to be expanded. The genomes were analyzed for genetic diversity and differentiation, and frequencies of fungicide resistance in fungicide-treated plantations were much higher than those in untreated wild-type P. fijiensis populations. A homologue of the Cladosporium fulvum Avr4 effector was identified in the P. fijiensis genome. Infiltration of the purified PfAVR4 protein into leaves of the resistant banana variety Calcutta 4 resulted in a hypersensitive-like response, suggesting that Calcutta 4 could carry an unknown resistance gene recognizing PfAVR4. The results of this study will aid in developing fungicide treatment schedules to combat this pathogen and in improving the efficiency of banana breeding programs.
 The evolution of lineage-specific traits is thought to be driven by changes in gene regulation, including transcription factor binding sites (TFBS). However, most computational approaches to study regulatory elements focus on highly conserved sites and rely heavily on multiple sequence alignments. In this study, we developed a novel framework that uses a birth-death model to trace the evolution of lineage-specific binding sites without relying on detailed base-by-base cross-species alignments. We applied our model to analyze the evolution of binding sites for six transcription factors along the lineage toward human after human-mouse common ancestor. We estimate that a substantial fraction of binding sites (58-79%) in humans have origins since the divergence with mouse. Over 15% of all binding sites are unique to hominids. Such elements are often enriched near genes associated with specific pathways and harbor more common SNPs than older binding sites in the human genome. These results support the ability of our method to identify lineage-specific regulatory elements and help understand their roles in shaping variation in gene regulation across species.
 The circadian clock is a biological mechanism that regulates the timing of various physiological processes in response to environmental cues, such as light. In mammals, the master clock is located in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the hypothalamus, which receives light signals from the retina. In non-mammalian vertebrates, the circadian clock is distributed throughout the body, and some tissues can be directly entrained by light. In zebrafish, the circadian clock is present in many tissues and cell lines, and can be entrained by light. The zebrafish per2 gene is a negative component of the circadian oscillator and is involved in the entrainment of the circadian clock by light. In this study, we identified a Light Responsive Module (LRM) within the zebrafish per2 promoter that is necessary and sufficient for light-driven gene expression and circadian clock regulation. We also demonstrated that the human LRM can substitute for the zebrafish LRM to confer light-regulated transcription in zebrafish cells. Our results suggest that a light-dependent crosstalk between E- and D-box binding factors is a central determinant of per2 expression. These findings extend our understanding of the mechanism whereby the clock is entrained by light and how the regulation of clock gene expression by light has evolved in vertebrates.
 In this study, the authors investigate the role of the actin filament-binding protein coronin in the motility of Plasmodium berghei sporozoites, the highly motile forms of a rodent malaria-causing parasite transmitted by mosquitoes.  The authors show that coronin regulates gliding motility in sporozoites, which is required for efficient transmission from mosquitoes to mice.  The authors also suggest a switch in signaling pathways linking calcium- and cAMP- mediated signaling during migration and invasion.  Overall, this study provides important insights into the mechanisms of parasite motility and transmission.
 Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania parasites. Amphotericin B (AmB) is a drug used to treat leishmaniasis. However, the emergence of resistance to AmB is a concern. In this study, we characterized four AmB-resistant Leishmania mexicana lines. We found that all lines had altered sterol biosynthesis and were hypersensitive to pentamidine. Whole genome sequencing revealed resistance-associated mutation of sterol C5-desaturase in one line, while loss of expression of sterol C24-methyltransferase (SMT) was associated with three lines. We also found loss of the miltefosine transporter in one of the lines. SMT is encoded by two tandem gene copies, which we found to have very different expression levels. In all cases, reduced overall expression was associated with loss of the 3’ untranslated region of the dominant gene copy, resulting from structural variations at this locus. We also found local regions of sequence homology between the gene copies themselves and also due to the presence of SIDER1 retrotransposon elements that promote multi-gene amplification. Our findings suggest that structural variations at the SMT locus may contribute to AmB resistance in Leishmania parasites.
 The brain is constantly processing information from the environment and making predictions about what will happen next. When these predictions are wrong, the brain needs to update its model of the environment. This process is thought to be optimized by two main mechanisms: prediction and attention. Prediction is the process of using stored information to make predictions about what will happen next, while attention is the process of focusing on certain parts of the environment. These two mechanisms are thought to work together to optimize information processing in the brain. In this study, researchers used electroencephalography ( EEG ) to measure the neural activity of human observers as they performed a simple visual task. The researchers found that surprising stimuli evoked neural responses that contained information related to the difference between predicted and observed stimulus features, and that attention increased the selectivity for mismatch information in the neural response to surprising stimuli. These findings support the idea that attention and prediction work together to optimize information processing in the brain.
 Trypanosoma brucei is a parasite that causes African sleeping sickness in humans. There are three subspecies of T. brucei, and two of them, T. b. rhodesiense and T. b. gambiense, are able to infect humans. T. b. gambiense is divided into two groups, group 1 and group 2, which differ in their human serum resistance phenotypes. Group 1 T. b. gambiense is resistant to trypanosome lytic factor 1 (TLF-1) due to reduced uptake of TLF-1 mediated by reduced expression of the TLF-1 receptor (HpHbR) gene. However, group 2 T. b. gambiense is innately resistant to TLF-1, which could be based on the same mechanism. Group 2 T. b. gambiense variably displays this phenotype and expression does not appear to correlate with a change in expression site or expression of HpHbR. Thus, there are differences in the mechanism of human serum resistance between T. b. gambiense groups 1 and 2.
 DNA methylation of retroviral promoters and enhancers localized in the provirus 5′ long terminal repeat ( LTR ) is considered to be a mechanism of transcriptional suppression that allows retroviruses to evade host immune responses and antiretroviral drugs . However, the role of DNA methylation in the control of HIV-1 latency has never been unambiguously demonstrated, in contrast to the apparent importance of transcriptional interference and chromatin structure, and has never been studied in HIV-1-infected patients. Here, we show in an in vitro model of reactivable latency and in a latent reservoir of HIV-1-infected patients that CpG methylation of the HIV-1 5′ LTR is an additional epigenetic restriction mechanism, which controls resistance of latent HIV-1 to reactivation signals and thus determines the stability of the HIV-1 latency. CpG methylation acts as a late event during establishment of HIV-1 latency and is not required for the initial provirus silencing. Indeed, the latent reservoir of some aviremic patients contained high proportions of the non-methylated 5′ LTR. The latency controlled solely by transcriptional interference and by chromatin-dependent mechanisms in the absence of significant promoter DNA methylation tends to be leaky and easily reactivable. In the latent reservoir of HIV-1-infected individuals without detectable plasma viremia, we found HIV-1 promoters and enhancers to be hypermethylated and resistant to reactivation, as opposed to the hypomethylated 5′ LTR in viremic patients. However, even dense methylation of the HIV-1 5′LTR did not confer complete resistance to reactivation of latent HIV-1 with some histone deacetylase inhibitors, protein kinase C agonists, TNF-α, and their combinations with 5-aza-2deoxycytidine: the densely methylated HIV-1 promoter was most efficiently reactivated in virtual absence of T cell activation by suberoylanilide hydroxamic acid. Tight but incomplete control of HIV-1 latency by CpG methylation might have important implications for strategies aimed at eradicating HIV-1 infection.
 The study presents a comprehensive catalog of genetic variants in 39 Drosophila melanogaster Genetic Reference Panel inbred lines. The authors used an integrative approach for variant discovery and identified more than 3.6 million distinct variants, including more than 800,000 unique insertions, deletions, and complex variants. The study also provides insights into the regulatory architecture of gene expression variation in adult flies by mapping cis-expression quantitative trait loci (cis-eQTLs) for more than 2,000 genes. The authors found that indels comprise around 10% of all cis-eQTLs and show larger effects than SNP cis-eQTLs. In addition, the study identified two-fold more gene associations in males as compared to females and found that most cis-eQTLs are sex-specific. Finally, the study performed RNA-seq-based allelic expression imbalance analyses in the offspring of crosses between sequenced lines, which revealed that the majority of strong cis-eQTLs can be validated in heterozygous individuals. The study provides valuable insights into the relationship between genetic and phenotypic variation in Drosophila.
 The rectified surface EMG signal is commonly used to estimate the neural drive to muscles and therefore to infer sources of synaptic input to motor neurons . However, the overlap of motor unit action potentials ( amplitude cancellation ) may distort the spectrum of the rectified EMG and thereby its correlation with the neural drive. In this study, we investigated the impact of amplitude cancelation on this correlation using analytical derivations and a computational model of motor neuron activity, force, and the EMG signal. We demonstrated that an ideal rectified EMG signal without amplitude cancellation ( EMGnc ) is superior to the actual rectified EMG signal as estimator of the neural drive. This observation was confirmed by the simulations, as the average coefficient of determination ( r2 ) between the neural drive in the 1–30 Hz band and EMGnc ( 0 . 59±0 . 08 ) was matched by the correlation between the rectified EMG and the neural drive only when the level of amplitude cancellation was low ( <40% ) at low contraction levels ( <5% of maximum voluntary contraction force; MVC ) . This correlation, however, decreased linearly with amplitude cancellation ( r = -0 . 83 ) to values of r2 <0 . 2 at amplitude cancellation levels >60% ( contraction levels >15% MVC ) . Moreover, the simulations showed that a stronger ( i . e . more variable ) neural drive implied a stronger correlation between the rectified EMG and the neural drive and that amplitude cancellation distorted this correlation mainly for low-frequency components ( <5 Hz ) of the neural drive. In conclusion, the results indicate that amplitude cancellation distorts the spectrum of the rectified EMG signal. This implies that valid use of the rectified EMG as an estimator of the neural drive requires low contraction levels and/or strong common synaptic input to the motor neurons.
 Aluminum (Al) is a common soil contaminant that inhibits root growth in acidic soils. The molecular mechanism controlling this inhibition is largely unknown. In this study, we found that YUCCA (YUC), which encodes flavin monooxygenase-like proteins, regulates local auxin biosynthesis in the root-apex transition zone (TZ) in response to Al stress. Al stress up-regulates YUC3/5/7/8/9 in the root-apex TZ, which results in the accumulation of auxin in the root-apex TZ and root-growth inhibition during the Al stress response. These Al-dependent changes in the regulation of YUCs in the root-apex TZ and YUC-regulated root growth inhibition are dependent on ethylene signaling. Increasing or disruption of ethylene signaling caused either enhanced or reduced up-regulation, respectively, of YUCs in response to Al stress. In addition, ethylene enhanced root growth inhibition under Al stress was strongly alleviated in yuc mutants or by co-treatment with yucasin, an inhibitor of YUC activity, suggesting a downstream role of YUCs in this process. Moreover, ethylene-insensitive 3 (EIN3) is involved in the direct regulation of YUC9 transcription in this process. Furthermore, we demonstrated that PHYTOCHROME INTERACTING FACTOR4 (PIF4) functions as a transcriptional activator for YUC5/8/9. PIF4 promotes Al-inhibited primary root growth by regulating the local expression of YUCs and auxin signal in the root-apex TZ. The Al–induced expression of PIF4 in root TZ acts downstream of ethylene signaling. Taken together, our results highlight a regulatory cascade for YUCs-regulated local auxin biosynthesis in the root-apex TZ mediating root growth inhibition in response to Al stress.
 In this study, we investigated the functional implications of interactions between two highly polymorphic molecules, killer-cell immunoglobulin-like receptors ( KIRs ) on NK cells and their major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class I ligands on target cells, in the context of simian immunodeficiency virus ( SIV ) infection in rhesus macaques. We found that certain SIV peptides bound by MHC class I molecules can suppress the cytolytic activity of primary NK cells expressing the inhibitory KIR3DL05. These peptides can also inhibit SIV replication in lymphocytes expressing the same MHC class I molecule. These results suggest that viruses may acquire changes in epitopes that enhance MHC class I binding to inhibitory KIRs to evade NK cell killing. This study provides a mechanism by which immunodeficiency viruses may escape NK cell responses.
 Bacterial pathogens must adapt to survive in a variety of environments, including nutrient-limited conditions.  In this study, we found that Nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae ( NTHI ) adapts to nutrient-limited conditions by mutating the icc gene, which encodes a 3' , 5'-cyclic adenosine monophosphate ( cAMP ) phosphodiesterase.  This mutation results in decreased cAMP phosphodiesterase activity, which allows NTHI to form more intracellular bacterial communities ( IBCs ) early during experimental otitis media ( OM ).  Although the number of IBCs formed by the parental strain was low at early stages of OM, we observed a significant increase at later stages that coincided with absence of recoverable effusion, suggesting the presence of a mucosal reservoir following resolution of clinical disease.  These data provide the first insight into NTHI microevolution during nutritional limitation and provide the first demonstration of IBCs in a preclinical model of chronic OM.
 The study aimed to investigate the role of iron in the pathogenesis of Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis.  The study found that B. pseudomallei has developed strategies to circumvent iron restriction mechanisms of the host.  Alterations in iron homeostasis can influence the course of murine melioidosis.  The study suggests that iron chelating drugs might be an additional therapeutic option for the treatment of melioidosis.  The study highlights the importance of iron in the pathogenesis of B. pseudomallei and the potential of iron chelating drugs as a therapeutic option for the treatment of melioidosis.
 Proteins are complex molecules that perform a wide range of functions in living organisms. These functions are often accomplished through collective motions of the protein. However, identifying these motions and their relationship to the protein's function can be challenging. In this study, the authors propose a new technique called "functional mode analysis" (FMA) to identify collective motions related to a specific protein function. The technique uses an ensemble of protein structures and a "functional quantity" that quantifies the functional state of the protein. The authors demonstrate the effectiveness of FMA by applying it to a variety of biomolecules, including a polyalanine helix, T4 lysozyme, Trp-cage, and leucine-binding protein. The results show that FMA can successfully identify functionally relevant collective motions in these proteins.
 Euglenids are a group of eukaryotic organisms that contain nonconventional introns in their nuclear genes. These introns are not removed in the order expected from their position in the transcript, and their removal is not always collinear with the progress of transcription. In this study, the order of intron removal from the transcripts of two euglenid genes, tubA and gapC, was analyzed. The results showed that nonconventional introns are removed in a rapid way but later than spliceosomal introns. The observed accumulation of transcripts with conventional introns removed and nonconventional present may suggest the existence of a time gap between the two types of splicing.
 Coxsackievirus B (CVB) is a common human pathogen that causes a self-limited febrile illness in infants, but can also cause severe inflammatory diseases including myocarditis. Chronic consequences of mild CVB infection are unknown, though there is an epidemiologic association between early subclinical infections and late heart failure. Here, we describe a mouse model of juvenile infection with a subclinical dose of coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3) which showed no evident symptoms, either immediately following infection or in adult mice. However, following physiological or pharmacologically-induced cardiac stress, juvenile-infected adult mice underwent cardiac hypertrophy and dilation indicative of progression to heart failure. Evaluation of the vasculature in the hearts of adult mice subjected to cardiac stress showed a compensatory increase in CD31+ blood vessel formation, although this effect was suppressed in juvenile-infected mice. Moreover, CVB3 efficiently infected juvenile c-kit+ cells, and cardiac progenitor cell numbers were reduced in the hearts of juvenile-infected adult mice. These results suggest that the exhausted cardiac progenitor cell pool following juvenile CVB3 infection may impair the heart's ability to increase capillary density to adapt to increased load.
 The innate immune system is the first line of defense against microbial infection. It is activated in response to invading microbes by the engagement of pattern-recognition receptors ( PRRs ) including membrane-bound Toll-like receptors ( TLRs ) and cytosolic nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain ( NOD ) -like receptors ( NLRs ). NLRC4 is a cytosolic NLR that specifically responds to a functional type III ( T3SS ) or type IV ( T4SS ) secretion system either indirectly by detecting flagellin [4]–[6] , [8] , [9] , [14] or directly by detecting T3SS rod proteins through a sequence motif that is also found in flagellin FliC [11] , [15] . The specificity of the NLRC4 inflammasome for different bacterial ligands is determined by its interaction with distinct members of the NAIP ( neuronal apoptosis inhibitor protein ) family . Murine NAIP5 and NAIP6 are required for sensing bacterial flagellin in the host cytoplasm , whereas murine NAIP2 specifically detects T3SS inner rod proteins such as PrgJ from Salmonella enterica subspecies Typhimurium ( S . typhimurium ) [13] , [16] . Human NAIP binds to T3SS needle subunits from several bacteria including S . typhimurium PrgI [13] . Moreover , the S . typhimurium T3SS effector protein SopE can activate Rho GTPases and thereby triggers host cell invasion and caspase-1 activation [17] . Caspase-1 cleaves the immature forms of IL-1β and IL-18 prior to their release as biologically active inflammatory cytokines . It also induces pyroptotic cell death , a key innate defence mechanism against intracellular bacteria [18] , [19] . NLRC4-mediated activation of caspase-1 has previously been reported to result in proteolytic processing of caspase-7 during S . typhimurium infection leading to restriction of Legionella replication in infected murine macrophages [20] . Burkholderia pseudomallei is a gram-negative flagellate bacterium that causes melioidosis , a disease endemic to Southeast Asia and northern Australia [22] , [23] . Infection results from subcutaneous inoculation , inhalation or ingestion and may lead to a wide range of clinical manifestations including pneumonia , organ abscesses and septicaemia . B . pseudomallei can invade phagocytic and non-phagocytic cells , is able to escape from the endocytic vacuole and to replicate in the host cell cytosol by the use of a T3SS3 [23] . Macrophages and interferon-γ ( IFN-γ ) are critical for the early control of B . pseudomallei infection [24]–[27] . B . pseudomallei is capable of inducing caspase-1-dependent cell death in murine macrophages [28] . In a previous study we described that this rapid pyroptotic cell death is involved in defence against B . pseudomallei by removing the pathogen's replication niche but caspase-1 contributes to the control of intracellular bacterial replication in macrophages as well [29] . Work by Ceballos-Olvera et al . [12] revealed that B . pseudomallei can activate the caspase-1 inflammasome by both NLRC4 and NLRP3 . NLRC4 mainly regulates pyroptosis , whereas NLRP3 is primarily important for production of IL-1β and IL-18 . IL-1β can play a deleterious role in melioidosis by causing excessive neutrophil recruitment and tissue damage but IL-18 may be protective through induction of IFN-γ production . Furthermore , it has been shown that cytosolic flagellin from closely related but far less virulent B . thailandensis is not able to interact with NAIP5-NLRC4 and to stimulate caspase-1 activation , whereas the T3SS3 inner rod protein BsaK can interact with the NAIP2-NLRC4 inflammasome .  Pollen germination is a crucial step in the process of pollination and fertilization. The process involves a series of regulated events, including pollen adhesion, hydration, and germination on the stigma. However, the internal signaling of pollen that regulates these events is poorly understood. In this study, we found that Arabidopsis KINβγ is a cytoplasm- and nucleus-localized protein in the vegetative cells of pollen grains. The pollen of the Arabidopsis kinβγ mutant could not germinate on stigma, although it germinated normally in vitro. Further analysis revealed that the hydration of kinβγ mutant pollen on the stigma was compromised. We also found that the kinβγ mutant exhibited reduced levels of reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) in pollen. The addition of H2O2 in vitro partially compensated for the reduced water absorption of the mutant pollen in vivo, suggesting that the compromised hydration of the mutant pollen led to its defective germination. In kinβγ mutant pollen, the structure of the mitochondria and peroxisomes was destroyed, and their numbers were significantly reduced compared with those in the wild type. Furthermore, we found that the kinβγ mutant exhibited reduced levels of ROS in pollen. The addition of H2O2 in vitro partially compensated for the reduced water absorption of the mutant pollen in vivo, suggesting that the compromised hydration of the mutant pollen led to its defective germination. In kinβγ mutant pollen, the structure of the mitochondria and peroxisomes was destroyed, and their numbers were significantly reduced compared with those in the wild type. Furthermore, we found that the kinβγ mutant exhibited reduced levels of ROS in pollen. The addition of H2O2 in vitro partially compensated for the reduced water absorption of the mutant pollen in vivo, suggesting that the compromised hydration of the mutant pollen led to its defective germination. These results indicate that Arabidopsis KINβγ is critical for the regulation of ROS levels by mediating the biogenesis of mitochondria and peroxisomes in pollen, which is required for pollen–stigma interactions during pollination.
RNase III is a key enzyme for double-stranded RNA processing in many biological systems. In bacteria, it is best known for its role in ribosomal RNA maturation and mRNA turnover. In Bacillus subtilis, RNase III is essential for the cell's survival. We show that RNase III protects B. subtilis from the expression of toxin genes borne by two prophages, Skin and SPβ, through antisense RNA. We further explore the mechanism of RNase III–mediated decay of the txpA mRNA when paired to its antisense RNA RatA, both in vivo and in vitro.
 The filarial nematode Brugia malayi is a parasite that causes lymphatic filariasis in humans. The parasite releases extracellular vesicles ( EVs) that contain proteins and small RNA molecules that can modulate host biology. In this study, the authors profiled EV release across all life stages of B. malayi, including microfilariae, L3, L4, adult male and female worms. They found that EV release is conserved across the life cycle and that the protein content of the vesicles varies in a stage- and sex-specific manner. The authors also found that ivermectin, a drug used to treat lymphatic filariasis, inhibits EV release. These findings suggest that EV release may be a potential target for drug discovery efforts.
 Scabies and impetigo are common skin conditions that can be treated. However, there is a lack of epidemiological data from many countries, including the Solomon Islands. In this study, we examined 1908 people from 10 rural villages in the Western Province of the Solomon Islands and found that the total unweighted prevalence of scabies was 19.2% and the total unweighted prevalence of impetigo was 32.7%. Scabies was most common in infants and children under 4 years old, while impetigo was most common in children aged 1-4 years. Scabies and impetigo were strongly associated with each other, and community control strategies may reduce the burden of both conditions and their downstream complications.
 Neurogenesis is the process of generating new neurons in the brain. It occurs throughout life in certain areas of the brain, including the hippocampus. The function of neurogenesis is not well understood, but it has been linked to learning, memory, and emotional regulation. We used a genetic approach to study the relationship between neurogenesis and other traits in heterogeneous stock (HS) mice. HS mice are a stock of mice descended from eight inbred progenitor strains that have been maintained for over 50 generations. We found that the rate of neurogenesis in the HS mice was highly correlated with the proportion of CD8+ versus CD4+ T lymphocyte subsets. This correlation was due to shared genetic loci, with the exception of the H-2Ea locus, which had a dominant influence on T cell subsets but no impact on neurogenesis. We also found that CD4+ T cells or subpopulations thereof mediate the effect of T cell subsets on neurogenesis. Our results suggest that adult neurogenesis has broader impacts on the organism than previously thought.
 Chagas disease is a major health problem in Latin America and an emerging infectious disease in the US. We have previously screened the Trypanosoma cruzi sequence database by a computational/bioinformatics approach and identified antigens that exhibited the characteristics of vaccine candidates. We investigated the protective efficacy of a multi-component DNA-prime/protein-boost vaccine ( TcVac2 ) constituted of the selected candidates and cytokine expression plasmids in a murine model. TcVac2 induced a strong antigen-specific antibody response and a moderate level of lymphocyte proliferation in mice. Upon challenge infection, TcVac2-vaccinated mice expanded the IgG2b/IgG1 antibodies and elicited a substantial CD8+ T cell response associated with type 1 cytokines ( IFN-γ and TNF-α ) that resulted in control of acute parasite burden. During chronic phase, antibody response persisted, splenic activation of CD8+ T cells and IFN-γ/TNF-α cytokines subsided, and IL-4/IL-10 cytokines became dominant in vaccinated mice. The tissue parasitism, inflammation, and fibrosis in heart and skeletal muscle of TcVac2-vaccinated chronic mice were undetectable by histological techniques. In comparison, mice injected with vector or cytokines only responded to T . cruzi by elicitation of a mixed ( type 1/type 2 ) antibody, T cell and cytokine response, and exhibited persistent parasite burden and immunopathology in the myocardium. TcVac2-induced activation of type 1 antibody and lymphocyte responses provided resistance to acute T . cruzi infection, and consequently, prevented the evolution of chronic immunopathology associated with parasite persistence in chagasic hearts.
 Genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) have been successful in identifying disease susceptibility loci for common and complex diseases . However, the question remains whether we can accurately predict individual disease risk based on genotype data. Previous studies have failed to achieve satisfactory performance due to the use of a limited number of confirmed susceptibility loci. In this study, we propose that sophisticated machine-learning approaches with a large ensemble of markers may improve the performance of disease risk assessment. We applied a Support Vector Machine ( SVM ) algorithm on a GWAS dataset for type 1 diabetes ( T1D ) and optimized a risk assessment model with hundreds of markers. We tested this model on two independent datasets and achieved an area under ROC curve ( AUC ) of ∼0 . 84 in both datasets. In contrast, poor performance was achieved when limited to dozens of known susceptibility loci in the SVM model or logistic regression model. Our study suggests that improved disease risk assessment can be achieved by using algorithms that take into account interactions between a large ensemble of markers. We are optimistic that genotype-based disease risk assessment may be feasible for diseases where a notable proportion of the risk has already been captured by SNP arrays.
 Memory CD8+ T cells are important for providing protective immunity against viral infections. These cells can be found in the circulation and in non-lymphoid tissues such as the skin. However, the mechanisms by which memory CD8+ T cells traffic to and differentiate in non-lymphoid tissues are not well understood. In this study, the authors found that memory CD8+ T cells rapidly infiltrate the skin following Vaccinia virus infection and provide significant protective immunity. They also found that only a subset of circulating memory CD8+ T cells differentiate into functional CD69+/CD103- TRM in the skin. Finally, the authors found that after entering VacV-infected skin, circulating memory CD8+ T cells express granzyme B and require cytolytic function to provide protection against VacV infection. These findings provide important insights into the mechanisms by which memory CD8+ T cells traffic to and differentiate in non-lymphoid tissues.
 Neurons have distinct axons and dendrites that are specialized for different functions. The transport of proteins to these different compartments is critical for neuronal function. Myosin motors are known to play a role in the transport of proteins to dendrites, but little is known about their role in the transport of proteins to axons. In this study, we found that Myosin VI, a minus-end-directed motor, plays a vital role in the enrichment of proteins on the surface of axons. We also found that Myosin VI mediates the enrichment of proteins on the axonal surface at least in part by stimulating dendrite-specific endocytosis. These findings suggest that myosin motors help shape the polarized distributions of both axonal and dendritic proteins.
 We have identified two Dsx genes from Daphnia magna, a freshwater branchiopod crustacean that parthenogenetically produces males in response to environmental cues. One of these genes, designated DapmaDsx1, is responsible for the male trait development when expressed during environmental sex determination. The domain organization of DapmaDsx1 was similar to that of Dsx from insects, which are thought to be the sister group of branchiopod crustaceans. Intriguingly, the molecular basis for sexually dimorphic expression of DapmaDsx1 is different from that of insects.
