Rather than being regulated sex-specifically at the level of pre–mRNA splicing in the coding region, DapmaDsx1 exhibits sexually dimorphic differences in the abundance of its transcripts. During embryogenesis, expression of DapmaDsx1 was increased only in males and its transcripts were primarily detected in male-specific structures. Knock-down of DapmaDsx1 in male embryos resulted in the production of female traits including ovarian maturation, whereas ectopic expression of this gene in female embryos resulted in the development of male-like phenotypes. Expression patterns of another D . magna Dsx gene, DapmaDsx2, were similar to those of DapmaDsx1, but silencing and overexpression of this gene did not induce any clear phenotypic changes. These results establish DapmaDsx1 as a key regulator of the male phenotype. Our findings reveal how ESD is implemented by selective expression of a fundamental genetic component that is functionally conserved in animals using GSD. We infer that there is an ancient, previously unidentified link between genetic and environmental sex determination.
 Genital herpes is a common sexually transmitted infection that causes pain and suffering, increases the risk of HIV transmission, and can lead to neonatal herpes in newborns. A trivalent HSV-2 subunit vaccine was evaluated in rhesus macaques and guinea pigs. The vaccine contains glycoproteins C, D, and E (gC2, gD2, gE2) to block virus entry by gD2 and immune evasion by gC2 and gE2. In rhesus macaques, the vaccine induced plasma and mucosa neutralizing antibodies, antibodies that block gC2 and gE2 immune evasion activities, and stimulated CD4 T cell responses. After intravaginal challenge, a self-limited vaginal infection of brief duration was detected by histopathology and immunohistochemistry in naïve, but not in trivalent immunized macaques. Vaccine efficacy was evaluated in female guinea pigs. Animals were mock immunized, or immunized with gD2, the trivalent vaccine, or the trivalent vaccine followed by a booster dose of gD2 (trivalent + gD2). The trivalent and trivalent + gD2 groups were 97% and 99% efficacious, respectively, in preventing genital lesions and both outperformed gD2 alone. As a marker of transmission risk, vaginal swabs were evaluated daily for HSV-2 DNA and replication competent virus between five and seven weeks after challenge. HSV-2 DNA shedding was reduced in all groups compared with mock. Shedding of replication competent virus occurred on fewer days in the trivalent than gD2 immunized animals while the trivalent + gD2 group had no shedding of replication competent virus. Overall, the trivalent group had genital lesions on <1% days and shedding of replication competent virus on 0.2% days. The vaccine has outstanding potential for prevention of genital herpes in humans.
 We have developed a new method, called Perm-seq, to analyze ChIP-seq data from highly repetitive regions of the genome. These regions are difficult to analyze because short reads from these regions can map to multiple locations in the reference genome. Our method uses additional data sources, such as DNase-seq and histone ChIP-seq, to improve the accuracy of multi-read allocation. We applied our method to ENCODE ChIP-seq data from GM12878 and K562 cells and identified many novel protein-DNA interactions in segmental duplication regions. Our analysis revealed that although the protein-DNA interaction sites in repetitive regions are evolutionarily less conserved, they share the overall sequence characteristics of protein-DNA interaction regions identified by uniquely mapping reads. Our method can be applied to other types of sequencing data and may improve the accuracy of multi-read allocation in other types of genomic analysis.
 Schistosomiasis is a parasitic infection that affects over 200 million people worldwide, with most cases occurring in Africa. Previous studies have suggested that people with schistosomiasis may have a higher risk of HIV-1 acquisition and impaired ability to control HIV-1 replication once infected. We conducted a nested case-control study within a large population-based survey of HIV-1 transmission in Tanzania to test these hypotheses. We found that women with schistosome infections had a higher odds of HIV-1 acquisition than those without, while men with schistosome infections did not. We also found that individuals with active schistosome infection at the time of HIV-1 acquisition had higher HIV-1 viral loads at the time of HIV-1 seroconversion. These findings suggest that pre-existing schistosome infection increases the odds of HIV-1 acquisition in women and raises HIV-1 viral load at the time of HIV-1 seroconversion. This is the first study to demonstrate the effect of schistosome infection on HIV-1 susceptibility and viral control, and to differentiate effects by gender.
45S rDNA is a highly variable and recombinogenic region in the human genome that encodes the ribosomal RNA. We used computational and experimental approaches to measure the copy number and sequence of 45S rDNA in normal and cancer states in human and mouse genomes. We found that copy number and sequence can change in cancer genomes, with loss of copies being associated with mTOR hyperactivity. We also found that rDNA copy number may be a simple and useful indicator of whether a cancer will be sensitive to DNA damaging treatments.
 Infections with Salmonella enterica are a major public health problem worldwide . Understanding the dynamics of bacterial growth and spread within the host is crucial for developing effective treatments and vaccines. In this study, we used a combination of genetic engineering, animal models, and mathematical modeling to investigate the dynamics of Salmonella enterica infections in mice. We generated eight isogenic strains of Salmonella enterica, each with a unique genetic tag, and inoculated them into mice. We then tracked the growth and spread of each strain over time using quantitative PCR and mathematical modeling. Our results show that bacterial growth and spread are highly dynamic and heterogeneous within the host. We found that bacterial growth rates vary significantly between strains and organs, and that bacterial spread occurs through a combination of local growth and systemic transfer. Our findings provide important insights into the dynamics of Salmonella enterica infections and have implications for the development of new treatments and vaccines.
3D motion perception is a fundamental problem that the visual system has to solve. In this study, we investigate the inverse problem of 3D motion perception and the aperture problem. We show that existing processing schemes such as interocular velocity difference, changing disparity over time, and joint encoding of motion and disparity do not offer a general solution to the inverse optics problem of local binocular 3D motion. Instead, we suggest that local velocity constraints in combination with binocular disparity and other depth cues provide a more flexible framework for the solution of the inverse problem. We predict perceived motion directions for ambiguous line motion and distinguish between two plausible default strategies of 3D motion processing. Our theoretical results suggest that velocity constraints and disparity from feature tracking are needed to solve the inverse problem of 3D motion perception. It seems plausible that motion and disparity input is processed in parallel and integrated late in the visual processing hierarchy.
 The bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa secretes the anionic, O-acetylated exopolysaccharide alginate during chronic infection in the lungs of cystic fibrosis patients to form the major constituent of a protective biofilm matrix . Four proteins have been implicated in the O-acetylation of alginate: AlgIJF and AlgX. To probe the biological function of AlgJ, we determined its structure to 1.83 Å resolution. AlgJ is a SGNH hydrolase-like protein, which while structurally similar to the N-terminal domain of AlgX exhibits a distinctly different electrostatic surface potential. Consistent with other SGNH hydrolases, we identified a conserved catalytic triad composed of D190, H192, and S288 and demonstrated that AlgJ exhibits acetylesterase activity in vitro. Residues in the AlgJ signature motifs were found to form an extensive network of interactions that are critical for O-acetylation of alginate in vivo. Using two different electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) assays, we compared the abilities of AlgJ and AlgX to bind and acetylate alginate. Binding studies using defined length polymannuronic acid revealed that AlgJ exhibits either weak or no detectable polymer binding while AlgX binds polymannuronic acid specifically in a length-dependent manner. Additionally, AlgX was capable of utilizing the surrogate acetyl-donor 4-nitrophenyl acetate to catalyze the O-acetylation of polymannuronic acid. Our results, combined with previously published in vivo data, suggest that the annotated O-acetyltransferases AlgJ and AlgX have separate and distinct roles in O-acetylation. Our refined model for alginate acetylation places AlgX as the terminal acetyltransferase and provides a rationale for the variability in the number of proteins required for polysaccharide O-acetylation.
β (1,3)-glucan is a major component of the fungal cell wall and is recognized by the host immune system through the C-type lectin receptor Dectin-1. The CHO1 gene encodes a phosphatidylserine synthase that is important for β (1,3)-glucan masking. The homozygous cho1Δ/Δ mutant exhibits increased β (1,3)-glucan exposure and is hyper-sensitive to cell wall stressors. We found that the Cek1 MAPK pathway is upregulated in the cho1Δ/Δ mutant and that activation of this pathway is sufficient to cause β (1,3)-glucan exposure. These findings suggest that the Cek1 MAPK pathway plays a role in β (1,3)-glucan masking and that disruption of this pathway may contribute to the virulence of C . albicans.
 Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a major public health challenge and a therapeutic imperative. A genome-wide association study was performed using neuropathologic data from 4,914 brain autopsies. Neuropathologic data were used to define clinico-pathologic AD dementia or controls, assess core neuropathologic features of AD (neuritic plaques, neurofibrillary tangles), and evaluate commonly co-morbid neuropathologic changes. Genome-wide significance was observed for clinico-pathologic AD dementia, neuritic plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, and Lewy body disease. Twelve of the 21 non-APOE genetic risk loci for clinically-defined AD dementia were confirmed in our clinico-pathologic sample. Correlation of effect sizes for risk of AD dementia with effect size for neurofibrillary tangles or neuritic plaques showed positive correlation, while those for risk of vascular brain injury showed a moderate negative correlation. The other co-morbid neuropathologic features showed only nominal association with the known AD loci. Our results discovered new genetic associations with specific neuropathologic features and aligned known genetic risk for AD dementia with specific neuropathologic changes in the largest brain autopsy study of AD and related dementias.
 Urea is a commonly used protein denaturant in biochemistry and biophysics. However, the exact role of urea in protein unfolding is still unclear. In this study, we used extensive molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the kinetic role of urea in protein unfolding. We found that urea concentrates in the first solvation shell of quasi-native proteins, but with a density lower than that of the fully unfolded state. Urea also reduces the magnitude of atomic vibrations, leading to a counterintuitive slow down of the atomic-motions that opposes unfolding. Urea stickiness and slow diffusion are crucial for unfolding. Long residence urea molecules placed around the hydrophobic core are crucial to stabilize partially open structures generated by thermal fluctuations. Our simulations indicate that although urea does not favor the formation of partially open microstates, it is not a mere spectator of unfolding. On the contrary, urea actively favors unfolding by selecting and stabilizing partially unfolded microstates, slowly driving the protein conformational ensemble far from the native one and also from the conformations sampled during thermal unfolding.
 Dengue disease is a major public health problem in Colombia, with a stable annual number of cases and major outbreaks in 2001-2003 and 2010. The majority of cases were among those under 15 years of age. Gaps in epidemiological knowledge regarding dengue disease in Colombia include studies of asymptomatic dengue virus infection, primary versus secondary infections, and under-reporting of the disease. Improved understanding of the factors that determine disease expression and enable improvement in disease control and management is also important.
Tegumentary leishmaniasis (TL) is a skin disease caused by Leishmania parasites. It is common in tropical and subtropical regions, and can be severe in people with weakened immune systems. In addition to Leishmania, people with TL may also carry other pathogens, such as HIV, bacteria, and helminths. These coinfections can affect the clinical outcome of TL and the response to treatment. This review summarizes the frequency of TL coinfections in human populations, interactions between Leishmania and other pathogens in animal models and human subjects, and implications of TL coinfections for clinical practice. The frequency of coinfections varies depending on the region and population, but is common in many areas where TL occurs. Interactions between Leishmania and other pathogens can affect the immune response to both diseases, and may increase the risk of treatment failure and disease recurrence. More research is needed to understand how coinfections affect the natural history of TL and the response to treatment.
 The major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) is a region of the genome that plays a crucial role in the immune system. It contains many genes that are involved in the presentation of antigens to T cells. The MHC is highly variable and has been linked to many diseases. In this study, the authors used two genetic models in rats to assess the impact of natural genetic variation on MHC expression and CD4∶CD8 lineage commitment. They found that QTLs associated with variation in MHC class I and II protein expression and the CD4∶CD8 T cell ratio colocalized within a region spanning the MHC. They also identified two intervals, each ∼0 . 25 Mb wide, in the MHC-I and II region that contributed to the phenotypic variation. The authors suggest that the variation in MHC expression and CD4∶CD8 lineage commitment may be due to polymorphisms in Tap2 and Tapbp. These findings provide new insights into the role of the MHC in the immune system and may have implications for understanding the genetic basis of disease.
 Chagas disease is a potentially life-threatening illness caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. It is endemic in 21 Latin American countries and has recently emerged in non-endemic countries, including Spain. In this study, we analyzed hospital discharge records in Spain from 1997 to 2011 to describe the evolution of Chagas disease in the country. We found that the number of hospitalizations increased after 2005, and that the predominant patient profile was asymptomatic women at fertile age. We also identified factors associated with organ affectation, such as male gender, age between 45 and 64 years, and a median hospitalization cost above 3,065 euro. These findings highlight the need for increased efforts towards the early detection of T cruzi in Spain.
 We present BlocBuster, a novel systems-level approach for identifying combinatorial interactions of genetic variants associated with complex diseases. BlocBuster is a powerful and efficient method that employs a custom correlation coefficient to construct an allele-specific network of SNP alleles, which is subsequently partitioned into clusters of correlated alleles. Each cluster is tested for phenotypic association, and the results are rigorously validated using multiple computational trials. We apply BlocBuster to genome-wide data for psoriasis and identify a bloc of SNP alleles that is significantly associated with the disease. This bloc is replicated in independent data, thereby ensuring its accuracy and suitability for further research efforts. We compare and contrast our approach with Pearson's Correlation Coefficient ( PCC ) and observe that the PCC network had substantially weaker community structure, was more likely to introduce false-positive correlations, and required three times as much computation time.
 Agenesis of the corpus callosum ( ACC ), cerebellar hypoplasia ( CBLH ) , and polymicrogyria ( PMG ) are severe congenital brain malformations that result in significant developmental disability and seizures . While the incidence of each malformation is low, they are nevertheless the most common developmental brain malformations encountered in the clinic and both ACC and CBLH are frequently seen in prenatal brain imaging . In this study, we conducted a large-scale chromosomal copy number variation ( CNV ) discovery effort in 545 patients with one or more of these three brain malformations and in 2 , 349 control individuals . We found that ACC patients had a significantly higher prevalence of large gene-rich CNVs than CBLH and PMG patients. We also found that ACC patients had a higher prevalence of de novo CNVs than CBLH and PMG patients. Our findings suggest that large gene-rich CNVs may play a more important role in the etiology of ACC than in CBLH and PMG.
 The planarian Schmidtea mediterranea is a model organism for studying regeneration and growth control. In this study, we investigated the role of the Hippo signaling pathway effector Yorkie (Yki) in planarian regeneration. We found that Yki is required for proper growth control and patterning during regeneration. In Yki-depleted animals, we observed hyper-activation of the injury response program, including increased stem cell proliferation and the expression of wound-induced genes. We also found that Yki-depleted animals have expanded epidermal and muscle cell populations. Finally, we demonstrated that Yki is required for proper scaling and size regulation of the brain, gut, and midline during morphallaxis. Our results suggest that Yki plays a critical role in integrating multiple aspects of the injury response program, including proliferation, patterning, and scaling.
 Exosomes are small vesicles that are released from cells and contain various proteins, lipids, and RNA molecules. They play important roles in intercellular communication and can be used by viruses to transfer their genetic materials to new host cells. In this study, we found that EV71 infection upregulated exosome secretion and resulted in differential packaging of the viral genomic RNA and miR-146a into exosomes. We provided evidence showing that miR-146a was preferentially enriched in exosomes while the viral RNA was not in infected cells. Moreover, the exosomal viral RNA could be transferred to and replicate in a recipient cell while the exosomal miR-146a suppressed type I interferon response in the target cell, thus facilitating the viral replication. Our findings provide evidence that exosomes secreted by EV71-infected cells selectively packaged high level miR-146a that can be functionally transferred to and facilitate exosomal EV71 RNA to replicate in the recipient cells by suppressing type I interferon response.
 Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that affects movement and is caused by the loss of dopaminergic neurons. Two genes, PINK1 and parkin, have been identified as early-onset autosomal recessive PD genes. PINK1 is a serine/threonine kinase with a predicted mitochondrial target sequence, while parkin is a RING-finger protein with ubiquitin-ligase activity. Recent genetic studies in Drosophila have suggested that dPINK1 acts as an upstream regulator of dParkin in a common pathway that influences mitochondrial maintenance in a subset of tissues. In this study, the authors biochemically purified PINK1-binding proteins from human cultured cells and screened the genes encoding these binding proteins using Drosophila PINK1 models to isolate a molecule involved in the PINK1 pathology. They found that a mitochondrial protein, PGAM5, modulates the PINK1 pathway. Loss of Drosophila PGAM5 (dPGAM5) can suppress the muscle degeneration, motor defects, and shorter lifespan that result from dPINK1 inactivation and that can be attributed to mitochondrial degeneration. However, dPGAM5 inactivation fails to modulate the phenotypes of parkin mutant flies. Conversely, ectopic expression of dPGAM5 exacerbated the dPINK1 and Drosophila parkin (dParkin) phenotypes. These results suggest that PGAM5 negatively regulates the PINK1 pathway related to maintenance of the mitochondria and that furthermore, that PGAM5 acts between PINK1 and Parkin, or functions independently of Parkin downstream of PINK1.
 Buruli ulcer ( BU ) is a chronic skin disease caused by infection with Mycobacterium ulcerans ( M . ulcerans ). The disease is characterized by the production of mycolactone, a cytotoxic macrolide exotoxin that induces necrosis and oedema in the skin. Despite extensive research, the role of interferon-γ ( IFNγ ) in host immune defense against M . ulcerans infection is not yet fully understood. In this study, we found that IFNγ is a critical regulator of early host immune defense against M . ulcerans infection in an experimental Buruli ulcer mouse model. IFNγ knockout mice displayed a faster progression of the infection compared to wild-type mice, with faster and more extensive tissue necrosis and oedema formation, as well as a significantly higher bacterial burden after five weeks of infection. These data demonstrate a prominent role of IFNγ in early defense against M . ulcerans infection and support the view that concepts for vaccine development against tuberculosis may also be valid for BU.
 The study of the mechanism of reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) production in mitochondria is important for understanding the pathogenesis of various diseases. The authors developed a new methodology for modeling the electron transport chain in mitochondria, which allowed them to identify two steady state modes of operation ( bistability ) of respiratory complex III at the same microenvironmental conditions. The authors also found that complex III can switch from a low ROS producing mode to a high ROS producing state during anoxia, which persists after the return to normal oxygen supply. This prediction was qualitatively validated experimentally. The authors suggest that recognition of bistability of complex III operation may enable novel therapeutic strategies for oxidative stress.
 We present a quantitative analysis of the role of the terminal gap gene huckebein (hkb) in pattern formation during Drosophila embryogenesis. We use gene circuit models to investigate the regulatory effect of hkb on gap gene expression. We show that hkb is involved in the regulation of the posterior hunchback (hb) domain, but does not have any other essential function. Specifically, hkb is required for the anterior shift in the posterior border of this domain, which is now reproduced correctly in our models. Our models are in agreement with earlier results, which they extend in two important respects: First, we show that Hkb is involved in the regulation of the posterior hb domain, but does not have any other essential function. Second, gap gene circuits presented here are able to reproduce mutants of terminal gap genes, while previously published models were unable to reproduce any null mutants correctly. As a consequence, our models now capture the expression dynamics of all posterior gap genes and some variational properties of the system correctly. This is an important step towards a better, quantitative understanding of the developmental and evolutionary dynamics of the gap gene network.
Brucellosis is a bacterial infection that affects humans and animals worldwide. It is caused by the bacteria Brucella abortus and is a major public health concern. Currently, there is no effective immunotherapy for Brucellosis, and treatment is often ineffective. In this study, we investigated the use of phage lysates of Brucella abortus strains S19 and RB51 as a potential immunotherapy for Brucellosis in cattle. We found that phage lysates of both strains were effective in inducing strong antibody and cell-mediated immune responses in cattle. Additionally, we developed a minimally invasive method for monitoring the efficacy of therapy using Brucella-specific RNA in plasma. Our results suggest that phage lysates of Brucella abortus strains S19 and RB51 could be a promising immunotherapy for Brucellosis in cattle.
α-Actinin-3 is a protein found in the muscles of most people around the world. It is encoded by the ACTN3 gene and is important for muscle function. In 1 . 5 billion people, a certain variation in the genetic sequence of their ACTN3 gene causes their muscles to produce no α-actinin-3 protein at all. These people have no muscle disease; however, in elite athletes, a lack of α-actinin-3 seems to be beneficial for endurance performance. Intriguingly, the ACTN3 577X null genotype is more common in European and Asian populations and less common in African populations. During recent evolution, there appears to have been strong positive selection for α-actinin-3 deficiency in places where food resources are scarce and climate is cold. We have previously demonstrated that α-actinin-3 deficiency in the Actn3 KO mouse causes a shift towards more “energy efficient” forms of muscle metabolism which would enhance survival in times of famine, and benefit endurance performance. Our present study, using single muscle fibres from Actn3 KO mice, demonstrates changes in calcium handling that would adapt muscles to cold environments and provide a survival advantage in cold climates. We uncovered a specific target of Cdk2 within the DNA repair machinery, and showed that transient, selective inhibition of analog-sensitive ( AS ) Cdk2 after exposure to ionizing radiation enhances cell-killing. Therefore, by chemical genetics, we uncovered both a non-redundant requirement for Cdk2 activity in response to DNA damage and a specific target of Cdk2 within the DNA repair machinery.
 In this study, we used the formaldehyde-assisted isolation of regulatory elements (FAIRE) method to map active regulatory elements at known loci associated with hematological quantitative traits, coronary artery disease, and myocardial infarction in a megakaryocytic and an erythroblastoid cell line. We found that the two cell types exhibit distinct patterns of open chromatin and that cell-specific open chromatin can guide the finding of functional variants. We identified an open chromatin region at chromosome 7q22.3 in megakaryocytes but not erythroblasts, which harbors the common non-coding sequence variant rs342293 known to be associated with platelet volume and function. Resequencing of this open chromatin region in 643 individuals provided strong evidence that rs342293 is the only putative causative variant in this region. We demonstrated that the C- and G-alleles differentially bind the transcription factor EVI1 affecting PIK3CG gene expression in platelets and macrophages. Our data suggested a molecular mechanism by which a non-coding GWA index SNP modulates platelet phenotype.
 The study investigates the mechanism of action of two commonly used pharmacological blockers of voltage-gated ion channels, tetrodotoxin (TTX) and riluzole (RZ), on persistent sodium current (INaP) in the pre-Bötzinger complex (pre-BötC) of the respiratory network. The study shows that the effects of INaP block by TTX and RZ are different due to their distinct mechanisms of action. Specifically, TTX directly obstructs the Na+ pore, while RZ shifts INaP inactivation in the hyperpolarizing direction. The study also shows that RZ blockade of INaP can be reactivated by transient hyperpolarizing perturbations, while TTX blockade of INaP cannot be reactivated. The study predicts that RZ will fail to effectively block INaP in the intact respiratory network, while complete block of INaP by experimental application of low concentration TTX within the pre-BötC will abolish the respiratory rhythm in the intact respiratory network. The study highlights the importance of considering the mechanism of action when interpreting and simulating experimental data from pharmacological blocking studies.
 In this study, we examined the role of miR-218 in gastric cancer (GC) metastasis. We found that miR-218 expression is decreased in metastatic GC cells and that this decrease is associated with poor prognosis in patients. We also found that miR-218 regulates the Slit-Robo1 pathway, which is involved in GC cell migration and invasion. Our results suggest that miR-218 may be a potential target for the treatment of GC metastasis.
 Atherosclerosis is a disease that causes plaque buildup in the arteries, leading to heart attacks and strokes. Statins are commonly used to treat atherosclerosis by lowering cholesterol levels in the blood. However, some patients experience severe side effects from statins. To better understand the effects of statins on atherosclerosis and to identify new targets for treatment, researchers used a mouse model with human-like hypercholesterolemia and a genetic switch to lower plasma lipoproteins. They found that when plasma cholesterol levels were lowered, the formation of advanced plaques was prevented, and a network of cholesterol-responsive atherosclerosis genes was identified. These genes may be useful for developing new atherosclerosis therapies.
 The cell envelope of Gram-negative bacteria is a complex structure that plays a crucial role in maintaining cellular integrity and protecting against external insults. The envelope is composed of three layers: an inner membrane, an outer membrane, and a peptidoglycan layer. The outer membrane is particularly important for the resistance of Gram-negative bacteria to antibiotics. However, the mechanisms by which the envelope is assembled and maintained are not well understood. In this study, the authors developed a simple, quantitative, and high-throughput assay for mutants with envelope biogenesis defects using the reporter β-galactosidase. They screened an ordered single-gene deletion library of Escherichia coli and identified 102 genes of unknown function that likely impact envelope biogenesis. As a proof of principle, the authors characterized one of these factors, ElyC (YcbC), further and found that it plays a critical role in the metabolism of the essential lipid carrier used for the biogenesis of cell wall and other bacterial surface polysaccharides. The screening assay described here should be adaptable to other organisms to study the biogenesis of different envelope architectures.
 The study presents a method for fusing heterogeneous datasets into an integrated view of multivariable dynamics. The method is demonstrated using a dataset from studies of pattern formation in Drosophila embryos. The result is a continuous trajectory that reveals the joint dynamics of gene expression, subcellular protein localization, protein phosphorylation, and tissue morphogenesis. The approach can be readily adapted to other imaging modalities and forms a starting point for further steps of data analytics and modeling of biological dynamics.
 Snake venom metalloproteinases ( SVMPs ) are zinc-dependent enzymes that cause hemorrhage by degrading basement membrane ( BM ) components.  In this study, we compared the tissue localization and ECM degradation patterns of three classes of SVMPs ( PI , PII and PIII ) in vivo and in vitro.  Immunohistochemical analyses revealed that PII and PIII SVMPs co-localized with type IV collagen in capillaries, arterioles, and post-capillary venules to a higher extent than PI SVMP, which showed a more widespread distribution in the tissue.  Proteomic analysis of exudates collected in tissue injected with these enzymes revealed similarities and differences between the action of the three SVMPs.  Higher extent of proteolysis was observed for the PI enzyme regarding several ECM components and fibrinogen, whereas exudates from mice injected with PII and PIII SVMPs had higher amounts of some intracellular proteins.  Our results provide novel clues for understanding the mechanisms by which SVMPs induce damage to the microvasculature and generate hemorrhage.
92 kb noncoding RNA (ncRNA) called iab-8 is responsible for repressing the homeotic gene abd-A in the posterior central nervous system (CNS) of Drosophila melanogaster. The iab-8 ncRNA produces a micro RNA (miR-iab-8) that represses abd-A, but also has a second, redundant repression mechanism that acts only "in cis" with the abd-A promoter. Transcriptional interference with the abd-A promoter is the most likely mechanism for this second repression. The iab-8 ncRNA is transcribed in a distal-to-proximal direction from the Abd-B transcription unit and is detected only in the developing CNS. The miR-iab-8 micro RNA is required for male and female fertility. The start site of this RNA is in the iab-8 regulatory region, downstream of Abd-B. The iab-8 ncRNA plays a crucial role in the repression of abd-A in the posterior CNS, and its function is essential for the proper development of Drosophila.
 Focal seizures are a type of epilepsy that arise from a localized area of the brain. Two common onset patterns of focal seizures are low amplitude fast oscillations (LAF) and high amplitude spikes (HAS). In this study, we used a computational model of neocortical tissue to investigate the mechanisms underlying these two patterns. We found that LAF onset is initiated by independent patches of localized activity that slowly invade the surrounding tissue and coalesce over time. In contrast, HAS onset is a global transition to a coexisting seizure state triggered by a local event. We also found that the difference in surrounding tissue excitability could explain the clinically reported difference in surgical outcomes. Finally, we demonstrated that changes in tissue excitability could be elucidated using active stimulation. Our findings suggest that the excitability of the tissue surrounding the seizure core may play a determining role in the seizure onset pattern and surgical outcome.
 We have identified four defensin-like cysteine-rich proteins (ZmES1-4) that are specifically expressed in the female gametophyte of maize. These proteins are released during fertilization and induce pollen tube burst and explosive sperm release. We found that ZmES4 induces pollen tube burst in a species-preferential manner and that K+ influx is required for this process. We also discovered that ZmES4 interacts with the intrinsic rectifying K+ channel KZM1, which opens upon ZmES4 application and closes after wash-out. Our findings suggest that ZmES4 and KZM1 are involved in a pre-zygotic hybridization barrier and may be a component of reproductive isolation in plants.
 Oncolytic viruses are being investigated as a potential treatment for cancer. One such virus is herpes simplex virus (HSV), which can be retargeted to cancer cells by modifying its tropism. In this study, we retargeted HSV to HER-2, a protein overexpressed in ovarian and breast cancer cells. We then assessed the efficacy of systemically delivered retargeted HSV against disseminated tumors in mouse models. Our results show that the retargeted HSV effectively inhibited the growth of ovarian and breast cancer cells in the peritoneal cavity. This study provides evidence for the potential use of retargeted HSV as a treatment for disseminated cancer.
 Centrosomes are essential organelles that serve as the poles of the mitotic spindle during cell division. The duplication of centrosomes once per cell cycle is tightly regulated to ensure proper chromosome segregation and prevent genomic instability. Our study has identified a new regulator of centrosome duplication, Sfi1, which is phosphorylated by the cyclin-dependent kinase Cdk1 and dephosphorylated by the protein phosphatase Cdc14. We found that reducing Cdk1 phosphorylation of Sfi1 leads to defects in spindle pole body (SPB) separation and reduplication during mitosis, as well as defects in bipolar spindle assembly and chromosome segregation. Our findings suggest that phosphoregulation of Sfi1 by Cdk1 and Cdc14 has dual functions in promoting SPB separation for spindle formation and preventing premature SPB duplication.
 The HIV-1 accessory protein Vpr has been shown to cause G2 cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in HIV-1-infected cells in vitro . However, its direct evidence in vivo has not been shown. In this study, we used a human hematopoietic stem cell-transplanted humanized mouse model to demonstrate that Vpr causes G2 cell cycle arrest and apoptosis predominantly in proliferating CCR5+ CD4+ T cells, which mainly consist of regulatory CD4+ T cells (Tregs), resulting in Treg depletion and enhanced virus production during acute infection. The Vpr-dependent enhancement of virus replication and Treg depletion is observed in CCR5-tropic but not CXCR4-tropic HIV-1-infected mice, suggesting that these effects are dependent on the coreceptor usage by HIV-1. When humanized mice were treated with denileukin diftitox (DD) to deplete Tregs, DD-treated humanized mice showed massive activation/proliferation of memory T cells compared to the untreated group. This activation/proliferation enhanced CCR5 expression in memory CD4+ T cells and rendered them more susceptible to CCR5-tropic wild-type HIV-1 infection than to vpr-deficient virus. Taken together, these results suggest that Vpr takes advantage of proliferating CCR5+ CD4+ T cells for enhancing viremia of CCR5-tropic HIV-1. Because Tregs exist in a higher cycling state than other T cell subsets, Tregs appear to be more vulnerable to exploitation by Vpr during acute HIV-1 infection.
 Plasmodium vivax is a major cause of malaria in Asia and the Middle East. It is prevalent in temperate areas, including South Korea, where it was successfully eliminated in the late 1970s. However, it re-emerged in 1993 and has been a persistent problem since then. To understand the genetic structure and temporal dynamics of the parasite population, we analyzed microsatellite DNA markers of 163 South Korean isolates collected from 1994 to 2008. We found that the parasite population structure changed drastically in 2002 and 2003, suggesting that the parasites were continually introduced from other population sources, possibly North Korea. Our findings highlight the importance of molecular epidemiology in understanding the transmission pattern and evaluating the effectiveness of malaria control measures.
 Introns are non-coding segments of DNA found within genes. They are thought to enhance gene expression, but the exact mechanism is not clear. In this study, the authors found that introns are important for regulating the direction of gene expression. They used a technique called strand-specific transcription run-on (TRO) analysis to measure the direction of gene expression in yeast. They found that the presence of an intron favors the expression of the mRNA over the upstream antisense transcripts (uaRNA) that initiate from the promoter. The authors also found that the intron-mediated enhancement of transcription is dependent on gene looping, which is the physical interaction of the promoter and terminator regions of a gene in a transcription-dependent manner. The authors propose that the intron-dependent gene looping places the terminator-bound factors in the vicinity of the promoter region for termination of the promoter-initiated upstream antisense transcription, thereby conferring promoter directionality. This study provides new insights into the role of introns in gene expression.
 In this study, we have identified a repressor protein that binds to a single nucleotide substitution in intron 3 of IGF2 in pigs, which leads to a 3-fold up-regulation of IGF2 in skeletal muscle. The repressor protein, named ZBED6, is previously unknown, specific for placental mammals, and derived from an exapted DNA transposon. Silencing of Zbed6 in mouse C2C12 myoblasts affected Igf2 expression, cell proliferation, wound healing, and myotube formation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) sequencing using C2C12 cells identified about 2,500 ZBED6 binding sites in the genome, and the deduced consensus motif gave a perfect match with the established binding site in Igf2. Genes associated with ZBED6 binding sites showed a highly significant enrichment for certain Gene Ontology classifications, including development and transcriptional regulation. The phenotypic effects in mutant pigs and ZBED6-silenced C2C12 myoblasts, the extreme sequence conservation, its nucleolar localization, the broad tissue distribution, and the many target genes with essential biological functions suggest that ZBED6 is an important transcription factor in placental mammals, affecting development, cell proliferation, and growth.
 RNA editing is a process that occurs during transcription and involves the conversion of one nucleotide to another. This process is widespread in many organisms, including humans, and can have important functional consequences. However, the mechanisms by which RNA editing is regulated and maintained are not well understood. In this study, the authors used next-generation sequencing technology to investigate the RNA editing process in rhesus macaques, a close relative of humans. They found that the majority of editing sites were A-to-G transitions and that these sites were flanked by sequences that are known to be substrates for the enzyme that catalyzes this type of editing. The authors also found that the levels of editing varied across different tissues and that these variations were associated with the expression of the enzymes that catalyze RNA editing. Overall, the findings of this study provide important insights into the mechanisms by which RNA editing is regulated and maintained in primates.
 In this study, we investigated how the brain decodes sensory information to make perceptual decisions. We found that the brain does not use an optimal decoding strategy, but instead uses a suboptimal strategy that may be due to imprecise read-out of the likelihood function. This suboptimal strategy may explain why previous studies have reported conflicting results on population decoding efficiency. Our findings suggest that the brain may not always use the most efficient decoding strategy, but instead may use a strategy that is good enough for most tasks.
21U RNAs are a class of germline-enriched small RNAs in Caenorhabditis elegans that are terminally methylated, show a 5′ uridine bias, and are dependent upon and bound by the Piwi Argonaute PRG-1. These RNAs target aberrant and coding transcripts broadly via imperfect complementarity, triggering production of secondary endogenous siRNAs. A conserved motif lies upstream of 21U RNA genomic loci, which is bound by forkhead family transcription factors and is required for 21U RNA expression. We have now demonstrated that piRNAs are expressed autonomously in C. elegans. We found that each 21U RNA locus encodes all of the information necessary for driving independent, autonomous transcription from more than 15,000 unique piRNA loci in C. elegans. We also showed that more than 70% of C. elegans piRNAs are preferentially enriched in male or female germline, and that this germline enrichment is enforced by a single nucleotide position within the core motif. Our results suggest that each 21U RNA locus encodes all of the information necessary for driving independent, autonomous transcription from more than 15,000 unique piRNA loci in C. elegans.
 Brucella spp. are gram-negative bacteria that cause a zoonotic disease known as brucellosis in humans and animals. Brucella spp. replicate within host cells in the form of endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-derived vacuoles. The mechanisms by which Brucella obtains a continuous membrane supply for its replication are not well understood. In this study, we found that the unfolded protein response (UPR) pathway, but not the PERK and ATF6 pathways, was activated in a time-dependent manner during Brucella infection. We also identified a novel host factor, Yip1A, for the activation of the IRE1 pathway in response to both tunicamycin treatment and infection with B. abortus. We found that Yip1A is responsible for the phosphorylation of IRE1 through high-order assembly of Ire1 molecules at ER exit sites (ERES) under UPR conditions. In Yip1A-knockdown cells, B. abortus failed to generate the ER-derived vacuoles and remained in endosomal/lysosomal compartments. These results indicate that the activation of the IRE1 pathway and the subsequent formation of ER-derived vacuole formation machineries are critical for B. abortus to establish a safe replication niche, and that Yip1A is indispensable for these processes.
 Tombusviruses are plant viruses that cause significant crop damage. In this study, we found that the tomato bushy stunt virus (TBSV) and the carnation Italian ringspot virus (CIRV) recruit the cellular Vps34 phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) into the large viral replication compartment. The kinase function of Vps34 is critical for TBSV replication, suggesting that phosphatidylinositol 3-phosphate (PI(3)P) phosphoinositide is utilized by TBSV for building the replication compartment. We also observed increased expression of Vps34 and the higher abundance of PI(3)P in the presence of the tombusviral replication proteins, which likely leads to more efficient tombusvirus replication. Overexpression of PI(3)P phosphatase in yeast or plants inhibited TBSV replication on the peroxisomal membranes and CIRV replication on the mitochondrial membranes. Moreover, the purified PI(3)P phosphatase reduced TBSV replicase assembly in a cell-free system. Detection of PI(3)P with antibody or a bioprobe revealed the enrichment of PI(3)P in the replication compartment. Vps34 is directly recruited into the replication compartment through interaction with p33 replication protein. Gene deletion analysis in surrogate yeast host unraveled that TBSV replication requires the vesicle transport function of Vps34. In the absence of Vps34, TBSV cannot efficiently recruit the Rab5-positive early endosomes, which provide PE-rich membranes for membrane biogenesis of the TBSV replication compartment. We found that Vps34 and PI(3)P needed for the stability of the p33 replication protein, which is degraded by the 26S proteasome when PI(3)P abundance was decreased by an inhibitor of Vps34. In summary, Vps34 and PI(3)P are needed for providing the optimal microenvironment for the replication of the peroxisomal TBSV and the mitochondrial CIRV.
Dengue virus ( DENV ) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes dengue fever, a severe flu-like illness. Transmission of DENV from humans to mosquitoes is a critical component of dengue epidemiology. However, examinations of this process have been hampered by a lack of methods that adequately represent natural acquisition of DENV by mosquitoes from humans. In this study, we assessed artificial and natural blood feeding methods based on rates of DENV infection and dissemination within mosquitoes for use in a field-based epidemiological cohort study in Iquitos, Peru. Our study was implemented stepwise between 2011 and 2015. Participants who were 5 years and older with 5 or fewer days of fever were enrolled from ongoing clinic- and neighborhood-based studies on dengue in Iquitos. Wild type, laboratory-reared Aedes aegypti were fed directly on febrile individuals or on blood collected from participants that was either untreated or treated with EDTA. Mosquitoes were tested after approximately 14 days of extrinsic incubation for DENV infection and dissemination. A total of 58 participants, with viremias ranging from 1.3 × 102 to 2.9 × 106 focus-forming units per mL of serum, participated in one or more feeding methods. DENV infection and dissemination rates were not significantly different following direct and indirect-EDTA feeding; however, they were significantly lower for mosquitoes that fed indirectly on blood with no additive. Relative to direct mosquito feeding, infection rates showed greater variation following indirect-EDTA than indirect-no additive feeding. Dissemination rates were similar across all feeding methods. No differences were detected in DENV infection or dissemination rates in mosquitoes fed directly on participants with different dengue illness severity. Our study demonstrates the feasibility of using direct and indirect feeding methods for field-based studies on vector competence. Direct mosquito feeding is preferable in terms of logistical ease, biosecurity, and reliability.
 We used the model organism Caenorhabditis elegans to investigate sensitivity to a group of anti-neoplastic drugs that target topoisomerase II. We found that wild strains of C . elegans vary in their sensitivity to these drugs and that this natural variation is explained by a methionine-to-glutamine substitution in topoisomerase II. We hypothesize that this stabilizing interaction results in increased genomic instability in strains that contain a methionine residue. We also showed that this amino acid difference between the two human topoisomerase isoforms influences cytotoxicity of topoisomerase II poisons in human cell lines. These results explain why hTOPIIα and hTOPIIβ are differentially affected by various poisons and demonstrate the utility of C . elegans in understanding the genetics of drug responses.
 The genetic mechanisms that determine lifespan and aging are poorly understood. Most research has been done on short-lived animals, and it is unclear if these insights can be transferred to long-lived mammals like humans. African mole-rats ( Bathyergidae ) have life expectancies that are multiple times higher than similar sized and phylogenetically closely related rodents. To gain new insights into genetic mechanisms determining mammalian lifespans, we obtained genomic and transcriptomic data from 17 rodent species and scanned 11 evolutionary branches associated with the evolution of enhanced longevity for positively selected genes ( PSGs ). We found that the set of 250 identified PSGs showed in liver of long-lived naked mole-rats and short-lived rats an expression pattern that fits the antagonistic pleiotropy theory of aging. Moreover, we found the PSGs to be enriched for genes known to be related to aging. Among these enrichments were “cellular respiration” and “metal ion homeostasis” , as well as functional terms associated with processes regulated by the mTOR pathway: translation , autophagy and inflammation . Remarkably, among PSGs are RHEB , a regulator of mTOR , and IGF1 , both central components of aging-relevant pathways. Exemplary protein homology modeling suggests functional consequences for amino acid changes under positive selection. Therefore, we conclude that our results provide a meaningful resource for follow-up studies to mechanistically link identified genes and amino acids under positive selection to aging and lifespan determination.
A new transinfection line of Aedes albopictus ( ARwP-M ) was generated by introducing wMel Wolbachia in the ARwP line which had been established previously by replacing wAlbA and wAlbB Wolbachia with the wPip strain . Various infection and fitness parameters were studied by comparing ARwP-M , ARwP and wild-type ( SANG population ) Ae . albopictus sharing the same genetic background . Moreover , the vector competence of ARwP-M related to chikungunya , dengue and zika viruses was evaluated in comparison with ARwP . ARwP-M showed a 100% rate of maternal inheritance of wMel and wPip Wolbachia . Survival , female fecundity and egg fertility did not show to differ between the three Ae . albopictus lines . Crosses between ARwP-M males and SANG females were fully unfertile regardless of male age while egg hatch in reverse crosses increased from 0 to about 17% with SANG males aging from 3 to 17 days . When competing with SANG males for SANG females , ARwP-M males induced a level of sterility significantly higher than that expected for an equal mating competitiveness ( mean Fried index of 1 . 71 instead of 1 ) . The overall Wolbachia density in ARwP-M females was about 15 fold higher than in ARwP , mostly due to the wMel infection . This feature corresponded to a strongly reduced vector competence for chikungunya and dengue viruses ( in both cases , 5 and 0% rates of transmission at 14 and 21 days post infection ) with respect to ARwP females . Results regarding Zika virus did not highlight significant differences between ARwP-M and ARwP . However , none of the tested ARwP-M females was capable at transmitting ZIKV . These findings are expected to promote the exploitation of Wolbachia to suppress the wild-type Ae . albopictus populations .
3D structures of protein-protein interactions reveal that peptide-mediated interactions have a characteristic structure that can be used to identify them. We have developed a method that uses Support Vector Machines to search for unnoticed peptide-mediated interactions among known 3D structures of protein complexes. We have also derived consensus patterns for these interactions, whenever enough information was available, and compared our results with established linear motif patterns and their binding domains. Finally, we cross-validated our newly derived patterns on interactome data and present a list of novel peptide-binding domains, along with their respective high-resolution 3D structures and consensus motifs.
 Environmental enteropathy ( EE ) is a condition that affects the small intestine and can lead to stunted growth, micronutrient malabsorption, and impaired responses to oral vaccines. We used confocal laser endomicroscopy ( CLE ) to study 49 adults with EE in Lusaka, Zambia. CLE images showed virtually ubiquitous small intestinal damage, with epithelial defects predominantly seen at the tips of villi. In multivariate analysis, circulating log-transformed lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) was correlated with cell shedding events and with serum glucagon-like peptide-2 ( GLP-2 ). Zinc uptake from a test dose of 25mg was attenuated in 30/47 ( 64% ) individuals and in multivariate analysis was reduced by HIV , but positively correlated with GLP-2 . There was a U-shaped relationship between circulating LPS and villus surface area. Transcriptomic analysis identified 23 differentially expressed genes in severe enteropathy, including protective peptides and proteins. Confocal endomicroscopy, claudin 4 immunostaining, and histology identify epithelial defects which are probably sites of bacterial translocation, in the presence of which increased epithelial surface area increases the burden of translocation. GLP 2 and other protective peptides may play an important role in mucosal protection in EE.
 Superinfection exclusion ( SIE ) is a phenomenon where a pre-existing virus prevents the replication of a second virus in the same cell. This phenomenon has been observed in many animal and plant viruses. In this study, the authors investigate the mechanism of SIE in turnip crinkle virus ( TCV ) infected cells. They found that the protein p28, one of the two replication proteins encoded by this virus, is exclusively responsible for SIE. The authors show that p28 expressed from a TCV replicon exerts strong SIE to a different TCV replicon. They also found that p28-mediated SIE is dramatically enhanced by C-terminally fused epitope tags or fluorescent proteins, but weakened by N-terminal modifications. The authors propose a model whereby TCV SIE is caused by the formation of multimeric p28 complexes that intercept fresh p28 monomers translated from superinfector genomes, thereby abolishing superinfector replication. This study provides new insights into the mechanism of SIE and suggests a novel target for antiviral therapy.
 Trypanosoma cruzi is a parasite that causes Chagas disease in humans. It is spread through contact with infected insects. A vaccine that has been shown to protect against acute infection is the trans-sialidase (TS) gene. However, long-term protection has not been reported. In this study, the authors tested whether adding a plasmid encoding IL-15 (pIL-15) to a plasmid encoding TS (pTS) would improve the duration of protection. They found that mice vaccinated with both pTS and pIL-15 had significantly better protection against lethal T. cruzi challenges 6 months after vaccination than mice vaccinated with pTS alone. This was due to an increase in the number of TS-specific IFN-γ producing total and CD8+ T cells that were better able to expand after in vitro re-stimulation. The addition of pIL-15 during genetic vaccination greatly improved long-term T cell survival, memory T cell expansion, and long-term protection against T. cruzi.
 Trypanosoma brucei is a parasitic protozoan that causes African sleeping sickness in humans and nagana in cattle. The Polo-like kinase homolog in T. brucei, TbPLK, plays essential roles in basal body segregation, flagellum attachment and cytokinesis. The level of TbPLK protein is tightly controlled, but the underlying mechanism remains elusive. In this study, the authors identified a Cullin-RING ubiquitin ligase composed of Cullin4, the DNA damage-binding protein 1 homolog TbDDB1 and a WD40-repeat protein WDR1 that controls TbPLK abundance in the basal body and the bilobe. WDR1 interacts with the PEST motif in TbPLK and binds to TbDDB1. Depletion of WDR1 inhibits bilobe duplication and basal body segregation, disrupts the assembly of the new flagellum attachment zone filament and detaches the new flagellum. The authors conclude that WDR1 is a TbPLK receptor in the Cullin4-DDB1 ubiquitin ligase complex for degrading TbPLK in the basal body and the bilobe after the G1/S cell cycle transition, thereby promoting bilobe duplication, basal body separation and flagellum-cell body adhesion.
 DDX3X is a protein that helps the immune system fight off infections. It is important for the production of IFN-I, which is a type of cytokine that helps the immune system fight off viruses and bacteria. DDX3X is also important for the production of other cytokines that help the immune system fight off infections. It is also important for the development of immune cells. Mice that lack DDX3X are more susceptible to infections and have altered immune cell populations. This protein is important for both the innate and adaptive immune systems.
 The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans is a model organism for studying the fundamental architectural design of nervous systems. In this study, we used computational network analysis to identify critical components of the C . elegans connectome that are essential for its function. We systematically removed individual neurons and synaptic connections and quantified the effects of each removal on global network properties that influence information processing. Our analysis identified 12 critical neurons and 29 critical synapses for establishing fundamental network properties. These critical components formed circuit-level pathways that provide evidence for the importance of backward locomotion, avoidance behavior, and social feeding behavior. We also identified specific evidence for parallel and serial design elements in the connectome. Our study provides a normative approach to help specify the network structure and dynamics—in which neurons are network nodes, and synapses are connections or edges between the nodes—and quantitatively identify critical components of the C . elegans connectome. These critical components are essential for the efficient information processing and integration that underlies the behavior of the organism. Our study provides a foundation for future research on the fundamental architectural design of nervous systems.
53 is a tumor suppressor protein that binds to DNA response elements ( REs ) to regulate gene expression. We used ChIP-seq to map genome-wide p53 binding in untreated and DXR-treated human lymphoblastoid cells. We found that p53 occupancy was inversely correlated with chromatin accessibility and evolutionary conservation. We also found that p53RE sequence content was highly correlated with genomic occupancy. These results suggest that p53RE sequence content and chromatin context interact to affect p53 binding and gene transactivation.
 Two-component signaling systems are a type of signaling system found in bacteria and some eukaryotes. These systems consist of a histidine kinase (HK) and a response regulator (RR) protein. The HK senses an environmental stimulus and transfers its phosphoryl group to the RR, which then mediates the output of the signaling pathway. The one HK-two RR motif, in which one HK phosphotransfers to two separate RRs, has been identified in several microbial and plant systems. In this study, the authors developed a mathematical model of the one HK-two RR motif and performed both analytical and simulation-based analyses. These analyses revealed that this system is capable of both enhancing signal termination time and implementing a threshold signal-response relationship, meaning that the steady state levels of the phosphorylated output RR remain low until a threshold level of signal is crossed. The authors then verified these dynamics experimentally by in vitro reconstitution of the two-component proteins from the chemotaxis pathway of S . meliloti. Using this in vitro setup, the authors further showed that specific properties of the threshold dynamics can be controlled through the concentrations of the core components and the presence of an auxiliary protein that binds the HK. These findings allow a better understanding of the physiological responses mediated by phosphate sink-containing two-component systems in microbes and plants and will facilitate the design of synthetic threshold devices using two-component signaling proteins.
 We used single-cell RNA sequencing to investigate the heterogeneity in stress tolerance among individual yeast cells. We found that some cells in an isogenic population can survive extreme heat stress, and this heterogeneity is not due to genetic mutations but rather to epigenetic processes. We also discovered that some cells in a culture can survive severe heat stress without mounting a stress response, and this is due to the decoupling of the expression of ribosomal protein genes from the environmental stress response. Our results suggest that cells maintain a cellular filter against decoupled bursts of transcription factor activation but mount a stress response upon coordinated regulation, even in a subset of unstressed cells.
 African trypanosomiasis is a disease caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei and transmitted by the bite of a tsetse fly. It has been shown that parasites accumulate in large numbers in various organs and tissues, including the mouse testis. Whether parasites are protected from the immune system in the male reproductive organ or can be transmitted through sexual route remains unknown. In this study, we show that parasites can be detected by fine needle aspiration cytology of the male reproductive system in mice, and histopathological analysis revealed that T . brucei accumulates in the stroma of the epididymis, epididymal adipose tissue, and fibrous tunics of the testis. No parasites were found in the lumen of intact epididymal ducts or seminiferous tubules of the testis, indicating that the large majority of the parasites are not located in immune-privileged sites. In fact, these parasites are associated with marked inflammatory cell infiltration, parasite degeneration, and severe tissue damage and rupture of epididymal ducts, which may be related with reduced fertility. Overall, we show that just like in the bloodstream and most other tissues, in the male reproductive organs, T . brucei are exposed to a strong immune response. The detection of a very high number of parasites in this organ and its accessibility opens the possibility of using fine needle aspiration cytology as a complementary diagnostic tool in Animal African Trypanosomiasis.
 Chemosensory systems are critical for survival and reproduction in many organisms. In Drosophila melanogaster, a model organism for chemosensory research, large families of chemosensory genes have evolved through repeated processes of gene duplication and diversification. These genes are expressed in a dynamic manner that is influenced by developmental stage, sex, reproductive state, and social context. In this study, we used customized cDNA microarrays to analyze the expression of chemosensory genes in D. melanogaster under various environmental conditions. We found that genes within clusters are independently regulated, while certain subgroups of chemosensory genes are co-regulated in response to environmental and physiological changes. We also identified a small number of exceptionally plastic genes that are differentially expressed across all environmental conditions. Our analysis of covariance of transcript levels across all environmental conditions revealed a finely pixilated modular organization of the chemosensory subgenome, which allows for fine-tuning of the chemoreceptor repertoire in response to ecologically relevant environmental and physiological conditions. Our findings provide insights into the evolution and function of chemosensory systems in D. melanogaster and may have broader implications for other organisms with large families of chemosensory genes.
 The study of human trisomies has revealed a relationship between abnormal meiotic recombination and nondisjunction at maternal meiosis I or II. Specifically, failure to recombine or recombination events located either too near to or too far from the centromere have been linked to the origin of human trisomies. In this work, we initiated studies of crossover-associated proteins (e.g., MLH1) in human fetal oocytes to analyze their number and distribution on nondisjunction-prone human chromosomes and, more generally, to characterize genome-wide levels of recombination in the human female. Our analyses indicate that the number of MLH1 foci is lower than predicted from genetic linkage analysis, but its localization pattern conforms to that expected for a crossover-associated protein. In studies of individual chromosomes, our observations provide evidence for the presence of “vulnerable” crossover configurations in the fetal oocyte, consistent with the idea that these are subsequently translated into nondisjunctional events in the adult oocyte.
 Blood-feeding arthropods, such as mosquitoes, sand flies, and ticks, transmit many diseases that impose serious public health and economic burdens . When a blood-feeding arthropod bites a mammal, it injects saliva containing immunogenic compounds that facilitate feeding . Evidence suggests that immune responses elicited by pre-exposure to arthropod saliva can alter disease progression if the host later becomes infected . Such pre-sensitisation of host immunity has been reported to both exacerbate and limit infection symptoms, depending on the system in question, with potential implications for recovery . To explore if and how immune pre-sensitisation alters the effects of vector control, we developed a general model of vector-borne disease. We found that the abundance of pre-sensitised infected hosts should increase when control efforts moderately increase vector mortality rates. If immune pre-sensitisation leads to more rapid clearance of infection, increasing vector mortality rates may achieve greater than expected disease control. However, when immune pre-sensitisation prolongs the duration of infection, e.g., through mildly symptomatic cases for which treatment is unlikely to be sought, vector control can actually increase the total number of infected hosts. The rising infections may go unnoticed unless active surveillance methods are used to detect such sub-clinical individuals, who could provide long-lasting reservoirs for transmission and suffer long-term health consequences of those sub-clinical infections. Sensitivity analysis suggests that these negative consequences could be mitigated through integrated vector management. While the effect of saliva pre-exposure on acute symptoms is well-studied for leishmaniasis, the immunological and clinical consequences are largely uncharted for other vector-parasite-host combinations. Our work shows that the interplay between vector saliva and host immunity can produce a variety of epidemiological outcomes, depending on the effect of pre-sensitisation on the duration of infection.
 Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite Leishmania amazonensis is a common cause of cutaneous leishmaniasis in Brazil. In this study, we compared the proteomes of amastigotes (the infective form of the parasite) isolated from BALB/c and BALB/c nude mice. BALB/c nude mice lack functional T cells and are a good model for studying the immune response to Leishmania infection. We found 44 differentially expressed proteins between the two strains, including proteins related to oxidative/nitrosative stress and proteases. Some of these proteins are known virulence factors of Leishmania, such as OPB and tryparedoxin peroxidase. We believe our study may help identify potential virulence factors and ways of regulating their expression.
 The study shows that the enzyme Activation-induced cytosine deaminase ( AID ) is regulated by the cell cycle. AID is responsible for initiating immunoglobulin gene diversification and reprogramming CpG methylation in early development. It is also involved in the development of B cell malignancies. The study shows that AID undergoes nuclear degradation more slowly in G1 phase than in S or G2-M phase, and that mutations that affect regulatory phosphorylation or catalytic activity can alter AID stability and abundance. The study also shows that nuclear AID accelerates somatic hypermutation and class switch recombination, but compromises viability in S-G2/M phase cells. The study suggests that cell cycle regulates abundance of nuclear AID and determines the ability of cells to respond to AID-initiated DNA damage. The study also suggests that cell cycle tags may be generally useful for studying DNA repair and recombination and RNA biogenesis, and for genome engineering.
 The study of how microbes degrade and metabolize plant biomass is important to understand carbon flow in the environment, promote healthy human nutrition, and develop industrial processes based on cellulosic bioconversion. Here, we demonstrate a broadly applicable method to analyze how microbes catabolize plant polysaccharides that integrates carbohydrate-active enzyme (CAZyme) assays, RNA sequencing (RNA-seq), and anaerobic growth screening. We apply this method to study how the bacterium Clostridium phytofermentans ferments plant biomass components including glucans, mannans, xylans, galactans, pectins, and arabinans. These polysaccharides are fermented with variable efficiencies, and diauxies prioritize metabolism of preferred substrates. Strand-specific RNA-seq reveals how this bacterium responds to polysaccharides by up-regulating specific groups of CAZymes, transporters, and enzymes to metabolize the constituent sugars. Fifty-six up-regulated CAZymes were purified, and their activities show most polysaccharides are degraded by multiple enzymes, often from the same family, but with divergent rates, specificities, and cellular localizations. CAZymes were then tested in combination to identify synergies between enzymes acting on the same substrate with different catalytic mechanisms. We discuss how these results advance our understanding of how microbes degrade and metabolize plant biomass.

LF is a disease caused by the lymphatic filarial roundworms Wuchereria bancrofti , Brugia malayi and Brugia timori , and transmitted by mosquitos . 16S rRNA gene sequencing is a powerful tool for studying microbial communities, but the analysis of such data can be challenging due to the compositional nature of the data. Compositional data are relative fractions of genes or species, rather than their absolute abundances. This can lead to unreliable results when using standard analysis techniques. We show that the severity of these compositional effects is modulated by community diversity. We developed a new approach, called SparCC, which is capable of estimating correlations from compositional data. Using SparCC, we inferred a rich ecological network connecting hundreds of interacting species across 18 sites on the human body. We estimated that the standard approach yields 3 spurious species-species interactions for each true interaction and misses 60% of the true interactions in the human microbiome data. As predicted, most of the erroneous links are found in the samples with the lowest diversity.
 Lysozyme is a host defense protein found in high concentrations in mucosal surfaces that can kill bacteria by hydrolyzing their peptidoglycan.  Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) is a common colonizer of the upper respiratory tract and causes pneumonia and meningitis.  Two enzymes, PgdA and Adr, have been shown to modify peptidoglycan and increase resistance to lysozyme in vitro.  In this study, the authors used competition experiments to examine the role of lysozyme and peptidoglycan modifications in pneumococcal colonization of the upper respiratory tract.  They found that the wild-type strain outcompeted a mutant strain lacking both PgdA and Adr in mice with normal levels of lysozyme, but not in mice lacking lysozyme.  This suggests that lysozyme and peptidoglycan modifications are important for pneumococcal colonization.  The authors also found that individual mutations in either PgdA or Adr were sufficient to increase sensitivity to lysozyme in vitro, but did not affect colonization in vivo.  This suggests that the combination of peptidoglycan modifications reduces overall fitness, but that this is outweighed by the benefits of resistance to the peptidoglycan degrading activity of lysozyme.  Overall, this study provides important insights into the role of lysozyme and peptidoglycan modifications in pneumococcal colonization and host defense.
 Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral disease that causes a wide range of clinical symptoms, from mild fever to severe hemorrhagic fever and shock. It is a major public health problem in many tropical and subtropical countries, including Brazil. The goal of this study was to investigate the usefulness of NS1 capture tests as an alternative tool to detect DENV in tissue specimens from previously confirmed dengue fatal cases. The study included 23 cases of dengue hemorrhagic fever and 874 fatal cases that occurred in 2002 in Brazil. The overall dengue fatal case diagnosis based on the tissues analyzed by Dengue Early ELISA, Platelia NS1, and the NS1 Ag Strip was 34.7%, 60.8%, and 91.3%, respectively. The NS1 Ag Strip was the most sensitive in liver, lung, kidney, brain, spleen, and thymus when compared to the other two ELISA assays. This study shows the DENV NS1 capture assay as a rapid and valuable approach to postmortem dengue confirmation. With an increasing number of DHF and fatal cases, the availability of new approaches useful for cases confirmation plays an important tool for the disease surveillance.
 Multiple Myeloma (MM) is a blood cancer that affects plasma cells. The study aimed to understand the differences in molecular alterations in MM as a function of self-reported race and genetic ancestry. The study used somatic whole exome, RNA-sequencing, and correlated clinical data from 718 MM patients from the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation CoMMpass study Interim Analysis 9. The study found that BCL7A, BRWD3, and AUTS2 have significantly higher mutation frequencies among African American (AA) cases. These genes are all involved in translocations in B-cell malignancies. The study also found that TP53 and IRF4 have significantly higher mutation frequencies among Caucasian (CA) cases. The study provides rationale for interrogating diverse tumor cohorts to best understand tumor genomics across populations.
 The vast majority of mutations in cancer cells are neutral ( passengers ) and do not affect the reproductive rate of the cell . These passengers can provide important information about the evolutionary history of an individual cancer and serve as a molecular clock . Passengers can also become targets for immunotherapy or confer resistance to treatment . We study the stochastic expansion of a population of cancer cells describing the growth of primary tumors or metastatic lesions . We first analyze the process by looking forward in time and calculate the fixation probabilities and frequencies of successive passenger mutations ordered by their time of appearance . We compute the likelihood of specific evolutionary trees , thereby informing the phylogenetic reconstruction of cancer evolution in individual patients . Next , we derive results looking backward in time: for a given subclonal mutation we estimate the number of cancer cells that were present at the time when that mutation arose . We derive exact formulas for the expected numbers of subclonal mutations of any frequency . Fitting this formula to cancer sequencing data leads to an estimate for the ratio of birth and death rates of cancer cells during the early stages of clonal expansion .
 Huntington's disease (HD) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by an expansion of the polyglutamine (polyQ) repeat in the huntingtin protein. The polyQ region is prone to misfolding and aggregation, leading to the formation of toxic inclusions in neurons. To understand the misfolding and aggregation of the polyQ region, we performed molecular dynamics simulations on monomeric XN1, the first exon of the huntingtin protein, with and without the flanking regions. We found that the flanking regions play a significant role in the misfolding and aggregation of the polyQ region. The polyproline regions in particular, compete with the polyQ region to form PPII helices, which may protect against aggregation. The Nt17 region, which is N-terminal to the polyQ region, can also affect the aggregation of the polyQ region. Our study provides insights into the misfolding and aggregation of the polyQ region in XN1 and highlights the importance of considering the flanking regions in understanding the pathogenesis of HD.
 CRISPRs ( Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats ) are a type of immune defense system found in bacteria and archaea that protects against foreign nucleic acids such as viruses and plasmids. CRISPRs consist of repeats and spacers, which are acquired from foreign DNA and used to target and destroy invading nucleic acids. CRISPRs are highly diverse and abundant in the genomes of bacteria and archaea, and can change rapidly in response to viral predation. The Human Microbiome Project ( HMP ) provides a wealth of shotgun metagenomic data that can be used to study the distribution and diversity of CRISPRs in human-associated microbial communities.
