We developed a targeted assembly strategy to identify CRISPRs in these data, and found that CRISPRs are largely body-site specific and can be used to trace rare species and the virus exposure of individuals. Our work highlights the importance of CRISPRs in understanding the dynamic ecology of microbiomes.
 The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans is a well-established model organism for the study of development and behavior. However, the presence of a bona fide circadian clock in this organism remains unclear. Here, we used genome-wide expression profiling to identify light- and temperature-entrained oscillating transcripts in C . elegans. These transcripts exhibited rhythmic expression with temperature-compensated 24-h periods and were sustained under constant conditions, suggesting that they are under circadian regulation. Light and temperature cycles strongly drove gene expression and appeared to entrain largely nonoverlapping gene sets. We found that mutations in a cyclic nucleotide-gated channel required for sensory transduction abolished both light- and temperature-entrained gene expression, implying that environmental cues act cell nonautonomously to entrain circadian rhythms. Together, these findings demonstrate circadian-regulated transcriptional rhythms in C . elegans and suggest that further analyses in this organism will provide new information about the evolution and function of this biological clock.
 The Saccharomyces cerevisiae RAD3 gene is the homolog of human XPD, an essential gene encoding a DNA helicase of the TFIIH complex involved in both nucleotide excision repair (NER) and transcription. Some mutant alleles of RAD3 (rad3-101 and rad3-102) have partial defects in DNA repair and a strong hyper-recombination (hyper-Rec) phenotype. Previous studies showed that the hyper-Rec phenotype associated with rad3-101 and rad3-102 can be explained as a consequence of persistent single-stranded DNA gaps that are converted to recombinogenic double-strand breaks (DSBs) by replication. In this study, we further characterized these events using a system in which the reciprocal products of mitotic recombination are recovered. Both rad3-101 and rad3-102 elevate the frequency of reciprocal crossovers about 100-fold. Mapping of these events shows that three-quarters of these crossovers reflect DSBs formed at the same positions in both sister chromatids (double sister-chromatid breaks, DSCBs). The remainder reflects DSBs formed in single chromatids (single chromatid breaks, SCBs). The ratio of DSCBs to SCBs is similar to that observed for spontaneous recombination events in wild-type cells. We mapped 216 unselected genomic alterations throughout the genome including crossovers, gene conversions, deletions, and duplications. We found a significant association between the location of these recombination events and regions with elevated gamma-H2AX. In addition, there was a hotspot for deletions and duplications at the IMA2 and HXT11 genes near the left end of chromosome XV. A comparison of these data with our previous analysis of spontaneous mitotic recombination events suggests that a sub-set of spontaneous events in wild-type cells may be initiated by incomplete NER reactions, and that DSCBs, which cannot be repaired by sister-chromatid recombination, are a major source of mitotic recombination between homologous chromosomes.
 The gastric pathogen Helicobacter pylori has a large set of simple sequence repeats ( SSRs ) that constitute contingency loci. Through a slipped strand mispairing mechanism, the SSRs generate heterogeneous populations that facilitate adaptation. In this study, we present a model that explains, in molecular terms, how an intergenically located T-tract, via slipped strand mispairing, operates with a rheostat-like function to fine-tune activity of the promoter that drives expression of the sialic acid binding adhesin SabA. Using T-tract variants in an isogenic strain background, we show that the length of the T-tract generates multiphasic output from the sabA promoter. Consequently, this alters the H . pylori binding to sialyl-Lewis x receptors on gastric mucosa. Fragment length analysis of post-infection isolated clones shows that the T-tract length is a highly variable feature in H . pylori. This mirrors the host-pathogen interplay, where the bacterium generates a set of clones from which the best-fit phenotypes are selected in the host. In silico and functional in vitro analyses revealed that the length of the T-tract affects the local DNA structure and thereby binding of the RNA polymerase, through shifting of the axial alignment between the core promoter and UP-like elements. We identified additional genes in H . pylori with T- or A-tracts positioned similar to that of sabA and show that variations in the tract length likewise acted as rheostats to modulate cognate promoter output. Thus, we propose that this generally applicable mechanism mediated by promoter-proximal SSRs provides an alternative mechanism for transcriptional regulation in bacteria, such as H . pylori, which possesses a limited repertoire of classical trans-acting regulatory factors.
HPVs are a group of viruses that cause cervical cancer and other genital cancers. To establish persistent infection, HPVs must evade the host immune system. One way they do this is by downregulating the expression of a protein called STAT-1. In this study, the authors found that HPVs also downregulate the expression of another protein called STAT-5. They also found that STAT-5 is important for HPV genome amplification, which is necessary for the production of new viral particles. The authors suggest that STAT-5 may be a potential target for new treatments against HPV infections.
 Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi (S . Typhi) is a human-specific pathogen that causes enteric fever (typhoid fever) globally. It can persist in the biliary tract of infected individuals, resulting in a state of asymptomatic chronic carriage. Chronic carriers may act as persistent reservoirs of infection within a community and may introduce infection to susceptible individuals and new communities. Little is known about the interaction between the host and pathogen in the biliary tract of chronic carriers, and there is currently no reliable diagnostic assay to identify asymptomatic S . Typhi carriage. To study host-pathogen interactions in the biliary tract during S . Typhi carriage, we applied an immunoscreening technique called in vivo-induced antigen technology (IVIAT) to identify potential biomarkers unique to carriers. Thirteen S . Typhi antigens that were immunoreactive in carriers but not in healthy individuals from a typhoid endemic area were identified. The identified antigens included a number of putative membrane proteins, lipoproteins, and hemolysin-related proteins. YncE (STY1479), an uncharacterized protein with an ATP-binding motif, gave prominent responses in our screen. The response to YncE in patients whose biliary tract contained S . Typhi was compared to responses in patients whose biliary tract did not contain S . Typhi, patients with acute typhoid fever, and healthy controls residing in a typhoid endemic area. Seven of 10 (70%) chronic carriers, 0 of 8 bile culture-negative controls (0%), 0 of 8 healthy Bangladeshis (0%), and 1 of 8 (12.5%) Bangladeshis with acute typhoid fever had detectable anti-YncE IgG in blood. IgA responses were also present. Further evaluation of YncE and other antigens identified by IVIAT could lead to the development of improved diagnostic assays to identify asymptomatic S . Typhi carriers.
 In this study, we investigated the role of cellular RNA pools produced by homologous genomic loci in defining the transcriptional state of a silenced gene. We found that non-functional alleles of the white gene, unable to produce a coding transcript, could reactivate in trans the expression of a wild type copy of the same gene silenced by heterochromatin. This new epigenetic phenomenon of transcriptional trans-reactivation is heritable, relies on the presence of homologous RNA's, and is affected by mutations in genes involved in post-transcriptional gene silencing. Our data suggest a general new unexpected level of gene expression control mediated by homologous RNA molecules in the context of heterochromatic genes.
 Ticks are blood-sucking insects that use protease inhibitors to prevent the host's immune system from attacking them. These inhibitors are found in the salivary glands and midgut of ticks. Boophilin is a protease inhibitor found in the midgut of the tick Rhipicephalus microplus. It inhibits thrombin, elastase, kallikrein, and FXIa. Boophilin also blocks platelet aggregation, fibrin formation, and clot-bound thrombin in vitro. It also inhibits carotid artery occlusion in vivo triggered by FeCl3 and promotes bleeding according to the mice tail transection method. Boophilin plays a major role in keeping the midgut microenvironment at low hemostatic and inflammatory tonus, which allows ticks to successfully digest a blood meal.
 The gut epithelium is a complex system that plays a key role in maintaining homeostasis and protecting against pathogens. The Spatially Explicit General-purpose Model of Enteric Tissue ( SEGMEnT ) is a computational model that simulates the behavior of gut epithelial cells and their interactions with each other and their environment. SEGMEnT incorporates both healthy and diseased states of the gut, and can be used to explore the effects of different perturbations and treatments on gut function. SEGMEnT has been used to investigate the effects of inflammation on gut morphogenesis, and has been shown to accurately reproduce the effects of different signaling pathway inhibitions on gut architecture. SEGMEnT is a valuable tool for understanding the complex interactions that occur in the gut, and can be used to develop new treatments for a range of gastrointestinal diseases.
 The study aimed to determine the role of insulin action in myeloid cells in obesity-associated insulin resistance. The authors conditionally inactivated the insulin receptor in myeloid lineage cells in mice ( IRΔmyel-mice ) and found that these animals exhibit unaltered glucose metabolism on a normal diet but are protected from the development of obesity-associated insulin resistance upon high fat feeding. Euglycemic, hyperinsulinemic clamp studies demonstrated that this results from decreased basal hepatic glucose production and from increased insulin-stimulated glucose disposal in skeletal muscle. Furthermore, IRΔmyel-mice exhibit decreased concentrations of circulating tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) α and thus reduced c-Jun N-terminal kinase ( JNK ) activity in skeletal muscle upon high fat feeding, reflecting a dramatic reduction of the chronic and systemic low-grade inflammatory state associated with obesity. This is paralleled by a reduced accumulation of macrophages in white adipose tissue due to a pronounced impairment of matrix metalloproteinase ( MMP ) 9 expression and activity in these cells. These data indicate that insulin action in myeloid cells plays an unexpected, critical role in the regulation of macrophage invasion into white adipose tissue and in the development of obesity-associated insulin resistance.
Poxviruses are a group of viruses that cause diseases in humans and animals. They have a complex signaling system that helps them to replicate and spread. In this study, researchers used a technique called experimental evolution to search for new ways that the poxvirus signaling system works. They found that a protein called B12 helps to regulate the signaling system. This protein is not normally active in the poxvirus, but when it is turned on, it helps to control the spread of the virus. The researchers also found that B12 is important for the poxvirus to replicate and spread in cells. This protein is not normally found in other viruses, so it may be a unique feature of poxviruses. Overall, this study provides new insights into how poxviruses work and how they can be controlled.
α-helical peptides are important for many biological processes, including protein folding, membrane penetration, and cell-to-cell communication. However, the folding and aggregation of these peptides are highly sensitive to environmental factors, such as pH, ion strength, and the presence of interfaces. In this study, we used molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the folding and aggregation behavior of two synthetic peptides, LK and EALA, which have built-in secondary amphiphilicity upon forming an α-helix. We found that the peptides are neither random coils in bulk water nor fully formed α-helices, but adopt multiple conformations and secondary structure elements with short lifetimes. These provide a basis for conformation-selection and population-shift upon environmental changes. We also found that the peptides’ aggregation behavior is strongly affected by the presence or absence of an interface, and their response to macroscopic and molecular interfaces can be linked to their inherent α-helical tendencies in bulk water. Our study provides insight into the folding and aggregation of α-helical peptides at interfaces and may help to understand the role of these peptides in biological processes.
iciHHV-6 is a rare genetic condition in which the HHV-6 virus integrates into the telomeres of host chromosomes, resulting in inherited chromosomally integrated HHV-6 ( iciHHV-6 ). The molecular mechanism of this integration remains unknown. In this study, the authors generated recombinant viruses with deleted or modified telomeric repeats ( TMR ) and analyzed their replication and integration properties. They found that the TMR are not essential for HHV-6A replication but are crucial for integration and genome maintenance in latently infected cells. The pTMR play the major role in integration, while the impTMR only make a minor contribution. The authors propose a model for HHV-6A integration based on their findings.
Poxviruses are a family of viruses that produce infectious particles that do not acquire their internal lipid membrane by budding through cellular compartments. Instead, poxvirus immature particles are generated from atypical crescent-shaped precursors whose architecture and composition remain contentious. Here, we describe the 2.6 Å crystal structure of vaccinia virus D13, a key structural component of the outer scaffold of viral crescents. D13 folds into two jellyrolls decorated by a head domain of novel fold. It assembles into trimers that are homologous to the double-barrel capsid proteins of adenovirus and lipid-containing icosahedral viruses. We show that, when tethered onto artificial membranes, D13 forms a honeycomb lattice and assembly products structurally similar to the viral crescents and immature particles. The architecture of the D13 honeycomb lattice and the lipid-remodeling abilities of D13 support a model of assembly that exhibits similarities with the giant mimivirus. Overall, these findings establish that the first committed step of poxvirus morphogenesis utilizes an ancestral lipid-remodeling strategy common to icosahedral DNA viruses infecting all kingdoms of life. Furthermore, D13 is the target of rifampicin and its structure will aid the development of poxvirus assembly inhibitors.
 The root system plays a crucial role in plant growth and survival. The root system architecture is determined by developmental and environmental factors. The root system can only respond to variation in such resources within its inherent developmental limits of growth rate and branching capacity. Optimization of root system architecture through breeding is therefore of particular interest in crops. Our knowledge about the molecular genetic control of root growth and branching has been largely obtained from analyses of the dicotyledon plant model system Arabidopsis thaliana ( Arabidopsis ) through mutagenesis approaches. Many of the genes identified through these efforts encode proteins with regulatory functions, and among them components of plant hormone signaling pathways are particularly preeminent. For example, interference with the auxin-signaling pathway typically impairs primary root elongation or root branching, and in extreme cases even abolishes root formation. The same is true for loss-of-function mutations in genes that encode enzymes involved in tryptophan-dependent auxin biosynthesis. In particular, auxin biosynthesis from tryptophan via indole-3-pyruvic acid ( IPA ) has been shown to be essential for root formation. Two enzyme classes define this pathway: the TRYPTOPHAN AMINOTRANSFERASE OF ARABIDOPSIS 1 ( TAA1 ) and TAA1-RELATED ( TAR ) proteins, which catalyze the conversion of tryptophan to IPA; and the family of YUCCA cytochrome P450s, which catalyze the conversion of IPA to indole-3-acetic acid ( IAA ), the major active form of auxin. Whereas the YUCCA genes were originally identified through a gain-of-function approach that led to auxin over-accumulation, TAA1/TAR genes were identified through loss-of-function approaches. For instance, one study isolated the taa1 mutant because of its root growth resistance to the application of 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic-acid ( ACC ), a rate-limiting precursor for the biosynthesis of another hormone, ethylene. This phenotype arises as a consequence of reduced auxin biosynthesis, which is normally up-regulated by ethylene through induction of TAA1/TAR gene expression. This finding also illustrates the dosage-dependent action of auxin, because although auxin and its perception are essential for root formation and growth, excess auxin application, biosynthesis, or signaling are eventually inhibitory. Indeed, it has been suggested that depending on the species, auxin levels might be supra-optimal for root growth. Phylogenetic analysis has identified bona fide TAA1/TAR homologous genes in monocotyledons, with varying degrees of redundancy. For instance, whereas maize contains five genes of this family, only two are found in both rice and the monocotyledon model system, Brachypodium distachyon ( Brachypodium ). So far, only one TAA1/TAR-related mutant has been identified in monocotyledons, the vanishing tassel 2 ( vt2 ) mutant of maize. Despite the presence of multiple TAA1/TAR homologs in maize, vt2 null mutants display rather severe shoot phenotypes, such as dwarfism, reduced axillary meristem formation, and associated impaired inflorescence development. Free auxin levels are reduced to ca. one third of wild type levels in vt2 mutants, suggesting that VT2 encodes the predominant TAA1/TAR activity in maize. Here we report the isolation and characterization of a Brachypodium mutant in the TAR2-LIKE ( BdTAR2L ) gene. Unlike vt2, this Bdtar2l mutant displays only mild shoot phenotypes. However, we observed dramatic root phenotypes, which surprisingly appear to result from upwardly disturbed auxin homeostasis.
The evolution of gene expression is a fundamental process in biology. In yeast, the rate at which genes diverge in expression is influenced by the organization of their promoter nucleosomes. We artificially selected for high expression of GFP-fused proteins and found that promoter organization did not affect the ability to increase expression. However, the two classes of genes adapted by distinct mechanisms: DPN genes increased expression through duplication of large genomic regions, while OPN genes favored trans mutations not involving duplications. When selection was removed, DPN genes reverted rapidly to wild-type expression levels, while OPN genes did not. Our results suggest that promoter organization impacts on the early evolutionary dynamics and biases the path of long-term evolution.
 The human T-lymphotropic virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) is a retrovirus that causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma ( ATL ) in 2-5% of infected individuals over a course of several decades . HTLV-1 transactivator/oncoprotein Tax is thought to play a key role in ATL development. Tax is a potent activator of HTLV-1 transcription and NF-κB. Tax activates the anaphase promoting complex/cyclosome ( APC/C ) and leads to premature poly-ubiquitination and degradation of mitotic regulators including cyclin B and Skp2. The premature degradation of Skp2 leads to SCFSkp2 inactivation and p27 protein stabilization. The massive surge in p21 and p27 leads to p53- and pRb-independent cellular senescence termed Tax-induced rapid senescence ( Tax-IRS ). Here, we show that the p21-/27-mediated cellular senescence induced by Tax constitutes a cellular checkpoint response towards chronic NF-κB hyper-activation. We further demonstrate that RelA is the primary effector of this pathway and RelA acts upstream of the APC/C and RelB to stabilize p27 protein and p21 mRNA respectively. Our results suggest that impairment to the p21-/27-mediated senescence checkpoint facilitates constitutive NF-κB activation and leukemia development. Importantly, we found that the HTLV-1 anti-sense RNA-encoded bZip protein, HBZ, could mitigate Tax-induced senescence by virtue of its ability to inhibit NF-κB. HBZ has been shown previously to block trans-activation of viral mRNA expression by Tax. Thus, active HTLV-1 replication characterized by potent Tax-mediated LTR and NF-κB activation leads to senescence, while moderation of Tax activities and attenuation of viral replication by HBZ allow HTLV-1-infected T cells to proliferate, expand, and persist.
 The frontal lobe is responsible for decision-making and executive control, but current models do not explain how humans make decisions in uncertain, changing, and open-ended situations.  We propose a new computational model of human executive function that clarifies this issue.  Using behavioral experiments, we show that our model predicts human decisions and their variations across individuals in naturalistic situations.  The model reveals that the frontal function monitors up to three/four concurrent behavioral strategies and infers online their ability to predict action outcomes.  This limitation is compensated by the binary structure of executive control that in ambiguous and unknown situations promotes the exploration and creation of new behavioral strategies.  The results support a model of human frontal function that integrates reasoning, learning, and creative abilities in the service of decision-making and adaptive behavior.
 The liver plays a crucial role in regulating lipid metabolism in the body. The liver X receptor ( LXR ) is a key regulator of lipid metabolism and is a potential drug target for treating atherosclerosis. However, pharmacological activation of LXR can induce unwanted side effects such as increased hepatic triglyceride levels and enlarged very-low-density-lipoprotein ( VLDL ) particles. In this study, we used a new modeling approach called Analysis of Dynamic Adaptations in Parameter Trajectories ( ADAPT ) to investigate the long-term effects of pharmacological activation of LXR on lipid metabolism in the liver. We found that the hepatic capacity to clear cholesterol was reduced upon prolonged treatment, which was predicted by the ADAPT model. We also found that the scavenger receptor class B1 ( SR-B1 ), a receptor that facilitates the uptake of cholesterol from high-density-lipoproteins ( HDL ) by the liver, was downregulated rather than upregulated upon treatment. These findings provide important insights into the long-term effects of pharmacological activation of LXR and may help in the design of new drug targets to treat atherosclerosis.
 The cerebellum is a vital structure for coordination of our multi-segmented bodies and limbs. The spinocerebellar and spino-reticulo-cerebellar systems are major sources of mossy fiber ( MF ) inputs for the cerebellum. These systems receive sensory feedback and motor command signals, which are combined in the neurons of origin. The granule cells ( GrCs ) that receive this input are thresholded with respect to their spike output. The spinal circuitry provides useful recombinations, which can be described as linear projections through aspects of the multi-dimensional sensorimotor input space. The cerebellar cortex enhances the utility of these projections by allowing the Purkinje cell to establish piecewise-linear approximations of non-linear functions. Our hypothesis provides a novel view on the function of the spinal circuitry and cerebellar granule layer, illustrating how the coordinating functions of the cerebellum can be crucially supported by the recombinations performed by the neurons of the spinocerebellar systems.
 We have identified microRNAs in Aedes albopictus mosquitoes and profiled their expression during CHIKV infection. We found that CHIKV infection specifically altered the miRNA profile of a specific set of eight miRNAs. These miRNAs may be playing a role in cellular modification during CHIKV infection. Our study provides an insight about cellular modification by miRNAs during CHIKV infection and the results provide leads for identifying potential candidates for vector based antiviral strategies.
Cystic echinococcosis (CE) is a parasitic infection that affects humans and livestock. It is a significant medical and economic problem in many developing countries, including Iran. The purpose of this study was to determine the monetary burden of CE in Iran. The study estimated the number of surgical cases per year for 2000–2009 at 1,295. The number of asymptomatic individuals living in the country was estimated at 635,232 (95% CI 149,466–1,120,998). The overall annual cost of CE in Iran was estimated at US$232.3 million (95% CI US$103.1–397.8 million), including both direct and indirect costs. The cost associated with human CE was estimated at US$93.39 million (95% CI US$6.1–222.7 million) and the annual cost associated with CE in livestock was estimated at US$132 million (95% CI US$61.8–246.5 million). The cost per surgical human case was estimated at US$1,539. CE has a considerable economic impact on Iran, with the cost of the disease approximated at 0.03% of the country's gross domestic product. Establishment of a CE surveillance system and implementation of a control program are necessary to reduce the economic burden of CE on the country. Cost-benefit analysis of different control programs is recommended, incorporating present knowledge of the economic losses due to CE in Iran.
 Polyomavirus ( MPyV ) is a small circular DNA virus that infects mouse cells and transforms rat cells in culture. We have used deep sequencing to follow MPyV infection of mouse NIH3T6 cells at various times after infection and analyzed both the viral and cellular transcriptomes. Alignment of sequencing reads to the viral genome illustrated the transcriptional profile of the early-to-late switch with both early-strand and late-strand RNAs being transcribed at all time points. A number of novel insights into viral gene expression emerged from these studies, including the demonstration of widespread RNA editing of viral transcripts at late times in infection. By late times in infection, 359 host genes were seen to be significantly upregulated and 857 were downregulated. Gene ontology analysis indicated transcripts involved in translation, metabolism, RNA processing, DNA methylation, and protein turnover were upregulated while transcripts involved in extracellular adhesion, cytoskeleton, zinc finger binding, SH3 domain, and GTPase activation were downregulated. The levels of a number of long noncoding RNAs were also altered. We discuss these results in light of what is currently known about the MPyV life cycle and its effects on host cell growth and metabolism.
 The present study uses a mathematical model to estimate the distance at which a marathon runner will exhaust his or her glycogen stores as a function of running intensity. The model takes into account the runner's aerobic capacity, the size of the glycogen reservoir, and the metabolic cost of running. The study reveals the functional dependencies of the distance required to run glycogen stores to depletion, as well as the fastest pace at which a given distance can be run without exhausting glycogen stores. The study also provides a quantitative approach to establishing an effective midrace fueling strategy, designed to extend the distance a given runner can cover or to increase the maximum pace at which a runner can cover a given distance before exhausting his or her glycogen stores. The study shows how individual physiologic variation as well as the population distribution of aerobic capacities limit marathon finishing times, providing a principled basis for marathon qualifying standards such as those used in the Boston Marathon.
 Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that infects many animals, including humans. Most isolates of Toxoplasma from Europe and North America fall into one of three genetically distinct clonal lineages, type I, II, and III. However, in South America, these strains are rarely isolated and instead a great variety of other strains are found. Toxoplasma strains differ widely in a number of phenotypes in mice, such as virulence, persistence, oral infectivity, migratory capacity, induction of cytokine expression, and modulation of host gene expression. The outcome of toxoplasmosis in patients is also variable and we hypothesize that, besides host and environmental factors, the genotype of the parasite strain plays a major role. To determine if non-canonical Toxoplasma strains have unique interactions with the host cell, we infected murine macrophages with 29 different Toxoplasma strains, representing global diversity, and used RNA-sequencing to determine host and parasite transcriptomes. We identified large differences between strains in the expression level of known parasite effectors and large chromosomal structural variation in some strains. We also identified novel strain-specifically regulated host pathways, including the regulation of the type I interferon response by some atypical strains. IFNβ production by infected cells was associated with parasite killing, independent of interferon gamma activation, and dependent on endosomal Toll-like receptors in macrophages and the cytoplasmic receptor retinoic acid-inducible gene 1 (RIG-I) in fibroblasts. These data provide insight into the host response to a large variety of Toxoplasma strains and, together with the SNPs dataset we recently published for these strains [18], can form the basis for the discovery of novel Toxoplasma effectors.
 Recombination is a key mechanism of genetic diversity in enteroviruses, which cause a wide range of diseases in humans. We have developed a novel reverse genetic system to study recombination in enteroviruses. Our studies suggest that replicative recombination is a biphasic process in which an initial chimeric genome is generated that contains a duplication of up to several hundred nucleotides ( nt . ) of the virus genome. Subsequent replication of these genomes results in a process of resolution in which variants are selected that have undergone an internal deletion to remove the duplicated sequences, resulting in genomes of the expected ( i . e . genomic ) length. These studies provide important insights into the molecular mechanism of recombination in positive strand RNA viruses and suggest a means by which ‘evolution by duplication’ may occur.
 In this study, the authors explore the role of organic cation transporter 3 (Oct3) in the clearance of norepinephrine (NE) in white adipose tissue (WAT). They show that Oct3 is highly expressed in WAT and displays the greatest uptake rate of NE as a selective non-neural route of NE clearance in white adipocytes. The authors further demonstrate that adipocytes express high levels of NE degradation enzymes and that Oct3 governs β-adrenergic receptor (β-AR) activity as a NE recycling transporter in white adipocytes. Under NE administration, adipocyte-specific Oct3 knockout (KO) mice show much stronger browning characteristics and significantly elevated expression of thermogenic and mitochondrial biogenesis genes than control mice. The authors suggest that Oct3 plays an essential role in the browning of WAT during adaptive thermogenesis and that inhibition of Oct3 may provide distinct therapeutic applications by activating energy expenditure pathways.
 HP1 proteins are important regulators of heterochromatin-mediated silencing and chromosome structure in diverse eukaryotes. In mammalian cells, the HP1 family is composed of HP1α, HP1β, and HP1γ. HP1 proteins are detected not only in dense heterochromatic regions but also on active euchromatic genes. HP1 proteins seem to be present both during phases of silencing and transcriptional activity. HP1 proteins contain two very similar domains known as the chromo-domain (CD) and the chromoshadow-domain (CSD) separated by a less structured hinge region. The CSD is required for dimerization and interaction with many molecular partners that share a PXVXL motif. The CD recognizes and binds histone H3 tails methylated on lysine 9 (K9), an epigenetic mark frequently associated with transcriptional repression. In contrast to the strong binding to peptides mimicking histone H3 tails methylated on K9, HP1 proteins bind only weakly to reconstituted methylated nucleosomal arrays. HP1 proteins bind more efficiently to native chromatin in vitro when DNA replication disrupts the histone octamers. HP1α interacts with Brg1 and Brm, the mutually exclusive catalytic subunit of the human SWI/SNF (hSWI/SNF) complex. HP1 proteins have a negative effect on hSWI/SNF-mediated chromatin remodeling. hSWI/SNF activity is involved in the recruitment of HP1 proteins to chromatin.
 RNA molecules fold into specific shapes that are critical for their function. The shape of a particular RNA substring may depend on its surrounding sequence. However, some RNAs such as microRNAs retain their specific structures during biogenesis, which involves extraction of the substructure from a larger structural context. We defined the property of self containment to be the tendency for an RNA sequence to robustly adopt the same optimal secondary structure regardless of whether it exists in isolation or is a substring of a longer sequence of arbitrary nucleotide content. We measured degree of self containment using a scoring method we call the self-containment index and found that miRNA stem loops exhibit high self containment, consistent with the requirement for structural invariance imposed by the miRNA biogenesis pathway. We also found that miRNAs display significantly enhanced self containment compared to other functional RNAs, but we also found a trend toward natural selection for self containment in most functional RNA classes. We suggest that self containment arises out of selection for robustness against perturbations, invariance during biogenesis, and modular composition of structural function. Analysis of self containment will be important for both annotation and design of functional RNAs.
 In this study, we identified four transcription factors that are important for disease resistance against necrotrophic fungal pathogens. We found that mutants defective in any of these TFs displayed increased disease susceptibility to Botrytis cinerea and Plectosphaerella cucumerina. Transcriptome analyses revealed that the mutants shared a common transcriptional signature of 77 up-regulated genes. We characterized several of the up-regulated genes that encode peptides with a secretion signal, which we named PROVIR (for provirulence) factors. Forward and reverse genetic analyses revealed that many of the PROVIRs are important for disease susceptibility of the host to fungal necrotrophs. The TFs and PROVIRs identified in our work thus represent novel genetic determinants for plant disease susceptibility to necrotrophic fungal pathogens.
 The uterine endometrium is receptive to the implanting embryo only during a discrete period in the female reproductive cycle, known as the “window of receptivity” ( WOR ) . The WOR is regulated at the level of gene expression by the ovarian hormones estrogen and progesterone acting via their cognate nuclear receptors, the estrogen receptor ( ESR1 ) and the progesterone receptor ( PGR ) . One of the transcription factors which co-regulates PGR action is the Forkhead Box O1 ( FOXO1 ) . FOXO1 is localized in the nucleus of the luminal ( LE ) and glandular ( GE ) epithelium of the endometrium during the WOR in humans and mice and in the cytoplasm of the murine decidua as pregnancy processes . The conditional ablation of Foxo1 using the PgrCre resulted in infertility due to disrupted implantation of the blastocyst . Surprisingly , the post implantation decidual process was not severely impacted . Analysis of the FOXO1-dependent transcriptome at day 4 . 5 of pseudopregnancy ( PPD 4 . 5 ) identified several important pathways involved in the fetal-maternal crosstalk regulated by FOXO1 . One of the processes altered was the expression of PGR in the uterine epithelium during the WOR . We then demonstrated that expression of FOXO1 and loss of PGR are interrelated and a can serve as a marker for the WOR in mice and humans .
Dengue is a tropical disease caused by the dengue virus and transmitted by female mosquitoes. It is a major public health problem in many countries, including Bangladesh. To better understand the spatial variation in dengue incidence in Bangladesh, we developed a negative binomial generalized linear mixed effects model that accounts for zero-inflation, spatial, and temporal random effects. We found that mean monthly temperature and its interaction with mean monthly diurnal temperature range, lagged by two months, were significantly associated with dengue incidence. Mean monthly rainfall at two months lag was positively associated with dengue incidence. Densely populated districts and districts bordering India or Myanmar had higher incidence than others. The model estimated that 92% of the annual dengue cases occurred between August and September. Cases were identified across the country with 94% in the capital Dhaka. Less than half of the affected districts reported cases as observed from the surveillance data. The proportion reported varied by month with a higher proportion reported in high-incidence districts, but dropped towards the end of high transmission season. Our findings can help target control interventions to areas of highest need at the appropriate time.
 We have found that mice establish a preferred place in a large empty arena, which they mark by performing a tortuous path full of twists and turns. We term this behavior knot-scribbling and have found that it is influenced by stress and arousal. Knot-scribbling could function as a way for mice to obtain an overview of the entire environment, allowing them to re-calibrate their internal map and compass directions.
 Invasive fungal infections are a major cause of death worldwide, and there is a need for new antifungal drugs. In this study, we identified a new ergoline compound, NGx04, that inhibits the growth of Candida albicans, Cryptococcus neoformans, and Aspergillus fumigatus. NGx04 targets the lipid transfer protein Sec14p, which is essential for the growth of these fungi. We used high-resolution chemogenomics to identify the binding site of NGx04 in Sec14p and found that NGx04 competes with the lipid substrates of Sec14p. We also found that NGx04 is fungicidal against a fluconazole-resistant strain of C. neoformans. Our study provides genetic evidence that NGx04 inhibits fungal Sec14p and initial data supporting NGx04 as a novel antifungal starting point.
 Schistosomiasis is a debilitating disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The current treatment relies on a single drug, praziquantel, which has been in use for decades. However, the widespread use of praziquantel has led to the emergence of drug-resistant parasites, highlighting the need for new antischistosomal drugs. In this study, we found that the antimalarial drug mefloquine has promising antischistosomal properties in mice. A single dose of mefloquine (200 or 400 mg/kg) administered orally to mice infected with adult Schistosoma mansoni or S. japonicum resulted in high or complete total and female worm burden reductions (72.3%–100%). Importantly, high worm burden reductions were also observed for young developing stages of S. mansoni and S. japonicum harbored in the mouse. Both mefloquine enantiomers resulted in high and comparable total and female worm burden reductions when given to mice with either a sub-patent or patent S. mansoni infection. Our findings hold promise for the development of a novel antischistosomal drug based on an aminoalcohol functionality. Further in vitro and in vivo studies have been launched to elucidate the possible mechanism of action and to study the effect of mefloquine on S. haematobium and other trematodes. It will be interesting to investigate whether mefloquine, which is widely and effectively used for the treatment of malaria, has an impact on schistosomiasis in areas where both malaria and schistosomiasis co-exist.
 Podoconiosis is a non-infectious disease that causes massive swelling of the lower legs. It was identified as a neglected tropical disease by the World Health Organization in 2011. The geographical distribution of podoconiosis is incomplete, and this study aimed to map its distribution in Cameroon. The study used a multi-stage sampling design with stratification of the country by environmental risk of podoconiosis. Seven hundred and sixty-two villages from forty health districts in ten regions of Cameroon were surveyed. All individuals aged 15 years or older in the village were screened for lymphedema, and a clinical algorithm was used to diagnose podoconiosis. Individuals with lymphedema were tested for circulating Wuchereria bancrofti antigen and specific IgG4 using the Alere Filariasis Test Strips (FTS) test and the Standard Diagnostics (SD) BIOLINE lymphatic filariasis IgG4 test (Wb123) respectively, in addition to thick blood films. Presence of DNA specific to W. bancrofti was checked on night blood using a qPCR technique. Overall, 10,178 individuals from 4,603 households participated in the study. In total, 83 individuals with lymphedema were identified. Of the 83 individuals with lymphedema, two were found to be FTS positive and all were negative using the Wb123 test. No microfilaria of W. bancrofti were found in the night blood of any individual with clinical lymphedema. None were found to be positive for W. bancrofti using qPCR. Of the two FTS positive cases, one was positive for Mansonella perstans DNA, while the other harbored Loa loa microfilaria. Overall, 52 people with podoconiosis were identified after applying the clinical algorithm. The overall prevalence of podoconiosis was found to be 0.5% (95% confidence interval CI; 0.4–0.7). At least one case of podoconiosis was found in every region of Cameroon except the two surveyed villages in Adamawa. Of the 40 health districts surveyed, 17 districts had no cases of podoconiosis; in 15 districts, mean prevalence was between 0.2% and 1.0%; and in the remaining eight, mean prevalence was between 1.2% and 2.7%. Our investigation has demonstrated low prevalence but almost nationwide distribution of podoconiosis in Cameroon. Designing a podoconiosis control program is a vital next step. A health system response to the burden of podoconiosis is important through case surveillance and morbidity management services.
 The ovary of the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster is a well-studied model for understanding the biology of stem cells. The stem cells in the ovary, called germline stem cells (GSCs), are housed in a specialized niche that provides them with the necessary signals to maintain their stemness. As the fly ages, the number of GSCs in the niche decreases, but the reasons for this decline are not well understood. In this study, we found that Notch signaling, a pathway that plays a crucial role in stem cell biology, is increased in GSCs as they age. This increase in Notch signaling leads to the loss of GSCs from the niche. We also found that Notch signaling in the niche cells, which maintain the integrity of the niche, is decreased as the fly ages. These findings suggest that Notch signaling plays a key role in regulating the niche residency of GSCs during aging.
 The human herpesviruses (HHVs) are a group of viruses that cause a wide range of diseases, including chickenpox, shingles, and mononucleosis. These viruses have a unique feature in that they encode their own protein kinases, which are important for viral replication and gene expression. In this study, the authors investigated the function of a group of these protein kinases called the conserved herpesvirus protein kinases (CHPKs). They found that the CHPKs from the beta- and gamma-herpesvirus families had Cdk-like activity, meaning they could phosphorylate the cellular retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor protein and lamin A/C proteins, which are also substrates of cellular Cdks. They also found that the CHPKs could disrupt the nuclear lamina. However, the CHPKs from the alpha-herpesvirus family did not have these functions. The authors conclude that the CHPKs are important for viral replication and gene expression, and that they may be potential targets for antiviral drugs.
 Melioidosis is a bacterial infection caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei . It is a rare but serious disease that can be fatal if left untreated. The disease is present in many tropical countries, but the global distribution of B. pseudomallei in the environment is not well understood. To address this, a working party was formed to develop consensus guidelines for the detection of environmental B. pseudomallei. The guidelines aim to reduce the probability of false-negative results and provide a low-tech methodology that is applicable in both developed and developing countries. The proposed guidelines provide the basis for the development of an accurate and comprehensive global map of environmental B. pseudomallei.
 The mechanism of membrane fusion by “class II” viral fusion proteins involves large-scale domain rearrangements of the envelope glycoprotein ( E ) and a transition from dimers to trimers . The rearrangement is believed to proceed by an outward rotation of the E ectodomain after loss of the dimer interface , followed by a reassociation into extended trimers . The ∼55-aa-residue , membrane proximal “stem” can then zip up along domain II , bringing together the transmembrane segments of the C-terminus and the fusion loops at the tip of domain II . We find that peptides derived from the stem of dengue-virus E bind stem-less E trimer , which models a conformational intermediate . In vitro assays demonstrate that these peptides specifically block viral fusion . The peptides inhibit infectivity with potency proportional to their affinity for the conformational intermediate , even when free peptide is removed from a preincubated inoculum before infecting cells . We conclude that peptides bind virions before attachment and are carried with virions into endosomes , the compartment in which acidification initiates fusion . Binding depends on particle dynamics , as there is no inhibition of infectivity if preincubation and separation are at 4°C rather than 37°C . We propose a two-step model for the mechanism of fusion inhibition . Targeting a viral entry pathway can be an effective way to block infection . Our data , which support and extend proposed mechanisms for how the E conformational change promotes membrane fusion , suggest strategies for inhibiting flavivirus entry .
 Cholera is a major global health concern, with an estimated 4 million cases and 95,000 deaths annually. Recent outbreaks in Haiti and Yemen highlight the need for rapid and accurate molecular analysis of Vibrio cholerae strains. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) of stool specimens enriched in alkaline peptone water (APW) and V. cholerae culture isolates spotted on filter paper provides valuable molecular epidemiological sequence information on V. cholerae strains from remote, low-resource settings. WGS identified the presence of co-infecting pathogens while providing rare insight into the specific V. cholerae strains causing outbreaks in cholera-endemic areas. This study demonstrates the potential of WGS to inform public health decisions by providing essential information on cholera genotype and co-infection burden.
 Epithelial cells are a type of cell that form a layer of tissue that lines organs and provides protection and support. These cells have a specific arrangement of proteins on their surface that helps them function properly. However, the mechanisms that control the arrangement of these proteins are not well understood. In this study, researchers used a genetic screen to identify proteins that are important for the proper arrangement of these proteins. They found that a protein called Dynein is important for the proper arrangement of these proteins. Dynein is a motor protein that moves cargo along microtubules. The researchers found that Dynein works with a protein called Stardust to move a specific type of mRNA to the apical surface of the epithelial cells. This mRNA codes for a protein called Crumbs, which is important for the proper arrangement of proteins on the surface of the epithelial cells. The researchers also found that the arrangement of these proteins changes as the epithelial cells mature. This study provides new insights into how the proper arrangement of proteins on the surface of epithelial cells is controlled.
 Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by the protozoan Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of infected sand flies and can cause a range of symptoms depending on the species of Leishmania and the host. While the reproductive cycle of Leishmania is thought to be mostly clonal, recent studies have suggested that sexual reproduction may also occur. In this study, the authors used transgenic L. infantum lines expressing drug resistance markers linked to green and red fluorescent reporters to investigate whether these parasites can recognize and mate with the same genotype. They found that yellow hybrid progeny was produced when individuals from the same species were fed to sand flies together, suggesting that intraclonal genetic exchange can occur in L. infantum. The hybrid progeny was stable throughout the parasite life cycle and had reduced virulence in mice. These findings provide evidence for intraclonal genetic exchange in L. infantum and suggest that this may be a common occurrence in other Leishmania species.
 Leishmaniasis is a major health problem in Ethiopia, caused by different parasites transmitted by different vectors in different regions. We here characterize 63 L. donovani strains isolated from patients in north and south Ethiopia using PCR targeting three regions: ITS1, cpb, and HASPB. ITS1- and cpb- PCR identified these strains as L. donovani. The k26- PCR amplicon size varied depending on the patient's geographic origin. Most strains from northwestern Ethiopia (36/40) produced a 290 bp product with a minority (4/40) giving a 410 bp amplicon. All of the latter strains were isolated from patients with HIV-VL co-infections, while the former group contained both VL and HIV-VL co-infected patients. Almost all the strains (20/23) from southwestern Ethiopia produced a 450 bp amplicon with smaller products (290 or 360 bp) only observed for three strains. Sudanese strains produced amplicons identical (290 bp) to those found in northwestern Ethiopia; while Kenyan strains gave larger PCR products (500 and 650 bp). HASPB repeat region (k26) shows considerable polymorphism among L. donovani strains from different regions. This should be taken into account when designing diagnostic assays and vaccines based on this antigen.
 HIV-1 is a highly diverse virus that is constantly evolving due to its high mutation rate and tendency to switch between different RNA templates during replication. This diversity is partitioned into distinct phylogenetic clusters known as subtypes and circulating recombinant forms (CRFs). It is widely assumed that some of these recombinant forms have novel properties that led to their prevalence, particularly in the case of CRFs. In this study, we generated a probabilistic model of HIV-1 copy-choice recombination and compared the predicted breakpoint distribution to the distribution from the HIV/AIDS pandemic. We found that the observed frequencies of inter-subtype recombination were predicted accurately by our model across much of the HIV-1 genome, indicating that in these regions a probabilistic model dependent on local sequence identity is sufficient to explain breakpoint locations. However, in regions where there is a significant over- or under-representation of breakpoints, we infer natural selection to be influencing the recombination pattern. Our findings thus provide the first clear indication of the existence of a specific portion of the genome that deviates from a probabilistic null model for recombination. This suggests that, despite the wide diversity of recombinant forms seen in the viral population, only a minority of recombination events appear to be of significance to the evolution of HIV-1.
 Computational modeling is increasingly used in neuroscience research to analyze experimental data. However, statistical methods used to address two interdependent problems, parameter estimation and model comparison, have limitations. Here, we propose a hierarchical Bayesian inference (HBI) framework that addresses both problems simultaneously. Our framework has several advantages over previous methods, including smaller errors in parameter estimation and robustness against outliers in model comparison. Furthermore, our fully Bayesian approach enables researchers to make inference on group-level parameters by performing HBI t-test. We demonstrate the advantages of our method through synthetic and empirical datasets.
The brainstem is a complex structure that plays a crucial role in sensory and motor functions. During development, the hindbrain becomes subdivided into rhombomeres (r), which are serially repeated segments of progenitor cells. Individual rhombomeres give rise to distinct portions of sensory and motor columns, and topographic patterns of connectivity. In this study, the authors show that r4 contributes to functionally linked sensory and motor components, including the ventral nucleus of lateral lemniscus, posterior ventral cochlear nuclei, and motor olivocochlear neurons. Assembly of the r4-derived auditory components is involved in sound perception and depends on regulatory interactions between Hoxb1 and Hoxb2. In Hoxb1 and Hoxb2 mutant mice, the transmission of low-level auditory stimuli is lost, resulting in hearing impairments. On the other hand, Hoxa2 regulates the Rig1 axon guidance receptor and controls contralateral projections from the anterior ventral cochlear nuclei to the medial nucleus of the trapezoid body, a circuit involved in sound localization. Thus, individual rhombomeres and their associated Hox codes control the assembly of distinct functionally segregated sub-circuits in the developing auditory brainstem.
 The marine bacterium Saccharophagus degradans strain 2-40 ( Sde 2-40 ) is a newly discovered species that can degrade a wide range of complex polysaccharides, including cellulose, chitin, and pectin. Its complete genome sequence has been determined, revealing an unusually large number of enzymes that degrade these polysaccharides. Many of these enzymes have unusual architecture, including novel combinations of catalytic and substrate-binding modules. We hypothesize that these features are adaptations that facilitate depolymerization of complex polysaccharides in the marine environment. Sde 2-40 is the first sequenced genome of a marine bacterium that can degrade plant cell walls, an important component of the carbon cycle that is not well-characterized in the marine environment. The genome of Sde 2-40 contains 4008 genes in a single replicon consisting of 5.06 Mb. The genome annotation reveals that Sde 2-40 is unique in its variety of depolymerases and unusual in its number of open reading frames coding for complex polysaccharide depolymerases. These carbohydrases and related proteins, comprising 10% of the genome, contain extraordinary modularity, interesting architecture, and a remarkable proportion of membrane targeting domains. Although such an arrangement is limited to few taxa, the bacteria within these taxa appear to be widely distributed in marine and estuarine waters.
 Japanese Encephalitis virus ( JEV ) is a zoonotic flavivirus that causes viral neurological infections in children throughout Asia . The virus has shifted from genotype III ( GIII ) to genotype I ( GI ) in recent years, but the exact mechanism of this displacement is unknown. We used Cx . pipiens mosquitoes from China as an in vivo mosquito model to explore if mosquitoes played a potential role in JEV genotype shift. We exposed female Cx . pipiens mosquitoes orally to either GI or GIII JEV strains. Midgut, whole mosquitoes, secondary organs, and salivary glands of JEV-infected mosquitoes were collected at 7 and 14 days of post infection ( dpi ) and subjected to measure the infection rate, replication kinetics, dissemination rate, and transmission potential of the infected JEV strains in Cx . pipiens mosquitoes by 50% tissue culture infective dose assay. We found that Cx . pipiens mosquitoes were competent vector for both GI and GIII JEV infection, with similar infection rates, growth kinetics, dissemination rates, and transmission rates. Our experiment data demonstrated that GI and GIII viruses have similar infectivity in Cx . pipiens mosquitoes, suggesting that Cx . pipiens mosquitoes from China may not play a critical role in JEV genotype shift. Although the current data were obtained solely from Cx . pipiens mosquitoes, it is likely that the conclusion drawn could be extrapolated to the role of mosquitoes in JEV genotype shift.
 Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral disease that affects millions of people worldwide, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions. Malaysia has experienced large dengue outbreaks in recent years, with a significant increase in cases from 2000 to 2014. We conducted a retrospective review of all dengue deaths that occurred in Malaysia between 2013 and 2014. Our study found that the mean age of dengue deaths was 40.7 years, with half of the cases being adults and 72.5% of them having co-morbidities such as diabetes and hypertension. The most common warning signs reported were lethargy and vomiting, with lethargy being more common in children and abdominal pain being more common in adults. However, 22.4% of the cases did not have any warning signs. Only 34% of the cases were suspected of dengue illness at their initial presentation. More adults developed severe plasma leakage, and more than half of the cases suffered from multi-organ involvement. Dengue shock syndrome was the leading cause of death, regardless of age groups. Our study highlights the dynamic progression of severe dengue infections and the importance of early recognition and aggressive intervention to prevent deaths.
 In this study, we investigated the relationship between insulin signaling and attractiveness in the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster. We found that insulin signaling in the fat body and ovarian follicle cells affects female attractiveness, and that these effects are opposite in direction. We also found that modulation of insulin signaling in the fat body and ovarian follicle cells affects fecundity in the corresponding direction. Furthermore, we found that the cues that reflect insulin pathway activity are distinct in the fat body and ovarian follicle cells. Our results suggest that the fruit fly uses a combination of signals from different tissues to assess attractiveness and fecundity.
 The Ebola virus disease ( EVD ) epidemic in West Africa in 2013–2015 spread heterogeneously across the three hardest-hit countries Guinea , Liberia and Sierra Leone . To investigate district-level transmissibility of EVD , we applied a statistical modelling approach to estimate the basic reproduction number ( R0 ) for each affected district and each country using weekly incident case numbers . We estimated growth rates during the early exponential phase of the outbreak using exponential regression of the case counts on the first eight weeks since onset . To take into account the heterogeneity between and within countries , we fitted a mixed effects model and calculated R0 based on the predicted individual growth rates and the reported serial interval distribution . At district level , R0 ranged from 0 . 36 ( Dubréka ) to 1 . 72 ( Beyla ) in Guinea , from 0 . 53 ( Maryland ) to 3 . 37 ( Margibi ) in Liberia and from 1 . 14 ( Koinadugu ) to 2 . 73 ( Western Rural ) in Sierra Leone . At national level , we estimated an R0 of 0 . 97 ( 95% CI 0 . 77–1 . 18 ) for Guinea , 1 . 26 ( 95% CI 0 . 98–1 . 55 ) for Liberia and 1 . 66 ( 95% CI 1 . 32–2 . 00 ) for Sierra Leone . Socio-demographic variables related to urbanisation such as high population density and high wealth index were found positively associated with R0 suggesting that the consequences of fast urban growth in West Africa may have contributed to the increased spread of EVD .
 The evolutionary rate of proteins is a topic of great interest in the field of biology. Several factors have been proposed to influence the evolutionary rate of proteins, including protein designability, solvent exposure, and age. However, it is unclear how these factors interact to determine the evolutionary rate of proteins. In this study, we used a large set of one-to-one orthologs between human and mouse proteins with mapped PDB structures to investigate the interplay of structural properties and evolutionary age as determinants of protein evolutionary rate. We found that previously observed structural correlations also hold within each age group, including relationships between solvent accessibility, designability, and evolutionary rates. However, age modulates the relationship between solvent accessibility and rate. Additionally, younger proteins tend to evolve faster than older ones, despite being less designable. We show that previously reported relationships between age and rate cannot be explained by structural biases among age groups. Finally, we introduce a knowledge-based potential function to study the stability of proteins through large-scale computation. We find that older proteins are more stable for their native structure and more robust to mutations than younger ones. Our results underscore that several determinants, both intrinsic and historical, can interact to determine rates of protein evolution.
 Polycomb repressive complex 2 ( PRC2 ) is a protein complex that regulates gene expression during development and differentiation. It contains several core components, including Suz12, Ezh2, and Eed, which trimethylate lysine 27 of histone H3 ( H3K27me3 ). Polycomb-like ( Pcl ) proteins are accessory proteins that modulate PRC2 function. Here, we show that Pcl3 is a component of PRC2 that promotes ESC self-renewal. We found that Pcl3 interacts with core PRC2 components and promotes H3K27me3 formation. Depletion of Pcl3 in ESCs causes decreased H3K27me3 and Suz12 binding to the genome, indicating that Pcl3 regulates PRC2 binding at diverse target genes. Pcl3 localizes with Suz12 at a subset of PRC2 targets, including genes and microRNAs associated with differentiation and development. We also identified two GC-rich binding motifs that are enriched at Pcl3-dependent PRC2 targets, indicating that Pcl3 promotes PRC2 binding at CpG islands. Taken together, these results reveal that Pcl3 is an important regulator of PRC2 at a subset of target genes.
 In this study, the authors investigate how feeding state affects the expression of a chemoreceptor gene in the ADL sensory neurons of Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that the expression of the chemoreceptor gene srh-234 is regulated by the transcription factor MEF-2 in a feeding-state dependent manner. They also found that MEF-2 acts together with bHLH transcription factors to regulate srh-234 expression. The authors show that HLH-2, HLH-3, and HLH-4 are expressed in ADL neurons and regulate srh-234 expression, while HLH-30 is expressed in the intestine and regulates srh-234 expression remotely. They also show that insulin signaling in ADL neurons is required for this non-cell-autonomous regulation of srh-234 expression. The authors suggest that MEF-2 and bHLH transcriptional factors link feeding state conditions via insulin signaling to the regulation of chemoreceptor genes in chemosensory neurons.
 Buruli ulcer ( BU ) is a destructive skin condition caused by infection with the environmental bacterium Mycobacterium ulcerans . The mode of transmission of M . ulcerans is not completely understood, but several studies have explored the role of biting insects. In this study, we tested for an association between the detection of M . ulcerans in mosquitoes and the risk of BU disease in humans in an endemic area of southeastern Australia. We found a strong dose-response relationship between the detection of M . ulcerans in mosquitoes and the risk of human disease ( r , 0.99; 95% CI , 0.92–0.99; p<0.001 ). The results of this study strengthen the hypothesis that mosquitoes are involved in the transmission of M . ulcerans in southeastern Australia. This has implications for the development of intervention strategies to control and prevent BU.
 The rat demyelination ( dmy ) mutation is a unique model for studying the maintenance of myelin in the central nervous system ( CNS ). We have now identified the causative gene as Mrs2, which encodes a protein that is an essential component of the major Mg2+ influx system in mitochondria. This protein is expressed in neurons rather than oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for myelin production. Our findings suggest that the maintenance of myelin has a different mechanism from its initial production and that Mg2+ homeostasis in CNS mitochondria is essential for the maintenance of myelin. This discovery provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying myelin maintenance and may lead to new therapies for demyelinating diseases.
 Microarray gene expression signatures have the potential to be powerful tools for patient stratification, diagnosis of disease, prognosis of survival, assessment of risk group, and selection of treatment. However, these signatures need to be communicated to other healthcare centers with data for external evaluation and ultimately to practitioners for use in clinical routine. This requires unambiguous documentation of the signature. We found that discrepancy between study-internal and study-external diagnoses can be as frequent as 30% and 18% respectively. By using the proposed documentation by value strategy, which documents quantitative preprocessing information, the median discrepancy was reduced to 1%. Our approach reduces ambiguity of diagnoses to a minimum.
 Amyloid fibrils are protein structures that are involved in a variety of diseases, including Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. In bacteria, amyloid fibrils are involved in biofilm formation, which is a process by which bacteria form communities that are resistant to environmental stressors. In this study, the authors present the crystal structures of amyloid-forming segments from the major curli subunit, CsgA, revealing steric zipper fibrils of tightly mated β-sheets. They also found that D-enantiomeric peptides, originally developed to interfere with Alzheimer's disease-associated amyloid-β, inhibited CsgA fibrillation and reduced biofilm formation in Salmonella typhimurium. The authors suggest that their findings provide structural insights into a biofilm-related amyloid, which could have bearing on amyloid diseases by cross-seeding and the creation of transmissible agents.
 Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a serious disease caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) and is endemic in most of Asia. It is a significant public health threat, with high case fatality rates and often significant neurologic sequelae among survivors. The epidemiology of JE in the Philippines is not well defined. To support consideration of JE vaccine for introduction into the national schedule in the Philippines, we conducted a systematic literature review and summarized JE surveillance data from 2011 to 2014. We identified 29 published reports and presentations on JE in the Philippines, including 5 serologic surveys, 18 reports of clinical cases, and 8 animal studies. JEV was the causative agent in 7% to 18% of cases of clinical meningitis and encephalitis combined, and 16% to 40% of clinical encephalitis cases. JE predominantly affected children under 15 years of age and 6% to 7% of cases resulted in death. Surveillance data from January 2011 to March 2014 identified 73 (15%) laboratory-confirmed JE cases out of 497 cases tested. This comprehensive review demonstrates the endemicity and extensive geographic range of JE in the Philippines, and supports the use of JE vaccine in the country. Continued and improved surveillance with laboratory confirmation is needed to systematically quantify the burden of JE, to provide information that can guide prioritization of high-risk areas in the country and determination of appropriate age and schedule of vaccine introduction, and to measure the impact of preventive measures including immunization against this important public health threat.
 We developed a computational model to study the evolution of metabolic robustness in bacteria. Our model combines two existing methods to predict the minimal set of externally acquired compounds and the set of all possible metabolites that can be produced from a set of compounds. We used this model to study the level of robustness across bacterial species and decoupled between robustness which is condition-dependent and robustness which is condition-independent. We found that environmental robustness is associated with the intrinsic metabolic capacities of a species, such as higher growth rates or the production of secondary metabolites. We also found that environmental robustness is a byproduct of the evolution of metabolic networks, and that it is not directly selected for. Our model provides a new framework for studying the evolution of metabolic robustness and its relationship to other adaptive traits.
The study aimed to investigate the effects of schistosoma infection on responses to childhood measles catch-up immunisation and the effect of praziquantel treatment on this outcome in a randomised trial. The Immune Modulation and Childhood Immunisation (IMoChI) study was based in Entebbe, Uganda. Children aged 3–5 years (193 S. mansoni-infected and 61 uninfected) were enrolled. Infected children were randomised in a 1:1:1 ratio to receive praziquantel 2 weeks before, at time of, or 1 week after measles catch-up immunisation. Plasma anti-measles IgG was measured at enrolment, 1 week and 24 weeks after measles immunisation. Primary outcomes were IgG levels and percentage of participants with levels considered protective against measles. Anti-measles IgG levels increased following immunisation, but at 1 week post-immunisation S. mansoni-infected, compared to uninfected, children had lower levels of anti-measles IgG (aGMR 0.4 [95% CI 0.2–0.7] ) and the percentage with protective antibody levels was also lower (aOR 0.1 [0–0.9]). Among S. mansoni-infected children, anti-measles IgG one week post-immunisation was higher among those treated with praziquantel than among those who were not yet treated (treatment before immunisation aGMR 2.3 [1.5–4.8]; treatment at immunisation aGMR 1.8 [1.1–3.5]). At 24 weeks post-immunisation, IgG levels did not differ between the trial groups, but tended to be lower among previously-infected children who were still S. mansoni stool-positive than among those who became stool-negative. The findings suggest that S. mansoni infection among pre-school children is associated with a reduced antibody response to catch-up measles immunisation, and that praziquantel treatment improves the response. S. mansoni infection may contribute to impaired vaccine responses in endemic populations; effective schistosomiasis control may be beneficial for vaccine efficacy. This should be further explored.
 The evolution of bacterial populations has become better understood through large-scale sequencing of population samples. However, traditional statistical methods for evolutionary inference, such as phylogenetic analysis, are associated with several difficulties under such an extensive sampling scenario, particularly when a considerable amount of recombination is anticipated. To meet the needs of large-scale analyses of population structure for bacteria, we introduce several statistical tools for the detection and representation of recombination between populations. We also introduce a model-based description of the shape of a population in sequence space, in terms of its molecular variability and affinity towards other populations. Extensive real data from the genus Neisseria are utilized to demonstrate the potential of an approach where these population genetic tools are combined with an phylogenetic analysis. The statistical tools introduced here are freely available in BAPS 5 software, which can be downloaded from http://web.abo.fi/fak/mnf/mate/jc/software/baps.html.
20 Hz beta rhythms have been linked to attention and are thought to be generated in higher cognitive areas. A computational model of sensory cortical areas was built to investigate the functional roles of beta rhythms and the underlying mechanisms. The simulation results show that top-down beta rhythms can activate ascending synaptic projections from L5 to L4 and L2/3, which are responsible for biased competition in superficial layers. Slow-inhibitory interneurons were shown to resonate to the 20 Hz input and modulate the activity in superficial layers in an attention-related manner. The predicted critical roles of these cells in attentional gain provide a potential mechanism by which cholinergic drive can support selective attention.
 The emergence of new human pathogens is a growing concern in public health. Accurate estimates of epidemic parameters during the initial phase of disease emergence are crucial for effective public health policy decisions. However, this is challenging due to the stochastic nature of the epidemic dynamics and the limited availability of data. In this study, we propose a novel calibration and prediction framework for stochastic compartmental transmission models of epidemics. Our method, Multiple Shooting for Stochastic systems (MSS), uses a linear noise approximation to describe the size of fluctuations and updates the belief about the true epidemic state with each new observation. We compare the performance of MSS with three benchmark methods and find that MSS significantly outperforms them in most epidemic scenarios. Our method provides accurate estimates of key epidemic parameters and can predict the number and timing of future hospitalizations and the overall attack rate. These findings suggest that MSS is a promising tool for calibrating and predicting stochastic epidemic models using limited data.
 In the present work, we show that human visual perception is constantly shaped by two contrasting forces exerted by sensory adaptation and past decisions. In a series of experiments, we used multilevel modeling and cross-validation approaches to investigate the impact of previous stimuli and decisions on behavioral reports during adjustment and forced-choice tasks. Our results revealed that each perceptual report is permeated by opposite biases from a hierarchy of serially dependent processes: Low-level adaptation repels perception away from previous stimuli, whereas decisional traces attract perceptual reports toward the recent past. In this hierarchy of serial dependence, “continuity fields” arise from the inertia of decisional templates and not from low-level sensory processes. This finding is consistent with a Two-process model of serial dependence in which the persistence of readout weights in a decision unit compensates for sensory adaptation, leading to attractive biases in sequential perception. We propose a unified account of serial dependence in which functionally distinct mechanisms, operating at different stages, promote the differentiation and integration of visual information over time.
 The circadian clock is a biological system that regulates daily rhythms in living organisms. In Drosophila, the core circadian clock consists of two transcription factors, Clock and Cycle (CLK–CYC). Recent studies have shown that post-translational modifications, such as phosphorylation, play a crucial role in regulating the activity of CLK–CYC. However, the role of transcription in core circadian function remains unclear. To address this question, we analyzed the effects of a fusion protein of Cycle and the viral protein 16 (VP16) in Drosophila. We found that the addition of VP16 to Cycle enhanced the transcriptional activity of CLK–CYC, leading to increased levels of CLK–CYC target gene mRNAs and a shortened period. These results suggest that transcription plays a crucial role in core circadian function in Drosophila.
 We have identified a mechanism by which a horizontally acquired gene product can activate an ancestral pathway in a different bacterial species. The Salmonella PmrD protein binds to the phosphorylated PmrA protein ( PmrA-P ) , protecting it from dephosphorylation by the PmrB protein . This results in transcription of PmrA-dependent genes , including those conferring polymyxin B resistance . We now report that the E . coli PmrD protein can activate the PmrA/PmrB system in Salmonella even though it cannot do it in E . coli , suggesting that these two species differ in an additional component controlling PmrA-P levels . We establish that the E . coli PmrB displays higher phosphatase activity towards PmrA-P than the Salmonella PmrB , and we identified a PmrB subdomain responsible for this property . Replacement of the E . coli pmrB gene with the Salmonella homolog was sufficient to render E . coli resistant to polymyxin B under PmrD-inducing conditions . Our findings provide a singular example whereby quantitative differences in the biochemical activities of orthologous ancestral proteins dictate the ability of a horizontally acquired gene product to confer species-specific traits . And they suggest that horizontally acquired genes can potentiate selection at ancestral loci .
 The differentiation of embryonic stem cells is a complex process that involves the expression of specific genes. To identify the genes that regulate differentiation, researchers have traditionally compared the gene expression of differentiated and undifferentiated cells. However, this approach can lead to a large number of false positives because it includes genes that respond to differentiation rather than regulate it. In this study, the authors developed a new statistical approach to identify differentially expressed genes at the early stages of differentiation without prior separation of cell types.
