They applied this approach to analyze the differentiation of murine embryonic stem cells and identified Smarcad1 as a novel regulator of pluripotency and self-renewal. The authors formalized their statistical approach as a statistical test that is generally applicable to analyze other differentiation processes. This study provides a new tool for identifying genes that regulate differentiation and may lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying differentiation.
 We have developed a new method to identify functional associations between genes implicated in the same disease. We control for confounding bias in coding-sequence length and find that genes mutated in the same disease cluster more significantly in an integrated phenotypic-linkage network than in other gene networks. We present a tool that identifies functional associations among genes mutated in the same disease even after accounting for significant sequencing study bias. Our method is suitable for functionally subclustering the gene variants underlying a polygenic disorder.
 In 2014, Mexico implemented an 8% tax on nonessential foods with high energy density and a peso-per-liter tax on sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs). The objective of this study was to examine changes in the volume of taxed and untaxed packaged food purchases in response to these taxes in the entire sample and stratified by socioeconomic status (SES). This study uses data on household packaged food purchases representative of the Mexican urban population from The Nielsen Company’s Mexico Consumer Panel Services (CPS). We analyzed the volume of purchases of taxed and untaxed foods from January 2012 to December 2014, using a longitudinal, fixed-effects model that adjusted for preexisting trends to test whether the observed post-tax trend was significantly different from the one expected based on the pre-tax trend. We controlled for household characteristics and contextual factors like minimum salary and unemployment rate. The mean volume of purchases of taxed foods in 2014 changed by -25 g (95% confidence interval = -46, -11) per capita per month, or a 5.1% change beyond what would have been expected based on pre-tax (2012-2013) trends, with no corresponding change in purchases of untaxed foods. Low SES households purchased on average 10.2% less taxed foods than expected (-44 [–72, –16] g per capita per month); medium SES households purchased 5.8% less taxed foods than expected (-28 [–46, –11] g per capita per month), whereas high SES households’ purchases did not change. The main limitations of our findings are the inability to infer causality because the taxes were implemented at the national level (lack of control group), our sample is only representative of urban areas, we only have 2 y of data prior to the tax, and, as with any consumer panel survey, we did not capture all foods purchased by the household. Household purchases of nonessential energy-dense foods declined in the first year after the implementation of Mexico’s SSB and nonessential foods taxes. Future studies should evaluate the impact of the taxes on overall energy intake, dietary quality, and food purchase patterns.
η-like response properties are observed in collision-sensitive neurons, such as the Lobula Giant Movement Detector ( LGMD ) neuron of the locust. A biophysically plausible model of these neurons is presented, which assumes that each information channel is noisy and has a response threshold. The model predicts many response characteristics of the LGMD, including the time between the peak at Tmax and collision ( Trel ), and the coincidence of the maximum LGMD activity with the angular size Θ ( tmax ). The model also suggests that the LGMD uses a power law for scaling its inhibitory input, and that the response curve to approaching objects would be significantly distorted without this scaling. The model emphasizes the importance of signal integration in order to account for many reported experimental observations.
 Buruli ulcer ( BU ) is a chronic infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans that leads to necrotizing ulcers and deformities if left untreated. BU is endemic in tropical and sub-tropical regions near stagnant or slow flowing water bodies and marshlands. Cameroon began institutional BU control in 2002 and has made significant progress in the past 14 years. The number of BU endemic health districts has increased from two to 64, and five BU diagnostic and treatment centers are currently functional. The health system has been strengthened, and BU research and education have gained more interest in Cameroon. However, resource allocation remains a major challenge for scaling up BU control activities in the country.
 We investigated how the valence of outcomes (gains or losses) affects confidence judgments in a reinforcement learning task. We found that individuals were more confident in their choices when learning to seek gains compared to avoiding losses, despite equal difficulty and performance between the two contexts. This bias was driven by the context-value, a dynamically updated estimate of the expected value of choice options. We also found that this biasing effect of context-value on confidence was domain-general, with likely important functional consequences. We show that one such consequence emerges in volatile environments, where the flexibility of individuals’ learning strategies differs when outcomes are framed as gains or losses. Despite apparent similar behavior, profound asymmetries might exist between learning to avoid losses and learning to seek gains.
 The alphavirus nsP3 protein is a component of the viral replication complex and is composed of a conserved aminoterminal macro domain and a poorly conserved carboxyterminal region. Despite the lack of overall homology, we found that the carboxyterminal proline-rich sequence motif shared by many alphaviral nsP3 proteins serves as a preferred target site for the Src-homology 3 ( SH3 ) domains of amphiphysin-1 and -2. Nsp3 proteins of Semliki Forest ( SFV ) , Sindbis ( SINV ) , and Chikungunya viruses all showed avid and SH3-dependent binding to amphiphysins. Upon alphavirus infection, the intracellular distribution of amphiphysin was dramatically altered and colocalized with nsP3. Mutations in nsP3 disrupting the amphiphysin SH3 binding motif as well as RNAi-mediated silencing of amphiphysin-2 expression resulted in impaired viral RNA replication in HeLa cells infected with SINV or SFV. Infection of Balb/c mice with SFV carrying an SH3 binding-defective nsP3 was associated with significantly decreased mortality. These data establish SH3 domain-mediated binding of nsP3 with amphiphysin as an important host cell interaction promoting alphavirus replication.
Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the skin caused by melanized fungi. In Brazil, the disease is caused by members of the order Chaetothyriales, with Fonsecaea pedrosoi being the most prevalent agent. The present study assessed the population diversity of 123 clinical strains of agents of the disease in Brazil using sequencing of the rDNA internal transcribed spacer region, and partial cell division cycle and β-tubulin genes. The study found that F. pedrosoi was the most prevalent agent, followed by F. monophora and F. nubica. Additional agents, including two novel species, were located among members of the genus Rhinocladiella and Cyphellophora. The study provides an enumeration of currently proven cases with molecular support in endemic areas in Brazil and highlights the importance of molecular identification for accurate diagnosis and treatment of chromoblastomycosis.
 The DNA damage response ( DDR ) is a crucial signaling pathway that detects and repairs DNA damage caused by endogenous or exogenous factors. In this study, we investigated the impact of Listeria monocytogenes infection on the DDR in human cells. We found that infection with L. monocytogenes induces DNA breaks, but only moderately activates the DDR. We discovered that the bacterial toxin LLO degrades the sensor Mre11, which is crucial for engaging the downstream response. We also found that inhibition of proteins involved in the DDR promotes bacterial replication, highlighting the importance of this mechanism for the control of infection. Our study uncovers a subversion of the DDR during infection by L. monocytogenes and a role for the DDR in blocking bacterial proliferation.
Herpes simplex virus-1 and -2 (HSV-1, HSV-2) are common pathogens of human diseases. Both host and viral factors are involved in HSV lytic infection, although detailed mechanisms remain elusive. By screening a chemical library of epigenetic regulation, we identified bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) as a critical player in HSV infection. We show that treatment with pan BD domain inhibitor enhanced both HSV infection and using JQ1 as a probe, we found that JQ1, a defined BD1 inhibitor, acts through BRD4 protein since knockdown of BRD4 expression ablated JQ1 effect on HSV infection. BRD4 regulates HSV replication through complex formation involving CDK9 and RNAP II; whereas, JQ1 promotes HSV-1 infection by allocating the complex to HSV gene promoters. Therefore, suppression of BRD4 expression or inhibition of CDK9 activity impeded HSV infection. Our data support a model that JQ1 enhances HSV infection by switching BRD4 to transcription regulation of viral gene expression from chromatin targeting since transient expression of BRD4 BD1 or BD1/2 domain had similar effect to that by JQ1 treatment. In addition to the identification that BRD4 is a modulator for JQ1 action on HSV infection, this study demonstrates BRD4 has an essential role in HSV infection.
 Noma, also known as cancrum oris, is a devastating ancient disease that causes severe facial disfigurement in over 140,000 children worldwide each year. The cause of noma is still unknown, but it is thought to be a combination of factors including malnutrition, poor oral hygiene, and a weakened immune system. To understand the microbial ecology of noma, we performed a cross-sectional sequencing study of 16S rRNA gene amplicons from 60 samples of gingival fluid from 12 healthy children, 12 children with noma (lesion and healthy sites), and 12 children with Acute Necrotizing Gingivitis (ANG) (lesion and healthy sites). We found that samples taken from lesions in diseased mouths were enriched with Spirochaetes and depleted for Proteobacteria, while samples taken from healthy sites of diseased mouths had proportions of Spirochaetes and Proteobacteria that were similar to healthy control individuals. We also found that samples from noma mouths did not have a higher abundance of Fusobacterium, casting doubt on its role as a causative agent of noma. Microbial communities sampled from noma and ANG lesions were dominated by the same Prevotella intermedia OTU, which was much less abundant in healthy sites sampled from the same mouths. Multivariate analysis confirmed that bacterial communities in healthy and lesion sites were significantly different. Several OTUs in the Orders Erysipelotrichales, Clostridiales, Bacteroidales, and Spirochaetales were identified as indicators of noma, suggesting that one or more microbes within these Orders is associated with the development of noma lesions. Future studies should include longitudinal sampling of viral and microbial components of this community, before and early in noma lesion development.
 Bacteria use quorum sensing to coordinate their behavior in response to environmental cues. The infectious cycle of Bacillus thuringiensis in the insect host is a powerful model to investigate the role of quorum sensing in natural conditions. The RNPP family of regulators, including NprR, is involved in quorum sensing and regulates gene expression in response to environmental stimuli. Here, we show that NprR, in the absence of bound peptide, negatively controls sporulation by preventing the initiation of the sporulation process. NprR inhibits expression of Spo0A-regulated genes by preventing the KinA-dependent phosphorylation of the phosphotransferase Spo0F. This NprR function displays striking similarities with the Rap proteins, which also belong to the RNPP family but are devoid of DNA-binding domain and indirectly control gene expression via protein-protein interactions. We propose a molecular regulatory mechanism in which key residues of the bifunctional regulator NprR are directly and alternatively involved in its two functions. NprX binding switches NprR from a dimeric inhibitor of sporulation to a tetrameric transcriptional activator involved in the necrotrophic lifestyle of B. thuringiensis. NprR thus tightly coordinates sporulation and necrotrophism, ensuring survival and dissemination of the bacteria during host infection.
 HIV is a virus that causes AIDS, and it is treated with a combination of drugs. However, some HIV strains are resistant to certain drugs, and it is important to know which drugs will be effective against a particular strain. In this study, we used a large dataset of HIV mutants and their corresponding drug sensitivities to create a model that can predict which drugs will be effective against a particular strain. We used a technique called proteochemometric modeling, which combines information about the chemical properties of drugs with information about the genetic properties of HIV strains. We found that our model was able to accurately predict which drugs would be effective against a particular strain of HIV, even if that strain had not been previously tested. This could be useful in the clinic, where doctors need to know which drugs will be effective against a particular patient's strain of HIV.
 The mechanism of eukaryotic chemotaxis, the movement of cells towards a source of attractants, is not well understood despite extensive research. A recent study proposed a pseudopod-based mechanism in which cells migrate by a self-generated cycle of pseudopod formation and retraction. The study used a computational model of cell movement and chemotaxis based on this mechanism to test its explanatory and predictive powers. The model reproduced a wide range of existing data about cell movement and chemotaxis, including cell polarization and persistence without stimuli and selection of accurate pseudopods when chemoattractant gradients are present. The model also predicted novel behaviors, such as lateral pseudopod initiation in high gradients and an increase in the angle between successive pseudopods at the front of the cell in proportion to the difference between the cell's direction and the direction of the gradient. The authors measured the angles between pseudopods in chemotaxing Dictyostelium cells under different conditions and found the results agreed with the model extremely well. The study suggests that in rapidly moving cells like Dictyostelium and neutrophils, an intrinsic pseudopod cycle lies at the heart of cell motility. This implies that the mechanism behind chemotaxis relies on modification of intrinsic pseudopod behavior, more than generation of new pseudopods or actin polymerization by chemoattractants.
Yersinia pestis is a bacterium that causes plague in humans and animals. It is transmitted by fleas, which become infected when they feed on a rodent with plague. There are two ways that fleas can transmit Y. pestis: early-phase transmission (EPT) and biofilm-dependent transmission (BDT). EPT occurs when a flea feeds on a rodent with plague and then transmits the bacteria to a new rodent within 4 days. BDT occurs when a flea feeds on a rodent with plague and then transmits the bacteria to a new rodent after 5-7 days, when a biofilm has formed in the flea's digestive tract. In this study, we found that fleas that fed on rat blood were more likely to transmit Y. pestis by BDT than by EPT. We also found that fleas that fed on rat blood were more likely to have a physical blockage in their digestive tract, which could interfere with their ability to transmit Y. pestis by EPT. These findings suggest that the source of the infectious blood meal can affect the way that fleas transmit Y. pestis.
 The brain is a complex system that processes information from the environment to make decisions. One of the most important aspects of this information processing is the encoding of sensory information into neural activity. In this study, we investigate how the encoding of sensory information is affected by correlations in the activity of neurons. We find that correlations can enhance the coding performance of a neural population by many orders of magnitude. Specifically, we show that the probability of discrimination error can be suppressed by many orders of magnitude and the number of stimuli encoded can be enhanced more than tenfold. These effects are robust to variations in the additional (‘untuned’) parameters in the system. We also discuss the nature of the pattern of correlation that leads to this enhancement and suggest experimental tests to identify it.
Cholera is a severe watery diarrhea caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. Protection against cholera is serogroup specific, meaning that vaccines must be tailored to the specific strain of V. cholerae causing the outbreak. Here, we describe a conjugate vaccine for cholera prepared via squaric acid chemistry from the O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) of V. cholerae O1 Inaba strain PIC018 and a recombinant heavy chain fragment of tetanus toxin (OSP:rTTHc). We assessed a range of vaccine doses based on the OSP content of the vaccine, vaccine compositions varying by molar loading ratio of OSP to rTTHc, effect of an adjuvant, and route of immunization. Immunized mice developed prominent anti-OSP and anti-TT serum IgG responses, as well as vibriocidal antibody and memory B cell responses following intramuscular or intradermal vaccination. In general, we found comparable immune responses in mice immunized with these variations, although memory B cell and vibriocidal responses were blunted in mice receiving the highest dose of vaccine (50 μg). We found no appreciable change in immune responses when the conjugate vaccine was administered in the presence or absence of immunoadjuvant alum. Administration of OSP:rTTHc resulted in 55% protective efficacy in a mouse survival cholera challenge model. We report development of an Inaba OSP:rTTHc conjugate vaccine that induces memory responses and protection against cholera in mice. Development of an effective cholera conjugate vaccine that induces high level and long-term immune responses against OSP would be beneficial, especially in young children who respond poorly to polysaccharide antigens.
 Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a debilitating disease caused by parasitic worms that are transmitted by mosquitoes. The World Health Organization (WHO) has set a goal to eliminate LF by 2020 through mass drug administration (MDA) programs. However, the success of these programs depends on accurate mapping of the disease to identify areas that need treatment. The immunochromatographic card test (ICT) is a rapid and easy-to-use test that has been widely used for mapping LF. However, recent studies have raised concerns about the specificity of the test, particularly in areas where loiasis, a disease caused by a different parasite, is highly endemic. This study aimed to investigate the cross-reactivity of the ICT when mapping LF in areas with contrasting levels of loiasis and mansonellosis endemicity in Cameroon. The study found that ICT positivity was strongly associated with high L. loa Mf prevalence and intensity, but not with M. perstans prevalence or intensity. These findings suggest that the ICT may not be suitable for mapping LF in areas where loiasis is highly endemic. The study highlights the importance of considering the prevalence and intensity of other filarial parasites when interpreting ICT results in areas with co-endemicity.
 We have used electron tomography to study the three-dimensional structure of coronavirus-induced membrane alterations in infected cells. Our analysis reveals a unique reticulovesicular network of modified endoplasmic reticulum that is used to organize viral replication and possibly hide replicating RNA from antiviral defense mechanisms. The network includes convoluted membranes, numerous interconnected double-membrane vesicles, and “vesicle packets” apparently arising from DMV merger. The convoluted membranes were most abundantly immunolabeled for viral replicase subunits, while double-stranded RNA, presumably revealing the site of viral RNA synthesis, mainly localized to the DMV interior. Since we could not discern a connection between the DMV interior and cytosol, our analysis raises several questions about the mechanism of DMV formation and the actual site of SARS-CoV RNA synthesis. Our data document the extensive virus-induced reorganization of host cell membranes into a network that is used to organize viral replication and may have important implications for the development of novel antiviral control strategies.
 In this study, we used the newly characterized esb1 mutant to establish a connection between suberin in the root and both water and mineral ion uptake and transport to the leaves. We found that esb1 mutants, characterized by increased root suberin, had reduced daytime transpiration rates and increased water-use efficiency during their vegetative growth period. These changes in suberin and water transport were associated with decreases in the accumulation of Ca, Mn, and Zn and increases in the accumulation of Na, S, K, As, Se, and Mo in the shoot. We also found that a significant component of the radial root transport of Ca, Mn, and Zn occurs in the apoplast. Our findings provide direct genetic evidence establishing that suberin in the roots plays a critical role in controlling both water and mineral ion uptake and transport to the leaves.
 The single photon response (SPR) in vertebrate phototransduction is regulated by the dynamics of R* during its lifetime, including the random number of phosphorylations, the catalytic activity, and the random sojourn time at each phosphorylation level. Because of this randomness, the electrical responses are expected to be inherently variable. However, the SPR is highly reproducible. The mechanisms that confer to the SPR such a low variability are not completely understood. The kinetics of rhodopsin deactivation is investigated by a Continuous Time Markov Chain (CTMC) based on the biochemistry of rhodopsin activation and deactivation, interfaced with a spatio-temporal model of phototransduction. The model parameters are extracted from the photoresponse data of both wild type and mutant mice, having variable numbers of phosphorylation sites, and, with the same set of parameters, the model reproduces both WT and mutant responses. The sources of variability are dissected into its components, by asking whether a random number of turnoff steps, a random sojourn time between steps, or both, give rise to the known variability. The model shows that only the randomness of the sojourn times in each of the phosphorylated states contributes to the Coefficient of Variation (CV) of the response, whereas the randomness of the number of R* turnoff steps has a negligible effect. These results counter the view that the larger the number of decay steps of R*, the more stable the photoresponse is. Our results indicate that R* shutoff is responsible for the variability of the photoresponse, while the diffusion of the second messengers acts as a variability suppressor.
 We present a general mathematical framework for modeling biochemical systems that are influenced by extrinsic noise. Extrinsic noise refers to fluctuations in the environment that affect the system under study. We show how to incorporate these fluctuations into a new model that decouples the system from its environment. This allows us to analyze the system without considering the extrinsic noise explicitly. We demonstrate the significance of our approach using several case studies. Our framework provides a self-contained stochastic model that summarizes all system behaviors attainable under all possible realizations of the extrinsic fluctuations. This model emulates the effect of extrinsic noise by exploiting its own stochasticity, leading to a self-exciting process.
 We developed a novel closed-loop BMI training architecture that allows for processing, control, and adaptation using spike events, enables robust control, and extends to various tasks. The architecture incorporates an infinite-horizon optimal feedback-control ( OFC ) model of the brain’s behavior in closed-loop BMI control, and a point process model of spikes. The OFC model infers the user’s motor intention during CLDA—a process termed intention estimation. OFC is also used to design an autonomous and dynamic assisted training technique. The point process model allows for neural processing, control, and decoder adaptation with every spike event and at a faster time-scale than current decoders; it also enables dynamic spike-event-based parameter adaptation unlike current CLDA methods that use batch-based adaptation on much slower adaptation time-scales. We conducted closed-loop experiments in a non-human primate over tens of days to dissociate the effects of these novel CLDA components. The OFC intention estimation improved BMI performance compared with current intention estimation techniques. OFC assisted training allowed the subject to consistently achieve proficient control. Spike-event-based adaptation resulted in faster and more consistent performance convergence compared with batch-based methods, and was robust to parameter initialization. Finally, the architecture extended control to tasks beyond those used for CLDA training. These results have significant implications towards the development of clinically-viable neuroprosthetics.
 The retina is a complex sensory organ that processes visual information from the environment. In order to understand how the retina processes visual information, researchers have studied the responses of individual neurons to different types of visual stimuli. However, the responses of individual neurons do not always provide a complete picture of how the retina processes visual information. In this study, researchers investigated how the responses of pairs of neurons change in response to different types of visual stimuli. They found that the responses of pairs of neurons are more correlated when the visual stimuli are spatio-temporally structured, such as natural movies, than when the visual stimuli are unstructured, such as white noise checkerboards. They also found that the responses of pairs of neurons are less correlated when the visual stimuli are purely spatial than when the visual stimuli are spatio-temporally structured. These findings suggest that the retina may adjust its coding strategy to represent different types of visual stimuli efficiently.
 We have developed a new approach to predicting genetic interactions in yeast that is more effective and robust than previous methods. Our approach uses a multi-network and multi-classifier system that incorporates a wide range of independent features to capture the relationships between genes. We have also used this approach to predict genetic interactions between known transcription factors in yeast and to predict interactions among all non-essential gene pairs in yeast. Our results are available at http://sage.fhcrc.org/downloads/downloads/predicted_yeast_genetic_interactions.zip. Our approach is expected to be more effective and robust in uncovering new genetic interactions from the tens of millions of unknown gene pairs in yeast and from the hundreds of millions of gene pairs in higher organisms like mouse and human.
 The BRCA Challenge is a global initiative to develop a comprehensive, standardized, and secure system for sharing and curating data on BRCA1 and BRCA2 variants. The BRCA Exchange is the central component of this initiative, providing a web portal and mobile application for variant annotation and sharing. The BRCA Exchange is built on a pipeline that merges variant data from multiple sources, including ClinVar , LOVD , BIC , and ExAC , and applies a set of classification criteria developed by the ENIGMA consortium to classify variants as benign or likely benign. The BRCA Exchange also provides a mobile application for variant annotation and sharing, which is currently available for BRCA1 and BRCA2 variants. The BRCA Challenge is a model for systematically engaging broad communities and resources for sharing data across genes and eventually regulatory regions of major clinical importance .
 Malaria is a major threat to human health and causes about one million deaths annually. The parasite Plasmodium falciparum, which causes the most dangerous form of malaria, is a rapidly multiplying unicellular organism that requires rapid adaptation to various environments. In order to deal with high fluxes of reactive oxygen species and maintain redox regulatory processes and pathogenicity, Plasmodium depends upon an adequate redox balance. We have obtained the first complete map of redox compartmentation in Plasmodium falciparum by studying the subcellular localization of major antioxidant and redox regulatory proteins. We demonstrate the targeting of two plasmodial peroxiredoxins and a putative glyoxalase system to the apicoplast, a non-photosynthetic plastid. We also obtained a complete picture of the compartmentation of thioredoxin- and glutaredoxin-like proteins. Notably, for the two major antioxidant redox-enzymes – glutathione reductase and thioredoxin reductase – Plasmodium makes use of alternative-translation-initiation ( ATI ) to achieve differential targeting. Dual localization of proteins effected by ATI is likely to occur also in other Apicomplexa and might open new avenues for therapeutic intervention.
 Intrinsically disordered proteins ( IDPs ) are proteins that do not have a well-defined structure in their unbound state . These proteins play important roles in many biological processes, such as transcriptional and translational regulation, cellular signal transduction, and molecular assembly . IDPs often undergo conformational changes upon binding to their biomacromolecular partners, a process known as coupled folding and binding . Electrostatic interactions are known to play important roles in binding processes, but so far only a limited number of experiments have investigated these interactions within coupled folding and binding reactions. Here, we study the process of coupled folding and binding of PUMA with Mcl-1 using coarse-grained simulations that are specifically designed to include contributions from electrostatic interactions. We find that electrostatic interactions are involved in formation of the initial encounter complex, and that non-native electrostatic interactions play a crucial role in the binding mechanism. Our results highlight the potential importance of electrostatic interactions for describing the binding reactions of IDPs.
 Polycomb group ( PcG ) proteins are conserved chromatin factors that maintain silencing of key developmental genes outside of their expression domains . Recent genome-wide analyses showed a Polycomb ( PC ) distribution with binding to discrete PcG response elements ( PREs ) . Within the cell nucleus , PcG proteins localize in structures called PC bodies that contain PcG-silenced genes . In this study, the authors studied the nuclear distribution of two PcG proteins, PC and Polyhomeotic ( PH ), during Drosophila embryogenesis. They found that PC and PH progressively accumulate within PC bodies, which form nuclear structures localized on distinct euchromatin domains containing histone H3 tri-methylated on K27. Time-lapse analysis indicates that two types of motion influence the displacement of PC bodies and chromatin domains containing H2Av-GFP. First, chromatin domains and PC bodies coordinately undergo long-range motions that may correspond to the movement of whole chromosome territories. Second, each PC body and chromatin domain has its own fast and highly constrained motion within volumes much smaller than chromosome territories, strongly restricting their possibility of interaction with other nuclear structures. The fast motion of PC bodies and chromatin domains observed during early embryogenesis strongly decreases in late developmental stages, indicating a possible contribution of chromatin dynamics in the maintenance of stable gene silencing.
 The study aimed to determine the mutation load in the liver of normally- and prematurely-aging mice using ultra-deep sequencing. The study found that mice that are homozygous for an allele expressing a proof-reading–deficient mtDNA polymerase ( mtDNA mutator mice ) have 10-times-higher point mutation loads than their wildtype siblings. In addition, the mtDNA mutator mice have increased levels of a truncated linear mtDNA molecule, resulting in decreased sequence coverage in the deleted region. Sequence analysis shows that the main proportion of the mutation load in heterozygous mtDNA mutator mice and their wildtype siblings is inherited from their heterozygous mothers consistent with germline transmission. The study found no increase in levels of point mutations or deletions in wildtype C57Bl/6N mice with increasing age, thus questioning the causative role of these changes in aging. In addition, there was no increased frequency of transversion mutations with time in any of the studied genotypes, arguing against oxidative damage as a major cause of mtDNA mutations. The results from studies of mice indicate that most somatic mtDNA mutations occur as replication errors during development and do not result from damage accumulation in adult life.
 The ATP synthase is a protein complex that generates ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate. It is found in bacteria, mitochondria, and chloroplasts. The ATP synthase consists of two sub-complexes: the water-soluble F1 sector, which harbors the catalytic centers, and the membrane-embedded Fo complex, which mediates ion translocation across the membrane. The Fo complex consists of eight to 15 copies of subunit c, which rotate around their axis as ions permeate across the enzyme. The c-ring harbors a series of identical ion-binding sites, typically one per c-subunit, which selectively recognize the coupling ion. In this study, the authors characterize the structure, ion specificity, and stoichiometry of the c-ring of the ATP synthase from Fusobacterium nucleatum, a Gram-negative bacterium implicated in the etiology of periodontal diseases. The authors find that the c-ring of F. nucleatum is composed of 12 subunits and that it is Na+-specific. They also find that the c-ring has two carboxyl side-chains, which coordinate Na+ ions. The authors suggest that the second carboxyl group could alter the assumed ion specificity of the c-ring, the ion-to-ATP ratio, or that it confers a novel coupling or regulatory mechanism to the enzyme. The authors' findings provide a basis for drug-design efforts against this opportunistic pathogen.
αβ T cell receptor ( TCR ) recognition of foreign peptides bound to major histocompatibility complex ( pMHC ) molecules on the surface of antigen presenting cells ( APCs ) is a key event in the initiation of adaptive cellular immunity . In vitro , high-affinity binding and/or long-lived interactions between TCRs and pMHC correlate with high-potency T cell activation . However , less is known about the influence of TCR/pMHC interaction parameters on T cell responses in vivo . We studied the influence of TCR/pMHC binding characteristics on in vivo T cell immunity by tracking CD4+ T cell activation , effector , and memory responses to immunization with peptides exhibiting a range of TCR/pMHC half-lives and in vitro T cell activation potencies . Contrary to predictions from in vitro studies , we found that optimal in vivo T cell responses occur to ligands with intermediate TCR/pMHC half-lives . The diminished in vivo responses we observed to the ligand exhibiting the longest TCR/pMHC half-life were associated with attenuation of intracellular signaling , expansion , and function over a broad range of time points . Our results reveal a level of control over T cell activation in vivo not recapitulated in in vitro assays and highlight the importance of considering in vivo efficacy of TCR ligands as part of vaccine design .
 The fungus Nectria haematococca ( asexual name Fusarium solani ) is a member of a group of over 50 species known as the “Fusarium solani species complex” . Members of this complex have diverse biological properties including the ability to cause disease on >100 genera of plants and opportunistic infections in humans . The current research analyzed the most extensively studied member of this complex , N . haematococca mating population VI ( MPVI ) . Several genes controlling the ability of individual isolates of this species to colonize specific habitats are located on supernumerary chromosomes . Optical mapping revealed that the sequenced isolate has 17 chromosomes ranging from 530 kb to 6 . 52 Mb and that the physical size of the genome , 54 . 43 Mb , and the number of predicted genes , 15 , 707 , are among the largest reported for ascomycetes . Two classes of genes have contributed to gene expansion: specific genes that are not found in other fungi including its closest sequenced relative , Fusarium graminearum; and genes that commonly occur as single copies in other fungi but are present as multiple copies in N . haematococca MPVI . Some of these additional genes appear to have resulted from gene duplication events , while others may have been acquired through horizontal gene transfer . The supernumerary nature of three chromosomes , 14 , 15 , and 17 , was confirmed by their absence in pulsed field gel electrophoresis experiments of some isolates and by demonstrating that these isolates lacked chromosome-specific sequences found on the ends of these chromosomes . These supernumerary chromosomes contain more repeat sequences , are enriched in unique and duplicated genes , and have a lower G+C content in comparison to the other chromosomes . Although the origin ( s ) of the extra genes and the supernumerary chromosomes is not known , the gene expansion and its large genome size are consistent with this species' diverse range of habitats . Furthermore , the presence of unique genes on supernumerary chromosomes might account for individual isolates having different environmental niches .
 The study investigates the egress of pseudorabies virus ( PRV ) particles from infected cells. PRV is a neuroanatomical tracing tool and related to human alpha herpesviruses. The study uses live-cell fluorescence microscopy to visualize the final transport and exocytosis of PRV particles in non-polarized epithelial cells. The study finds that PRV particles are transported inside small, acidified secretory vesicles that undergo fast, directional transport directly to the site of exocytosis. The study also identifies key regulators of the plasma membrane-directed secretory pathway that are spatially and dynamically associated with viral exocytosis. Based on these findings, the study proposes an integrated model that links together the intracellular transport pathways and exocytosis mechanisms that mediate alpha herpesvirus egress.
 The relationship between enterobiasis and chronic inflammatory diseases has been studied, but the results are contradictory. In this study, we recruited 109 primary school children in Taichung, Taiwan, to investigate the association between enterobiasis and gut microbiota and immune responses. We found that childhood exposure to pinworm and mebendazole is associated with increased bacterial diversity, an increased abundance of Actinobacteria including the probiotic Bifidobacterium, and a decreased proportion of Fusobacteria. The gut SIgA level was lower in the pinworm-infected group, and was increased in half of the individuals after mebendazole deworming treatment. A higher proportion of pre-treatment Salmonella spp. was associated with a non-increase in SIgA after mebendazole deworming treatment. These findings suggest that childhood exposure to pinworm and mebendazole may have protective effects against the development of allergies and autoimmunity.
 We used a genome-wide association (GWA) approach to identify loci contributing to root length variation in a population of wild-collected Arabidopsis thaliana accessions.  We found that the genomic narrow-sense heritability for root length was statistically zero, indicating that the genomic additive genetic variance was negligible.  However, the broad-sense heritability was significantly larger, primarily due to epistasis.  We therefore performed an epistatic GWA analysis to map loci contributing to the epistatic genetic variance.  Four interacting pairs of loci were revealed, involving seven chromosomal loci that passed a standard multiple-testing corrected significance threshold.  The genotype-phenotype maps for these pairs revealed epistasis that cancelled out the additive genetic variance, explaining why these loci were not detected in the additive GWA analysis.  We estimated the false-positive risk using a new statistical approach and suggest that half of the associated pairs are true positive associations.  Our experimental evaluation of candidate genes within the seven associated loci suggests that this estimate is conservative; we identified functional candidate genes that affected root development in four loci that were part of three of the pairs.  Our statistical epistatic analyses were thus indispensable for confirming known and identifying new candidate genes for root length in this population of wild-collected A. thaliana accessions.  We also illustrate how epistatic cancellation of the additive genetic variance explains the insignificant narrow-sense and significant broad-sense heritability by using a combination of careful statistical epistatic analyses and functional genetic experiments.
30,506 mtDNA sequences from around the world were analyzed to determine the characteristics of known pathogenic mtDNA mutations. The mean pathogenicity score for known disease-causing mutations was significantly different between mtDNA macro-haplogroups. Several mutations were observed across all haplogroup backgrounds, while others were only observed on specific clades. Disease-causing mutations were more frequent on young sequences and genomes with two or more disease-causing mutations were more common than expected by chance. These findings suggest that the mtDNA background is implicated in recurrent mutation events that have been purified through natural selection in older populations. This provides an explanation for the low frequency of mtDNA disease reported in specific ethnic groups.
1D collision assays are used to study the interactions between cells and how they coordinate their motion. In these assays, cells are restricted to moving along a micropatterned stripe, increasing the efficiency of the assay. In these assays, four possible outcomes of a collision between two cells have been observed: cells can reverse direction, stick to one another, walk past one another, or chain together. In this study, the authors used a computational phase field model to investigate the chemical and mechanical factors that control these interactions. They found that the balance between internal cell polarization, contact inhibition of locomotion, and cell-cell adhesion governs the collision outcome. The authors identified the parameters that control transitions between the different outcomes and suggest hypotheses for why different cell types have different collision behavior. They also suggest that interventions that modulate collision outcomes could be used to treat cancer.
 The thioredoxin (Trx) mixed disulfide complex is a key model for understanding the dissociation mechanism of disulfide bonds. In this study, we used theoretical reactivity analysis, molecular dynamics simulations, and biochemical complex formation experiments with Cys-mutants to study the Trx mixed disulfide complex dissociation. We observed that the conformational changes around the intermediate disulfide bring Cys32Trx in contact with Cys29Trx. Cys32Trx is activated for its nucleophilic attack by hydrogen bonds, and Cys32Trx is found to be more reactive than Cys82ArsC. Additionally, Cys32Trx directs its nucleophilic attack on the more susceptible Cys29Trx and not on Cys89ArsC. This multidisciplinary approach provides fresh insights into a universal thiol/disulfide exchange reaction mechanism that results in reduced substrate and oxidized Trx.
 The study examined how people change their preferences based on social information. The authors hypothesized that people can be uncertain about their preferences and that this uncertainty can be reflected in the variability of their choices. The authors found that people's choices became more similar to those of others when they observed others' choices, and that this effect was better accounted for by a Bayesian model that takes into account uncertainty and the relevance of social information. The authors suggest that this finding has important implications for understanding how people learn and make decisions in social contexts.
 In this study, we used a novel screening approach called secretion profiling to identify new aspects of filamentous growth regulation in budding yeast. We found that many of the major filamentation regulatory pathways ( RAS , RIM101 , OPI1 , and RTG ) were required for MAPK activation. Our study indicates that the pathways that control filamentous growth are connected in co-regulatory circuits, bringing to light a systems-level coordination of this differentiation response. This finding provides new insights into the complex regulation of filamentous growth and may have implications for other complex behaviors.
 Fungi are a diverse group of eukaryotic organisms that play important roles in the environment and in human health. The evolution of fungal morphologies has been hypothesized to be driven by changes in gene expression. To test this hypothesis, researchers compared the gene expression patterns of five filamentous fungi in the Sordariomycetes during five stages of fruiting body development. They identified genes with the largest evolved increases in gene expression across development and knocked out these genes in two divergent species to test their role in fruiting body development. The results showed that changes in gene expression are important for the evolution of fungal morphologies and that knocking out genes with evolved increases in expression can alter fruiting body development. The researchers also used Bayesian networks to identify regulatory modules that are important for fruiting body development and to test the evolution of these modules. Their findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the evolution of fungal morphologies and the role of gene expression in this process.
 The schistosome egg represents an attractive developmental stage at which to target transgenes because of its high ratio of germ to somatic cells, its availability from experimentally infected rodents, and its ability to be readily obtained from infected rodents. We investigated the utility of square wave electroporation to deliver transgenes and other macromolecules including fluorescent (Cy3) short interference (si) RNA molecules, messenger RNAs, and virions into eggs of Schistosoma mansoni. We found that electroporation was more effective for the transduction of eggs with pseudotyped Moloney murine leukemia virus than simply soaking the eggs in virions. These findings underscore the potential of targeting the schistosome egg for germ line transgenesis.
 In this study, we developed a novel approach called Perturbation-based Markovian Transmission ( PMT ) model to study the dynamic responses of macromolecular assemblies. By monitoring the simultaneous responses of all residues across many decades of time spanning from the initial perturbation until reaching equilibrium using a Krylov subspace projection method, we show that this approach can yield rich information. With criteria based on quantitative measurements of relaxation half-time, flow amplitude change, and oscillation dynamics, this approach can identify pivot residues important for macromolecular movement, messenger residues key to signal mediating, and anchor residues important for binding interactions. Based on a detailed analysis of the GroEL-GroES chaperone system, we found that our predictions have an accuracy of 71–84% judged by independent experimental studies reported in the literature. This approach is general and can be applied to other large macromolecular machineries such as the virus capsid and ribosomal complex.
 The physiological role of fungal galectins has remained elusive. In this study, we found that feeding of a mushroom galectin, Coprinopsis cinerea CGL2, to Caenorhabditis elegans inhibited development and reproduction and ultimately resulted in killing of this nematode. The lack of toxicity of a carbohydrate-binding defective CGL2 variant and the resistance of a C . elegans mutant defective in GDP-fucose biosynthesis suggested that CGL2-mediated nematotoxicity depends on the interaction between the galectin and a fucose-containing glycoconjugate. A screen for CGL2-resistant worm mutants identified this glycoconjugate as a Galβ1 , 4Fucα1 , 6 modification of C . elegans N-glycan cores. Analysis of N-glycan structures in wild type and CGL2-resistant nematodes confirmed this finding and allowed the identification of a novel putative glycosyltransferase required for the biosynthesis of this glycoepitope. The X-ray crystal structure of a complex between CGL2 and the Galβ1 , 4Fucα1 , 6GlcNAc trisaccharide at 1 . 5 Å resolution revealed the biophysical basis for this interaction. Our results suggest that fungal galectins play a role in the defense of fungi against predators by binding to specific glycoconjugates of these organisms.
 HIV is a virus that causes AIDS and is known to have a long-lived reservoir of infected cells in the body. This reservoir is thought to have an important role in the evolution of the virus, but this has not been well studied. In this study, the authors developed a mathematical model that incorporates the reservoir and used it to study the evolution of HIV. They found that the presence of the reservoir can delay the evolution of the virus within a single host, and this delay can have important effects on the evolution of the virus at the population level. The authors suggest that the reservoir may play a more important role in the evolution of HIV than previously thought.
 In this study, we used transgenic CD4+ and CD8+ T cells as sensors to evaluate in vitro and in vivo antigen presentation by coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3) and found that CVB3 almost completely inhibits antigen presentation via the MHC class I pathway, thereby evading CD8+ T cell immunity. In contrast, the presentation of CVB3-encoded MHC class II epitopes is relatively unencumbered, and CVB3 induces in vivo CD4+ T cell responses that are, by several criteria, phenotypically normal. The cells display an effector phenotype and mature into multi-functional CVB3-specific memory CD4+ T cells that expand dramatically following challenge infection and rapidly differentiate into secondary effector cells capable of secreting multiple cytokines. Our findings have implications for the efficiency of antigen cross-presentation during coxsackievirus infection.
 Leprosy is a chronic bacterial infection that affects the skin and peripheral nerves. Type 1 reactions (T1Rs) are a major cause of nerve damage and disability in leprosy patients. T1Rs are treated with oral corticosteroids, but there is limited information on the optimal dose and duration of treatment. This study investigated the efficacy of three days of high dose intravenous methylprednisolone at the start of prednisolone therapy in leprosy T1Rs and nerve function impairment. Forty-two individuals were randomized to receive methylprednisolone followed by oral prednisolone or oral prednisolone alone. There were no significant differences in adverse events or clinical improvement at the completion of the study. However, individuals treated with methylprednisolone were less likely to experience deterioration in sensory function between day 29 and day 113 of the study. The study also demonstrated that 50% of individuals with T1Rs and/or nerve function impairment required additional prednisolone despite treatment with 16 weeks of corticosteroids. The study lends further support to the use of more prolonged courses of corticosteroid to treat T1Rs and the investigation of risk factors for the recurrence of T1Rs and nerve function impairment during and after corticosteroid treatment.
 The immune system is responsible for protecting the body from pathogens and diseases. However, in some cases, the immune system can become overactive and cause inflammation, leading to tissue damage and disease. One way to regulate the immune system is through the use of regulatory T cells ( Treg ). Treg are a type of immune cell that help to suppress the immune response and prevent inflammation. In this study, the authors investigated the effects of Treg on CD8+ T cells, which are important for the immune response against viruses. They found that Treg from HIV-infected patients did not effectively suppress the function of CD8+ T cells, suggesting that Treg may not be able to effectively regulate the immune response in HIV-infected individuals. The authors also found that Treg from HIV-infected patients had higher levels of the protein PD-1, which is involved in regulating the immune response. These findings suggest that Treg may not be able to effectively regulate the immune response in HIV-infected individuals due to changes in their function and protein expression.
 Lymphatic filariasis is a mosquito-borne infection caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, or Brugia timori that affects 120 million people in 73 countries and another 1100 million people are at risk [1, 2]. The parasite survives within the lymphatic vessels for years despite the complex immune environment surrounding it. Parasites possibly accomplish this by adopting various immunomodulatory strategies, including releasing glutathione-S-transferases (GSTs) that counteract the oxidative free radicals produced by the host. Several studies have evaluated the potential of GSTs as vaccine candidates, especially against schistosomiasis, fascioliasis, and Seteria cervi. However, vaccine potential of GSTs of lymphatic filarial parasites has not been evaluated before. In the present study, the GST gene was cloned from the third stage larval (L3) cDNA libraries of Wuchereria bancrofti, and recombinant GST (rWbGST) was expressed and purified. Serum samples from individuals living in an endemic area were analyzed for their reactivity with rWbGST. These findings showed that sera from endemic normal individuals (EN) carry significant levels of anti-WbGST IgG antibodies compared to subjects who are microfilaraemic (Mf) or show symptoms of clinical pathology (CP). Isotype analysis of the anti-WbGST IgG antibodies showed a predominance of IgG1 and IgG3 antibodies in EN individuals. Subsequent functional analysis of the rWbGST showed that the rWbGST protein retained the enzymatic activity of GST and the antibodies in EN sera could inhibit this enzymatic activity. Similar results were obtained when anti-rWbGST antibodies raised in mice were used in the neutralization assay. Brugia malayi GST and WbGST show significant sequence similarity. Therefore, to evaluate the vaccine potential of rWbGST, we used B. malayi L3 as challenge parasites. Vaccine potential of rWbGST was initially evaluated by confirming the role of human and mice WbGST antibodies in an antibody dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) assay. Subsequent vaccination studies in a jird model showed that approximately 61% protection could be achieved against a B. malayi L3 challenge infection in jirds immunized with rWbGST. Results of this study show that rWbGST is a potential vaccine candidate against lymphatic filariasis. Nearly 61% protection can be achieved against a B. malayi challenge infection in a jird model. The study also showed that the WbGST protein retained the enzymatic activity of GST and this enzymatic activity appears to be critical for the survival of the parasite in the host.
 CRISPR-Cas9 is a powerful tool for genome editing, but concerns remain about the potential for off-target effects. Recent studies have used whole-genome sequencing to search for de novo mutations (DNMs) in gene-edited embryos or animals, but these studies used strain-matched, not pedigree-matched controls. This means that generational or colony-related differences were not reliably distinguished from true DNMs. In this study, we used a trio design and whole-genome sequenced 8 parents and 19 embryos, where 10 of the embryos were mutagenized with well-characterized gRNAs targeting the coat color Tyrosinase (Tyr) locus. Detailed analyses of these whole-genome data allowed us to conclude that if CRISPR mutagenesis were causing SNV or indel off-target mutations in treated embryos, then the number of these mutations is not statistically distinguishable from the background rate of DNMs occurring due to other processes.
 Stomata are pores on the surface of plant leaves that regulate the exchange of gases between the plant and its environment. The opening and closing of stomata are controlled by various environmental signals, including light. Blue light is one of the environmental signals that regulate stomatal opening. The perception of blue light is mediated by the blue/UV-A light-absorbing cryptochromes and phototropins. In this study, two new players, Hypersensitive to Red and Blue 1 (HRB1) and Protein Phosphatase 7 (PP7), were identified and their genetic and biochemical interactions in the control of stomatal aperture were reported. Mutations in either HRB1 or PP7 lead to the misregulation of the stomatal aperture and reduce water loss under blue light. Both HRB1 and PP7 are expressed in the guard cells in response to a light-to-dark or dark-to-light transition. HRB1 interacts with PP7 through its N-terminal ZZ-type zinc finger motif and requires a functional PP7 for its stomatal opening response. HRB1 is phosphorylated in vivo, and PP7 can dephosphorylate HRB1. HRB1 is mostly dephosphorylated in a protein complex of 193 kDa in the dark, and blue light increases complex size to 285 kDa. In the pp7 mutant, this size shift is impaired, and HRB1 is predominately phosphorylated. The authors propose that a modification of HRB1 by PP7 under blue light is essential to acquire a proper conformation or to bring in new components for the assembly of a functional HRB1 protein complex. Guard cells control stomatal opening in response to multiple environmental or biotic stimuli. This study may furnish strategies that allow plants to enjoy the advantages of both constitutive and ABA-induced protection under water-limiting conditions.
 The Mediator is a conserved multi-protein complex that plays a critical role in RNA polymerase II-dependent gene expression. In C . elegans , the Mediator subunit MDT-15 is required for the expression of genes involved in fatty acid metabolism, detoxification, and stress responses. In this study, we found that MDT-15 is also required for the expression of genes involved in the regulation of metabolism, development, and aging. We propose a model in which MDT-15 integrates multiple transcriptional regulatory pathways to monitor the availability and quality of ingested materials, including nutrients and xenobiotic compounds. Our findings suggest that MDT-15 is a key regulator of metabolic homeostasis and may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of metabolic diseases.
 The hippocampus is responsible for spatial navigation and memory. Place cells in the hippocampus fire in specific locations in space, creating a map of the environment. However, the exact nature of this map is not fully understood. In this study, we propose a new hypothesis that the hippocampal map is a topological map based on the connectivity and adjacency of place fields. We use computer simulations to test this hypothesis and find that the temporal pattern of neuronal firing, particularly co-firing, can convey topological information about the environment in a biologically realistic length of time. We also identify a “learning region” that highlights the interplay between different parameters in forming a hippocampal map. Our findings suggest that the hippocampal map is a topological map that is based on connectivity and adjacency, and that this map is formed through a learning process that involves the interplay of different parameters.
 Hepatitis C virus ( HCV ) is a highly infectious virus that causes chronic liver disease in humans. The current model of HCV production involves the assembly of virions on or near the surface of lipid droplets, envelopment at the ER in association with components of VLDL synthesis, and egress via the secretory pathway. However, the cellular requirements for and a mechanistic understanding of HCV secretion are incomplete. In this study, we combined an RNA interference ( RNAi ) analysis of host factors for infectious HCV secretion with the development of live cell imaging of HCV core trafficking to gain a detailed understanding of HCV egress. RNAi studies identified multiple components of the secretory pathway, including ER to Golgi trafficking, lipid and protein kinases that regulate budding from the trans-Golgi network ( TGN ) , VAMP1 vesicles and adaptor proteins, and the recycling endosome. Our results support a model wherein HCV is infectious upon envelopment at the ER and exits the cell via the secretory pathway. We next constructed infectious HCV with a tetracysteine ( TC ) tag insertion in core ( TC-core ) to monitor the dynamics of HCV core trafficking in association with its cellular cofactors. In order to isolate core protein movements associated with infectious HCV secretion, only trafficking events that required the essential HCV assembly factor NS2 were quantified. TC-core traffics to the cell periphery along microtubules and this movement can be inhibited by nocodazole. Sub-populations of TC-core localize to the Golgi and co-traffic with components of the recycling endosome. Silencing of the recycling endosome component Rab11a results in the accumulation of HCV core at the Golgi. The majority of dynamic core traffics in association with apolipoprotein E ( ApoE ) and VAMP1 vesicles. This study identifies many new host cofactors of HCV egress, while presenting dynamic studies of HCV core trafficking in infected cells.
 The study investigates the role of an imprinted gene, Grb10, in tumorigenesis. Grb10 is expressed from only one parental allele and its loss can occur during tumorigenesis. The study used mouse models of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) to investigate the role of Grb10 in tumorigenesis. The study found that Grb10 loss can occur during tumorigenesis and can promote hyperproliferation, a feature of tumor development. The study also found that restoring Grb10 in NF1 null tumors can suppress tumor growth in a Ras-dependent mechanism. The study suggests that mutations in imprinted genes should be considered with regard to parental origin.
Pavlovian threat conditioning is a fundamental skill in changing environments that involves learning to predict aversive events from environmental cues. Despite a plethora of studies on the neural mechanisms supporting this process, our computational understanding of it is fragmented. Here, we investigate human autonomic nervous system (ANS) responses to conditioned stimuli during Pavlovian fear conditioning using a statistical framework for psychophysiological modeling. We find that a probabilistic learning model best explains ANS responses, and that skin conductance and pupil size responses reflect different quantities of the same model. These findings could inform theories of neural implementation of aversive learning.
 We have identified a negative regulator of septation and conidiation in the filamentous fungus A. nidulans, PomA, which is a suppressor of SepH, a key player in the septum initiation network (SIN). PomA and SepH indirectly regulate the phosphorylation of HogA, a mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) involved in osmotic stress response. We found that PomA and SepH are required for early events during cytokinesis but not for the last step in the SIN cascade. Our results suggest that crosstalk exists between the SIN and MAPK pathways.
 Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania parasites and transmitted by sandflies. It is endemic in many parts of the world, including Brazil, where it causes significant morbidity and mortality. The disease can manifest as cutaneous, mucosal, or diffuse forms, and the factors that determine the severity of the disease are not fully understood. Recent studies have suggested that the presence of Leishmania RNA virus 1 (LRV1) in Leishmania parasites may be associated with the development of mucosal leishmaniasis. In this study, we investigated the presence of LRV1 in Leishmania parasites isolated from patients with cutaneous and mucosal leishmaniasis in Rondonia, Brazil. We found that LRV1 was present in Leishmania parasites isolated from patients with both cutaneous and mucosal leishmaniasis, and that the frequency of LRV1 was higher in parasites isolated from patients with mucosal leishmaniasis. Our findings suggest that the presence of LRV1 in Leishmania parasites may be associated with the development of mucosal leishmaniasis.
 The bacterium Streptococcus pneumoniae is a leading cause of bacterial pneumonia, sepsis, and meningitis. Type I interferon (IFN-I) is known to play a role in antiviral and intracellular bacterial immunity, but its functional significance during pneumococcal infection is not well defined. Here, we show that IFN-I plays an important role in host defense against pneumococci by counteracting the transmigration of bacteria from the lung to the blood. Mice lacking the type I interferon receptor (Ifnar1−/−) or mice treated with a neutralizing antibody against the type I interferon receptor exhibited enhanced development of bacteremia following intranasal pneumococcal infection, while maintaining comparable bacterial numbers in the lung. In turn, treatment of mice with IFNβ or IFN-I-inducing synthetic double-stranded RNA (poly (I:C)) dramatically reduced the development of bacteremia following intranasal infection with S. pneumoniae. IFNβ treatment led to upregulation of tight junction proteins and downregulation of the pneumococcal uptake receptor, platelet activating factor receptor (PAF receptor). In accordance with these findings, Ifnar1−/− mice showed overall enhanced lung permeability. As such, our data identify IFN-I as an important component of the host immune defense that regulates two possible mechanisms involved in pneumococcal invasion, i.e., PAF receptor-mediated transcytosis and tight junction-dependent pericellular migration, ultimately limiting progression from a site-restricted lung infection to invasive, lethal disease.
 Neural networks with a single plastic layer can learn simple foraging tasks, but advanced pattern discrimination and continuous learning in a network of spiking neurons with multiple plastic layers is demonstrated in this study. The network utilized both reward modulated and non-reward modulated spike time dependent plasticity (STDP) and implemented multiple mechanisms for homeostatic regulation of synaptic efficacy, including heterosynaptic plasticity, gain control, output balancing, activity normalization of rewarded STDP, and hard limits on synaptic strength. The study predicts a critical set of properties of the spiking neuronal network with STDP that was sufficient to solve a complex foraging task involving pattern classification and decision making.
 The ETS transcription factor ELF5 is a key regulator of mammary gland development and function. In breast cancer, ELF5 is a key transcriptional determinant of tumor subtype and has been implicated in the development of antiestrogen resistance. In the MMTV-PyMT mouse model of luminal breast cancer, increased ELF5 levels drive metastasis by co-opting the innate immune system. Depletion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSC) using specific Ly6G antibodies prevented ELF5 from driving vasculogenesis and metastasis. Expression signatures in luminal A breast cancers indicated that increased myeloid cell invasion and inflammation were correlated with ELF5 expression, and increased ELF5 immunohistochemical staining predicted much shorter metastasis–free and overall survival of luminal A patients. Thus, in the MMTV-PyMT mouse mammary model, increased ELF5 levels drive metastasis by co-opting the innate immune system. As ELF5 has been previously implicated in the development of antiestrogen resistance, this finding implicates ELF5 as a defining factor in the acquisition of the key aspects of the lethal phenotype in luminal A breast cancer.
 In this study, we developed a mechanistic model that maps three fundamental patterns for two interacting DNA loops into a 4–state model of stochastic transcription. We found that nested loops enhance mRNA expression and reduce expression noise whereas alternating loops have just opposite effects. We also compared effects of facilitated tracking and direct looping on gene expression. We found that the former performs better than the latter in controlling mean expression and in tuning expression noise, but this control or tuning is distance–dependent, remarkable for moderate loop lengths, and there is a limit loop length such that the difference in effect between two communication forms almost disappears. Our analysis and results justify the facilitated chromatin–looping hypothesis.
 The authors present a novel approach to design and develop pure riboregulators that repress gene expression by blocking translation initiation. These riboregulators, referred to as translation inhibiting RNAs (tiRNAs), are designed de novo and do not require coexpressed proteins. The authors use a combination of in silico and in vivo approaches to identify and optimize the features of tiRNAs. They find that six features are important for efficient gene repression by pure riboregulators, including the formation of paired termini structures, the formation of a stem-loop structure, and the presence of a bulge. The authors also develop a partial least squares (PLS) model that links the features of tiRNAs to gene repression. This model allows for the prediction of the repression efficiency of new tiRNAs based on their sequence and structure. Overall, the authors' approach provides a framework for the design of efficient pure riboregulators that can be used for metabolic engineering and other applications.
 The brain is made up of billions of neurons that communicate with each other through electrical and chemical signals. These signals can be measured using electroencephalography ( EEG ) and local field potentials ( LFPs ). LFPs are a measure of the electrical activity of a group of neurons in a specific area of the brain. In this study, the authors recorded LFPs from multiple sites in the cortex of awake monkeys and organotypic cultures of cortex. They found that when the activity of a local neuronal group exceeded a certain threshold, its activity pattern occurred without distortion at other cortex sites via fast synaptic transmission. These large-amplitude LFPs, which the authors called coherence potentials, extended up to hundreds of milliseconds and marked periods of loss-less spread of temporal and amplitude information much like action potentials at the single-cell level. However, coherence potentials also had an additional degree of freedom in the diversity of their waveforms, which provided a high-dimensional parameter for encoding information and allowed identification of particular associations. These results suggest that the brain may use a "tipping point" in its network dynamics to encode and identify particular associations, similar to the spread of ideas and behaviors in social networks.
 Nuclear size correlates with cell size, but the mechanism by which this scaling is achieved is not known. We screened fission yeast gene deletion mutants to identify essential factors involved in this process. Our screen has identified 25 essential factors that alter nuclear size, and our analysis has implicated RNA processing and LINC complexes in nuclear size control. This study has revealed lower and more extreme higher nuclear size phenotypes and has identified global cellular processes and specific structural nuclear components important for nuclear size control.
 Deep brain stimulation ( DBS ) is a widely used treatment for neurological disorders such as Parkinson’s disease and essential tremor. However, the underlying mechanisms of how DBS works are still unclear. In this study, we used a mathematical model called the Kuramoto model to understand how DBS affects the brain. The Kuramoto model is a simplified representation of the brain as a network of neurons that oscillate in phase. We found that the best time to apply DBS is when the brain oscillations are at their lowest amplitude. This is because when the brain oscillations are at their lowest amplitude, they are more easily disrupted by the DBS. We also found that the best phase at which to apply DBS is when the brain oscillations are at their highest phase. This is because when the brain oscillations are at their highest phase, they are most easily disrupted by the DBS. These findings have important implications for the design of future DBS treatments.
 Schistosomiasis is a major public health problem worldwide, with over 230 million people affected. The freshwater pulmonate snails of the genus Biomphalaria are the intermediate hosts of the parasite. The development of new molecular monitoring assays for large-scale screening of snails from transmission sites to detect the presence of schistosomes is an important point to consider for snail control interventions related to schistosomiasis elimination. Our work was focused on developing and evaluating a new LAMP assay combined with a simple DNA extraction method to detect S . mansoni in experimentally infected snails as a diagnostic tool for field conditions. The assay could be potentially useful for large-scale screening in searching infected snails with S . mansoni in field applicable conditions.
Dengue is a major public health problem affecting more than half of the world’s population living in tropical and subtropical regions of the world. In Sri Lanka, dengue is considered to be hyperendemic with all four distinct serotypes of the dengue virus in circulation for more than 30 years. The Ministry of Health is responsible for controlling dengue and other disease outbreaks and associated health care. The involvement of large numbers of public health staff in year-around dengue control activities and the provision of free medical care to dengue patients at public hospitals place a formidable financial burden on the public health sector. We estimated the public sector costs of dengue control activities and the direct costs of hospitalizations in Colombo district during the epidemic year of 2012 from the Ministry of Health’s perspective. The total cost of dengue control and reported hospitalizations was estimated at US$3.45 million (US$1.50 per capita) in Colombo district in 2012. Personnel costs accounted for the largest shares of the total costs of dengue control activities (79%) and hospitalizations (46%). The results indicated a per capita cost of US$0.42 for dengue control activities. The average costs per hospitalization ranged between US$216–609 for pediatric cases and between US$196–866 for adult cases according to disease severity and treatment setting. This analysis is a first attempt to assess the economic burden of dengue response in the public health sector in Sri Lanka. Our results suggest that dengue poses a major economic burden on the public health sector in Sri Lanka.
40,000 years ago, anatomically modern humans migrated out of Africa and into Europe. The genetic makeup of modern Europeans has been the subject of intense debate, with some arguing that the majority of genetic diversity in Europe comes from Paleolithic hunter-gatherers, while others argue that it comes from Neolithic farmers from the Near East. In this study, the authors analyzed the geographical distribution of microsatellite diversity within the most common European Y-chromosomal lineage, haplogroup R1b1b2, and found that it is best explained by spread from a single source in the Near East via Anatolia during the Neolithic. This indicates that the majority of European Y chromosomes originate from the Neolithic expansion. The authors argue that this reinterpretation makes Europe a prime example of how technological and cultural change is linked with the expansion of a Y-chromosomal lineage. The contrast of this pattern with that shown by maternally inherited mitochondrial DNA suggests a unique role for males in the transition.
 We have found that motor variability can have a broad range of effects on motor learning, both positive and negative. We have also found that across a wide range of experiments, motor variability has no statistical relation with learning rate. Our findings suggest that motor variability is task-specific and depends on which factor predominantly affects task performance. We have designed a series of experiments to test this hypothesis and found that adaptation rate was correlated to variability in completely different ways across tasks. We have also presented a new meta-analysis to show a lack of relation between variability and learning rate across a broad range of previously published data. Our findings highlight the importance of considering the specific task and the factors that affect it when studying the relationship between motor variability and learning rate.
 NF-κB is a transcription factor that plays a vital role in the immune response and inflammation. To activate transcription, NF-κB interacts with CBP/p300, a general transcriptional co-activator. The interaction between NF-κB and CBP/p300 is bipartite, with the DNA binding domain of NF-κB interacting with the KIX domain of CBP/p300 and the transcriptional activation domain of NF-κB interacting with the TAZ1 domain of CBP/p300. The role of the latter interaction in the transcription of NF-κB-activated genes is unclear. Here, we provide the solution structure of the latter component of the NF-κB:CBP complex by NMR spectroscopy. The structure reveals the folding of RelA–TA2 upon binding to TAZ1 through its well-conserved hydrophobic sites in a series of grooves on the TAZ1 surface. The structural analysis coupled with the mechanistic studies by mutational and isothermal calorimetric analyses allowed the design of RelA-mutants that selectively abrogated the two distinct components of the NF-κB:CBP/p300 interaction.
