Detailed studies of these RelA mutants using cell-based techniques, mathematical modeling, and genome-wide gene expression analysis showed that a major set of the NF-κB-activated genes, larger than previously believed, is affected by this interaction. We further show how the NF-κB:CBP/p300 interaction controls the nuclear response of NF-κB through the negative feedback loop of NF-κB pathway. Additionally, chromatin analyses of RelA target gene promoters showed constitutive recruitment of CBP/p300, thus indicating a possible role of CBP/p300 in recruitment of RelA to its target promoter sites.
 The paper introduces a new method for analyzing longitudinal gene expression data, called Time-course Gene Set Analysis (TcGSA). TcGSA is a hypothesis-driven method that uses linear mixed effects models to test for significant changes in gene expression over time within predefined gene sets. The method accounts for missing data and heterogeneity within gene sets, and has been shown to be more powerful than other methods for analyzing time-course gene expression data. The paper provides an example of how TcGSA can be used to analyze longitudinal data from a HIV vaccine trial and an influenza and pneumococcal vaccine study. TcGSA identified additional gene sets that were not found by other methods, and revealed common pathways across the three vaccines. The paper concludes that TcGSA is a useful tool for analyzing longitudinal gene expression data and can provide new insights into the mechanisms underlying vaccine responses.
 Plasmodium vivax is a major human malaria parasite that is often neglected in research and control efforts. Here, we present the first systematic effort to map the global endemicity of P. vivax. We updated our earlier estimate of the geographical limits of P. vivax transmission and used a spatiotemporal Bayesian model-based geostatistical approach to estimate endemicity within every 5×5 km resolution grid square. Our results show that P. vivax endemicity is relatively low and sparsely populated in most areas of the world. We hope that this detailed depiction of geographically varying risk will contribute to a much-needed paradigm shift towards geographically stratified and evidence-based planning for P. vivax control and elimination.
 Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of skin and soft tissue infections ( SSTIs ) and is becoming increasingly resistant to antibiotics. The cell wall-anchored protein clumping factor B ( ClfB ) has been shown to facilitate S . aureus nasal colonization through high affinity interactions with the cornified envelope in the anterior nares. However, the role of ClfB during SSTIs has never been investigated. This study reveals a novel role for ClfB during SSTIs. ClfB is crucial in determining the abscess structure and bacterial burden early in infection and this is dependent upon a specific interaction with the ligand loricrin which is expressed within the abscess tissue. Targeting ClfB using a model vaccine that induced both protective humoral and cellular responses, leads to protection during S . aureus skin infection. This study therefore identifies ClfB as an important antigen for future SSTI vaccines.
 HIV is a major public health challenge that continues to affect millions of people worldwide. To prevent HIV transmission, the World Health Organization (WHO) has set a goal of reducing new HIV infections to 500,000 by 2020. One of the strategies to achieve this goal is pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), which involves taking antiretroviral medication to prevent HIV infection. Truvada (emtricitabine-tenofovir) is the only medication approved for PrEP. However, Truvada is costly and requires individuals to adhere to a once-daily regimen. To improve PrEP, next-generation regimens are being investigated. However, pre-clinical testing may not translate into clinical efficacy, and long and large clinical trials are expensive and ethically problematic. To prioritize and design PrEP regimens, tools are needed that integrate pharmacological, viral, and host factors determining prophylactic efficacy. In this study, we developed an efficient and exact stochastic simulation approach to predict prophylactic efficacy, as an example for dolutegravir (DTG). We combined the population pharmacokinetics of DTG with the stochastic framework to predict that plasma concentrations of 145.18 nM and 722.23 nM prevent 50% and 90% sexual transmissions, respectively. We then predicted the reduction in HIV infection when DTG was used in PrEP, PrEP "on demand," and post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) before/after virus exposure. Once daily PrEP with 50 mg oral DTG prevented 99-100% infections, and 85% of infections when 50% of dosing events were missed. PrEP "on demand" prevented 79-84% infections, and PEP >80% when initiated within 6 hours after virus exposure and continued for as long as possible. Our simulations indicated that oral 50 mg DTG is non-inferior to Truvada. Moreover, the predicted 90% preventive concentrations can guide release kinetics of currently developed DTG nano-formulations. Our integrative framework can be adapted to other PrEP candidates and guide the design of PrEP regimens.
 Hepatitis C virus ( HCV ) induces autophagy to enhance its replication . However, how HCV regulates the autophagic pathway remains largely unclear. In this report, we demonstrated that HCV infection could induce the expression of Rubicon and UVRAG, which inhibited and stimulated the maturation of autophagosomes, respectively. The induction of Rubicon by HCV was prompt whereas the induction of UVRAG was delayed, resulting in the accumulation of autophagosomes in the early time points of viral infection. The role of Rubicon in inhibiting the maturation of autophagosomes in HCV-infected cells was confirmed by siRNA knockdown and the over-expression of Rubicon, which enhanced and suppressed the maturation of autophagosomes, respectively. Rubicon played a positive role in HCV replication, as the suppression of its expression reduced HCV replication and its over-expression enhanced HCV replication. In contrast, the over-expression of UVRAG facilitated the maturation of autophagosomes and suppressed HCV replication. The HCV subgenomic RNA replicon, which expressed only the nonstructural proteins, could also induce the expression of Rubicon and the accumulation of autophagosomes. Further analysis indicated that the HCV NS4B protein was sufficient to induce Rubicon and autophagosomes. Our results thus indicated that HCV, by differentially inducing the expression of Rubicon and UVRAG, temporally regulated the autophagic flux to enhance its replication.
 Cyclin Y-like 1 ( Ccnyl1 ) is a newly-identified member of the cyclin family that is highly similar in protein sequences to Cyclin Y ( Ccny ) . However , the function of Ccnyl1 is poorly characterized in any organism . In this study , we found that Ccnyl1 was most abundantly expressed in the testis of mice and was about seven times higher than the level of Ccny . Male Ccnyl1-/- mice were infertile , whereas both male and female Ccny-/- mice displayed normal fertility . These results suggest that Ccnyl1 , but not Ccny , is indispensable for male fertility . We found that the protein , but not the mRNA , level of cyclin-dependent kinase 16 ( CDK16 ) was decreased in the testis of Ccnyl1-/- mice . Further study demonstrated that CCNYL1 interacted with CDK16 and this interaction mutually increased the stability of these two proteins . Moreover , the interaction increased the kinase activity of CDK16 . In addition , we observed an alteration of phosphorylation levels of CDK16 in the presence of CCNYL1 . We identified the phosphorylation sites of CDK16 by mass spectrometry and revealed that several phosphorylation modifications on the N-terminal region of CDK16 were indispensable for the CCNYL1 binding and the modulation of CDK16 kinase activity . Our results therefore reveal a previously unrecognized role of CCNYL1 in regulating spermatogenesis through the interaction and modulation of CDK16 .
 Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) is a major cause of diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) in humans. EHEC hemolysin (EHEC-Hly) is a virulence factor that causes hemolysis of human red blood cells. We found that EHEC-Hly is also associated with outer membrane vesicles (OMVs) released by EHEC during growth. The OMV-associated EHEC-Hly is more stable than the free form and can bind to human microvascular endothelial cells (HBMEC) and intestinal epithelial cells (Caco-2). We found that OMV-associated EHEC-Hly is internalized by HBMEC and Caco-2 cells via dynamin-dependent endocytosis of OMVs. The toxin is then separated from OMVs in endosomes and targets mitochondria, leading to apoptosis via the intrinsic caspase-9-dependent pathway. Our findings suggest a novel mechanism of EHEC-Hly involvement in the pathogenesis of EHEC diseases.
 Transcription is a complex process that involves many different proteins and modifications to the DNA and histones. One of the key modifications to histones is mono-ubiquitylation of histone H2B (H2Bub1), which plays a role in coordinating co-transcriptional histone modification. In this study, the authors reveal a novel function of H2Bub1 in regulating elongation by RNA polymerase II (RNAPII). They found that H2Bub1 regulates gene expression through an unidentified, methylation-independent mechanism. The authors also found that H2Bub1 is required for normal cell growth and morphology, and for elongation by RNAPII at select target genes. They discovered that H2Bub1 is regulated by a conserved subset of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) associated with the transcription machinery. The authors propose a new regulatory paradigm whereby regulatory proteins in the cell are controlled predominantly by the specific regulation they conduct.
 Yellow fever virus ( YFV ) is a mosquito-borne disease that causes severe morbidity and mortality in humans. To determine the evolutionary history of YFV, we performed a phylogenetic analysis of the largest YFV data set compiled to date, representing the prM/E gene region from 133 viral isolates sampled from 22 countries over a period of 76 years. We estimate that the currently circulating strains of YFV arose in Africa within the last 1,500 years and emerged in the Americas following the slave trade approximately 300–400 years ago. These viruses then spread westwards across the continent and persist there to this day in the jungles of South America. We therefore illustrate how gene sequence data can be used to test hypotheses of viral dispersal and demographics, and document the role of human migration in the spread of infectious disease.
 Streptococcus pneumoniae (the pneumococcus) is a leading cause of disease in humans, including otitis media, pneumonia, and sepsis. The pneumococcus is a commensal organism that colonizes the nasopharynx of humans, and it is transmitted from person to person through respiratory secretions. In this study, we used an infant mouse model of pneumococcal colonization, disease, and transmission to identify potential bottlenecks in the pathogenesis of pneumococcal disease. We found that in the setting of influenza A (IAV) co-infection, the pneumococcus must pass through single-cell bottlenecks during bloodstream invasion from the nasopharynx within the host and in transmission between hosts. These bottlenecks were not associated with genetic adaptation by the pathogen. The bottleneck in transmission occurred between bacterial exit from one host and establishment in another, explaining why the number of shed organisms in secretions is critical to overcoming it. These observations demonstrate how viral infection and TLR-dependent innate immune responses stimulated by viral infection drive bacterial contagion.
 In this study, we aimed to identify recombinant proteins derived from P . orientalis salivary gland secretions that could be used as markers of exposure to sand fly bites in humans. We produced five recombinant proteins using bacterial expression systems and four using mammalian expression systems. We then tested these proteins as antigens in human sera from Sudan and Ethiopia, two countries endemic for visceral leishmaniasis. We found that two proteins, mAG5 and mYEL1, were the most promising antigens, showing high correlation coefficients and good specificity in comparison to whole sand fly salivary gland homogenate. Combining these two proteins led to an even further increase in the capability to detect anti-P . orientalis antibody responses. This is the first report of screening human sera for anti-P . orientalis antibodies using recombinant salivary proteins. Our findings suggest that these two proteins could be used as markers of exposure to P . orientalis bites in humans from endemic areas of Eastern Africa.
 The study investigates the role of the tra genes of Salmonella genomic island 1 ( SGI1 ) in the transfer of SGI1 and IncC plasmids. SGI1 is a mobile genetic element that carries genes conferring antibiotic resistance and is frequently found in clinical isolates of Salmonella enterica. The study shows that the tra genes of SGI1 are under the control of the master activator AcaCD and are important for the transfer of SGI1. The study also shows that substitution of the TraG subunit enables SGI1 to escape an entry exclusion mechanism encoded by IncC plasmids, thereby enhancing its transfer. The findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the transfer of SGI1 and IncC plasmids and may have implications for the development of strategies to combat antibiotic resistance.
 DNA damage is a common occurrence in cells, and the DNA damage checkpoint is a mechanism that helps cells repair the damage before it becomes too severe. The Saccharomyces cerevisiae polo-like kinase Cdc5 plays a role in this checkpoint, and overexpression of Cdc5 has been shown to promote faster adaptation to DNA damage. In this study, the authors overexpressed Cdc5 from the GAL1 promoter and examined key steps in checkpoint activation individually. They found that Cdc5 overproduction had little effect on the early steps leading to Rad53 activation, but significantly reduced Rad53 hyperphosphorylation, which is required for cell-cycle arrest. The authors conclude that Cdc5 acts to attenuate the DNA damage checkpoint through loss of Rad53 hyperphosphorylation to allow cells to adapt to DNA damage. This study provides important insights into the role of Cdc5 in the DNA damage checkpoint and its function in promoting adaptation to DNA damage.
 The brain is a complex network of neurons and neuroglia that communicate through the exchange of ions across their plasma membranes. The extracellular space ( ECS ) is filled with a salt solution that plays a crucial role in the electrodiffusion of ions. The dynamics of ion concentrations and the electrical potential in the ECS are governed by the Kirchhoff-Nernst-Planck ( KNP ) framework, which is tailored to explore electrodiffusive effects on large spatiotemporal scales. In this work, we present the 3-D KNP framework and demonstrate its efficiency by simulating the dynamics of ion concentrations and the electrical potential surrounding a morphologically detailed pyramidal cell. We envision that future applications of the framework to more complex and biologically realistic systems will be useful in exploring pathological conditions associated with large concentration variations in the ECS.
 The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has proposed a budget cut for its vector-borne diseases program, which could have a significant impact on mosquito surveillance and research. To demonstrate the consequences of such a measure, we used a mathematical model to evaluate the impact of delayed control responses to dengue epidemics in an economically developed urban environment. Our study shows that halting mosquito surveillance can increase the management costs of epidemics by up to an order of magnitude in comparison to a strategy with sustained surveillance and early case detection. Our findings provide a science-based justification for the re-assessment of the current proposal to slash the budget of the CDC vector-borne diseases program and emphasize the need for improved and sustainable systems for vector-borne disease surveillance.
 Dengue is a rapidly spreading infectious disease that affects millions of people worldwide. In Nicaragua, dengue has been well documented in urban areas, but less is known about its prevalence in rural areas. To study dengue in rural western Nicaragua, we obtained epidemiologic and clinical data as well as acute and convalescent sera from a convenience sample of consecutively enrolled patients aged ≥ 1 year presenting with acute febrile illness. We found that dengue is an important and largely unrecognized cause of fever in rural western Nicaragua. Since Zika virus is transmitted by the same vector and has been associated with severe congenital infections, the population we studied is at particular risk for being devastated by the Zika epidemic that has now reached Central America.
 Plant-parasitic nematodes are a major threat to global food security, causing billions of dollars in crop losses annually. In this study, we show that nematode-derived proteinaceous elicitor/s can induce PTI in Arabidopsis in a manner dependent on the common immune co-receptor BAK1. We identified a leucine-rich repeat receptor-like kinase, termed NILR1, that is specifically regulated upon infection by nematodes. NILR1 is essential for PTI responses initiated by nematodes and nilr1 loss-of-function mutants are hypersusceptible to a broad category of nematodes. To our knowledge, NILR1 is the first example of an immune receptor that is involved in induction of basal immunity (PTI) in plants or in animals in response to nematodes. Manipulation of NILR1 will provide new options for nematode control in crop plants in future.
 The current study examined the effect of treating Schistosoma mansoni adult worms with miltefosine on exposure of worm surface antigens in vitro. In an indirect immunofluorescence assay, rabbit anti-S. mansoni adult worm homogenate and anti-S. mansoni infection antisera gave strong immunofluorescence of the S. mansoni adult worm surface after treatment with miltefosine. Rabbit antibodies that recognized surface antigens exposed on miltefosine-treated worms were recovered by elution off the worm surface in low pH buffer and were used in a western immunoblotting assay to identify antigenic targets in a homogenate extract of adult worms (SmWH). Four proteins reacting with the antibodies in immunoblots were purified and proteomic analysis (MS/MS) combined with specific immunoblotting indicated they were the S. mansoni proteins: fructose-1,6-bisphosphate aldolase (SmFBPA), Sm22.6, alkaline phosphatase, and malate dehydrogenase. These antibodies were also found to bind to the surface of 3-hour schistosomula and induce immune agglutination of the parasites, suggesting they may have a role in immune protection. This study reveals a novel mode of action of miltefosine as an anti-schistosome agent. The immune-dependent hypothesis we investigated has previously been lent credence with praziquantel (PZQ), whereby treatment unmasks parasite surface antigens not normally exposed to the host during infection. Antigens involved in this molecular mechanism could have potential as intervention targets and antibodies against these antigens may act to increase the drug’s anti-parasite efficacy and be involved in the development of resistance to re-infection.
 In host-pathogen interactions, the struggle for iron may have major consequences on the outcome of the disease. To overcome the low solubility and bio-availability of iron, bacteria have evolved multiple systems to acquire iron from various sources such as heme, hemoglobin, and ferritin. The molecular basis of iron acquisition from heme and hemoglobin has been extensively studied; however, very little is known about iron acquisition from host ferritin, a 24-mer nanocage protein that stores thousands of iron atoms within its cavity. In the human opportunistic pathogen Bacillus cereus, a surface protein named IlsA binds heme, hemoglobin, and ferritin in vitro and is involved in virulence. Here, we demonstrate that IlsA acts as a ferritin receptor causing ferritin aggregation on the bacterial surface. Isothermal titration calorimetry data indicate that IlsA binds several types of ferritins through direct interaction with the shell subunits. UV-vis kinetic data show a significant enhancement of iron release from ferritin in the presence of IlsA indicating for the first time that a bacterial protein might alter the stability of the ferritin iron core. Disruption of the siderophore bacillibactin production drastically reduces the ability of B. cereus to utilize ferritin for growth and results in attenuated bacterial virulence in insects. We propose a new model of iron acquisition in B. cereus that involves the binding of IlsA to host ferritin followed by siderophore assisted iron uptake. Our results highlight a possible interplay between a surface protein and a siderophore and provide new insights into host adaptation of B. cereus and general bacterial pathogenesis.
The circadian clock of the cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongatus is driven by a protein phosphorylation cycle consisting of three proteins, KaiA, KaiB, and KaiC. KaiC forms a homohexamer with two phosphorylation sites per monomer, serine 431 and threonine 432. The phosphorylation cycle proceeds via the transfer of phosphate groups between the threonine/serine residues and the nucleotide bound to CII. ATP hydrolysis in the CI domain provides the thermodynamic driving force for the clock, while phosphorylation in the CII domain provides the timer for the hydrolysis in the CI domain. The model predicts that ATP hydrolysis in the CI domain is the place where detailed balance must be broken in order to generate sustained oscillations. The model also explains the characteristic sequence in which the threonine and serine sites are phosphorylated, the sequestration of KaiA, and the delay between the moment that a given KaiC hexamer reaches its point of maximum phosphorylation and the moment that the same KaiC actually sequesters KaiA. The model can also explain the robustness of the oscillation period to variations in steady-state ATP/ADP levels and the entrainment of the clock by transient changes in this ratio.
 Hepatitis B virus ( HBV ) is a DNA virus that suppresses innate immune signaling to establish persistent infection. Although HBV is a DNA virus, its pre-genomic RNA ( pgRNA ) can be sensed by RIG-I and activates MAVS to mediate interferon ( IFN ) λ synthesis. Despite the activation of RIG-I-MAVS axis by pgRNA, the underlying mechanism explaining how HBV infection fails to induce interferon-αβ ( IFN ) synthesis remained uncharacterized. We demonstrate that HBV induced parkin is able to recruit the linear ubiquitin assembly complex ( LUBAC ) to mitochondria and abrogates IFN β synthesis. Parkin interacts with MAVS, accumulates unanchored linear polyubiquitin chains on MAVS via LUBAC, to disrupt MAVS signalosome and attenuate IRF3 activation. This study highlights the novel role of parkin in antiviral signaling which involves LUBAC being recruited to the mitochondria. These results provide avenues of investigations on the role of mitochondrial dynamics in innate immunity.
 The human immune system is designed to recognize and attack foreign invaders, such as bacteria and viruses. However, sometimes the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own cells, leading to autoimmune diseases. One such disease is Crohn's disease, which affects the digestive system. Researchers have identified a protein called I2 that is associated with Crohn's disease and may play a role in its development. In this study, the researchers used X-ray crystallography to determine the structure of I2 and found that it belongs to a family of proteins called TetR. They also found that I2 can bind to a protein called HLA-DR, which is important for the immune system to recognize and attack foreign invaders. The researchers believe that I2 may be a superantigen, which is a type of protein that can stimulate the immune system to attack many different types of cells. This could explain why I2 is associated with Crohn's disease. The researchers hope that their findings will help to better understand the development of Crohn's disease and lead to new treatments for the disease.
 Nanog is a key pluripotency regulator that exhibits a disperse distribution within stem cell populations. Recent studies have shown that this heterogeneity is due to allelic control of Nanog expression, whereby each cell expresses either one or both alleles of the gene. We have developed a multiscale stochastic population balance equation framework to investigate the effects of allelic control on Nanog expression and stem cell population heterogeneity. Our results show that allelic control is sufficient to generate a multimodal distribution of Nanog in stem cell populations, even in the absence of transcriptional noise. We also demonstrate how the use of reporter cell lines carrying a single allelic knock-in of Nanog can lead to misinterpretation of the data. Finally, we show that Nanog+/− mutant ESCs maintain a group of self-renewing cells through allelic control, despite their higher propensity for differentiation and lower average content of NANOG protein. Our findings highlight the importance of considering allelic control in models of stem cell population heterogeneity and provide a framework for the analysis of reporter cell lines.
 The costs and benefits of protein expression are balanced through evolution . Expression of un-utilized protein ( that have no benefits in the current environment ) incurs a quantifiable fitness costs on cellular growth rates; however , the magnitude and variability of un-utilized protein expression in natural settings is unknown , largely due to the challenge in determining environment-specific proteome utilization . We address this challenge using absolute and global proteomics data combined with a recently developed genome-scale model of Escherichia coli that computes the environment-specific cost and utility of the proteome on a per gene basis . We show that nearly half of the proteome mass is unused in certain environments and accounting for the cost of this unused protein expression explains >95% of the variance in growth rates of Escherichia coli across 16 distinct environments . Furthermore , reduction in unused protein expression is shown to be a common mechanism to increase cellular growth rates in adaptive evolution experiments . Classification of the unused protein reveals that the unused protein encodes several nutrient- and stress- preparedness functions , which may convey fitness benefits in varying environments . Thus , unused protein expression is the source of large and pervasive fitness costs that may provide the benefit of hedging against environmental change .
 Type 2 diabetes mellitus ( T2D ) is a major chronic disease worldwide , affecting more than 300 million people . The greatest increase in the prevalence of T2D in the coming years is likely to be in Asia , home to half of the world's population with 3 billion people [1]–[2] . In Singapore , a multi-ethnic demography consisting mainly of Chinese , Malays and Asian Indians , there is vast potential for investigating the genetic etiology of T2D . We performed genome-wide association scans for T2D in 3 , 955 Chinese ( 2 , 010 cases , 1 , 945 controls ) , 2 , 034 Malays ( 794 cases , 1 , 240 controls ) , and 2 , 146 Asian Indians ( 977 cases , 1 , 169 controls ) . We identified 11 novel loci associated with T2D in these ethnic groups, and confirmed the associations at 10 previously identified loci. Our findings highlight the value of surveying across diverse racial/ethnic groups towards the fine-mapping efforts for the causal variants and also of the search for variants , which may be population-specific . , Introduction:  Type 2 diabetes mellitus ( T2D ) is a major chronic disease worldwide , affecting more than 300 million people . The greatest increase in the prevalence of T2D in the coming years is likely to be in Asia , home to half of the world's population with 3 billion people [1]–[2] . In Singapore , a multi-ethnic demography consisting mainly of Chinese , Malays and Asian Indians , there is vast potential for investigating the genetic etiology of T2D . We performed genome-wide association scans for T2D in 3 , 955 Chinese ( 2 , 010 cases , 1 , 945 controls ) , 2 , 034 Malays ( 794 cases , 1 , 240 controls ) , and 2 , 146 Asian Indians ( 977 cases , 1 , 169 controls ) . Our findings highlight the value of surveying across diverse racial/ethnic groups towards the fine-mapping efforts for the causal variants and also of the search for variants , which may be population-specific . , Methods:  We performed genome-wide association scans for T2D in 3 , 955 Chinese ( 2 , 010 cases , 1 , 945 controls ) , 2 , 034 Malays ( 794 cases , 1 , 240 controls ) , and 2 , 146 Asian Indians ( 977 cases , 1 , 169 controls ) . We used a mixed linear model to account for the population structure and relatedness among individuals. We identified 11 novel loci associated with T2D in these ethnic groups, and confirmed the associations at 10 previously identified loci. The replication results were consistent with the original associations in the Chinese population, but not in the other ethnic groups. This may be due to the limited sample size in the other ethnic groups, or the differences in the genetic background or environmental exposures between the populations.
