 Neurons are specialized cells that communicate with each other through electrical signals called action potentials. The leaky integrate-and-fire model is a mathematical model that describes the behavior of neurons. In this model, the voltage of the neuron changes over time due to the influx and efflux of charged particles called ions. The voltage of the neuron can also be affected by the activity of other neurons, which can cause the voltage to change in a non-linear way. This non-linearity can be described using a mathematical concept called a fractional derivative. In this study, the authors developed a new version of the leaky integrate-and-fire model that includes a fractional derivative. They found that this new model can better describe the behavior of neurons in certain situations, such as when the neuron is receiving input from other neurons. The authors also found that the new model can better explain certain properties of neuronal behavior, such as the way that neurons adapt to changes in their input over time. Overall, the study shows that the inclusion of a fractional derivative in the leaky integrate-and-fire model can improve our understanding of how neurons work.
 Paracoccidioides is a fungal pathogen that causes a systemic mycosis in humans. It exists in two forms: mycelium at low temperatures and yeast at higher temperatures. To survive, Paracoccidioides must defend itself against reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced by host effector cells and by its own metabolism. Superoxide dismutases (SODs) are enzymes that help Paracoccidioides neutralize ROS. In this study, we identified six SODs isoforms encoded by the Paracoccidioides genome and determined their gene expression levels in different life cycle stages and under different conditions. We also used antisense RNA technology to further evaluate the role of specific isoforms. Our results suggest that PbSOD1 and PbSOD3 are involved in the response of the fungus against host effector cells, particularly the oxidative stress response.
 Intrinsically disordered proteins ( IDPs ) are proteins that do not have a fixed three-dimensional structure and are highly sensitive to proteolysis in vitro . However, they are not degraded at a higher rate in vivo . It has been suggested that IDPs are associated with chaperones in the cell, which may protect them from degradation by proteases . In this study, we analyzed pairwise interaction data from high-throughput interaction studies to test this hypothesis. Our major finding is that predicted disorder actually shows a negative correlation with chaperone binding in E . coli , S . cerevisiae , and metazoa species. We argue that chaperone binding is primarily required for folding of globular proteins, as reflected in an increased preference for chaperones of proteins in which at least one Pfam domain exists. In terms of the functional consequences of chaperone binding of mostly disordered proteins, we suggest that its primary reason is not the assistance of folding, but promotion of assembly with partners. In support of this conclusion, we show that IDPs that bind chaperones also tend to bind other proteins.
 The Drosophila wing imaginal disc is a complex tissue that grows and differentiates during development. The wing disc is controlled by a variety of signaling pathways, including the Decapentaplegic (Dpp) pathway. The Dpp pathway regulates cell viability and motility during dorsal closure, but also controls growth and patterning during imaginal disc development. The Spalt proteins, Salm and Salr, are Zn-finger transcription factors that are regulated by the Dpp pathway and are required for wing growth and patterning. In this study, the authors used microarray analysis to identify candidate Salm/Salr target genes in the wing disc. They found that Salm/Salr regulate both the activation and repression of gene expression in the wing disc. The authors also used in situ hybridization and phenotypic analysis to validate their findings and identify a collection of candidate genes that are regulated by the Spalt proteins. Their work provides new insights into the genetic hierarchy controlling wing growth and patterning in Drosophila.
 In this study, we investigated the regulation of centriole duplication in the nematode worm C. elegans. We found that the protein kinase Plk4, which is required for centriole duplication, is regulated by the protein phosphatase PP1. We also identified two PP1 regulators, I-2SZY-2 and SDS-22, that are required for the regulation of Plk4. We found that down-regulation of PP1 activity can rescue the loss of centriole duplication associated with a zyg-1 hypomorphic allele. Our results suggest that PP1 regulates Plk4 through a post-translational mechanism and that PP1 regulates centriole duplication by controlling the levels of Plk4. This study provides new insights into the regulation of centriole duplication and highlights the importance of understanding the mechanisms that control centriole number in development and disease.
 Leishmaniasis is a rapidly expanding zoonosis that shows increasing urbanization. Concern exists regarding the role of wildlife in visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) transmission, due to frequent natural or anthropogenic environmental changes that facilitate contact between wildlife, humans, and their pets. The municipality of Campinas, in southeastern Brazil, initially recorded VL in 2009, when the first autochthonous case was confirmed in a dog living in an upscale residential condominium located inside an environmentally protected area ( EPA ). Since then, disease transmission remains restricted to dogs inhabiting two geographically contiguous condominiums within the EPA. We conducted a cross-sectional study of the VL focus to investigate Leishmania spp. infection in domestic dogs, wild mammals, and sand flies using molecular tools and recommended serological techniques. Canine seroprevalences of 1.5% and 1.2% were observed in 2013 and 2015, respectively. Six insect species, confirmed or suspected vectors or potential transmitters of Leishmania, were identified. Two specimens of the main L. ( L . ) infantum vector in Brazil, Lutzomyia longipalpis, were captured in the EPA. Natural infection by L. ( L . ) infantum was recorded in one Expapillata firmatoi specimen and two Pintomyia monticola. Natural infection by L. ( L . ) infantum and Leishmania subgenus Viannia was also detected in two white-eared opossums ( Didelphis albiventris ). Geographical coordinates of each sampling of infected animals were plotted on a map of the EPA, demonstrating proximity between these animals, human residences, including the dogs positive for VL, and forest areas. The EPA, which is inhabited by humans, has an active VL focus. The risk of establishing and maintaining disease transmission foci in similar scenarios, i.e., wild areas that undergo environmental modifications, is evident. Different epidemiological profiles of VL must be included to elaborate prevention and control measures that consider the particularities of each transmission area.
 Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) is a common human virus that causes infectious mononucleosis and is associated with several types of cancer, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma ( NPC ). EBV encodes a large number of microRNAs ( miRNAs ), which are small RNA molecules that regulate gene expression. In this study, we investigated the role of one of these miRNAs, miR-BART9, in NPC. We found that miR-BART9 promotes the migration and invasiveness of NPC cells in vitro and in vivo. We also discovered that miR-BART9 directly targets the E-cadherin gene, which is important for maintaining the epithelial cell phenotype and suppressing metastasis. Our results suggest that miR-BART9 is a prometastatic viral miRNA that contributes to the aggressiveness of NPC.
 Alternative splicing is a process that produces different combinations of exons from the same gene, resulting in a variety of mature transcripts. Visualizing splicing events is crucial for exploratory data analysis, but current visualization tools are annotation-dependent and cannot handle large genomic regions. We present ggsashimi, a command-line tool for visualizing splicing events across multiple samples. It creates sashimi plots for individual RNA-seq experiments as well as aggregated plots for groups of experiments. ggsashimi is annotation-independent and allows the visualization of splicing events even for large genomic regions by scaling down the genomic segments between splice sites. It is freely available at https://github.com/guigolab/ggsashimi and is implemented in python.
 West Nile virus (WNV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has been circulating in North America since 1999. The house sparrow (HOSP) is a highly competent host for WNV that has contributed to its rapid spread across the U.S. However, the competence of HOSPs for WNV has been evaluated primarily using an early WNV strain (NY99) that is no longer circulating. Here, the authors report that the competence of wild HOSPs for the NY99 strain has decreased significantly over time, suggesting that HOSPs may have developed resistance to this early WNV strain. Moreover, recently isolated WNV strains generate higher peak viremias and mortality in contemporary HOSPs compared to NY99. These data indicate that opposing selective pressures in both the virus and avian host have resulted in a net increase in the level of host competence of North American HOSPs for currently circulating WNV strains. This study provides new insights into the different ways WNV activates the immune response to evade destruction in the host.
19-22 nt piRNAs are small RNAs that play a role in transposon silencing and genome integrity in the germline of Drosophila. In this study, the authors found that mutations in piRNA pathway genes led to extensive fragmentation of the zygotic genome during the cleavage stage of embryonic divisions. Additionally, the authors found that mutations in two piRNA pathway genes, aub and armi, disrupted telomere binding of HOAP, a component of the telomere protection complex, and reduced expression of a subpopulation of 19-22 nt telomere-specific piRNAs. The authors also found that mutations in lig-IV, which disrupts non-homologous end joining, enhanced chromosome fragmentation. These findings uncover genetically separable functions for the Drosophila piRNA pathway, including transposon silencing and maintenance of chromosome integrity during cleavage-stage embryonic divisions, as well as assembly of the telomere protection complex.
 In November 2007, a hemorrhagic fever outbreak occurred in Bundibugyo District, Western Uganda. The initial 29 suspect-case blood specimens were tested using classic methods (antigen capture, IgM and IgG ELISA) and a recently developed random-primed pyrosequencing approach. The laboratory investigation quickly identified this to be an Ebola hemorrhagic fever outbreak associated with a newly discovered ebolavirus species (Bundibugyo ebolavirus) distantly related to the Côte d'Ivoire ebolavirus found in western Africa. The findings have important implications for the design of future diagnostic assays to monitor Ebola hemorrhagic fever disease in humans and animals, and ongoing efforts to develop effective antivirals and vaccines.
648 Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) patients were followed for an average of 4.78 years, and the duration of each Global Deterioration Scale (GDS) stage was calculated. The standard deviations for GDS stages 4–6 were comparable with their mean values, indicating a large amount of heterogeneity in the course of AD progression among patients. This heterogeneity is consistent with the existence of several sub-groups of AD patients that differ by their patterns of decline. The GDS/Functional Assessment Staging procedure (FAST) is a widely used instrument to stage the course of AD, and it has been shown to correlate with both behavioral measures and anatomic brain changes. However, the quantification of the variance of GDS/FAST stage durations is essential to compare the delay gained by a treatment strategy with the amount of natural variation in stage durations. This study provides a quantitative measure of the amount of heterogeneity in AD progression rates and their variances among patients for each stage of AD.
 In this study, we extended our previous model of adult neurogenesis in the hippocampus to include realistic, spatially driven input firing patterns in the form of grid cells in the entorhinal cortex. We compared network performance across a sequence of spatial environments using three distinct adaptation strategies: conventional synaptic plasticity, neuronal turnover, and additive neurogenesis. We confirmed that additive neurogenesis is a superior adaptation strategy when using realistic, spatially structured input patterns. We then showed that a more biologically plausible neurogenesis rule that incorporates cell death and enhanced plasticity of new granule cells has an overall performance significantly better than any one of the three individual strategies operating alone. We also examined the time course of adult neurogenesis over the lifetime of an animal raised under different hypothetical rearing conditions. These growth profiles have several distinct features that form a theoretical prediction that could be tested experimentally. Finally, we showed that place cells can emerge and refine in a realistic manner in our model as a direct result of the sparsification performed by the dentate gyrus layer.
 The study investigates the role of glutathione peroxidase (GPx) in African trypanosomes, which are the causative agents of human sleeping sickness and Nagana cattle disease. The study shows that the lysosome, not the mitochondrion, is the primary site of oxidative damage in these parasites. The cytosolic GPx I-II enzymes protect the lysosome from iron-induced membrane peroxidation. The study also reveals that the mitochondrial GPx III is fully dispensable for parasitism. The study has important implications for understanding the mechanisms of oxidative stress in African trypanosomes and for developing new therapeutic strategies against these parasites.
 PMEL is a protein that is expressed exclusively in pigment cells and forms intralumenal fibrils within early stage melanosomes upon which eumelanins deposit in later stages . PMEL is well conserved among vertebrates and allelic variants in several species are associated with reduced levels of eumelanin in epidermal tissues . However, in most of these cases it is not clear whether the allelic variants reflect gain-of-function or loss-of-function . Here, we have created a mouse line in which the Pmel gene has been inactivated ( Pmel−/− ) . These mice are fully viable, fertile, and display no obvious developmental defects. Melanosomes within Pmel−/− melanocytes are spherical in contrast to the oblong shape present in wild-type animals. This feature was documented in primary cultures of skin-derived melanocytes as well as in retinal pigment epithelium cells and in uveal melanocytes. Inactivation of Pmel has only a mild effect on the coat color phenotype in four different genetic backgrounds, with the clearest effect in mice also carrying the brown/Tyrp1 mutation. This phenotype, which is similar to that observed with the spontaneous silver mutation in mice, strongly suggests that other previously described alleles in vertebrates with more striking effects on pigmentation are dominant-negative mutations. Despite a mild effect on visible pigmentation, inactivation of Pmel led to a substantial reduction in eumelanin content in hair, which demonstrates that PMEL has a critical role for maintaining efficient epidermal pigmentation.
Dengue is a mosquito-borne disease that affects millions of people worldwide. Vector control is the primary method to prevent dengue infections. Environmental interventions represent sustainable and safe methods as there are limited risks of environmental contamination and toxicity. In this study, we performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of the effectiveness of the following environmental methods for dengue vector control: container covers with and without insecticides, waste management and clean-up campaigns, and elimination of breeding sites by rendering potential mosquito breeding sites unusable or by eliminating them. Our results showed that all three methods had some effectiveness in reducing larval and pupal densities of Aedes sp. mosquitoes. However, there is a need for more comparable high-quality studies at an adequate standard to strengthen this evidence.
 The discovery of small molecules that selectively inhibit protein synthesis by stalling the ribosome has opened up a new avenue for therapeutic development . These compounds have been identified that reduce low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) in preclinical models and affect the translation of only a few off-target proteins . However, it is not known how these compounds impact the physiology of cells or ribosome quality control pathways . In this study, we used a genome-wide CRISPRi screen to identify proteins and pathways that modulate cell growth in the presence of high doses of a selective PCSK9 translational inhibitor, PF-06378503 (PF8503). The two most potent genetic modifiers of cell fitness in the presence of PF8503, the ubiquitin binding protein ASCC2 and helicase ASCC3, bind to the ribosome and protect cells from toxic effects of high concentrations of the compound. Surprisingly, translation quality control proteins Pelota (PELO) and HBS1L sensitize cells to PF8503 treatment. In genetic interaction experiments, ASCC3 acts together with ASCC2, and functions downstream of HBS1L. These results identify new connections between ribosome quality control pathways and provide new insights into the selectivity of compounds that stall human translation, which will aid the development of next-generation selective translation stalling compounds to treat disease.
The Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus ( KSHV ) is a human herpesvirus that causes Kaposi's sarcoma, a rare tumor found predominantly in elderly Mediterranean or African men. KSHV promotes widespread destruction of cellular mRNAs to block host gene expression and evade immune detection. The viral factor SOX (shutoff and exonuclease) is responsible for this host shutoff phenotype. SOX stimulates cellular transcriptome turnover via a unique mechanism involving aberrant polyadenylation. SOX-induced polyadenylation changes correlate with its RNA turnover function, and inhibition of poly (A) tail formation blocks SOX activity. Both nuclear and cytoplasmic poly (A) binding proteins are critical cellular cofactors for SOX function, the latter of which undergoes striking nuclear relocalization by SOX. SOX-induced mRNA turnover therefore represents both a novel mechanism of host shutoff as well as a new model system to probe the regulation of poly (A) tail-stimulated mRNA turnover in mammalian cells.
 The interferon ( IFN ) family is composed of three subgroups ( types I , II , and III IFN ) , and through their distinct receptors , IFNs signal through STAT transcription factors to upregulate expression of over 300 IFN dependent genes . In the lung bacterial pathogen associated molecular patterns ( PAMPs ) can be internalized and thus gain access to the intracellular receptors involved in type I IFN signaling [1]–[3] . Activation of type I IFN signaling can be either protective or detrimental to the host depending on the specific pathogen [4]–[9] . Type I IFNs promote the pathogenesis of Staphylococcus aureus pulmonary infection through upregulation of CXCR3 chemokines and T-cell recruitment while improving eradication of Pseudomonas aeruginosa by reducing inflammasome signaling [1] , [10]–[16] . Interferons induce expression of downstream genes through distinct receptors . Type I IFN signals through the ubiquitously expressed interferon-α/β receptor ( IFNAR ) , while the type III IFN ( IFNλ ) family , composed of IL-28A/B and IL-29 , signals through the more cell specific receptor complex of IL-10R2 and IL-28R [17]–[21] . Following activation of either IFN pathway , an autocrine signaling network mediates the cellular response , primarily through JAK/STAT signaling and the induction of IFN dependent gene expression . It would seem that the two IFNs activate redundant downstream signaling pathways . However altered signaling kinetics and the limited distribution of IL-28R , restricted primarily to mucosal tissues , suggest distinct roles for type I and type III IFN depending on the infection site [22]–[28] . For example in the lung type III IFN is the primary IFN produced by respiratory epithelial cells in response to viral stimulation and is required for clearance of influenza from the airway [29]–[32] . Several of the immunological effects of IFNλ such as upregulation of MHC I and II , induction of NF-κB dependent cytokine production and effects on DC maturation and differentiation , could be highly relevant to the pathogenesis of bacterial infection [33]–[36] . Interferon signaling is linked to the regulation of micro RNAs , small non-coding RNA inhibitors of mRNA translation capable of directly influencing innate immune signaling [4]–[9] . In tumor cells , miR-21 targets the tumor suppressor programmed cell death protein 4 ( PDCD4 ) promoting tumor growth and contributing to the inflammatory tumor microenvironment [1] , [10]–[16] . PDCD4 represses translation of cellular mRNA through its binding to eukaryotic initiation factor 4A ( eIF4A ) [17]–[21] . Phosphorylation of PDCD4 by the ribosomal S6 kinase ( p70S6K ) results in release of eIF4A from PDCD4 , ubiquitin dependent degredation of PDCD4 , and enhanced mRNA translation [22]–[28] . Inflammatory cytokine production in response to toll like receptor ( TLR ) 2 or 4 activation by decorin or lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) is significantly influenced by expression of miR-21 and PDCD4 [29]–[32] . Therefore the pro-inflammatory contribution of PDCD4 to host signaling during bacterial pneumonia could significantly contribute to lung pathology [33]–[36] . In the experiments detailed in this report , we examined the importance of type III IFNs in the innate immune response to two major airway pathogens , USA300 MRSA and P . aeruginosa , currently the most common causes of ventilator associated pneumonia [37] , [38] . We found that IFNλ is induced in the course of bacterial airway infection and results in downregulation of the microRNA miR-21 , sustained expression of PDCD4 , and increased proinflammatory cytokine production . Mice lacking the IFNλ receptor , IL-28R , or PD
781 patients with advanced stage-2 sleeping sickness were admitted to a hospital in the Democratic Republic of Congo between 1989 and 2012. The patients were treated with different drugs, and the study looked at the factors that affected their mortality. The factors that affected mortality included the patient's age, gender, duration of disease, location of trypanosomes in body fluids, cytorachy, protidorachy, clinical status on admission, and treatment regimen. The study found that the most effective treatment was the short schedule melarsoprol, with a mortality rate of 12.1%. The least effective treatment was the selectively severely affected patients given eflornithine, with a mortality rate of 36%. The study also found that high protidorachy, the presence of parasites in the cerebrospinal fluid, and clinical dysfunction on admission were significant predictors of mortality. The study recommends that clinical status on admission should be assessed using a standardized tool to facilitate comparison of results in large-scale multicenter studies.
 Social isolation has profound effects on human behavior and health. In Drosophila melanogaster, a model organism for studying small-scale, temporally-transient social behavior, isolation has been shown to affect gene expression and metabolism. However, tracking and analyzing large groups of flies has been challenging due to the lack of effective and reliable tools. We developed a new imaging arena and improved the existing tracking algorithm to reliably follow a large number of flies simultaneously. We then designed an algorithm to quantify changes in the social network in response to prior social isolation. We observed that isolation significantly and swiftly enhanced individual and local social network parameters depicting near-neighbor relationships. We explored the genome-wide molecular correlates of these behavioral changes and found that whereas behavior changed throughout the six days of isolation, gene expression alterations occurred mostly on day one. These changes occurred mostly in metabolic genes, and we verified the metabolic changes by showing an increase of lipid content in isolated flies. In summary, we describe a highly reliable tracking and analysis pipeline for large groups of flies that we use to unravel the behavioral, molecular, and physiological impact of isolation on social network dynamics in Drosophila.
The World Health Organization ( WHO ) diarrheal disease management guidelines  are widely used in clinical practice, but they are not always accessible or user-friendly in resource-limited settings. To address this issue, we developed a smartphone adaptation of these guidelines, including a modality for age-based weight estimation. We conducted a clinical pilot study in rural Bangladesh to evaluate the impact of this tool on clinical care. The study consisted of a 6 week pre-intervention and 6 week intervention period with a 10-day post-discharge follow-up. During the intervention, the proportion of prescriptions for intravenous ( IV ) fluids decreased at both hospitals, with risk ratios ( RRs ) of 0 . 5 and 0 . 2 , respectively. When IV fluids were prescribed, the volume better adhered to recommendations. The proportion of prescriptions for the recommended antibiotic azithromycin increased, with RRs of 6 . 9 and 1 . 6 at the district and sub-district hospitals, respectively, while prescriptions for other antibiotics decreased. Zinc adherence increased. Limitations included an absence of a concurrent control group and no independent dehydration assessment during the pre-intervention. Despite these limitations, opportunities were identified to improve clinical care, including better assessment, weight estimation, and fluid/antibiotic selection. These findings demonstrate that a smartphone-based tool can improve guideline adherence. This study should serve as a catalyst for a randomized controlled trial to expand on the findings and address limitations.
Climate change is expected to have a significant impact on the dynamics of infectious diseases. However, it is difficult to predict how host-parasite systems will respond to changing temperatures. In this study, we used experimental data from Daphnia magna and its microsporidian parasite to fit a mechanistic model of within-host parasite population dynamics. We found that the thermal dependencies of host and parasite traits affecting within-host parasite dynamics and host survival are well described by variants of the Van’t Hoff–Arrhenius and Sharpe–Schoolfield models. Our results demonstrate the predictive power of linking MTE-based thermal relationships for host and parasite traits in mechanistic within-host parasite models to understand the impacts of temperature changes on disease.
 GABAergic interneurons play a crucial role in shaping the activity of excitatory pyramidal cells (PCs) in the brain. However, the functional roles of different interneuron types and how they are supported by their individual characteristics are still largely unknown. Here, we propose a functional role for a widespread network motif consisting of parvalbumin- (PV), somatostatin- (SOM) and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP)-expressing interneurons. We suggest that mutual inhibition between VIP and SOM cells translates weak inputs to VIP interneurons into large changes of somato-dendritic inhibition of PCs. Using a computational model, we show that the neuronal and synaptic properties of the circuit support this hypothesis. Moreover, we demonstrate that the SOM-VIP motif allows transient inputs to persistently switch the circuit between two processing modes, in which top-down inputs onto apical dendrites of PCs are either integrated or cancelled. Our findings suggest that the SOM-VIP motif plays a key role in the redistribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition and in the control of different input streams in the brain.
 Microbiota, the collection of microorganisms living in and on our bodies, have been linked to many aspects of human health and disease. To identify specific microbes associated with specific diseases, researchers use a technique called microbiome-wide association studies (MWAS). However, MWAS can produce many spurious associations that do not reflect direct links between microbes and diseases. In this study, the authors developed a new method to remove indirect associations and applied it to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Their method, called Direct Association Analysis (DAA), corrected the inflation of p-values in standard association tests and showed that only a small subset of associations is directly linked to the disease. The direct associations had a much higher accuracy in separating cases from controls and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate production, and the brain-gut axis as important factors in IBD. This study highlights the importance of considering microbial interactions when analyzing microbiome data and provides a new tool for identifying direct links between microbes and diseases.
 Wolbachia is a bacterium that infects many insect species and has been shown to have a variety of effects on its host, including blocking the transmission of some viruses. In this study, the authors compared the effects of Wolbachia on two different mosquito species, Aedes aegypti and Culex tarsalis, using two different infection models: stable transinfection and transient somatic infection. They found that Wolbachia had similar blocking effects on both mosquito species and both infection models, but the magnitude of the blocking effect was significantly lower in mosquitoes transiently infected with Wolbachia. The authors conclude that their results provide evidence that Wolbachia can be used as a natural control method for mosquito-borne pathogens such as dengue virus and West Nile virus.
Cilia are microtubule-based organelles that mediate signal transduction and are found in many cell types. In vertebrates, the cystoprotein Inversin localizes to a portion of the cilia shaft adjacent to the transition zone, a region termed the “Inversin compartment” (InvC). The mechanisms that establish and maintain the InvC are unknown. In the roundworm C. elegans, the cilia shafts of amphid channel and phasmid sensory cilia are subdivided into two regions defined by different microtubule ultrastructure: a proximal doublet-based region adjacent to the transition zone, and a distal singlet-based region. It has been suggested that C. elegans cilia also possess an InvC, similarly to mammalian primary cilia. Here we explored the biogenesis, structure, and composition of the C. elegans ciliary doublet region and InvC. We show that the InvC is conserved and distinct from the doublet region, and that components in these two regions interact to regulate ciliogenesis via cilia placement, ciliary microtubule ultrastructure, and protein localization.
 Myelin sheaths are essential for rapid and efficient nerve conduction in the central nervous system (CNS). Myelin sheaths are formed by oligodendrocytes, which are the myelin-forming cells of the CNS. During myelination, oligodendrocytes undergo profound changes in cell shape that lead to myelin sheath initiation and formation. Here, we demonstrate that the basal polarity complex protein Scribble is required for myelination and remyelination. Scribble is expressed throughout oligodendroglial development and is up-regulated in mature oligodendrocytes where it is localized to both developing and mature CNS myelin sheaths. Knockdown of Scribble expression in cultured oligodendroglia results in disrupted morphology and myelination initiation. When Scribble expression is conditionally eliminated in the myelinating glia of transgenic mice, myelin initiation in the CNS is disrupted, both during development and following focal demyelination, and longitudinal extension of the myelin sheath is disrupted. At later stages of myelination, Scribble acts to negatively regulate myelin thickness while suppressing the extracellular signal-related kinase (ERK)/mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAP) kinase pathway and localizes to non-compact myelin flanking the node of Ranvier where it is required for paranodal axo-glial adhesion. These findings demonstrate an essential role for the evolutionarily-conserved regulators of intracellular polarity in myelination and remyelination.
 Streptolysin S (SLS) is a bacteriocin-like virulence factor produced by Group A Streptococcus (GAS) that contributes to its virulence by causing haemolysis and cytotoxicity. SLS is a post-translationally modified peptide that is rich in cysteines, glycines, and hydroxylated amino acids. It has been found that SLS-like virulence factors are also produced by other Gram-positive pathogens, including Listeria monocytogenes, Clostridium botulinum, and Staphylococcus aureus. The genetic basis for the production of these virulence factors has been revealed, and it has been shown that they play a role in the virulence of these pathogens. The genetic basis for the production of these virulence factors has been revealed, and it has been shown that they play a role in the virulence of these pathogens.
Mycetoma is a chronic inflammatory disease caused by fungi or bacteria. The disease is characterized by the formation of granulomas, which are surrounded by a massive inflammatory reaction. The present study aimed to determine the expression of interleukin-17 (IL-17) and matrix metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9) in mycetoma granulomas. The study found that IL-17 was mainly expressed in zones I and II, while MMP-9 was expressed in zones II and III. The study also found that MMP-9 levels were directly proportional to the levels of IL-17. The only significant association between MMP9 and the patients’ characteristics was the disease duration. There was an insignificant correlation between the IL-17 levels and the patients’ demographic characteristics. The study suggests that IL-17 and MMP-9 play important roles in the formation of mycetoma granulomas.

 Lyme disease is caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi and transmitted by ticks. The bacterium has two putative ATP-dependent proteases, Lon-1 and Lon-2. In this study, we found that Lon-1 is upregulated in B. burgdorferi exposed to blood in vitro, while Lon-2 is not. We also found that Lon-1 and Lon-2 have distinct functional roles. Lon-1 is involved in host adaptation during the transition from tick to mammal, while Lon-2 fulfills the role of canonical Lon and is involved in cellular quality control and homeostasis. Our findings provide insight into the mechanisms of B. burgdorferi adaptation to different hosts and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for Lyme disease.
 The study aimed to investigate the role of antibody-dependent phagocytosis (ADP) in preventing HIV infection. The authors used green-fluorescent protein-expressing HIV-1JRFL virions and HIV-specific polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies to measure the ability of HIV-specific antibodies to mediate the internalization of HIV-1 virions and HIV-1-decorated cells by phagocytes. The authors found minimal or no ADP of virions with any of the antibodies, but after coating virions with gp41 or with gp41-derived peptides, gp41-specific mAbs efficiently mediated phagocytosis. The authors estimated that a minimum of a few hundred gp41 molecules were needed for successful phagocytosis, which is similar to the number of envelope spikes on viruses that are readily phagocytosed. The authors also found a clear association between virus aggregation and ADP. In contrast to virions themselves, virion-decorated cells were targets for ADP or trogocytosis in the presence of HIV-specific antibodies. The authors concluded that ADP of virions may not play a role in preventing HIV infection, likely due to the paucity of trimers and the consequent inability of virion-bound antibody to cross-link FcyRs on phagocytes. However, ADP or trogocytosis could play a role in clearing HIV-infected cells and cells on the verge of infection.
The economic and health burden of hookworm infection is not well known, making it difficult for decision makers to determine how much time, energy, and resources to invest in hookworm control. We developed a computational simulation model to estimate the economic and health burden of hookworm infection worldwide, in every country, and in WHO regions. Globally, hookworm infection resulted in 2,126,280 DALYs using 2004 disability weight estimates and 4,087,803 DALYs using 2010 disability weight estimates (excluding cognitive impairment outcomes). Including cognitive impairment did not significantly increase DALYs worldwide. Total productivity losses varied with the probability of anemia and calculation method used, ranging from $7.5 billion to $138.9 billion annually using gross national income per capita as a proxy for annual wages and ranging from $2.5 billion to $43.9 billion using minimum wage as a proxy for annual wages. Even though hookworm is classified as a neglected tropical disease, its economic and health burden exceeded published estimates for a number of diseases that have received comparatively more attention than hookworm. Certain large countries that are transitioning to higher income countries such as Brazil and China still face considerable hookworm burden.
30% of premature infants experience neurodevelopmental impairments due to chronic hypoxic injury. The mechanisms of hypoxic injury to the developing human brain are poorly understood. Recent work in the invertebrate Caenorhabditis elegans has shown that hypoxia causes discrete axon pathfinding errors in certain interneurons and motorneurons. However, it is unknown whether developmental hypoxia would have similar effects in a vertebrate nervous system. We have found that developmental hypoxic injury disrupts pathfinding of forebrain neurons in zebrafish, leading to errors in which commissural axons fail to cross the midline. The pathfinding defects result from activation of the hypoxia-inducible transcription factor (hif1) pathway and are mimicked by chemical inducers of the hif1 pathway or by expression of constitutively active hif1α. Further, we found that blocking transcriptional activation by hif1α helped prevent the guidance errors. We identified ephrinB2a as a target of hif1 pathway activation, showed that knock-down of ephrinB2a rescued the guidance errors, and showed that the receptor ephA4a is expressed in a pattern complementary to the misrouting axons. By targeting a constitutively active form of ephrinB2a to specific neurons, we found that ephrinB2a mediates the pathfinding errors via a reverse-signaling mechanism. Finally, magnesium sulfate, used to improve neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm births, protects against pathfinding errors by preventing upregulation of ephrinB2a. These results demonstrate that evolutionarily conserved genetic pathways regulate connectivity changes in the CNS in response to hypoxia, and they support a potential neuroprotective role for magnesium.
 Paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM) is a fungal disease that affects the lungs and other organs. It is caused by the Paracoccidioides brasiliensis fungus. In this study, researchers used high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) to monitor the progression of PCM in mice. They found that HRCT was useful for identifying patterns of lung lesions and quantifying lung density. The study also showed that HRCT could be used to monitor treatment efficacy in PCM. This study highlights the potential of HRCT as a non-invasive tool for monitoring the progression of PCM in mice and for evaluating treatment efficacy.
 Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is a severe form of leishmaniasis that affects the spleen, liver, and other internal organs. It is caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani and is endemic in certain regions of the world, including India, Nepal, and Brazil. The disease is often fatal if left untreated. However, many people who are infected with L. donovani do not develop the disease, and it is not clear why. In this study, the authors propose a new way to detect L. donovani infection using an interferon-gamma release assay (IFN-γRA). They modified a commercial kit called QuantiFERON to include five different leishmania-specific antigens, and they tested the assay on blood samples from people with active VL, cured VL, healthy endemic controls, and healthy non-endemic controls. The assay based on soluble leishmania antigen (SLA) had a sensitivity of 80% and a specificity of 100%. The authors suggest that this assay could be used to measure the cell-mediated immune response in L. donovani infection and could help with the elimination program for VL.
Yersiniae are a group of bacteria that can cause gastrointestinal infections in humans. These infections can become persistent and lead to severe autoimmune disorders. In this study, we show that the CNFY toxin, which enhances the translocation of the antiphagocytic Yop effectors, induces inflammatory responses. This results in extensive tissue destruction, alteration of the intestinal microbiota, and bacterial clearance. Suppression of CNFY function, however, increases interferon-γ-mediated responses, comprising non-inflammatory antimicrobial activities and tolerogenesis. This process is accompanied by a preterm reprogramming of the pathogen's transcriptional response towards persistence, which gives the bacteria a fitness edge against host responses and facilitates the establishment of a commensal-type life style.
 In this study, we identified a novel pathogenicity gene, DES1, in Magnaporthe oryzae, the causative agent of rice blast disease. We found that DES1 is required for the successful colonization of rice plants and for the suppression of plant defense responses. We demonstrated that DES1 functions as a pathogenicity factor that compromises oxidative signaling in plants. Our results suggest that DES1 serves as a key regulator of fungal virulence in the early infectious stage of the plant–fungus interaction.
 Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease that affects millions of people worldwide, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. The disease is caused by infection with trematode worms of the genus Schistosoma, which are transmitted through freshwater snails. The current study aimed to evaluate the accuracy of model-based geostatistics (MBG) predictions for Schistosoma haematobium infection in Ghana. To do this, school surveys were conducted in 79 sites to gather empiric prevalence values that could be compared with values derived from recently published MBG predictions. Based on these findings, schools were categorized according to World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines so that practical implications of any differences could be determined. Using the mean predicted values alone, 21 of the 25 empirically determined ‘high-risk’ schools requiring yearly praziquantel would have been undertreated, and almost 20% of the remaining schools would have been treated despite empirically-determined absence of infection. Using the current predictive map for Ghana as a spatial decision support tool by aggregating prevalence estimates to the district level was clearly not adequate for guiding the national program. The study concludes that for practical usefulness, predictive risk mapping should not be thought of as a one-time exercise but must be an iterative process that incorporates empiric testing and model refining to create updated versions that meet the needs of disease control operational managers.
 In this study, the authors investigate the role of prostaglandins in sperm guidance during fertilization in Caenorhabditis elegans. They show that oocytes synthesize F-series prostaglandins from polyunsaturated fatty acid ( PUFA ) precursors provided in yolk lipoprotein complexes. They also show that multiple F-series prostaglandins function collectively to promote sperm motility important for fertilization. The authors use genetics and electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry to delineate F-series prostaglandin metabolism pathways. They find that omega-6 and omega-3 PUFAs are converted into more than 10 structurally related F-series prostaglandins, which function collectively and largely redundantly to promote sperm motility important for fertilization. The authors also show that a conserved cytochrome P450 enzyme, whose human homolog is implicated in Bietti's Crystalline Dystrophy, negatively regulates prostaglandin synthesis. These results support the model that multiple cyclooxygenase-independent prostaglandins function together to promote sperm motility important for fertilization. This cyclooxygenase-independent pathway for F-series synthesis may be conserved.
 The development of biotherapeutic proteins is a promising approach to treat various diseases. However, the immunogenicity of these proteins can pose a barrier to their widespread clinical application. To overcome this challenge, we have developed a novel algorithm that simultaneously optimizes protein function and reduces immunogenicity. The algorithm, called Pepfr, generates a spectrum of designs that exhibit tradeoffs between immunogenic potential and molecular function. We have experimentally validated the Pepfr algorithm by designing and producing 18 Pareto optimal variants of a therapeutic enzyme. Our results show that the Pepfr algorithm can be used to rapidly assess and design for tradeoffs between protein immunogenicity and functionality. This approach may prove useful in augmenting, accelerating, and de-risking experimental deimmunization efforts.
 In plants, meiosis is a specialized form of cell division that produces haploid gametes from diploid progenitor cells. During meiosis, homologous chromosomes exchange DNA through a process called crossing-over (CO). COs are critical for stabilizing homologous chromosome pairing and ensuring proper segregation of homologous chromosomes during meiosis. In Arabidopsis thaliana, COs are formed through two pathways: the interference-sensitive Type I pathway and the interference-insensitive Type II pathway. In this study, we show that elevated temperature induces meiotic hyper-recombination in Arabidopsis thaliana and that the extra COs are derived from the Type I interference-sensitive pathway. We also show that heat-induced COs are not the result of an increase in DNA double-strand breaks and that the hyper-recombinant phenotype is likely specific to thermal stress rather than a more generalized stress response. These findings provide initial mechanistic insight into how environmental cues modulate plant meiotic recombination and may also offer practical applications.
 The profusion of high-throughput instruments and the explosion of new results in the scientific literature  are both a blessing and a curse to the bench researcher . Even knowledgeable and experienced scientists can benefit from computational tools that help navigate this vast and rapidly evolving terrain . In this paper , we describe a novel computational approach to this challenge , a knowledge-based system that combines reading , reasoning , and reporting methods to facilitate analysis of experimental data . Reading methods extract information from external resources , either by parsing structured data or using biomedical language processing to extract information from unstructured data , and track knowledge provenance . Reasoning methods enrich the knowledge that results from reading by, for example , noting two genes that are annotated to the same ontology term or database entry . Reasoning is also used to combine all sources into a knowledge network that represents the integration of all sorts of relationships between a pair of genes , and to calculate a combined reliability score . Reporting methods combine the knowledge network with a congruent network constructed from experimental data and visualize the combined network in a tool that facilitates the knowledge-based analysis of that data . An implementation of this approach , called the Hanalyzer , is demonstrated on a large-scale gene expression array dataset relevant to craniofacial development . The use of the tool was critical in the creation of hypotheses regarding the roles of four genes never previously characterized as involved in craniofacial development; each of these hypotheses was validated by further experimental work .
 We have used a combination of proteomics and lectin microarray analysis to characterize the surface proteins and glycoconjugates of two different types of extracellular vesicles (EVs) released by the liver fluke Fasciola hepatica .  We found that the 15k EVs are released from the gut of the parasite, while the 120k EVs are released from the protonephridial system.  We also found that the surface proteins of both EVs are recognized by host antibodies, and that pre-treatment of EVs with host antibodies enhances their uptake by macrophages.  Our results provide a detailed characterization of the surface proteins and glycoconjugates of F. hepatica EVs, which may be useful for developing new therapeutic strategies to target these parasite-derived vesicles.
200-300 words. The precise regulation of microRNA (miRNA) transcription and processing is important for eukaryotic development. In plants, miRNAs are first transcribed as stem-loop primary miRNAs (pri-miRNAs) by RNA polymerase II, then cleaved in the nucleus into mature miRNAs by Dicer-like 1 (DCL1). We identified a cycling DOF transcription factor, CDF2, which interacts with DCL1 and regulates the accumulation of a population of miRNAs. CDF2 binds directly to the promoters of some miRNA genes and works as a transcription activator or repressor for these miRNA genes. CDF2 binds preferentially to the pri-miRNAs regulated by itself and affects DCL1-mediated processing of these pri-miRNAs. Genetically, CDF2 works in the same pathway as miR156 or miR172 to control flowering. We conclude that CDF2 regulates a group of pri-miRNAs at both the transcriptional and posttranscriptional levels to maintain proper levels of their mature miRNAs to control plant development.
 The oocyte-granulosa cell communication is a crucial process for folliculogenesis, which is essential for female reproductive function. In this study, we found that oocyte geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GGPP), a metabolic intermediate involved in protein geranylgeranylation, is required to establish the oocyte-granulosa cell communication. GGPP and Ggpps levels in oocytes increased during early follicular development. The selective depletion of GGPP in mouse oocytes impaired the proliferation of granulosa cells, primary-secondary follicle transition, and female fertility. Mechanistically, GGPP depletion inhibited Rho GTPase geranylgeranylation and its GTPase activity, which was responsible for the accumulation of cell junction proteins in the oocyte cytoplasm and the failure to maintain physical connection between oocyte and granulosa cells. GGPP ablation also blocked Rab27a geranylgeranylation, which might account for the impaired secretion of oocyte materials such as Gdf9. Our study provides the evidence that GGPP-mediated protein geranylgeranylation contributes to the establishment of oocyte-granulosa cell communication and then regulates the primary-secondary follicle transition, a key phase of folliculogenesis essential for female reproductive function.
 The RNA polymerase II ( Pol II ) is a eukaryotic enzyme that catalyzes the synthesis of the messenger RNA using a DNA template . Despite numerous biochemical and biophysical studies, it remains elusive whether the “secondary channel” is the only route for NTP to reach the active site of the enzyme or if the “main channel” could be an alternative. In this study, we have built a structural model of Pol II with a complete transcription bubble based on multiple sources of existing structural data and used Molecular Dynamics ( MD ) simulations together with structural analysis to shed light on NTP entry pathways. Interestingly, we found that although both channels have enough space to allow NTP loading, the percentage of MD conformations containing enough space for NTP loading through the secondary channel is twice higher than that of the main channel. Further energetic study based on MD simulations with NTP loaded in the channels has revealed that the diffusion of the NTP through the main channel is greatly disfavored by electrostatic repulsion between the NTP and the highly negatively charged backbones of nucleotides in the non-template DNA strand. Taken together, our results suggest that the secondary channel is the major route for NTP entry during Pol II transcription.
 Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral disease that is increasing in incidence and economic importance worldwide. However, it is generally believed that these numbers still represent a large underestimate of the actual disease burden. In most countries, reporting of dengue is based solely on clinical criteria, which complicates dengue disease surveillance. To overcome this problem, authors of several published dengue studies multiplied the number of reported cases by a set factor to obtain an estimate of actual cases. However, usually these multiplication factors (MFs) have been based on data derived from a single study, often performed in a different country, or based on “expert opinion.” In this study, the authors utilized laboratory-confirmed incidence of symptomatic DENV infection both in inpatients and outpatients identified in prospective cohort studies at three field sites in Thailand and Cambodia to estimate the magnitude of dengue underrecognition in these countries. The results indicate that non-hospitalized patients with dengue illness represent a substantial proportion of the overall disease burden. These data are crucial for the assessment of the economic impact of dengue and the cost-effectiveness of a potential dengue vaccine in the future.
 The immune system is a complex network of cells and molecules that work together to protect the body from infection and disease. Natural killer ( NK ) cells are a type of immune cell that can directly kill infected cells and help activate other immune cells. In this study, we used a mouse model to investigate how NK cells may help orchestrate global antiviral defense against cytomegalovirus ( MCMV ). We found that NK cells accelerate CD8 T cell responses against MCMV infection in vivo, and that this is achieved through the ability of NK cells to limit IFN-α/β production to levels not immunosuppressive to the host. This is achieved through the early control of viral replication, which reduces the activation of plasmacytoid dendritic cells ( pDCs ) and preserves the conventional dendritic cell ( cDC ) compartment. Our findings suggest that the ability of NK cells to respond very early to cytomegalovirus infection critically contributes to balance the intensity of other innate immune responses, which dampens early immunopathology and promotes optimal initiation of antiviral CD8 T cell responses. Thus, the extent to which NK cell responses benefit the host goes beyond their direct antiviral effects and extends to the prevention of innate cytokine shock and to the promotion of adaptive immunity.
45S rRNA genes are arranged in tandem arrays in copy numbers ranging from several hundred to several thousand in plants . Although it is clear that not all copies are transcribed under normal growth conditions , the molecular basis controlling the expression of specific sets of rRNA genes remains unclear . Here , we report four major rRNA gene variants in Arabidopsis thaliana . Interestingly , while transcription of one of these rRNA variants is induced , the others are either repressed or remain unaltered in A . thaliana plants with a disrupted nucleolin-like protein gene ( Atnuc-L1 ) . Remarkably , the most highly represented rRNA gene variant , which is inactive in WT plants , is reactivated in Atnuc-L1 mutants . We show that accumulated pre–rRNAs originate from RNA Pol I transcription and are processed accurately . Moreover , we show that disruption of the AtNUC-L1 gene induces loss of symmetrical DNA methylation without affecting histone epigenetic marks at rRNA genes . Collectively , these data reveal a novel mechanism for rRNA gene transcriptional regulation in which the nucleolin protein plays a major role in controlling active and repressed rRNA gene variants in Arabidopsis .
 Our study identifies the human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) protein pUL38 as a novel component of the NuRD complex, a multi-protein complex that regulates chromatin structure and gene expression. We show that pUL38 interacts with HDAC1, a component of the NuRD complex, and that this interaction is required for efficient HCMV replication. We also show that pUL29/28, another HCMV protein, is necessary for the interaction between pUL38 and HDAC1. Our findings suggest that HCMV co-opts the NuRD complex to enhance expression of its immediate-early genes.
Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is the leading cause of pneumonia in infants and children. In this study, the authors used whole genome-fragment phage display libraries (GFPDL) to map the antibody repertoire following primary RSV infection and traced its evolution through adolescence and adulthood. They found that antibody responses to RSV-F and RSV-G proteins were different and that antibody responses to RSV-G declined significantly in adults. The authors identified several novel epitopes in RSV-F and G proteins and an immunodominant epitope in the F-p27. They also demonstrated an unlinked evolution of the antibody responses to F and G proteins in humans. These findings could help in the development of effective countermeasures, including vaccines, for RSV.
 Filariasis is a group of diseases caused by parasitic worms called filariae. These diseases are transmitted by mosquitoes and affect millions of people worldwide. The current treatment for filariasis is ineffective against adult worms, which are the source of transmission. Emodepside is a veterinary drug that has shown macrofilaricidal effects in filariae. In this study, we investigated the mode of action of emodepside in the adult worms of Brugia malayi, one of the species that causes filariasis. We found that emodepside targets SLO-1 K channels, which are more sensitive in male worms than in female worms. We also found that selectively knocking down the SLO-1A splice variant in female worms increased the efficacy of emodepside. These findings suggest that the sex of the filarial target is an important therapeutic variable to consider when evaluating a dose-regimen for treatments.
 Lymphatic filariasis ( LF ) is a disabling and disfiguring disease caused by mosquito-borne, filarial (threadlike) parasitic worms. The Global Program to Eliminate LF ( GPELF ) has reduced the at-risk population for LF from 1.2 billion to 789 million (a 46% reduction) between 2000 and 2012 by providing repeated, annual rounds of anti-filarial medications by mass drug administration ( MDA ). However, LF elimination in Africa lags behind other endemic regions with only a 25% reduction. This is due in part to slow rollout of MDA in regions of central Africa co-endemic with Loa loa, because drugs used for MDA can cause severe adverse effects in people with loiasis. The GPELF strategy relies on point of care rapid diagnostic tests ( RDTs ) to map regions endemic for LF and to determine when regions have successfully eliminated the disease. Two RDTs have been used to detect a circulating antigen of Wuchereria bancrofti, the filarial species that causes LF in Africa. These are the Binax NOW Filariasis immunochromatographic card test ( ICT ) and the Alere Filariasis Test Strip ( FTS ). The FTS is more stable, more sensitive, and less expensive than the ICT. Both are lateral flow assays that work as follows: whole blood is applied to a sample pad containing colloidal gold-conjugated polyclonal antifilarial antibodies. The sample pad retains blood cells, while capillary action pulls the serum across the test strip and over a test line containing an immobilized IgM class monoclonal antibody called AD12. The AD12 antibody binds a carbohydrate epitope that is abundantly present on a high molecular weight (200–250 kDa) W . bancrofti circulating filarial antigen ( CFA ). AD12 traps W . bancrofti CFA bound to the colloidal gold-labeled polyclonal antibodies to form a pink line that indicates a positive test result. The molecular structure and saccharide composition of the carbohydrate epitope recognized by the AD12 antibody is unknown. This carbohydrate moiety, which we refer to as the AD12 epitope, appears to be specific to nematodes and is not phosphorylcholine. A second IgM monoclonal antibody developed in the Weil laboratory, DH6 . 5, also recognizes the AD12 epitope. Like the AD12 carbohydrate epitope, the exact identity of the high molecular weight W . bancrofti CFA remains unknown. It is clear, however, that it contains multiple AD12 epitopes per molecule, since capture of the molecule by DH6 . 5 in an ELISA format does not prevent AD12 / DH6 . 5 from binding to the non-bound surface of the molecule. While other nematodes have antigens that contain the AD12 epitope, the ICT and FTS tests have been considered functionally specific for W . bancrofti infection, since until recently, such antigens had not been found circulating in the blood of persons with other infections. It has now become clear, however, that some persons with loiasis, especially those with high L . loa microfilaria ( Mf ) counts, have positive LF RDT results. This complicates mapping and monitoring for LF elimination programs in central Africa. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to identify filarial antigens in the blood of persons infected with L . loa that could cause false-positive LF RDT results. This information may lead to the development of improved diagnostic tests for both infections.
 We used RNA-Seq to identify new ciliary proteins in C . elegans . We found a unique expression profile for ciliary genes and confirmed that our clustering analysis identifies known ciliary proteins. We also discovered a novel conserved ciliary protein, RAB-28, which is expressed exclusively in ciliated cells and behaves as an IFT cargo via BBSome- and nucleotide binding-dependent mechanisms. Overexpression of predicted active or inactive forms of RAB-28 leads to variant-specific ciliary and cell non-autonomous sensory pore morphogenesis defects. Our work provides a novel approach to finding new ciliary proteins and uncovers a functional association between the BBSome, IFT, and the orthologue of the cone-rod dystrophy protein, RAB28.
 The brain is responsible for representing the outside world, but it can only rely on neural responses and has no independent access to external stimuli. In this study, we investigated how the brain may do this by using hippocampal place cells as a model system. We found that simply knowing which groups of cells fire together reveals a surprising amount of structure in the underlying stimulus space. This may enable the brain to construct its own internal representations. We also found that the simple knowledge of which groups of hippocampal place cells fire together is enough to extract global topological features of the environment and reconstruct an accurate geometric representation of physical space within which the animal's position can be tracked. This is made possible by using standard tools from algebraic topology and graph theory.
 We report here the nearly complete genomic sequence of 20 different individuals , determined using “next-generation” sequencing technologies . We use these data to characterize the type of genetic variation carried by humans in a sample of this size , which is to our knowledge the largest set of unrelated genomic sequences that have been reported . We summarize different categories of variation in each genome , and in total across all 20 of the genomes , finding a surprising number of variants predicted to reduce or remove the proteins encoded by many different genes . This work provides important fundamental information about the scope of human genetic variation , and suggests ways to further explore the relationship between these genetic variants and human disease .
Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus are two species of hookworms that cause anemia and iron deficiency in children. The intensity of the infection is related to the severity of disease. The conventional method for determining infection load is done with a proxy marker, number of eggs, using Kato-Katz microscopy slides with a fixed amount of feces. However, this method is laborious and frequently omitted. Necator americanus is predominant in tropical environments, whereas Ancylostoma duodenale is adapted to colder and drier circumstances. Ancylostoma duodenale causes 2 to 10 times more blood loss per worm than Necator americanus. Multiplex real-time PCR is a powerful diagnostic tool for public health research to combat anemia and iron deficiency in children living in resource poor settings. The objective of this study was to determine prevalence of the two hookworm species, infection load, and species association with severe anemia and bone marrow iron deficiency in pre-school Malawian children using a species-specific multiplex real-time PCR. The study found that Ancylostoma duodenale was more prevalent than Necator americanus and that Ancylostoma duodenale infection was significantly associated with severe anemia and bone marrow iron deficiency. The study recommends that quantitative and species-specific screening of hookworm infections should be done to combat anemia and iron deficiency in children.
DNA double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) are harmful to cells and can lead to cancer if not repaired correctly . Two main pathways exist for repairing DSBs: homologous recombination ( HR ) and non-homologous end joining ( NHEJ ) . HR is more accurate but requires an undamaged template, while NHEJ is faster but error-prone . In germ cells, HR is essential for repairing meiotic DSBs and creating crossovers ( COs ) that are necessary for proper chromosome segregation during meiosis . In C . elegans, germ cells have NHEJ activity, but it is efficiently inhibited . We found that COM-1, the C . elegans homolog of CtIP/Sae2/Ctp1, is crucial for inhibiting NHEJ and promoting HR in germ cells. COM-1 is not required for Spo11 removal or initiation of meiotic DSB repair, but it is needed to prevent chromosome aggregation and CO failure. COM-1 also acts parallel to the nuclease EXO-1 to promote interhomolog HR at early pachytene stage. Our results reveal a dual role for COM-1 during meiosis: it blocks toxic NHEJ activity and guarantees timely formation of interhomolog COs.
 The bacterium Burkholderia pseudomallei causes melioidosis, a disease that is common in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia. Melioidosis is a serious infection that can lead to sepsis and death. A goat model of aerosol infection with B. pseudomallei was used to study the humoral immune response. Antigenic protein profiling was generated from the infecting strain, and ELISA and western blot were used to analyze the immune response. The results showed that the humoral immune response was dominated by IgG antibodies, and that the most reactive antigen was the heat shock protein GroEL1. The study provides insight into the immune response to B. pseudomallei infection and may help identify immunogenic proteins for new diagnostics and vaccine candidates.
 Mitosis is a complex process that requires precise regulation of cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity. The activation of cyclin B1–Cdk1 is triggered by a positive feedback loop at the end of G2 phase, which leads to mitotic entry. The activation of cyclin B1–Cdk1 is maintained by the inhibition of the APC/C complex, which prevents the degradation of cyclin B1. The dephosphorylation of Cdk1 and the phosphorylation of the Cdk1 target anaphase-promoting complex/cyclosome 3 are used to determine the temporal development of cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity in single cells. The results show that cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity is maintained even when cyclin B1 translocates to the nucleus in prophase. The study suggests that the development of cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity in vivo proceeds as if it were governed by bistability. The results explain how cyclin B1–Cdk1 can be responsible for cytoplasmic rearrangements even during nuclear translocation. The study proposes a model in which different thresholds of cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity, in combination with a gradual increase in activity, help to coordinate early and late mitotic events.
 HIV-1 vaccines have failed to elicit neutralizing antibodies ( Nabs ) that are capable of protecting against globally diverse HIV-1 subtypes . One relevant setting to study the development of a strong, cross-reactive Nab response is HIV-1 superinfection ( SI ) , defined as sequential infections from different source partners . In this study, we examined the post-SI Nab responses from 21 Kenyan women collectively exposed to subtypes A , C , and D and superinfected after a median time of ~1 . 07 years following initial infection . Plasma samples chosen for analysis were collected at a median time point ~2 . 72 years post-SI . Using standard epitope mapping techniques that were applied to the previous cohorts , we focused on four main epitopes on the HIV-1 Envelope—the CD4-binding site , a V1/V2 glycan , the N332 supersite in V3 , and the membrane proximal external region of gp41 . Using computational sera delineation analyses, we found that 20 of the 21 superinfected women’s Nab responses could not be ascribed a single specificity with high confidence. These data are consistent with a model in which SI with diverse subtypes promotes the development of a broad polyclonal Nab response, and thus would provide support for vaccine designs using multivalent HIV immunogens to elicit a diverse repertoire of Nabs.
β-herpesviruses, such as human cytomegalovirus (HCMV), are a major cause of birth defects and neurological disorders. HCMV infection has been shown to disrupt Notch signaling in neural progenitor cells (NPCs), which are essential for fetal brain development. Hes1, a downstream effector of Notch signaling, is a key regulator of NPC fate and differentiation. In this study, we found that HCMV infection downregulates Hes1 protein levels in infected NPCs. We also identified IE1, a viral immediate-early protein, as a potential E3 ubiquitin ligase that mediates Hes1 ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation. Our findings suggest a novel mechanism by which HCMV disrupts Notch signaling and NPC differentiation, which may contribute to the neurological disorders caused by HCMV infection.
 In this study, we compared gene expression and transcription factor binding in blastoderm embryos of four Drosophila species: D. melanogaster, D. yakuba, D. pseudoobscura, and D. virilis. We found that mRNA levels are much better conserved than individual transcription factor binding events, and that changes in a gene's expression are poorly explained by changes in adjacent transcription factor binding. However, highly bound sites, sites in regions bound by multiple factors, and sites near genes are conserved more frequently than other binding, suggesting that a considerable amount of transcription factor binding is weakly or non-functional and not subject to purifying selection. Our study provides insights into the evolution of gene expression and transcription factor binding in Drosophila.
The goal of the global programmes to eliminate lymphatic filariasis (GPELF) is to eliminate the disease as a public health problem by 2020. The programme aims to achieve the goal by interrupting transmission through annual single dose mass drug administration (MDA) of albendazole (fixed dose 400 mg) either with diethylcarbamazine citrate (DEC, 6 mg/kg body weight) or ivermectin (150–200 µg/kg) for at least 5–6 years. By 2010 the programme had made significant progress in 53 of the 72 endemic countries, delivering billions of treatments to nearly 897 million people in the world. In India, the programme was initiated on a pilot basis in 13 of the 250 endemic districts during 1996–97 with DEC alone and thereafter with DEC and albendazole. The programme has been gradually scaled up to reach all the 250 endemic districts spread over 20 states and union territories covering nearly 421 of the 590 million people at risk in 2007. The impact of the programme is monitored once in two years in each implementation unit (IU) by screening the population in at least one sentinel and one spot-checks sites for microfilaraemia (Mf) [2]. Several endemic countries reported that delivering 5–6 rounds of MDA reduced the prevalence of Mf and antigenaemia (Ag) in many IUs [3]. In India, it has been reported that in 192 of the 250 IUs Mf-prevalence has reached <1% – the recommended threshold for proceeding with further epidemiological assessment [3]. Such an assessment is required prior to making a decision to stop or continue MDA in these IUs. The WHO monitoring and evaluation guidelines (2005) required a multi-step process to be completed before MDA could be stopped [2]. The recommended sampling strategy for stopping MDA in an IU is to test (i) by a cluster design based lot quality assurance-cluster sampling (LQAS) of 10 young children (age-class depends on number of rounds of MDA) from each of 30-clusters (communities) for antigenaemia (Ag) status and (ii) if no positives are found, an additional LQAS of 3000 school entrants drawn from the entire IU for Ag-status. MDA has to be stopped if no Ag-positives are detected by (ii) . The above procedure is applicable only when (a) the Mf-prevalence is <1% in both sentinel and spot check sites (b) Mf-prevalence is <1% in 5–10 additional sites of high risk transmission, and (c) Ag is negative among children aged 2–4 years in all these sites. Although this rigorous process was designed to ensure that transmission was stopped with a high degree of probability, it was cumbersome. Therefore, the WHO has revised the guidelines in 2011 [4] and proposed transmission assessment surveys (TAS) for making decision to stop/continue MDA. As per the revised guidelines, the recommended Ag-threshold for TAS is a defined number of Ag-positive children (depends on the target population size) such that there is at least a 75% chance of stopping MDA if the true prevalence is less than 1.0% and no more than a 5% chance of stopping MDA (incorrectly) if the true prevalence is ≥2.0%. TAS are to be carried out in IUs that have completed at least five rounds of MDA, each with >65% coverage and with Mf-prevalence of <1% in both sentinel and spot check sites. However, both the old and the revised guidelines suggested cluster design for the LQAS, which is not based on empirical evidence about the distributions of infection at household and site level. We carried out a study to address the above mentioned issues in two primary health centres (PHC) in Thanjavur district, India, known to be endemic for filariasis caused by periodic Wuchereria bancrofti and transmitted by Culex quinquefasciatus (National Vector Borne Disease Control programme, NVBDCP). A large proportion of the population of these two PHC areas, where eight rounds of MDA were completed, was screened for Mf and
 The systematic literature review found that temephos was effective at reducing entomological indices when applied as a single intervention. However, when applied in combination with other interventions, the effect was not sustained over time or failed to reduce immature stages. The community-effectiveness of temephos was dependent on factors such as quality of delivery, water turnover rate, type of water, and environmental factors. Timing of temephos deployment and its need for reapplication, along with behavioural factors such as reluctance to apply it to drinking water, and operational aspects such as cost, supplies, time and labour were further limitations identified in this review. In conclusion, when applied as a single intervention, temephos was found to be effective at suppressing entomological indices, but there is no evidence to suggest that it is associated with reductions in dengue transmission.
 The cohesin complex is a protein complex that holds sister chromatids together from the time of their duplication in S phase until their separation during mitosis. In budding yeast, cohesin is most abundant at the centromere and surrounding region, the pericentromere. We show that the budding yeast Ctf19 kinetochore subcomplex and the replication fork-associated factor, Csm3, are both important mediators of pericentromeric cohesion, but they act through distinct mechanisms. We propose that the Ctf19 complex ensures additional loading of cohesin at centromeres prior to passage of the replication fork, thereby ensuring its incorporation into functional linkages through a process requiring Csm3. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms controlling endogenous stem cell pools that are likely to be relevant for modulating stem cell regenerative capabilities.
 Dengue virus ( DENV ) is a major public health concern, with an estimated 100 million infections occurring every year . The complex array of concurrent host physiologic changes has hampered a complete understanding of underlying molecular mechanisms of dengue pathogenesis . We performed a systems level characterization of serum metabolome and lipidome of adult dengue fever ( DF ) patients at early febrile, defervescence, and convalescent stages of DENV infection using liquid chromatography- and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry . Sixty differential metabolites were identified in our metabolomics analysis and the main metabolite classes were free fatty acids , acylcarnitines , phospholipids , and amino acids . Major perturbed metabolic pathways included fatty acid biosynthesis and β-oxidation , phospholipid catabolism , steroid hormone pathway , etc . Analysis of phospholipids and sphingolipids verified the temporal trends and revealed association with lymphocytes and platelets numbers . These metabolites were significantly perturbed during the early stages , and normalized to control levels at convalescent stage , suggesting their potential utility as prognostic markers . DENV infection causes temporally distinct serum metabolome and lipidome changes , and many of the differential metabolites are involved in acute inflammatory responses . Our global analyses revealed early anti-inflammatory responses working in concert to modulate early pro-inflammatory processes , thus preventing the host from development of pathologies by excessive or prolonged inflammation .
