We also found that this association is not present in endosymbionts or obligate parasitic bacteria.  This suggests that SIDD sites may be more important for prokaryotes that are capable of adapting to changing environments.  Overall, our findings suggest that SIDD sites may play a role in regulating gene expression in response to environmental changes in prokaryotes.
 High-mobility group ( HMG ) B proteins are a group of eukaryotic DNA-binding proteins that play a pivotal role in global genomic functions and in the control of genes involved in specific developmental or metabolic pathways . In the filamentous ascomycete Podospora anserina, there are 12 HMG-box genes, including four mating-type genes that control fertilization and development of the fruit-body, and a mitochondrial gene involved in mitochondrial DNA stability. Systematic deletion analysis of the eight remaining uncharacterized HMG-box genes indicated that none were essential for viability, but that seven were involved in the sexual cycle. Transcriptional analyses of HMG-box genes in HMG-box deletion strains indicated that PaHMG5 is at the hub of a network of several HMG-box factors that regulate mating-type genes and mating-type target genes. Genetic analyses revealed that this network also controls fertility genes that are not regulated by mating-type transcription factors. This study points to the critical role of HMG-box members in sexual reproduction in fungi, as 11 out of 12 members were involved in the sexual cycle in P . anserina. PaHMG5 and SpSte11 are conserved transcriptional regulators of mating-type genes, although P . anserina and S . pombe diverged 550 million years ago. Two HMG-box genes, SOX9 and its upstream regulator SRY, also play an important role in sex determination in mammals. The P . anserina and S . pombe mating-type genes and their upstream regulatory factor form a module of HMG-box genes analogous to the SRY/SOX9 module, revealing a commonality of sex regulation in animals and fungi.
2013–2016 West African Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic was unprecedented in terms of the number of cases and survivors. Prior to this epidemic, limited data was available on the persistence of Ebola virus in survivors’ body fluids and the potential risk of transmission, including sexual transmission. Given the urgent need to determine the persistence of Ebola virus in survivors’ body fluids, an observational cohort study was designed and implemented during the epidemic response operation in Sierra Leone. The study was conducted in two phases, assessing the persistence of virus in multiple body fluids of 120 men and 120 women. Data from this study informed national and global guidelines in real time and demonstrated the need to implement semen testing programs among Ebola virus disease survivors. The study tools developed accelerated the implementation of such programs in Ebola virus disease affected countries and also informed studies examining persistence of Zika virus. Research is a vital component of the public health response to an epidemic of a poorly characterized disease. Adequate resources should be rapidly made available to answer critical research questions in order to better inform response efforts.
 The bacterium Escherichia coli lives in a complex chemical environment in the human intestine. To understand what chemical gradients these bacteria typically encounter, we used information theory and simulations to predict the distributions of gradients. We found that the bacterial chemotaxis sensory system is optimized to detect broad distributions of exponential gradients, which lead to log-normal stimuli and maximal drift velocity. Our results provide a first step towards deciphering the chemical nature of complex microenvironments, such as the human intestine.
 Hematopoietic stem cells ( HSCs ) are responsible for generating all mature blood cells throughout an individual's life. The lifespan of HSCs has been a topic of interest for many years, with some studies suggesting that HSCs are immortal and can self-renew indefinitely. However, recent research has shown that HSCs have a finite lifespan and that this lifespan is determined by the number of self-renewal cycles a HSC can undergo. The authors of this study used clonal repopulation experiments and computational-mathematical modeling to test the hypothesis that HSCs differ in their lifespan due to differences in their ability to self-renew. The results of the study suggest that HSCs with shorter lifespans have a higher probability of failure during self-renewal, while HSCs with longer lifespans have a lower probability of failure. The authors propose a new model based on reliability theory to account for the diversity of lifespans of HSCs. This model suggests that HSCs differ a priori in the number of self-renewal cycles they can undergo. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms underlying HSC lifespan and may have important implications for bone marrow transplantation and other stem cell therapies.
 Helminth infections are a major global health burden, with no effective vaccines currently available. Antibodies and alternatively activated macrophages ( AAM ) are crucial components of protective immunity against helminth infections. However, the mechanisms by which antibodies target these large multi-cellular parasites remain obscure. In this study, we demonstrate that helminth-specific antibodies induce the rapid trapping of tissue migrating helminth larvae and prevent tissue necrosis following challenge infection with the natural murine parasite Heligmosomoides polygyrus bakeri ( Hp ). Mice lacking antibodies ( JH−/− ) or activating Fc receptors ( FcRγ−/− ) harbored highly motile larvae, developed extensive tissue damage and accumulated less Arginase-1 expressing macrophages around the larvae. Moreover, Hp-specific antibodies induced FcRγ- and complement-dependent adherence of macrophages to larvae in vitro, resulting in complete larval immobilization. Antibody-induced expression of Arginase-1 in vitro and in vivo occurred independently of IL-4Rα signaling. In summary, we present a novel IL-4Rα-independent mechanism of alternative macrophage activation that is antibody-dependent and which both mediates anti-helminth immunity and prevents tissue disruption caused by migrating larvae.
DNA double strand breaks ( DSB ) are a major threat to genome integrity . The most accurate way to repair DSB is homologous recombination ( HR ) with an intact copy of the broken locus . However, the dynamics of HR are not well understood. We have developed a new, non-intrusive method to visualize resection in single living cells. By applying it to HO cleavage of the MAT locus on Saccharomyces cerevisiae chromosome III, we provide the first real-time analysis of resection in single living cells. We find that resection begins with transient confinement of the damaged chromatin region. Resection in a yku70 mutant began ∼10 min earlier than in wild type, defining this as the period of commitment to homology-dependent repair. Our new DNA-labelling and -targeting method will be widely applicable to fine-scale analysis of genome organization, dynamics and function in normal and pathological contexts.
 Chagas disease is a vector-borne disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. Reinfections by T. cruzi are possible in humans and can lead to lower or even hardly detectable parasitaemia. The frequency and timing of reinfections are not well understood. We used stochastic agent-based models to estimate the rate of re-inoculation in humans and to assess how frequent are reinfections during the acute and chronic stages of the disease. The best model predicted 0.032 (0.008–0.042) annual reinfections per individual with 98.4% of them occurring in the chronic phase. In addition, the parasite escapes to the adaptive immune response mounted after the primary infection in at least 20% of the events of re-inoculation. With these low rates, the risks of reinfection during the typically long chronic stage of the disease stand around 14% (4%-18%) and 60% (21%-70%) after 5 and 30 years, respectively. These low rates are better explained by the weak efficiency of the stercorarian mode of transmission than a highly efficient adaptive immune response. These estimates are of particular interest for vaccine development and for our understanding of the higher risk of chronic disease manifestations suffered by infected people living in endemic areas.
Dengue fever is a viral infection that can cause severe illness in some cases. The majority of dengue infections are subclinical, meaning they do not cause any symptoms. However, some people who have had a subclinical infection in the past may develop severe dengue illness when they are infected again. Researchers have been trying to understand why this happens and what factors contribute to severe dengue illness. In this study, researchers collected blood samples from school-aged children in Thailand before and after the dengue season. They then stimulated the cells from the blood samples with dengue virus and measured the amount of 30 different cytokines produced by the cells. They found that there were significant differences in the amount of cytokines produced by the cells depending on the type of dengue virus used for stimulation and whether the children developed symptomatic dengue illness or not. These findings suggest that there may be differences in the immune responses of people who develop severe dengue illness compared to those who develop subclinical infections. These results may be useful for evaluating dengue vaccines and understanding the pathology of dengue fever.
 The Drosophila wing imaginal disc is a model system for studying pattern formation in developing tissues. The Hedgehog ( Hh ) signaling pathway plays a crucial role in patterning the wing disc by controlling the expression of target genes along the anterior-posterior axis. However, the relationship between Hh concentration and gene expression patterns has not been fully understood. In this study, we used mathematical modeling to investigate how Hh signaling patterns the wing disc. Our results suggest that the steady-state Hh gradient is insufficient to determine more than two gene expression patterns in a concentration-dependent manner. Instead, we propose that Hh-dependent Patched ( Ptc ) up-regulation causes a transient expansion ( or “overshoot” ) of the Hh gradient before approaching its final distribution. Through experiments conducted in vivo, we provide evidence that this transient overshoot exists and that it is required to distinguish different spatial domains of gene expression in response to Hh. Our findings suggest a new model of pattern formation that takes into consideration gradient dynamics to explain Hh-dependent patterning of the wing disc.
 Alcohol abuse is a major public health issue worldwide. The mechanisms by which ethanol and anesthetics influence the nervous system are poorly understood. In this study, we describe the positional cloning and characterization of a new mouse mutation isolated in an N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea ( ENU ) forward mutagenesis screen for animals with enhanced locomotor activity. This allele, Lightweight ( Lwt ), disrupts the homolog of the Caenorhabditis elegans ( C . elegans ) unc-79 gene. While Lwt/Lwt homozygotes are perinatal lethal, Lightweight heterozygotes are dramatically hypersensitive to acute ethanol exposure. Experiments in C . elegans demonstrate a conserved hypersensitivity to ethanol in unc-79 mutants and extend this observation to the related unc-80 mutant and nca-1;nca-2 double mutants. Lightweight heterozygotes also exhibit an altered response to the anesthetic isoflurane, reminiscent of unc-79 invertebrate mutant phenotypes. In addition, Lightweight heterozygotes are mildly hyperactive when exposed to a novel environment and are smaller than wild-type animals. They also exhibit increased food consumption yet have a leaner body composition. Interestingly, Lightweight heterozygotes voluntarily consume more ethanol than wild-type littermates. The acute hypersensitivity to and increased voluntary consumption of ethanol observed in Lightweight heterozygous mice in combination with the observed hypersensitivity to ethanol in C . elegans unc-79 , unc-80 , and nca-1;nca-2 double mutants suggests a novel conserved pathway that might influence alcohol-related behaviors in humans.
 The immune response of mosquitoes against Plasmodium falciparum , the causative agent of human malaria, has been identified as a potential source of anti-Plasmodium genes and mechanisms to be exploited in efforts to control the malaria transmission cycle. One such mechanism is the Imd pathway, a conserved immune signaling pathway that has potent anti-P . falciparum activity. Silencing the expression of caspar, a negative regulator of the Imd pathway, or over-expressing rel2, an Imd pathway-controlled NFkappaB transcription factor, confers a resistant phenotype on A . gambiae mosquitoes that involves an array of immune effector genes. However, unexplored features of this powerful mechanism that may be essential for the implementation of a malaria control strategy still remain. Using RNA interference to singly or dually silence caspar and other components of the Imd pathway, we have identified genes participating in the anti-Plasmodium signaling module regulated by Caspar, each of which represents a potential target to achieve over-activation of the pathway. We also determined that the Imd pathway is most potent against the parasite's ookinete stage, yet also has reasonable activity against early oocysts and lesser activity against late oocysts. We further demonstrated that caspar silencing alone is sufficient to induce a robust anti-P . falciparum response even in the relative absence of resident gut microbiota. Finally, we established the relevance of the Imd pathway components and regulated effectors TEP1 , APL1 , and LRIM1 in parasite infection intensity-dependent defense, thereby shedding light on the relevance of laboratory versus natural infection intensity models. Our results highlight the physiological considerations that are integral to a thoughtful implementation of Imd pathway manipulation in A . gambiae as part of an effort to limit the malaria transmission cycle, and they reveal a variety of previously unrecognized nuances in the Imd-directed immune response against P . falciparum.
 Bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells ( BMMSCs ) are a promising therapy for fibrotic diseases. In this study, we investigated the anti-fibrotic potential of BMMSCs in an experimental model of lung fibrosis caused by the fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. We found that BMMSCs did not have any anti-fibrotic effect, and in fact, their interaction with the fungus promoted collagen expression and tissue remodeling.
 The recent expansion of phlebotomine vectors of Leishmania infantum in the Mediterranean subregion has been attributed to ongoing climate changes. The activity of sand flies is typically seasonal, and seasonal phenomena are sensitive to variations in climate. Therefore, current phenological data sets can provide a baseline for continuing investigations on sand fly population dynamics that may impact on future scenarios of leishmaniasis transmission. With this aim, in 2011–2013, a consortium of partners from eight Mediterranean countries carried out entomological investigations in sites where L . infantum transmission was recently reported. A common protocol for sand fly collection included monthly captures by CDC light traps, complemented by sticky traps in most of the sites. Collections were replicated for more than one season in order to reduce the effects of local weather events. Data from 99,000 collected specimens were analyzed, resulting in the description of seasonal dynamics of 56,000 sand flies belonging to L . infantum vector species throughout a wide geographical area, namely P . perniciosus ( Portugal , Spain and Italy ) , P . ariasi ( France ) , P . neglectus ( Greece ) , P . tobbi ( Cyprus and Turkey ) , P . balcanicus and P . kandelakii ( Georgia ) . Time of sand fly appearance/disappearance in collections differed between sites, and seasonal densities showed variations in each site. Significant correlations were found between latitude/mean annual temperature of sites and i ) the first month of sand fly appearance, that ranged from early April to the first half of June; ii ) the type of density trend, varying from a single peak in July/August to multiple peaks increasing in magnitude from May through September . A 3-modal trend, recorded for P . tobbi in Cyprus , represents a novel finding for a L . infantum vector . Adults ended the activity starting from mid September through November, without significant correlation with latitude/mean annual temperature of sites. The period of potential exposure to L . infantum in the Mediterranean subregion, as inferred by adult densities calculated from 3 years , 37 sites and 6 competent vector species , was associated to a regular bell-shaped density curve having a wide peak center encompassing the July-September period , and falling between early May to late October for more than 99% of values. Apparently no risk for leishmaniasis transmission took place from December through March in the years considered . We found a common pattern of nocturnal females activity , whose density peaked between 11 pm and 2 am . Despite annual variations, multiple collections performed over consecutive years provided homogeneous patterns of the potential behavior of leishmaniasis vectors in selected sites , which we propose may represent sentinel areas for future monitoring . In the investigated years , higher potential risk for L . infantum transmission in the Mediterranean was identified in the June-October period ( 97% relative vector density ) , however such risk was not equally distributed throughout the region , since density waves of adults occurred earlier and were more frequent in southern territories .
 Orientia tsutsugamushi is a bacterium that causes scrub typhus, a life-threatening disease. It is an obligate intracellular bacterium that mainly infects endothelial cells. In this study, the authors demonstrated that O . tsutsugamushi also replicated in monocytes isolated from healthy donors. In addition, O . tsutsugamushi altered the expression of more than 4,500 genes, as demonstrated by microarray analysis. The expression of type I interferon, interferon-stimulated genes and genes associated with the M1 polarization of macrophages was significantly upregulated. O . tsutsugamushi also induced the expression of apoptosis-related genes and promoted cell death in a small percentage of monocytes. Live organisms were indispensable to the type I interferon response and apoptosis and enhanced the expression of M1-associated cytokines. These data were related to the transcriptional changes detected in mononuclear cells isolated from patients with scrub typhus. Here, the microarray analyses revealed the upregulation of 613 genes, which included interferon-related genes, and some features of M1 polarization were observed in these patients, similar to what was observed in O . tsutsugamushi-stimulated monocytes in vitro. This is the first report demonstrating that monocytes are clearly polarized in vitro and ex vivo following exposure to O . tsutsugamushi. These results would improve our understanding of the pathogenesis of scrub typhus, during which interferon-mediated activation of monocytes and their subsequent polarization into an M1 phenotype appear critical. This study may give us a clue of new tools for the diagnosis of patients with scrub typhus.
The ability of ants to navigate through complex environments has been a topic of interest for many years. However, the neural mechanisms underlying this ability are still not well understood. In this study, we used a spiking neural model of the mushroom body neuropils in the ant brain to simulate the ability of ants to learn and remember visual routes. We found that the model was able to successfully learn and remember visual routes, even when the routes were complex and contained many turns. Our results suggest that the mushroom body neuropils in the ant brain may play a crucial role in visual navigation.
Plants have evolved sophisticated defense mechanisms against disease. In this study, we developed a system to study pathogen-triggered leaf abscission in Arabidopsis. We found that when Arabidopsis protects itself against drought by abscising its cauline leaves, it uses the same set of signaling components as are required for the shedding of flower petals after fertilization. We also found that the abscission receptor, HAE, utilizes SOMATIC EMBRYOGENESIS RECEPTOR-LIKE KINASES (SERK) as a co-receptor in the recognition of IDA peptide. Additionally, we found that the defense hormone salicylic acid (SA) likely regulates leaf shedding since a number of genes necessary for SA mediated defense are also necessary for the full leaf shedding defense response. Our findings suggest that leaf abscission is a bona fide defense mechanism against bacterial infection.
 The detection of image motion and the computation of its direction and speed is a major function of the visual system. In addition to being an intensely studied example of retinal signal processing, motion detection represents an important class of computational problems in neuroscience: the detection of spatiotemporal patterns. The retina's ability to detect the direction of motion was discovered more than 40 years ago when Barlow and his colleagues found direction-selective ganglion cells. It was later shown that starburst amacrine cells (SACs), which provide input to direction-selective ganglion cells, generate direction-selective Ca2+ signals in their dendrites. Optical recordings of visual stimulus-evoked Ca2+ signals also showed that dendritic sectors can be activated independently and that the strongest [Ca2+] increases are in the distal portions of the dendrites, near the output synapses. Electrical isolation of sectors from each other, which is necessary for dendritic processing to be local, is provided by the peculiar dendritic morphology of SACs and a low impedance at the soma. At least two fundamentally different mechanisms have been proposed for direction-selective computation in SAC dendrites: dendrite-intrinsic electrotonics and lateral inhibition. Despite extensive modeling, the physiological mechanism underlying intrinsic direction-selective computation in SAC dendrites has remained elusive. In this study, we focused on the electrical properties of SACs using whole-cell recording, two-photon imaging, and compartmental modeling. We show that direction-selective computation in SACs can be generated by a dendrite-autonomous mechanism that relies on active conductances and a somatodendritic voltage gradient.
43 different human pathogens from a range of taxonomic groups with diverse life-histories were analyzed to determine the relationship between infective dose and mode of action of molecules used by pathogens to infect hosts. It was found that pathogens using local action have lower infective doses, but are not less virulent than those using distant action. Instead, virulence was negatively correlated with infective dose, and higher in pathogens infecting wounded skin compared with those ingested or inhaled. These results show that broad-scale comparative analyses can explain variation in parasite traits such as infective dose and virulence, while highlighting the importance of mechanistic details.
 Schistosomes are parasitic flatworms that cause schistosomiasis, a disease affecting over 200 million people worldwide. The most experimentally tractable schistosome species, S. mansoni, is used in this study to investigate the role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in developmental processes. Using the "miRNA-blind" bioinformatics tool Sylamer, the authors analyzed the 3'-UTRs of transcripts differentially expressed between juvenile and adult worms. They found that the miR-277/4989 family target sequence is the only one significantly enriched in the transition from juvenile to adult worms. The authors also describe a novel miRNA, sma-miR-4989, and propose hairpin folds for both miRNAs compatible with the miRNA pathway. They found that sma-miR-4989 is expressed in tegumental cells located proximal to the oesophagus gland and also distributed throughout the male worms' body. The authors suggest that sma-miR-277/4989 might play a dominant role in post-transcriptional regulation during development of juvenile worms and an important role in the sexual development of female schistosomes.
 The SARS-CoV-2 virus, which causes COVID-19, has been identified as a member of the Betacoronavirus genus. The SARS-CoV-2 virus is believed to have originated from bats, but the exact origin of the virus is unknown. In this study, researchers conducted a 5-year surveillance of SARS-related coronaviruses (SARSr-CoVs) in a cave inhabited by multiple species of horseshoe bats in Yunnan Province, China. The full-length genomes of 11 newly discovered SARSr-CoV strains, together with previous findings, revealed that the SARSr-CoVs circulating in this single location are highly diverse in the S gene, ORF3, and ORF8. Importantly, strains with high genetic similarity to SARS-CoV in the hypervariable N-terminal domain (NTD) and receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the S1 gene, the ORF3 and ORF8 region, respectively, were all discovered in this cave. In addition, SARSr-CoVs highly similar to human SARS-CoV in ORF3b and in the split ORF8a and 8b were also discovered. Moreover, SARSr-CoV strains from this cave were more closely related to SARS-CoV in the non-structural protein genes ORF1a and 1b compared with those detected elsewhere. Recombination analysis showed evidence of frequent recombination events within the S gene and around the ORF8 between these SARSr-CoVs. The researchers hypothesize that the direct progenitor of SARS-CoV may have originated after sequential recombination events between the precursors of these SARSr-CoVs. Cell entry studies demonstrated that three newly identified SARSr-CoVs with different S protein sequences are all able to use human ACE2 as the receptor, further exhibiting the close relationship between strains in this cave and SARS-CoV. This work provides new insights into the origin and evolution of SARS-CoV and highlights the necessity of preparedness for future emergence of SARS-like diseases.
 Soil-transmitted helminths ( STHs ) are a major cause of morbidity in humans, particularly in developing countries. The faecal egg count reduction test ( FECRT ) is a widely used method for monitoring drug efficacy in STH infections. However, recent evidence suggests that density-dependent fecundity may affect the accuracy of the FECRT. Density-dependent fecundity refers to the phenomenon whereby the number of eggs laid by female worms decreases as the worm burden increases. This may lead to an underestimation of drug efficacy in the FECRT if surviving worms increase their egg output after treatment. The study examined the potential impact of density-dependent fecundity on the accuracy of the FECRT using recent evidence from hookworm infections in dogs and humans. The results suggest that density-dependent fecundity may affect the accuracy of the FECRT, particularly in cases where the worm burden is heavy. The study highlights the need for further research to better understand the impact of density-dependent fecundity on the accuracy of the FECRT and to develop alternative methods for monitoring drug efficacy in STH infections.
 We have shown that Heparan Sulfate ( HS ) synthetase Ext1 is required for lung branching morphogenesis in mice. We found that deletion of Ext1 in the lung epithelium resulted in expanded branching tips and reduced branching number, associated with several mesenchymal developmental defects. We also demonstrated an expanded Fgf10 expression and increased FGF signaling activity in Ext1 mutant lungs, suggesting a cell non-autonomous mechanism. Consistent with this, we observed reduced levels of SHH signaling which is responsible for suppressing Fgf10 expression. Moreover, reactivating SHH signaling in mutant lungs rescued the tip dilation phenotype and attenuated FGF signaling. Importantly, the reduced SHH signaling activity did not appear to be caused by decreased Shh expression or protein stability; instead, biologically active form of SHH proteins were reduced in both the Ext1 mutant epithelium and surrounding wild type mesenchymal cells. Together, our study highlights the epithelial HS as a key player for dictating SHH signaling critical for lung morphogenesis.
 We present a theoretical model for detecting genome rearrangements and fusion genes using paired-end sequencing. We derive a formula for the probability of detecting a fusion gene given a set of paired-end reads and use it to predict fusion genes in breast cancer samples. We find that we can accurately predict fusion genes with a relatively small number of large-size fragments. We also evaluate how different parameters of a sequencing strategy impact breakpoint detection, breakpoint localization, and fusion gene detection. These results will be useful in calibrating future cancer sequencing efforts, particularly large-scale studies of many cancer genomes that are enabled by next-generation sequencing technologies.
 In this study, we developed a mathematical model of chemotaxis that accounts for the coordinated action of separable but interrelated processes: motility, gradient sensing, and polarization. We implemented the modules in terms of reaction-diffusion equations and demonstrated migration and accompanying changes in cellular morphology in simulations using a mechanical model of the cell cortex. The central module is an excitable network that accounts for random migration, while a local excitation, global inhibition module biases the direction in which excitability is directed. A polarization module linked to the excitable network through the cytoskeleton allows unstimulated cells to move persistently and for cells in gradients to gradually acquire distinct sensitivity between front and back. Finally, by varying the strengths of various feedback loops in the model, we obtained cellular behaviors that mirror those of genetically altered cell lines. Our model accounts for nearly all the reported observations of chemotaxing cells.
 Tudor containing protein 6 ( TDRD6 ) is a male germ line-specific protein essential for chromatoid body ( ChB ) structure and elongated spermatid development. Here we show that TDRD6 interacts with the key protein arginine methyl transferase PRMT5 , which supports splicing. TDRD6 also associates with spliceosomal core protein SmB in the absence of RNA and in an arginine methylation dependent manner. In Tdrd6-/- diplotene spermatocytes PRMT5 association with SmB and arginine dimethylation of SmB are much reduced. TDRD6 deficiency impairs the assembly of spliceosomes, which feature 3 . 5-fold increased levels of U5 snRNPs. In the nucleus, these deficiencies in spliceosome maturation correlate with decreased numbers of SMN-positive bodies and Cajal bodies involved in nuclear snRNP maturation. Transcriptome analysis of TDRD6-deficient diplotene spermatocytes revealed high numbers of splicing defects such as aberrant usage of intron and exons as well as aberrant representation of splice junctions. Together, this study demonstrates a novel function of TDRD6 in spliceosome maturation and mRNA splicing in prophase I spermatocytes.
 The study of bacterial colonization dynamics is important for understanding the transmission of infectious diseases and the success of clinical decolonization protocols. However, determining whether two strains should be considered the same strain is challenging, especially when the genomes are closely related. Here, we present a fully Bayesian model that provides probabilities of whether two strains should be considered the same strain, allowing us to determine bacterial clearance and acquisition from genomes sampled over time. We demonstrate the method's utility by analyzing a large collection of methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) genomes obtained through a clinical trial. The method provides a rigorous quantification of uncertainty and explicit statement of modeling assumptions, making it suitable for studies of the characteristics that impact colonization in the presence and absence of interventions.
Plants generate new organs through the activity of populations of stem cells called meristems. The shoot apical meristem (SAM) initiates leaves, flowers, and lateral meristems in highly ordered, spiralled, or whorled patterns via a process called phyllotaxis. It is commonly accepted that the active transport of the plant hormone auxin plays a major role in this process. Current hypotheses propose that cellular hormone transporters of the PIN family would create local auxin maxima at precise positions, which in turn would lead to organ initiation. To explain how auxin transporters could create hormone fluxes to distinct regions within the plant, different concepts have been proposed. A major hypothesis, canalization, proposes that the auxin transporters act by amplifying and stabilizing existing fluxes, which could be initiated, for example, by local diffusion. This convincingly explains the organised auxin fluxes during vein formation, but for the shoot apical meristem a second hypothesis was proposed, where the hormone would be systematically transported towards the areas with the highest concentrations. This implies the coexistence of two radically different mechanisms for PIN allocation in the membrane, one based on flux sensing and the other on local concentration sensing. Because these patterning processes require the interaction of hundreds of cells, it is impossible to estimate on a purely intuitive basis if a particular scenario is plausible or not. Therefore, computational modelling provides a powerful means to test this type of complex hypothesis. Here, using a dedicated computer simulation tool, we show that a flux-based polarization hypothesis is able to explain auxin transport at the shoot meristem as well, thus providing a unifying concept for the control of auxin distribution in the plant. Further experiments are now required to distinguish between flux-based polarization and other hypotheses.
 Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease that affects humans and animals. The visceral form of the disease, called kala-azar, is caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani and can be fatal if left untreated. Currently, the diagnosis of kala-azar relies on the detection of specific antibodies in the blood. However, these antibodies can persist even after successful treatment, making it difficult to determine whether a patient has been cured. To address this issue, researchers have been searching for new biomarkers that can be used to monitor the clinical status of patients with kala-azar. In this study, the researchers used a combination of genomic and bioinformatic approaches to identify potential biomarkers. They first compared the genomes of different Leishmania species to identify proteins that are unique to L. donovani. They then used bioinformatic tools to predict which of these proteins are likely to be recognized by human antibodies. Finally, they tested the most promising candidates in prototype diagnostic tests. The results of this study suggest that the protein rK28 could be a useful biomarker for monitoring the clinical status of patients with kala-azar.
 Cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) is a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania parasites that are transmitted by sandflies. The disease is characterized by a wide range of clinical manifestations, including papules, nodules, plaques, and ulcers. The most common form of CL is caused by Leishmania major and Leishmania tropica, which are found in the Mediterranean region, the Middle East, and North Africa. The diagnosis of CL is usually made by a combination of clinical examination, microscopy, and molecular testing. In this study, we reviewed the clinical and microscopic data of 317 patients with CL from six different countries. We found that 195 (61.5%) of the cases had granulomas, which were divided into four types: caseating, suppurative, and tuberculoid without necrosis. The caseating and tuberculoid granuloma groups were significantly different in terms of the geographical source and the distribution of RP. The time needed to achieve healing was notably shorter in tuberculoid vs. caseating group. Parasitic Index, CL species, and other considered variables did not differ for the granuloma type groups. In our multiregional large cohort, a notable 18.2% of all CL cases harbored caseating granulomas, therefore; CL should be considered part of the differential diagnosis for cases with caseating granulomas in endemic regions, especially considering that the regions included in our cohort are also endemic for TB. Of note, cases of CL with caseating granulomas also showed a slower healing process, with no association with specific species, which may be due to worse host immune response in such cases or to a more aggressive leishmania strains.
 Type 2 diabetes is a complex disease that results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors. In this study, the authors identified a candidate gene for a diabetogenic QTL in mice. The QTL, Nidd/SJL, was previously identified in an outcross population of New Zealand Obese (NZO) and SJL mice. The authors used congenic introgression and reporter crosses to identify a critical interval of distal chromosome 4 that conferred the diabetic phenotype. They then sequenced, qRT-PCR, and RACE-PCR 10 genes in the critical interval and found that Zfp69 was the most likely candidate for the diabetogenic effect of Nidd/SJL. The authors also found that a retrotransposon in intron 3 of Zfp69 disrupted the gene in NZO and C57BL/6J mice, leading to the production of a truncated mRNA that lacked the coding sequence for the KRAB and Znf-C2H2 domains of Zfp69. When combined with the B6.V-Lepob background, the diabetogenic Zfp69SJL allele produced hyperglycaemia, reduced gonadal fat, and increased plasma and liver triglycerides. The authors conclude that Zfp69 is the most likely candidate for the diabetogenic effect of Nidd/SJL and that retrotransposon IAPLTR1a contributes substantially to the genetic heterogeneity of mouse strains. Expression of the transcription factor in adipose tissue may play a role in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes.
 Th cell differentiation is a complex process that involves the interplay of multiple signaling pathways and transcriptional regulatory networks. In this study, we propose an integrated and comprehensive model of the regulatory network and signaling pathways controlling Th cell differentiation. We use a logical formalism to perform extensive dynamical analyses and identify stable states corresponding to canonical Th1, Th2, Th17, and Treg subtypes. However, we also find that these subtypes coexist with other hybrid cell types that co-express combinations of Th1, Th2, Treg, and Th17 markers in an environment-dependent fashion. Our logical analysis highlights the nature of these cell types and their relationships to canonical Th subtypes. This study provides a valuable resource for understanding the complex process of Th cell differentiation and its regulation.
 We have developed a thermodynamic model of transcription factor binding to evaluate the contribution of different biophysical forces to the binding of five regulators of early embryonic anterior-posterior patterning in Drosophila melanogaster . Our model uses DNA sequence and in vitro protein-DNA affinities alone to achieve a correlation of ∼0 . 4 with experimental measurements of in vivo binding . Incorporating cooperativity and competition among the five factors , and accounting for spatial patterning by modeling binding in every nucleus independently , had little effect on prediction accuracy . A major source of error was the prediction of binding events that do not occur in vivo , which we hypothesized reflected reduced accessibility of chromatin . To test this , we incorporated experimental measurements of genome-wide DNA accessibility into our model , effectively restricting predicted binding to regions of open chromatin . This dramatically improved our predictions to a correlation of 0 . 6–0 . 9 for various factors across known target genes . Finally , we used our model to quantify the roles of DNA sequence , accessibility , and binding competition and cooperativity . Our results show that , in regions of open chromatin , binding can be predicted almost exclusively by the sequence specificity of individual factors , with a minimal role for protein interactions . We suggest that a combination of experimentally determined chromatin accessibility data and simple computational models of transcription factor binding may be used to predict the binding landscape of any animal transcription factor with significant precision .
 The basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factors are important regulators of cell proliferation and differentiation. The E protein family of bHLH transcription factors and their inhibitors, the Id proteins, regulate cell proliferation in metazoans. The Drosophila E protein orthologue Daughterless (Da) and the Id orthologue Extramacrochaetae (Emc) are the only members of these classes of bHLH proteins in Drosophila. Although these factors are involved in controlling proliferation, the mechanism underlying this regulatory activity is poorly understood. Through a genetic analysis, we show that during the development of epithelial cells in the imaginal discs, the G2/M transition, and hence cell proliferation, is controlled by Emc via Da. In eukaryotic cells, the main activator of this transition is the Cdc25 phosphatase, string. Our genetic analyses reveal that the ectopic expression of string in cells with reduced levels of Emc or high levels of Da is sufficient to rescue the proliferative defects seen in these mutant cells. Moreover, we present evidence demonstrating a role of Da as a transcriptional repressor of string. Taken together, these findings define a mechanism through which Emc controls cell proliferation by regulating the activity of Da, which transcriptionally represses string.
 Filamentous growth is a developmental transition observed in yeast cells that form elongated and connected multicellular filaments. This transition is induced in response to several cell stresses and is regulated by a number of signaling pathways. In this study, we used quantitative phosphoproteomics to identify key proteins in specific pathways and discover protein-protein interactions that underlie the filamentous growth transition in yeast. We developed a comprehensive quantitative analysis pipeline customized for SILAC data that includes phosphopeptide meta-analysis, correlation network analysis, and causal relationship discovery. We applied this pipeline to our current yeast data and identified candidate proteins that contribute to the filamentous growth response. We validated these proteins by literature mining and inferred causal relationships between them. Our results suggest potential proteins that can be further intervened and studied in the future.
 The evolution of heteromorphic sex chromosomes ( e.g., XY in males or ZW in females ) has repeatedly elicited the evolution of two kinds of chromosome-specific regulation: dosage compensation (e.g., equalization of X chromosome gene expression in males and females) and meiotic sex chromosome inactivation (MSCI) (e.g., transcriptional silencing and heterochromatinization of the X during meiosis in the male germline). How the X chromosome is regulated in the Drosophila melanogaster male germline is unclear. Here we report three new findings concerning gene expression from the X in Drosophila testes. First, X chromosome-wide dosage compensation appears to be absent from most of the Drosophila male germline. Second, microarray analysis provides no evidence for X chromosome-specific inactivation during meiosis. Third, we confirm the previous discovery that the expression of transgene reporters driven by autosomal spermatogenesis-specific promoters is strongly reduced when inserted on the X chromosome versus the autosomes; but we show that this chromosomal difference in expression is established in premeiotic cells and persists in meiotic cells. The magnitude of the X-autosome difference in transgene expression cannot be explained by the absence of dosage compensation, suggesting that a previously unrecognized mechanism limits expression from the X during spermatogenesis in Drosophila. These findings help to resolve several previously conflicting reports and have implications for patterns of genome evolution and speciation in Drosophila.
 The study focused on the early dynamics and control of attachment and effacement (A/E) lesion development during Citrobacter rodentium infection in mice. The authors found that the initiation of colonic C. rodentium microcolonies is limited to a very early stage of infection and that these early-established, clonally-renewing A/E lesions trigger a local innate immune response that protects the epithelium from de novo A/E lesion formation by luminal bacteria. This local innate immune response critically determines disease severity and outcome. The study provides new insights into the pathogenesis of C. rodentium infection and highlights the importance of early immune responses in controlling intestinal pathogens.
β-diversity is a measure of the difference between two populations of species, taxonomical units, or gene variants. However, traditional methods for measuring β-diversity suffer from bias due to subsampling. Here, we developed a Bayesian method to estimate β-diversity from incomplete samples when the total number of objects in each population is known. Our method takes into account the rates of subsampling and produces unbiased and Bayes-optimal estimates of β-diversity. We applied our method to the var family of P. falciparum, a malaria parasite. We found that our method produced more accurate estimates of β-diversity than traditional methods. We also developed a web tool and open-source code for our method.
 In this study, the authors used cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA) as a model to understand the intramolecular interactions that regulate the active state mechanics of eukaryotic protein kinases (EPKs). They found that the previously identified salt bridge between a lysine from the β3-strand and a glutamate from the αC-helix is not essential for phosphoryl transfer but is essential for the active state mechanics. The authors also identified an electrostatic interaction between the phosphorylated activation loop and αC-helix and an ensemble of hydrophobic residues of the Regulatory spine and Shell. They further showed that the highly conserved β3-lysine is not required for phosphoryl transfer but is essential for the active state mechanics. The authors used molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, molecular modeling, and a thermal shift assay to decipher the interactions required for the mechanics of the catalytic cycle as well as phosphoryl transfer. Their findings provide a new understanding of the intramolecular interactions that regulate the active state mechanics of EPKs.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a neglected tropical disease caused by the parasite Wuchereria bancrofti and transmitted by mosquitoes. The Global Programme to Eliminate LF recommends conducting Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS) to assess recent transmission after mass drug administration (MDA). Two survey designs were compared in American Samoa: a school-based survey of children aged 6–7 years and a community-based survey of people aged ≥8 years. The school-based survey identified nine antigen-positive children and found an overall adjusted CFA prevalence of 0.7%. Of the nine positive children, one was microfilariaemic. The community-based survey identified 102 antigen-positive people and estimated an overall adjusted CFA prevalence of 6.2%. Adjusted village-level prevalence ranged from 0–47.1%. School-based TAS had limited sensitivity and negative predictive value but had high specificity and positive predictive value for identifying villages with ongoing transmission. American Samoa failed the school-based TAS in 2016, and the community-based survey identified higher than expected numbers of antigen-positive people. School-based TAS was logistically simpler and enabled sampling of a larger proportion of the target population but the results did not provide a good indication of the overall CFA prevalence in older age groups and was not sensitive at identifying foci of ongoing transmission. The community-based survey identified antigen-positive individuals of all ages and foci of high antigen prevalence. Both surveys confirmed recrudescence of LF transmission.
 Sex determination is the process by which an animal decides whether it will develop as a male or a female. In vertebrates, sex determination is generally divided into two phases: primary and secondary. Primary sex determination is the process by which the primordial gonad commits to either an ovary or a testis developmental fate. Secondary sex determination is the process by which the somatic tissues of the organism differentiate with sex-specific characteristics. In zebrafish, primary sex determination appears to be regulated by a ZZ/ZW genetic system, though the gene (s) involved has not been identified. By contrast, several studies have concluded that the most commonly used domesticated zebrafish strains lack any major genetic sex determinant, and instead rely on a polygenic system that is strain dependent. However, even in wild strains where the W chromosome is necessary for female primary sex determination, it is not absolutely correlated with female development, as a fraction of ZW individuals develop as males. These results show that while a genetic sex determining system can strongly influence the outcome of sex determination in zebrafish, it is not an absolute prerequisite. In addition, oocytes are required for primary female sex determination and throughout adult life to maintain the differentiated female state. In the present study, we test whether the oocyte-expressed signaling molecules Gdf9 and Bmp15 have any role in female sex determination or maintenance of female sex differentiation in zebrafish. We find that bmp15 mutant females initially have normal development, but during the juvenile stage, oocytes are degraded after they arrest at early stages, and the premeiotic germ cells switch to a spermatogenic program as the gonad transforms to a fully functional testis. Consequently, all bmp15 mutant adults are fertile males. Additionally, we find that by mutational analysis, the somatic gonad-expressed Cyp19a1a aromatase, an enzyme responsible for estrogen production by the ovary, is required for female sexual development because all mutant animals develop as males. Interestingly, we find that in wild-type ovaries, cyp19a1a is initially expressed in theca cells, but not granulosa cells that surround early stage oocytes, but then is upregulated in granulosa cells that surround stage II oocytes. In bmp15 mutants, by contrast, cyp19a1a expression in theca cells is apparently normal, but we do not detect its expression in granulosa cells. Together, these results argue that bmp15 functions to maintain female sex determination, in part by promoting cyp19a1a expression, and therefore estrogen production, by granulosa cells. To our knowledge, this is the first instance in a vertebrate of the identification of a germ cell–derived signal that is required for maintaining a specific sexual phenotype.
 Hox proteins are transcription factors that play a crucial role in controlling morphogenesis along the anterior-posterior body axis of animals. They regulate distinct sets of target genes in a highly localized manner, sometimes even only in a single cell. In this study, we analyzed the regulation of the cell death gene reaper ( rpr ) by the Hox protein Deformed ( Dfd ) and found that local activation of rpr expression in the anterior part of the maxillary segment is achieved through a combinatorial interaction of Dfd with at least eight functionally diverse transcriptional regulators on a minimal enhancer. This suggests that context-dependent combinations of Hox proteins and other transcription factors on small, modular Hox response elements could be responsible for the proper spatio-temporal expression of Hox targets. Thus, a large number of transcription factors are likely to be directly involved in Hox target gene regulation in vivo.
Plants have a two-layered immune system that protects them from pathogens. The first layer is called MAMP-triggered immunity (MTI), which is activated by the recognition of microbe-associated molecular patterns (MAMPs) by pattern recognition receptors (PRRs). The second layer is called effector-triggered immunity (ETI), which is activated by the recognition of effectors by NB-LRR proteins. In this study, the authors studied the genetic requirements for defense responses of an autoactive mutant of ADR1-L2, a coiled-coil (CC)-NB-LRR protein. They found that the autoactive mutant requires an intact P-loop, which is a conserved homology region necessary for proper plant NB-LRR activity. The authors also found that the autoactive mutant is negatively regulated by EDS1 and AtMC1, and that its transcriptional regulation is correlated with its phenotypic outputs. These findings provide insight into an SA-dependent feedback regulation loop, which includes ADR1-L2.
 DNA methylation is a key epigenetic modification that plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression. In Arabidopsis, DNA methylation is mediated by the RdDM (RNA-directed DNA methylation) pathway, which involves the production of noncoding RNAs that guide DNA methylation. In this study, we found that the SU(VAR)3-9 homolog SUVH9 and the double-stranded RNA-binding protein IDN2 are components of the RdDM pathway that interact with MORC6 to mediate transcriptional silencing. We also found that other RdDM components, including Pol IV, Pol V, RDR2, and DRM2, are required for transcriptional silencing at a subset of MORC6 target loci. These results suggest that DNA methylation is linked to heterochromatin condensation and thereby enhances transcriptional silencing at methylated genomic regions.
 The molecular chaperone Hsp90 is a stress-response protein that helps maintain protein homeostasis in cells. In this study, the authors used zebrafish as a model organism to investigate the role of Hsp90 in developmental anomalies. They found that partial inhibition of Hsp90 function in zebrafish led to the uncovering of previously unobserved developmental anomalies, including anophthalmia, microphthalmia, and coloboma. These anomalies were caused by missense mutations in different genes, and the severity of the anomalies was modified by Hsp90 inhibition. The authors also found that Hsp90 inhibition could ameliorate the severity of some developmental anomalies. These findings suggest that Hsp90 plays a role in the development of certain anomalies and that its inhibition can modify the severity of these anomalies.
 N-terminal acetylation is a common modification of proteins that occurs during protein synthesis. It is important for protein folding, stability, and function. However, the biological function of N-terminal acetylation is not well understood. In this study, we analyzed the N-terminal peptides of proteins extracted from Drosophila Kc167 cells and found that N-terminal acetylation occurs in insects with a similar frequency as in humans. We also identified the ( X ) PX rule, which indicates the prevention of acetylation under all circumstances. We used this rule to genetically modify a protein to study the biological relevance of N-terminal acetylation. Our results suggest that N-terminal acetylation is important for protein folding and function.
 RNA polymerase III ( RNAP III ) is a multisubunit enzyme that synthesizes small RNAs such as tRNAs, which are essential for protein synthesis.  RNAP III terminates transcription at specific sequences called terminators, which are usually short tracts of nucleotides.  The termination process involves multiple subunits of RNAP III, including C11, which is required for efficient termination and reinitiation.  In this study, the authors used two genetic screens to identify mutations in the largest subunit of RNAP III, Rpc1, that affect termination.  They found that mutations in the bridge helix and trigger loop of Rpc1, as well as in the pore entrance and funnel, affect termination efficiency.  The authors also found that mutations in the trigger loop increase elongation rate, while mutations in the pore entrance and funnel increase transcription output.  These findings suggest that the mobile elements of the RNAP III active center, including C11, are key determinants of termination and that some of the mutations activate RNAP III for overall transcription.  The authors propose a kinetic coupling model in which elongation rate is inversely related to termination efficiency.  These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of RNAP III termination and transcription regulation.
 The ability of cells to respond to internal and external cues depends largely on reversible post-translational modifications of proteins, such as phosphorylation. SH2 domains are responsible for recognizing phosphorylated tyrosine residues and play an important role in signal transduction. Experiments using peptide libraries indicate that each SH2 domain binds a different spectrum of phosphopeptides. However, the genome-wide determination of the binding specificity of SH2 domains using peptide libraries seems impractical. We developed a method to predict SH2-mediated protein-protein interactions using the structure of SH2-phosphopeptide complexes and the FoldX algorithm. Our approach performs similarly to experimentally derived consensus sequences and substitution matrices at predicting known in vitro and in vivo targets of SH2 domains. We used our method to provide a set of high-confidence interactions for human SH2 domains with known structure filtered on secondary structure and phosphorylation state. We validated the predictions using literature-derived SH2 interactions and a probabilistic score obtained from a naive Bayes integration of information on coexpression, conservation of the interaction in other species, shared interaction partners, and functions. Our predictions lead to a new hypothesis for the role of SH2 domains in signaling.
 The accumulation of amyloidogenic proteins is a hallmark of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Intrinsically disordered proteins, like tau, are enriched with proline residues that regulate both secondary structure and aggregation propensity. Cyclophilin 40 (CyP40), a proline isomerase, dissolves tau amyloids in vitro and ameliorates silver-positive and oligomeric tau species in a mouse model of tau accumulation, preserving neuronal health and cognition. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) revealed that CyP40 interacts with tau at sites rich in proline residues. CyP40 was also able to interact with and disaggregate other aggregating proteins that contain prolines. Moreover, CyP40 lacking PPIase activity prevented its capacity for disaggregation in vitro. Finally, we describe a unique structural property of CyP40 that may permit disaggregation to occur in an energy-independent manner. This study identifies a novel human protein disaggregase and, for the first time, demonstrates its capacity to dissolve intracellular amyloids.
 Heterocyst differentiation is a process of cellular differentiation in which a subset of cells in a filament of cyanobacteria differentiate into specialized nitrogen-fixing cells. This process is regulated by a genetic circuit that controls the expression of specific genes. In this work, we develop a mathematical model of the genetic circuit that controls heterocyst differentiation. We show that the model can reproduce the main features of the process, including the formation and maintenance of heterocyst patterns. We also show that noise plays an important role in the onset of differentiation. Our work provides insight into the mechanisms underlying heterocyst differentiation and highlights the importance of noise in the development of complex biological systems.
 Onchocerciasis is a parasitic disease that causes skin lesions and blindness. The Community Directed Treatment with Ivermectin (CDTI) program has been implemented in Cameroon since 2005 to control the disease. However, despite the program's success in reducing the prevalence of onchocerciasis, it is still above the non-transmission threshold in some regions. This study aimed to explore the association between people's beliefs and perceptions of the CDTI program and their adherence to ivermectin in three regions of Cameroon. The study found that people who had a positive opinion of the program were more likely to adhere to ivermectin than those who had a negative opinion. The most common misconception about onchocerciasis transmission was the lack of hygiene, especially in Bafia and Yabassi. In Bafang, high proportions of people believed that onchocerciasis was due to high consumption of sugar. The study highlights the importance of addressing misconceptions about onchocerciasis transmission and involving communities in the implementation of the CDTI program.
 Epigenetic alterations have been associated with disease status, but it is unclear if they are directly causal for disease pathogenesis. In this study, we combined SNP and DNA methylation data with measurements of protein biomarkers for cancer, inflammation, or cardiovascular disease to investigate the relative contribution of genetic and epigenetic variation on biomarker levels. We identified 124 and 45 loci with effect sizes up to 0.22 standard units’ change per 1% change in DNA methylation levels and up to four standard units’ change per copy of the effective allele in the EWAS and GWAS respectively. Most GWAS loci were cis-regulatory whereas most EWAS loci were located in trans. We present associations between protein biomarker and DNA methylation levels at numerous loci in the genome. The associations are likely to reflect the underlying pattern of genetic variants, specific environmental exposures, or represent secondary effects to the pathogenesis of disease.
 We have discovered that varicella zoster virus ( VZV ) can directly inhibit the function of natural killer ( NK ) cells, which are important anti-viral immune effectors. VZV can infect NK cells and render them unresponsive to target cell stimulation, leading to a loss of both cytotoxic and cytokine responses. This impairment of function was dependent on direct contact between NK cells and VZV infected inoculum cells. Furthermore, we found that VZV also differentially targeted cytokine production compared to herpes simplex virus type 1 ( HSV-1 ). Our findings provide the first evidence that multiple aspects of NK cell anti-viral function are directly targeted for immune evasion by two human alphaherpesviruses.
 Apparent motion ( AM ) is a visual illusion where two stimuli presented alternately at different locations are perceived as a single stimulus moving continuously between the two locations. The neural mechanism underlying this illusion is not well understood. Some studies have suggested that increased activation of primary visual cortex ( V1 ) neurons tuned to locations along the AM path is responsible for the illusion. However, other studies have failed to find evidence for this. In this study, the authors used a computational model to investigate the neural mechanism underlying AM. They found that the model that incorporated only AM-related activation was not able to account for the observed masking effects. Instead, a model that incorporated strong suppression of responses to stimuli on the AM path captured the observed masking effects, arguing in favor of predictive coding theory.
 The HTLV-1 oncoprotein Tax plays a key role in CD4+ T cell transformation by promoting cell proliferation and survival through permanent activation of the NF-κB pathway and induction of many NF-κB target genes. Elucidating the underlying molecular mechanism is therefore critical in understanding HTLV-1-mediated transformation. We reconstituted Tax-stimulated IKK activation in a cell-free system to dissect the essential cellular components for primary IKK activation by Tax and studied the underlying biochemical mechanism. We found that Tax is a putative E3 ubiquitin ligase, which together with UbcH2, UhcH5c, or UbcH7, catalyzes the assembly of free mixed-linkage polyubiquitin chains. These free mixed-linkage polyubiquitin chains are then responsible for direct IKK activation by binding to the NEMO subunit of IKK. Our studies revealed the biochemical function and the underlying mechanism of Tax in the process of IKK activation, which utilizes the minimal cellular ubiquitination components for NF-κB activation.
 The propagule pressure hypothesis suggests that the number of individuals introduced to a new environment is a key determinant of the success of an alien species. However, the relationship between propagule pressure and establishment success has been largely unexplored. We conducted a systematic and quantitative review of this relationship using Bayesian meta-analytical methods. We found a positive mean effect of propagule pressure on establishment success for all taxa and life histories. However, the relationship was most critical for propagule pressures in the range of 10–100 individuals. Heterogeneity in effect size was associated with different analytical approaches, with some evidence of larger effect sizes in animal rather than plant introductions. We also found that studies conducted at spatial scales on which data can be directly measured produced larger effect sizes than those that relied on data that contained inconsistencies and reporting errors. Proxies for components of propagule pressure produced relatively weaker effect sizes than direct measures. Our analyses revealed remarkable consistency in the form of the relationship between propagule pressure and alien population establishment success.
 Interleukin-17A (IL-17) is a cytokine that enhances the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by attenuating the decay of their encoding mRNAs. The decay of many of these mRNAs depends on proteins called AUBps that target AU-rich elements in the 3′-untranslated region of mRNAs. Here we show that AUBps and the target mRNA assemble in a novel ribonucleoprotein complex in the presence of microRNA16 (miR16), which leads to the degradation of the target mRNA. IL-17 attenuates miR16 expression and promotes the binding of stabilizing AUBps over that of destabilizing AUBps, reducing mRNA decay. These findings indicate that miR16 independently of a seed sequence, directs the competition between degrading and stabilizing AUBps for target mRNAs. Since AUBps affect expression of about 8% of the human transcriptome and miR16 is ubiquitously expressed, IL-17 may in addition to inflammation affect many other cellular processes.
 The study aimed to investigate the relationship between human T . b . rhodesiense infection and human infective and non-human T . brucei s . l . circulating in cattle at village level in Kaberamaido and Dokolo Districts, Uganda. The study was undertaken in villages that had reported a case of sleeping sickness in the six months prior to sample collection and those villages that had never reported a case of sleeping sickness. The sleeping sickness status of the villages had a significant effect with higher odds of infection in cattle from case than from non-case villages for T . brucei s . l . ( OR: 2 . 94 , 95%CI: 1 . 38–6 . 24 ) . Cattle age had a significant effect ( p<0 . 001 ) on the likelihood of T . brucei s . l . infection within cattle: cattle between 18–36 months ( OR: 3 . 51 , 95%CI: 1 . 63–7 . 51 ) and cattle over 36 months ( OR: 4 . 20 , 95%CI: 2 . 08–8 . 67 ) had significantly higher odds of T . brucei s . l . infection than cattle under 18 months of age . Furthermore , village human sleeping sickness status had a significant effect ( p<0 . 05 ) on the detection of T . b . rhodesiense in the village cattle herd , with significantly higher likelihood of T . b . rhodesiense in the village cattle of case villages ( OR: 25 , 95%CI: 1 . 2–520 . 71 ) . Overall a higher than average T . brucei s . l . prevalence ( >16 . 3% ) in a village herd over was associated with significantly higher likelihood of T . b . rhodesiense being detected in a herd ( OR: 25 , 95%CI: 1 . 2–520 . 71 ) .
 The nervous system combines visual and physical motion cues to estimate our body movement for the control of posture. Here we show that the optimal strategy for combining these cues is to weight visually perceived movement velocities proportional to a power law. We find that this model accounts for the nonlinear influence of experimentally induced visual motion on human postural behavior both in our data and in previously published results. Our results suggest that the nervous system may use a power law to combine sensory cues for the control of posture.
 Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy (FSHD) is a progressive muscular dystrophy caused by decreased epigenetic repression of the D4Z4 macrosatellite repeats and ectopic expression of DUX4, a retrogene encoding a germline transcription factor encoded in each repeat. We have generated transgenic mice carrying D4Z4 arrays from an FSHD1 allele and from a control allele. These mice recapitulate important epigenetic and DUX4 expression attributes seen in patients and controls, respectively, including high DUX4 expression levels in the germline, (incomplete) epigenetic repression in somatic tissue, and FSHD-specific variegated DUX4 expression in sporadic muscle nuclei associated with D4Z4 chromatin relaxation. In addition, we show that DUX4 is able to activate similar functional gene groups in mouse muscle cells as it does in human muscle cells. These transgenic mice therefore represent a valuable animal model for FSHD and will be a useful resource to study the molecular mechanisms underlying FSHD and to test new therapeutic intervention strategies.
 The malaria vaccine candidate AMA1 induces protection against parasites that are closely related to the vaccine, but not against more distant strains. To overcome this problem, a vaccine containing four diverse allelic proteins (3D7, FVO, HB3, and W2mef) was developed and tested. The vaccine induced broadly inhibitory antibodies that were associated with increased conserved face and domain-3 responses and reduced domain-2 response. Inhibitory monoclonal antibodies raised against the vaccine reacted with a novel cross-reactive epitope at the rim of the hydrophobic trough on domain-1, which mapped to the conserved face of AMA1. Another novel mAb, which bound to domain-3, was broadly inhibitory and it blocked the proteolytic processing of AMA1. By itself, the epitope of a previously characterized 3D7-specific mAb was partially conserved across strains. The study suggests that a vaccine containing multiple diverse antigenic proteins could provide universal coverage by redirecting the immune response towards conserved epitopes.
 The asymmetric division of cells is a fundamental process in development and is essential for many biological processes. In this study, the authors investigate the timing of asymmetric cell division in the one-cell stage Caenorhabditis elegans embryo. They found that the mitotic spindle displaces to an asymmetric position at a precise time during mitosis, and that this displacement is regulated by the mitotic progression mechanism. The authors show that reducing the function of the proteasome, the anaphase-promoting complex (APC), or its activator Cdc20/Fizzy delays spindle displacement, while inactivating cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) in prometaphase causes the spindle to displace early. The authors conclude that the mitotic spindle is displaced at a specific time during mitosis to ensure that it is fully assembled before it begins to move. This study provides new insights into the mechanisms that regulate asymmetric cell division and may have important implications for understanding the development of multicellular organisms.
 High-altitude hypoxia is a severe environmental stress that affects the human body. Two regions where humans have adapted to high altitude are the Andean Altiplano and the Tibetan Plateau. In this study, we used a genome scan to identify genes that show evidence of positive natural selection in these two populations. We found that several key HIF-regulatory and targeted genes are responsible for adaptation to high altitude in Andeans and Tibetans, and several different chromosomal regions are implicated in the putative response to selection. These data suggest a genetic role in high-altitude adaptation and provide a basis for future genotype/phenotype association studies necessary to confirm the role of selection-nominated candidate genes and gene regions in adaptation to altitude.
DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) are dangerous events that can lead to genetic instability and cell death. To prevent this, cells have evolved several pathways to repair DSBs accurately. However, some pathways can lead to genetic instability, such as break-induced replication (BIR). Inverted DNA repeats (IRs) are a type of repeated sequence that can interfere with DSB repair and promote BIR. In this study, the authors used IRs to investigate the effects of IRs on DSB repair in yeast. They found that IRs can promote BIR by interfering with the repair of DSBs via gene conversion. The authors also found that the length of the spacer between IRs affects the type of repair that occurs. IRs separated by a long spacer promote BIR, while IRs separated by a short spacer promote gene conversion. The authors suggest that the choice of repair pathway is important for maintaining genome stability.
 Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a bacterium that can cause both acute and chronic infections in humans. Chronic infections are thought to be caused by biofilms, which are complex communities of bacteria that form a protective matrix. To study the role of biofilms in chronic infections, researchers used the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster as a model organism. They found that P. aeruginosa forms biofilms in the crop of infected flies, and that these biofilms are associated with increased resistance to antibiotics and decreased expression of antimicrobial peptides. The researchers also found that the Toll and Imd pathways, which are important for the immune response in Drosophila, are involved in the host response to P. aeruginosa biofilm infections. Overall, this study provides new insights into the host-pathogen interactions during P. aeruginosa biofilm infections and highlights the potential of Drosophila as a model organism for studying these infections.
 The vasopressin 1a receptor ( V1aR ) is a G-protein coupled receptor that mediates many of the behavioral effects of arginine vasopressin ( AVP ) . The neural distribution of V1aR varies across species and within species, and this variation is thought to contribute to species-specific behaviors. The vasopressin 1a receptor gene ( Avpr1a ) has a 5′ flanking region that contains regulatory sequences that contribute to species-specific expression patterns. In addition, the Avpr1a gene contains a polymorphic microsatellite element within the 5′ flanking region that is thought to contribute to individual variation in gene expression. Using homologous recombination in mice, we replaced 3.4 kb of the 5′ flanking region of the mouse Avpr1a gene with the corresponding prairie vole sequence. We found that the 5′ flanking region is not sufficient to confer species-typical binding patterns, but is sufficient to quantitatively change expression levels in a direction consistent with species differences in binding. We also found that alterations in receptor binding are associated with differences in coping strategy in the forced swim test but not with differences in learning and memory in the novel object recognition task. Our results suggest that both the 5′ flanking region and the microsatellite element contribute to species-specific expression patterns and individual variation in gene expression.
 Transcription of the switch ( S ) regions of immunoglobulin genes in B cells generates stable R-loops that are targeted by Activation Induced Cytidine Deaminase ( AID ) , triggering class switch recombination ( CSR ) . In Saccharomyces cerevisiae , stable R-loops are formed co-transcriptionally in mutants of THO , a conserved nuclear complex involved in mRNP biogenesis . In this study, we devised a yeast chromosomal system based on different segments of mammalian S regions and c-MYC for the analysis of chromosomal rearrangements in both wild-type and THO mutants . We demonstrate that AID acts in yeast at heterologous S and c-MYC transcribed sequences leading to double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) which in turn cause chromosomal translocations via Non-Homologous End Joining ( NHEJ ) . AID–induced translocations were strongly enhanced in yeast THO null mutants , consistent with the idea that AID–mediated DSBs depend on R-loop formation . Our study not only provides new clues to understand the role of mRNP biogenesis in preventing genome rearrangements and the mechanism of AID-mediated genome instability , but it shows that yeast cells have the factors and pathways required to channel AID-mediated DNA lesions into DSBs responsible for NHEJ-dependent genome rearrangements and CSR .
 In this study, we investigated how Escherichia coli cells with asymmetrically placed cell division planes partition their chromosomes during cell division. We found that the DNA translocase FtsK can pump as much as 80% of the chromosome (3.7 Mb of DNA) from one daughter compartment to another at an average rate of about 1700 bp/s. The majority of DNA transport occurs only after the early arriving Z-ring components have dissociated from the division septum and cell constriction has closed to a narrow channel with a diameter smaller than the resolution limit of an optical microscope (~250 nm). Our findings suggest that the narrow constriction is needed for effective translocation of DNA by FtsK.
 Epitope-based vaccines ( EVs ) are a promising approach for the treatment of various diseases, including cancer and infectious diseases. The selection of epitopes is a critical step in the development of EVs, and it is often performed manually. However, this approach is time-consuming and may not always yield the best results. In this study, we propose an integer linear programming approach to select the optimal set of epitopes for an EV. Our approach takes into account various factors, such as the immunogenicity of the epitopes, the population coverage, and the antigen coverage. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach by comparing it to a simple greedy heuristic and a genetic algorithm.
