This reduces the seroconversion rate in newborns and young children , while those who seroconverted before the start of control remain antibody positive . Both the microfiladermia prevalence in the population aged 5 years and above and the Ov16 antibody prevalence in children under 10 declined with increasing duration of MDA . The association between either of these indicators and the model-predicted probability of elimination was not influenced much by the assumed treatment coverage levels , but was found to depend on baseline endemicity levels , assumptions regarding the trigger of seroconversion , and diagnostic test characteristics ( sensitivity and specificity ) . Better understanding of the dynamics of Ov16 antibody responses is required for accurate interpretation of seroprevalence data and more precise estimation of endpoint for MDA . Our study demonstrates that this endpoint will be dependent on baseline endemicity levels , which should be taken into account in guidelines for defining when to stop MDA .
22L prions, which are naturally swainsonine resistant, were propagated in PK1 cells in the presence of swainsonine. Interestingly, this led to the emergence of swainsonine-sensitive variants. However, when these swainsonine-sensitive variants were propagated in the presence of swainsonine, they reverted back to swainsonine resistance. This suggests that prions can adapt to their environment and that these adaptations can be stable. The misfolded prion protein associated with swainsonine-dependent variants was less rapidly cleared in PK1 cells than that associated with swainsonine-sensitive variants, indicating that likely structural differences of the misfolded prion protein underlie the properties of the prions.
 Metabolism is a fundamental system that sustains life by extracting energy from external sources. In this study, we analyzed the potential for innovation in metabolism by mapping all possible metabolic genotypes and their associated phenotypes. We found that metabolic genotype space is vast, with over 1015 possible metabolisms. Using flux balance analysis, we predicted the viability of these metabolisms on 10 different carbon sources, resulting in 1024 potential metabolic phenotypes. We found that viable metabolisms with any one phenotype typically form a single network of genotypes that extends far or all the way through metabolic genotype space. This suggests that metabolic innovation is possible through a small number of genotypic changes. We also found that the minimal distance of genotype networks associated with different phenotypes is small, such that one can reach metabolisms with novel phenotypes through one or few genotypic changes. These findings suggest that metabolic evolution is constrained by the structure of metabolic genotype space, but also has the potential for innovation.
 The population genetics of Triatoma dimidiata haplogroups were analyzed at landscape and sub-regional scales in Chiapas and regional level across the Mexican Neotropics . Two contiguous fragments of the ND4 gene were analyzed due to bias from differential haplogroup specificity using a previously designed sequence. At both landscape ( anthropic modification gradient ) and regional ( demographic , fragmentation , biogeographic , climate ) scales , lowest T . dimidiata genetic diversity occurs where there is greatest historical anthropic modification , and where T . cruzi infection prevalence is significantly highest. Trypanosoma cruzi prevalence was significantly higher than expected in haplogroups 1 and 3 , while lower than expected in haplogroup 2 . There was also a significant difference of DTUI and DTUVI infection frequencies in both haplogroups 1 and 3 , while no difference of either in haplogroup 2 . All haplogroups from the Mexican Neotropics had moderate to high haplotype diversity , while greatest genetic differentiation was between haplogroups 1 and 3 ( above FST = 0 . 868 , p < 0 . 0001 ) . Divergence of the complex from the MRCA was estimated between 0 . 97 MYA ( 95% HPD interval = 0 . 55–1 . 53 MYA ) and 0 . 85 MYA ( 95% HPD interval = 0 . 42–1 . 5 MYA ) for ND4A and both concatenated fragments , respectively , with primary divergence from the MRCA of haplogroups 2 and 3 ( above FST = 0 . 868 , p < 0 . 0001 ) . Effective population size for Mexican haplogroups 1 and 2 increased between 0 . 02 and 0 . 03 MYA . This study supports previous ecological niche evidence for the complex´s origin surrounding the Tehuantepec Isthmus , and provides evidence for recent divergence of three primary dimidiata haplogroups , with differential T . cruzi infection frequency and DTU specificity , important components of vector capacity .
 Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome ( HFRS ) is a rodent-borne disease caused by two hantaviruses in China: Hantaan virus and Seoul virus . Environmental factors can significantly affect the risk of contracting hantavirus infections . We aimed to clarify the environmental risk factors favoring rodent-to-human transmission to provide scientific evidence for developing effective HFRS prevention and control strategies . The 10-year ( 2006–2015 ) field surveillance data from the rodent hosts for hantavirus , the epidemiological and environmental data extracted from satellite images and meteorological stations , rodent-to-human transmission rates and impacts of the environment on rodent community composition were used to quantify the relationships among environmental factors , rodent species and HFRS occurrence . Rodent species in Chenzhou , a hantavirus hotspot , comprise mainly Rattus norvegicus , Mus musculus , R . flavipectus and some other species ( R . losea and Microtus fortis calamorum ) . The rodent species played different roles across the various land types we examined , but all of them were associated with transmission risks . Some species were associated with HFRS occurrence risk in forest and water bodies . R . norvegicus and R . flavipectus were associated with risk of HFRS incidence in grassland , whereas M . musculus and R . flavipectus were associated with this risk in built-on land . The rodent community composition was also associated with environmental variability . The predictive risk models based on these significant factors were validated by a good-fit model , where: cultivated land was predicted to represent the highest risk for HFRS incidence , which accords with the statistics for HFRS cases in 2014–2015 . The spatial heterogeneity of HFRS disease may be influenced by rodent community composition , which is associated with local environmental conditions . Therefore , future work should focus on preventing HFRS is moist , warm environments .
 Costello syndrome (CS) is a rare genetic disorder caused by activating mutations in the HRAS proto-oncogene. The most common mutation in CS is c . 34G>A (p . Gly12Ser), but a rare mutation c . 35G>T (p . Gly12Val) has been associated with severe, early lethal CS. We identified a new germline p . Gly12Val mutation in a 12-year-old boy with attenuated CS. Analysis of his HRAS cDNA showed high levels of exon 2 skipping. Using wild type and mutant HRAS minigenes, we confirmed that c . 35_36GC>TG results in exon 2 skipping by simultaneously disrupting the function of a critical Exonic Splicing Enhancer (ESE) and creation of an Exonic Splicing Silencer (ESS). We show that this vulnerability of HRAS exon 2 is caused by a weak 3’ splice site, which makes exon 2 inclusion dependent on binding of splicing stimulatory proteins like SRSF2 to the critical ESE. Because the majority of cancer- and CS- causing mutations are located here, they affect splicing differently. Therefore, our results also demonstrate that the phenotype in CS and somatic cancers is not only determined by the different transforming potentials of mutant HRAS proteins, but also by the efficiency of exon 2 inclusion resulting from the different HRAS mutations. Finally, we show that a splice switching oligonucleotide (SSO) that blocks access to the critical ESE causes exon 2 skipping and halts proliferation of cancer cells. This unravels a potential for development of new anti-cancer therapies based on SSO-mediated HRAS exon 2 skipping.
6-methyladenosine ( m6A ) is a common modification on mRNAs that plays important roles in various biological processes . Inactivation of Mettl3, a key factor in m6A formation, in the developing mouse brain causes severe developmental defects in the cerebellum . Loss of m6A leads to extended RNA half-lives and aberrant splicing events, which consequently induce premature CGC death and impaired cerebellar development . Our findings reveal a critical role of METTL3-mediated m6A in regulating the development of the mammalian cerebellum.
 Embryonic stem (ES) cells are derived from the inner cell mass of the blastocyst and are capable of differentiating into any cell type of the developing embryo. The transcription factors OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG are essential for maintaining the pluripotent state of ES cells. In this study, the authors show that combinatorial binding of these transcription factors is strongly associated with co-localization of the transcriptional co-activator Mediator, H3K27ac, and increased expression of nearby genes in ES cells. They also observe that the same loci bound by Oct4, Nanog, and Sox2 in ES cells frequently drive expression in early embryonic development. The authors compare mouse and human ES cells and find that less than 5% of individual binding events for OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG are shared between species. In contrast, about 15% of combinatorial binding events and even between 53% and 63% of combinatorial binding events at enhancers active in early development are conserved. The authors suggest that the combination of OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG binding is critical for transcription in ES cells and likely plays an important role for embryogenesis by binding at conserved early developmental enhancers. Their data suggests that the fast evolutionary rewiring of regulatory networks mainly affects individual binding events, whereas "gene regulatory hotspots" which are bound by multiple factors and active in multiple tissues throughout early development are under stronger evolutionary constraints.
 Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood cells. AML is caused by genetic mutations that lead to the production of abnormal proteins. One of these abnormal proteins is AML1/ETO, which is produced when two genes, AML1 and ETO, fuse together. AML1/ETO is responsible for the development of AML. In this study, researchers used a technique called chromatin immunoprecipitation and expression profiling to identify the genes that are regulated by AML1/ETO. They found that AML1/ETO and AML1, the wild-type version of the gene, bind to the same regions of DNA. However, AML1/ETO also binds to regions of DNA that are not bound by AML1. The researchers also found that AML1/ETO binds to regions of DNA that are bound by a protein called HEB. HEB is a protein that is involved in the development of blood cells. The researchers found that AML1/ETO and HEB bind to the same regions of DNA. The study provides important information about how AML1/ETO regulates gene expression and how it is related to the wild-type version of the gene, AML1. This information could help researchers develop new treatments for AML.
 In this study, we investigated the role of the Leishmania donovani histone acetyltransferase HAT2 in regulating gene expression. We found that HAT2 is essential for the parasite's survival and that it acetylates histone H4K10 in vitro and in vivo. We also found that HAT2-depleted cells displayed growth and cell cycle defects, and poor survival in host cells. Real time PCR and DNA microarray analyses, as well as rescue experiments, revealed that downregulation of cyclins CYC4 and CYC9 were responsible for S phase and G2/M defects of HAT2-depleted cells respectively. We also found that CYC4 and CYC9 have their own specific promoters, at least some of which are activated in a cell-cycle dependent manner. This report presents the first data pointing to cell cycle-specific activation of promoters in trypanosomatids, thus uncovering new facets of gene regulation in this parasite family.
 In this study, we used computational modeling to investigate the underlying mechanisms of inferring others' intentions during social interactions. We designed an interactive economic game in which 16 pairs of volunteers interacted with each other. The player performed a probabilistic reinforcement learning task and received information about a binary lottery from a visual pie chart. The adviser, who received more predictive information, issued an additional recommendation. Critically, the game was structured such that the adviser's incentives to provide helpful or misleading information varied in time. Using a meta-Bayesian modeling framework, we found that the players' behavior was best explained by the deployment of hierarchical learning: they inferred on the volatility of the advisers' intentions in order to optimize their predictions about the validity of their advice. Beyond learning, volatility estimates also affected the trial-by-trial variability of decisions: participants were more likely to rely on their estimates of advice accuracy for making choices when they believed that the adviser's intentions were presently stable. Finally, our model of the players' inference predicted the players' interpersonal reactivity index ( IRI ) scores, explicit ratings of the advisers' helpfulness, and the advisers' self-reports on their chosen strategy. Overall, our results suggest that humans ( i ) employ hierarchical generative models to infer on the changing intentions of others, ( ii ) use volatility estimates to inform decision-making in social interactions, and ( iii ) integrate estimates of advice accuracy with non-social sources of information. The Bayesian framework presented here can quantify individual differences in these mechanisms from simple behavioral readouts and may prove useful in future clinical studies of maladaptive social cognition.
 Scrub typhus is a mite-borne infectious disease that is endemic in Asia. It has been a rural disease, but indigenous urban cases have been observed in Seoul, South Korea. Urban scrub typhus may have a significant impact because of the large population. Indigenous urban scrub typhus was epidemiologically identified in Seoul, the largest metropolitan city in South Korea, using national notifiable disease data from 2010 to 2013. For detailed analysis of clinical features, patients from one hospital that reported the majority of cases were selected and compared to a historic control group. Chigger mites were prospectively collected in the city using a direct chigger mite-collecting trap, and identified using both phenotypic and 18S rDNA sequencing analyses. Their infection with Orientia tsutsugamushi was confirmed by sequencing the 56-kDa antigen gene. Eighty-eight cases of urban scrub typhus were determined in Seoul. The possible sites of infection were mountainous areas (56.8%), city parks (20.5%), the vicinity of one’s own residence (17.0%), and riversides (5.7%). Eighty-seven chigger mites were collected in Gwanak mountain, one of the suspected infection sites in southern Seoul, and seventy-six (87.4%) of them were identified as Helenicula miyagawai and eight (9.2%) as Leptotrombidium scutellare. Pooled DNA extracted from H. miyagawai mites yielded O. tsutsugamushi Boryong strain. Twenty-six patients from one hospital showed low APACHE II score (3.4 ± 2.7), low complication rate (3.8%), and no hypokalemia. We identified the presence of indigenous urban scrub typhus in Seoul, and a subgroup of them had mild clinical features. The chigger mite H. miyagawai infected with O. tsutsugamushi within the city was found. In endemic area, urban scrub typhus needs to be considered as one of the differential febrile diseases and a target for prevention.
26G and 21U RNAs are small RNA molecules that play a role in RNA interference (RNAi) in Caenorhabditis elegans. These RNAs are bound by specific Argonaute (Ago) proteins and are involved in the regulation of gene expression. The stability of these RNAs is regulated by the enzyme HEN1, which methylates the 3′ end of the RNA. The authors of this study have studied the effects of HEN1 on the different RNAi pathways in C. elegans. They found that HEN1 has differential effects on the 26G and 21U RNA pathways. In the germline, the stability of 21U RNAs is only mildly affected by the loss of HEN1, while most 26G RNAs display reduced stability and respond to the loss of HENN-1 by displaying increased 3′-uridylation frequencies. The authors also found that HENN-1 specifically modifies ERGO-1–bound 26G RNAs, while ALG-3/ALG-4–bound 26G RNAs are not modified. Global gene expression analysis of henn-1 mutants revealed mild effects, including down-regulation of many germline-expressed genes. The authors suggest that the effects on global gene expression are indirect and that HENN-1 likely plays a role in the stability of 26G RNAs.
Glycosylation is a process that adds sugars to proteins, and it is important for many biological processes. However, the genetic regulation of glycosylation is not well understood. In this study, researchers used genome-wide association and high-throughput glycomics analysis to identify common variants in three population cohorts that affect N-glycan levels in human plasma. They found that variants in the Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1α ( HNF1α ) and fucosyltransferase genes FUT6 and FUT8 influence N-glycan levels. They also found that HNF1α regulates the expression of key fucosyltransferase and fucose biosynthesis genes. These findings suggest that HNF1α is a master transcriptional regulator of multiple stages in the fucosylation process. This mechanism has implications for the regulation of immunity, embryonic development, and protein folding, as well as for our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying cancer, coronary heart disease, and metabolic and inflammatory disorders.
 Centromeres are the regions of chromosomes that attach to the spindle during cell division. In many organisms, including plants, centromeres are marked by specific DNA sequences that are not essential for the function of the centromere. In maize, centromeres are marked by repeats of the DNA sequence 350 bp in length. These repeats are not necessary for the function of the centromere, but they are important for the localization of the inner kinetochore protein CENPC. CENPC is a protein that binds to DNA and is required for the proper localization of the kinetochore. In this study, the authors used genetic and biochemical techniques to study the DNA-binding region of CENPC in maize. They found that CENPC has a DNA-binding region that is localized to a 122 amino acid region of the protein. They also found that RNA is important for the proper localization of CENPC. The authors propose that RNA helps to recruit CENPC to the centromere by altering its DNA-binding characteristics.
 We have used genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) to identify genetic variants associated with birth weight ( BW ), childhood obesity ( CO ), and childhood body mass index ( CBMI ). We then used eQTL analysis to identify genes that are differentially expressed in the placenta in response to these genetic variants. We found that placental eQTLs are significantly enriched for GWAS loci associated with BW, CO, and CBMI. We also found that eight, six, and one transcripts colocalized with BW, CO, and CBMI risk loci, respectively. Our study suggests that placental transcription in utero plays a key role in determining postnatal body size and may hold new possibilities for therapeutic interventions to prevent childhood obesity.
 The study aimed to determine the prevalence of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) in an endemic area of Malda district, West Bengal, India, and to compare three diagnostic tools for PKDL case detection. The prevalence of PKDL was determined by active surveillance and confirmed by PCR-based diagnosis. Patients were treated with either sodium stibogluconate or oral miltefosine and followed up for two years to observe lesion regression. PCR-based method was found to be highly sensitive for case confirmation. In majority of the cases, skin lesions persisted after treatment completion which gradually disappeared during 6–12 months post treatment period. The study highlights the importance of active mass surveys to detect PKDL cases and the need for a well-designed study with higher number of samples to establish when/whether PKDL patients are free from parasite after treatment. The PCR-based method is helpful in confirming diagnosis of PKDL and can be used in a referral laboratory at district or state level to achieve the goal of eliminating kala-azar.
 The pneumococcus is a bacterium that causes pneumonia and other infections. It has a unique genetic system that allows it to take up DNA from its environment and incorporate it into its own genome. This process, called transformation, is controlled by a set of genes that are turned on and off in a specific order. The genes are turned on in response to a chemical signal called competence stimulating peptide (CSP), which is produced by the bacteria themselves. The genes are turned off when another chemical signal, called fratricide, is produced. The timing of when the genes are turned on and off is important for the transformation process to work properly. In this study, the authors looked at how the genes are turned on and off in different strains of the pneumococcus. They found that the timing of when the genes are turned on and off is different in different strains, and that this difference is important for the transformation process to work properly. The authors also found that the CSP signal is important for turning on the genes, but that it is not the only signal that is important. Overall, the study provides important insights into how the pneumococcus controls its genetic system.
 Human papillomavirus ( HPV ) is a common sexually transmitted infection that can cause cervical cancer. HPV16 is the most common high-risk HPV type and is responsible for over 60% of cervical cancer cases. The HPV16 capsid is composed of 72 pentamers of the major capsid protein L1 and approximately 20–40 copies of the minor capsid protein L2. L2 plays important roles in capsid assembly and genome encapsidation, and is essential for establishing infection within the cell. The current study investigates the translocation of L2 from the trans-Golgi network ( TGN ) to the nucleus, which is a critical step in HPV infection. The authors developed a novel assay to monitor L2 translocation based on the compartmentalization of a specific BirA enzyme-substrate reaction. They found that inhibition of cellular processes and factors that are essential for L2/vDNA trafficking to the TGN, including furin, endosome acidification, cyclophilins, and γ-secretase, potently block L2 translocation. Furthermore, the authors found that mitotic entry is sufficient for L2 translocation to occur and that translocation coincides with mitosis in synchronized cells. Finally, they propose a model whereby chromatin binding of L2 in prometaphase is a necessary prerequisite for translocation of L2/vDNA across limiting membranes. This study provides important insights into the mechanisms of HPV infection and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of HPV-related diseases.
 We present a method to measure the relative transmissibility of one strain of a pathogen compared to another. This is important in understanding the dynamics of influenza outbreaks and the potential impact of interventions such as NAI distribution. We use data from ferret transmission studies to demonstrate the framework's behaviour and suggest how to optimise experimental design for assessment of transmissibility. The method introduced here has applicability beyond influenza to other viral and bacterial pathogens.
 The study presented here investigates the role of the B-box protein BBX21 in the integration of light and abscisic acid (ABA) signaling during seed germination and early seedling development in Arabidopsis thaliana . The authors found that BBX21 negatively regulates ABI5 expression by interfering with HY5 binding to the ABI5 promoter. They also showed that ABI5 binds to its own promoter and activates its expression, while BBX21 negatively regulates this activity. The authors propose that BBX21 coordinates with HY5 and ABI5 on the ABI5 promoter and that these transcriptional regulators work in concert to integrate light and ABA signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana .
 The Mediator complex is an essential co-regulator of RNA polymerase II that is conserved throughout eukaryotes . Here we present the first study of Mediator in the pathogenic fungus Candida albicans . We focused on the Middle domain subunit Med31 , the Head domain subunit Med20 , and Srb9/Med13 from the Kinase domain . The C . albicans Mediator shares some roles with model yeasts Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Schizosaccharomyces pombe , such as functions in the response to certain stresses and the role of Med31 in the expression of genes regulated by the activator Ace2 . The C . albicans Mediator also has additional roles in the transcription of genes associated with virulence , for example genes related to morphogenesis and gene families enriched in pathogens , such as the ALS adhesins . Consistently , Med31 , Med20 , and Srb9/Med13 contribute to key virulence attributes of C . albicans , filamentation , and biofilm formation; and ALS1 is a biologically relevant target of Med31 for development of biofilms . Furthermore , Med31 affects virulence of C . albicans in the worm infection model . We present evidence that the roles of Med31 and Srb9/Med13 in the expression of the genes encoding cell wall adhesins are different between S . cerevisiae and C . albicans: they are repressors of the FLO genes in S . cerevisiae and are activators of the ALS genes in C . albicans . This suggests that Mediator subunits regulate adhesion in a distinct manner between these two distantly related fungal species .
 The bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of biofilm-associated infections in humans, and its antibiotic tolerance is a major challenge in treating these infections. In this study, the authors used a novel experimental approach to identify the genetic determinants of antibiotic tolerance in P. aeruginosa biofilms and planktonic growth conditions. They found that many loci contribute to antibiotic tolerance predominantly in the biofilm or planktonic setting only. The authors' results provide insights into the differences and similarities between biofilm and planktonic antibiotic tolerance and reveal how the cellular state and multi-cellular interactions combine to impact the response to an antibiotic challenge. Their findings may help in the development of novel therapeutics against P. aeruginosa biofilm-associated infections.
 The ability to identify the most appropriate mathematical model to describe a biological system is a major challenge in systems biology.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    
Chagas disease is a parasitic infection caused by Trypanosoma cruzi that affects millions of people worldwide, particularly in Latin America. The disease can be transmitted through infected insect bites, blood transfusions, or contaminated food. Chagas disease can be treated with benznidazole (BNZ), but the long-term efficacy of the drug is uncertain. In this study, we followed the treatment of 103 school-aged children with chronic Chagas disease in Bolivia who were treated with BNZ. We used a combination of serological and molecular tests to monitor the treatment efficacy. Our results showed that 73 of the children completed the treatment, with three interruptions due to side effects. We found that the molecular test was more sensitive than the serological test in detecting parasites in the blood. Additionally, we found that the levels of the cytokine IL-17A decreased significantly after treatment, suggesting that IL-17A could be used as a biomarker for treatment efficacy. Overall, our study provides valuable information for the development of more effective treatment strategies for Chagas disease.
 Neisseria meningitidis is a Gram-negative bacterium that causes bacterial meningitis and septicemia. The bacterium has a large amount of repetitive DNA, including a miniature inverted-repeat transposable element called the Correia element (CE). The CE is a transposon that is responsible for the generation of new alleles in the meningococcus. In this study, we have analyzed the structure and function of the CE in N. meningitidis. We have identified eight different subtypes of the CE and found that some of them have much higher promoter activity than others. We have also identified a recurrent polymorphism that dictates the strength of the strongest promoter. Our results provide a resource that allows the transcriptional effects of a particular subtype at a given locus to be predicted. We have also analyzed the distribution of the CE in the population and found that no more than two-thirds of the elements maintain their subtype at any particular locus. This is due to recombinational class switching between elements in a single strain. Upon switching subtype, a new allele is available to spread through the population by natural transformation. Our study suggests that the strain-to-strain variability of the CE and the large number of strong promoters encoded by them allow for potentially widespread effects within the population as a whole.
 In filamentous fungi, development and secondary metabolism are intimately coordinated. VeA and LaeA are central regulators of these processes in Aspergillus spp. and Penicillium spp. VeA and LaeA form a complex that regulates secondary metabolism and differentiation in response to light signals. In this study, we identified and characterized the orthologs of VeA and LaeA in the maize pathogen Cochliobolus heterostrophus. We found that ChLae1 and ChVel1 positively regulate T-toxin biosynthesis, pathogenicity, and super virulence, oxidative stress responses, sexual development, and aerial hyphal growth, and negatively control melanin biosynthesis and asexual differentiation. ChLAE1 OE strains are female sterile, while ChVEL1 OE strains are more fertile than WT. ChLae1 and ChVel1 repress expression of 1, 8-dihydroxynaphthalene (DHN) melanin biosynthesis genes, and accordingly, melanization is enhanced in Chlae1 and Chvel1 mutants, and reduced in OE strains. These observations establish ChLae1 and ChVel1 as the first factors known to regulate host selective toxin production.
 The authors used molecular dynamics simulations to study the mechanism of selective ion permeation in bacterial Nav channels. They found that two or three extracellular K+ ions can block the entrance to the selectivity filter of NavAb in the presence of applied forces in the inward direction, but not in the outward direction. The block state occurs in an unstable local minimum of the equilibrium unperturbed free-energy landscape of two K+ ions that can be ‘locked’ in place by modest applied forces. In contrast to K+, three Na+ ions move favorably through the selectivity filter together as a unit in a loose “knock-on” mechanism of permeation in both inward and outward directions. There is no similar local minimum in the two-dimensional free-energy landscape of two Na+ ions for a block state. The authors suggest that the inclusion of non-equilibrium factors in the simulations can provide detailed information about mechanisms of ion selectivity that is missing from mechanisms derived from either crystal structures or equilibrium unperturbed free-energy landscapes.
Rabies is a deadly disease caused by a neurotropic RNA virus in the family Rhabdoviridae, genus Lyssavirus. The two main clinical forms of rabies are furious and paralytic, which occur in humans and dogs in a ratio of approximately 2:1. The furious form is characterized by limbic symptoms, while the paralytic form is characterized by lower motor neuron type paralysis. Studies have shown that there is a higher RNA viral load with less immune response in the brain in the furious form of rabies. Our previous studies in naturally infected dogs during the early disease stage showed disruption of axonal integrity in the brainstem exclusively in paralytic dogs from pronounced inflammation. We also previously demonstrated that the percentage of neuronal cell bodies containing rabies viral nucleocapsid antigen decreased in a caudal-rostral direction, which was the inverse of the level of rabies viral RNA. The present study aimed to compare intracellular viral spread (and thereby viral propagation) between paralytic and furious forms of rabies by determining the amount of rabies viral antigen beyond the neuronal cell body at different CNS levels. Our results showed that there was a delay in cell process involvement following cell body involvement, consistent with replication occurring in the cell body region and subsequent transport out to cell processes. Greater amounts of antigen were seen in cell processes in dogs with the furious compared to paralytic form, at all anatomic levels examined. These findings suggest that intracellular transport of the virus may be slower in the paralytic form, resulting in slower viral propagation.
 CTCF is a zinc-finger protein that plays an important role in the regulation of transcription by preventing inappropriate enhancer/promoter interaction. In Drosophila, CTCF has only been characterized recently. We carried out chromatin immunopurification coupled with genomic microarray analysis to identify CTCF binding sites within representative regions of the Drosophila genome. Our data indicate that CTCF is directly associated with all known or predicted insulators in the BX-C, suggesting that the functioning of these insulators involves a common CTCF-dependent mechanism. Comparison of the locations of the CTCF sites with characterised Polycomb target sites and histone modification provides support for the domain model of BX-C regulation.
 We previously demonstrated that actinonin, a slow, tight-binding inhibitor of peptide deformylase (PDF), induces a conformational change in the enzyme that is essential for its inhibitory activity. Here, we provide a detailed mechanism for this induced-fit process at atomic resolution. We solved crystal structures of the initial open state and final closed state, as well as several intermediate mimics captured during the process. Ligand-induced reshaping of a hydrophobic pocket drives closure of the active site, which is finally “zipped up” by additional binding interactions. Together with biochemical analyses, these data allow a coherent reconstruction of the sequence of events leading from the encounter complex to the key-lock binding state of the enzyme. A “movie” that reconstructs this entire process can be further extrapolated to catalysis.
 The thalamus is a key relay center for sensory information from the periphery to the cerebral cortex. While the thalamus receives input from many sensory modalities, it also receives feedback from the cortex. This feedback is thought to play a role in modulating the transfer of sensory information from the thalamus to the cortex. In this study, we used a combination of theoretical and experimental approaches to model the impact of cortical feedback on the transfer efficiency of sensory information from the thalamus to the cortex. We found that the transfer efficiency of sensory information is influenced by the number of thalamocortical cells involved in the many-to-one convergence from thalamus to cortex, the statistics of the corticothalamic synaptic bombardment, and the level of correlation imposed between converging thalamic relay cells. We also found that the transfer efficiency of relay cells could be selectively amplified when they become simultaneously desynchronized by the cortical feedback. These findings suggest that the cortical feedback plays a key role in modulating the transfer of sensory information from the thalamus to the cortex.
6mA is a novel DNA modification found in metazoans, but its biological role is not well understood. We previously identified NMAD-1 as a 6mA DNA demethylase in C. elegans. Here, we show that nmad-1 mutants have reduced fertility due to defects in meiosis. We found that NMAD-1 regulates DNA replication and repair during meiosis by binding to topoisomerase TOP-2. These results suggest that NMAD-1 functions at DNA replication sites to regulate DNA replication and repair during meiosis.
 This study identifies a novel host cell protein, adipocyte plasma membrane-associated protein (APMAP), that promotes human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection in multiple cell types. APMAP is necessary for HCMV infection in both epithelial and fibroblast cells, and its overexpression promotes HCMV infection in canine MDCK and murine NIH/3T3 cells, which are refractory to HCMV infection. Reduced viral immediate early gene transcription and delayed nucleus translocation of tegument delivered pp65 were detected in APMAP-deficient cells. Biochemical studies suggest that APMAP may participate in HCMV infection through interaction with gH/gL containing glycoprotein complexes at low pH and through mediating nuclear translocation of pp65. Taken together, these results indicate that APMAP is a cellular factor that augments HCMV infection at the early stage of viral infection.
 The study investigates the role of cytokine-mediated positive receptor feedback in regulating cell commitment decisions during hematopoiesis.  The results suggest that cytokine-mediated positive receptor feedback can induce a "switch-like" response to external stimuli during multilineage differentiation by providing robustness to both bipotent and committed states while protecting progenitors from noise-induced differentiation or decommitment.  The model provides support to both the instructive and stochastic theories of commitment: cell fates are ultimately driven by lineage-specific transcription factors, but cytokine signaling can strongly bias lineage commitment by regulating these inherently noisy cell-fate decisions with complex, pertinent behaviors such as ligand-mediated ultrasensitivity and robust multistability.  Lastly, the model shows good agreement with lineage-specific receptor expression kinetics from microarray experiments and provides a computational framework that can integrate both classical and alternative commitment paths in hematopoiesis that have been observed experimentally.
 The genus Orthobunyavirus within the family Bunyaviridae is a group of emerging viruses that pose a threat to human and animal health. Despite their medical importance, little is known about their structure, which is a prerequisite for understanding virus assembly and entry. Using electron cryo-tomography, we report the ultrastructure of Bunyamwera virus, the prototypic member of this genus. Whilst Bunyamwera virions are pleomorphic in shape, they display a locally ordered lattice of glycoprotein spikes. Each spike protrudes 18 nm from the viral membrane and becomes disordered upon introduction to an acidic environment. Using sub-tomogram averaging, we derived a three-dimensional model of the trimeric pre-fusion glycoprotein spike to 3-nm resolution. The glycoprotein spike consists mainly of the putative class-II fusion glycoprotein and exhibits a unique tripod-like arrangement. Protein–protein contacts between neighboring spikes occur at membrane-proximal regions and intra-spike contacts at membrane-distal regions. This trimeric assembly deviates from previously observed fusion glycoprotein arrangements, suggesting a greater than anticipated repertoire of viral fusion glycoprotein oligomerization. Our study provides evidence of a pH-dependent conformational change that occurs during orthobunyaviral entry into host cells and a blueprint for the structure of this group of emerging pathogens.
 Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness worldwide, with primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG) being more common in Asian countries. To identify genetic variants associated with PACG, we conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) on anterior chamber depth (ACD), a key anatomical risk factor for PACG. Our study identified a sequence variant within ABCC5 (rs1401999) that was associated with an increase in risk of PACG. The association was strengthened when a sub-group of controls with open angles was included in the analysis. Our findings suggest that genetic sequence variants influencing anterior chamber dimensions may play a role in PACG risk.
 The identification of homologies between different species is fundamental to our understanding of common biological principles. In this study, the authors describe the first conserved regulatory elements, called bilaterian conserved regulatory elements (Bicores), between deuterostomes and protostomes. These elements show conservation of sequence and gene synteny, and they act as developmental enhancers that drive expression of transcriptional repressors in the vertebrate central nervous system. Although the small number of identified Bicores suggests extensive rewiring of cis-regulation between the protostome and deuterostome clades, additional Bicores may be revealed as our understanding of cis-regulatory logic and sample of bilaterian genomes continue to grow. The discovery of these conserved regulatory elements offers a new avenue for exploring how developmental logic is encoded in the genome and how this logic evolves.
 Influenza virus diversity and antigenic drift have been well characterized on a global scale, but the factors that influence the virus’ rapid evolution within and between human hosts are less clear. We used next generation sequencing of patient-derived viruses from a randomized, placebo-controlled trial of vaccine efficacy to characterize the diversity of influenza A virus and to define the impact of vaccine-induced immunity on within-host populations. We found that the vast majority of intrahost single nucleotide variants were rare and that very few were found in more than one individual. Most samples had fewer than 15 single nucleotide variants across the entire genome, and the level of diversity did not significantly vary with day of sampling, vaccination status, or pre-season antibody titer. Contrary to what has been suggested in experimental systems, our data indicate that seasonal influenza vaccination has little impact on intrahost diversity in natural infection and that vaccine-induced immunity may be only a minor contributor to antigenic drift at local scales.
 Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania parasites that can cause severe illness and death. The disease is more prevalent in children and older adults. The immune system declines with age, which can lead to a less effective immune response to Leishmania parasites. A previous study showed that a live-attenuated Leishmania parasite strain (LdCen-/-) induced a strong protective immune response in young mice. In this study, the authors analyzed the immune response in aged mice (18 months old) and compared it to young mice (2 months old) after infection with LdCen-/-. They found that LdCen-/- infection significantly enhanced the innate immune response in both age groups, leading to a stronger Th1-type adaptive immune response. However, the adaptive immune response was reduced in aged mice compared to young mice, which correlated with less protection in aged mice. The authors suggest that further studies are needed to understand the mechanisms underlying the reduced adaptive immune response in aged mice and to develop effective vaccines for all age groups.
 Enteroviruses ( EVs ) are a group of viruses that cause a wide range of human diseases, including respiratory and gastrointestinal infections. EVs have different biophysical properties and cause different diseases. To understand the genetic basis of these differences, we created chimeras between EV-D68 ( a respiratory EV ) and EV-D94 ( an enteric EV ). We found that the capsid proteins of EV-D68 and EV-D94 have different functions. EV-D68 capsid proteins are important for acid sensitivity and temperature adaptation, while EV-D94 capsid proteins are important for tissue tropism. We also found that EV-D68 and EV-D94 have different interactions with the host immune system. These findings provide new insights into the genetic basis of EV virulence and may help guide the development of new treatments for EV infections.
 The Herpes Simplex Virus 1 ( HSV-1 ) glycoprotein gE-gI is a transmembrane Fc receptor found on the surface of infected cells and virions that binds human immunoglobulin G ( hIgG ) . gE-gI can also participate in antibody bipolar bridging ( ABB ) , a process by which the antigen-binding fragments ( Fabs ) of the IgG bind a viral antigen while the Fc binds to gE-gI . IgG Fc binds gE-gI at basic , but not acidic , pH , suggesting that IgG bound at extracellular pH by cell surface gE-gI would dissociate and be degraded in acidic endosomes/lysosomes if endocytosed . The fate of viral antigens associated with gE-gI–bound IgG had been unknown: they could remain at the cell surface or be endocytosed with IgG . Here , we developed an in vitro model system for ABB and investigated the trafficking of ABB complexes using 4-D confocal fluorescence imaging of ABB complexes with transferrin or epidermal growth factor , well-characterized intracellular trafficking markers . Our data showed that cells expressing gE-gI and the viral antigen HSV-1 gD endocytosed anti-gD IgG and gD in a gE-gI–dependent process , resulting in lysosomal localization . These results suggest that gE-gI can mediate clearance of infected cell surfaces of anti-viral host IgG and viral antigens to evade IgG-mediated responses , representing a general mechanism for viral Fc receptors in immune evasion and viral pathogenesis .
 Cystic hydatid disease ( CHD ) is a serious parasitic infection caused by the larval stages of the cestode Echinococcus granulosus . The parasite's larval stages, specifically protoscoleces ( PSCs ), are the only infectious form and can interact with both definitive and intermediate hosts. In this study, we used Roche 454 sequencing technology and in silico secretome analysis to explore the transcriptome profiles of E . granulosus PSCs and elucidate the potential functions of the excretory-secretory proteins ( ESPs ) released by the parasite. We found that many proteins were significantly enriched in development-related signaling pathways, such as the TGF-β receptor pathways and insulin pathways. This study provides valuable information on the metabolic adaptation of parasites to their hosts that can be used to aid the development of novel intervention targets for hydatid treatment and control.
 Nitrate is a vital source of nitrogen for plants and fungi. In the fungus Aspergillus nidulans, the transcription factor NirA regulates the expression of genes involved in nitrate assimilation. NirA is inactive in the cytosol and becomes active when it is imported into the nucleus. The import of NirA into the nucleus is regulated by the exportin KapK/CRM1. In this study, the authors found that the oxidation of a methionine residue in the nuclear export sequence of NirA is required for its nuclear import and transcriptional activity. The oxidation of this methionine is catalyzed by the flavin-containing monooxygenase FmoB. The authors also found that the replacement of this methionine with an isoleucine residue leads to partial loss of NirA activity and insensitivity to FmoB-mediated nuclear export. In contrast, the replacement of this methionine with an alanine residue transforms the protein into a permanently nuclear and active transcription factor. These findings suggest that the oxidation of this methionine regulates the subcellular localization and transcriptional activity of NirA.
 Voltage-gated sodium channels are responsible for the propagation of action potentials in neurons and muscle cells. These channels are encoded by nine genes in mammals, which are highly similar in sequence. However, the multiplicity of these genes raises the question of why so many different mechanisms for generating an action potential are necessary. In this study, we used mathematical models to investigate how functional constraints bound and shape evolution of sodium channels. We found that the simplest theoretical constraints on action potential propagation, such as the requirement for membrane excitability and a unique resting potential, directly constrain the activation and inactivation curves of sodium channels. We compared these constraints with measurements of mammalian sodium channels reported in the literature and found that the excitability properties alone distinguish the nine sodium channels into four different groups. These groups correspond to channels expressed in nerve and muscle tissue, respectively, as well as channels with the potential for a voltage threshold substantially higher than the other channels and channels that can only produce action potentials in a narrow conductance range. Our findings suggest that these channels have evolved to perform specialized tasks.
 Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory illness worldwide. The viral polymerase is an attractive target for antiviral drugs since it performs transcription and replication of the RNA genome. The unique cap-snatching mechanism of viral transcription can be inhibited by targeting either the PB2 cap-binding or PA endonuclease domains. Here, we describe high resolution X-ray co-crystal structures of the 2009 pandemic H1N1 ( pH1N1 ) PA endonuclease domain with a series of specific inhibitors, including four diketo compounds and a green tea catechin. These results will be important in optimising the design of more potent inhibitors targeting the cap-snatching endonuclease activity of influenza virus polymerase.
Snake envenomation is a major health problem in many tropical countries, with an estimated 1.8 million people affected annually and about 94,000 deaths. Antivenoms are the only effective treatment for these cases, but the production of these antisera is challenging. In this study, we developed a new immunization protocol for producing potent polyspecific antisera against three medically important vipers in Thailand and its neighboring countries. The protocol involved immunizing horses with a mixture of the three viper venoms using the "low dose, low volume, multi-site" method. The antisera showed rapid rise in ELISA titers against the three venoms and reached plateau at about the 8th week post-immunization. The in vivo neutralization potency of the antisera against the three venoms was much higher than the minimal potency limits set by Queen Soavabha Memorial Institute. The polyspecific antisera also effectively neutralized the procoagulant, hemorrhagic, necrotic, and nephrotoxic activities of the viper venoms. This effective immunization protocol should be useful in the production of potent polyspecific antisera against snake venoms and equine antisera against tetanus, diphtheria, or rabies.
 Salmonella enterica is a pathogenic bacterial species that causes systemic infections in humans and animals. In mice, Salmonella typhimurium can establish a chronic systemic infection that lasts for months. We have identified the bacterial effector protein SseI as a critical factor for this long-term infection. SseI inhibits normal cell migration of primary macrophages and dendritic cells in vitro, and this inhibition requires the host factor IQGAP1. SseI binds directly to IQGAP1 and co-localizes with this factor at the cell periphery. In addition, infection with wild-type Salmonella suppresses dendritic cell migration to the spleen in vivo in an SseI-dependent manner. These results demonstrate that SseI inhibits normal host cell migration, which ultimately counteracts the ability of the host to clear systemic bacteria.
 We report that the transcription product of the psm-mec gene, located in the mobile genetic element SCCmec of HA-MRSA, but not CA-MRSA, suppresses the expression of phenol-soluble modulin α (PSMα), a cytolytic toxin of S. aureus. We found that psm-mec RNA inhibits translation of the agrA gene encoding a positive transcription factor for the PSMα gene via specific binding to agrA mRNA. Furthermore, 25% of 325 clinical MRSA isolates had a mutation in the psm-mec promoter that attenuated transcription, and 9% of the strains had no psm-mec. In most of these psm-mec-mutated or psm-mec-deleted HA-MRSA strains, PSMα expression was increased compared with strains carrying intact psm-mec, and some mutated strains produced high amounts of PSMα comparable with that of CA-MRSA. Deletion of psm-mec from HA-MRSA strains carrying intact psm-mec increased the expression of AgrA protein and PSMα, and virulence in mice. Thus, psm-mec RNA suppresses MRSA virulence via inhibition of agrA translation and the absence of psm-mec function in CA-MRSA causes its high virulence property.
 Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The disease can range from mild to severe, with the potential for life-threatening complications. The current understanding of dengue pathogenesis is limited due to the lack of suitable animal models. We have previously reported that AG129 mice, which lack type I interferon receptors, can be used as a model for dengue infection. In this study, we used A129 mice, which have an intact type I interferon receptor signaling pathway, to investigate the role of type I interferon in dengue pathogenesis. We found that A129 mice born to dengue immune mothers were more susceptible to dengue infection and developed severe disease compared to mice born to naive mothers. Our results suggest that type I interferon plays a protective role in dengue pathogenesis.
 The study is the first systematic review with meta-analysis about factors associated with Leishmania infantum infection in humans in the Americas. The study found that male sex, younger individuals, lower socioeconomic status, and highly vegetated areas were associated with L. infantum infection. The study also identified some inconsistencies in the results of the studies analyzed, which may be due to differences in the quality of the studies, the design used, the methods of data analysis, the control for confounders, and the way results were reported. The study highlights the need for more well-designed studies to better understand the factors associated with L. infantum infection in the Americas.
 Francisella tularensis ( Ft ) is a highly pathogenic bacterium that causes acute and fatal pneumonia in humans and animals . The lung cytokine milieu favors exponential Ft replication, but the mechanisms underlying acute pathogenesis and death remain unknown . In this study, the authors found that in contrast to overwhelming bacterial burden or cytokine production, an overt innate cellular response to Ft drives tissue pathology and host mortality . They also found that lethal infection with Ft elicits medullary and extra-medullary myelopoiesis supporting recruitment of large numbers of immature myeloid cells and MDSC to the lungs . These cells fail to mature and die, leading to subsequent necrotic lung damage, loss of pulmonary function, and host death that is partially dependent upon immature Ly6G+ cells . The authors suggest that acceleration of this process may account for the rapid lethality seen with Ft SchuS4 . In contrast, during sub-lethal infection with Ft LVS the pulmonary cellular response is characterized by a predominance of mature neutrophils and monocytes required for protection, suggesting a required threshold for lethal bacterial infection . Further, eliciting a mature phagocyte response provides transient, but dramatic, innate protection against Ft SchuS4 . This study reveals that the nature of the myeloid cell response may be the primary determinant of host mortality versus survival following Francisella infection .
 The Asian tiger mosquito ( Ae . albopictus ) is a vector of several arboviruses, including chikungunya, dengue, and Zika viruses. It has been rapidly spreading around the world, and its invasion has been facilitated by human activities. In this study, we used population genetics and Approximate Bayesian Computation ( ABC ) approaches to infer the demographic history of Ae . albopictus populations from different regions. We found that the invasion process of this mosquito was primarily supported by a chaotic propagule distribution, which cooperates in maintaining a relatively high genetic diversity within the adventive populations. Our results suggest that independent and trans-continental introductions of Ae . albopictus may have facilitated the rapid establishment of adventive populations through admixture of unrelated genomes. This may extend to the genetic mechanisms controlling vector competence, which may contribute to creating the conditions for the efficient transmission of arboviruses and for outbreak establishment.
 The bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of both acute and chronic infections. While much is known about acute infections, the mechanisms of chronic infections are not well understood. In this study, we examined the genes and functions that are important for the fitness of P. aeruginosa in chronic wound infections. We found that clinical isolates from chronic wounds were often defective in virulence functions and biofilm formation. We also found that many virulence and biofilm formation genes were not required for bacterial fitness in experimental mouse wounds. Instead, genes involved in anaerobic growth, some metabolic and energy pathways, and membrane integrity were critical. These findings suggest that different bacterial functions are important in different phases of infection. We also found that some wound-impaired mutants could be represented by anaerobic, oxidative, and membrane-stress conditions ex vivo, and more comprehensively by high-density bacterial growth conditions in the absence of a host. These data provide insights into the bacterial functions needed in chronic wound infections, the nature of stresses applied to bacteria at infection sites, and suggest therapeutic targets that might compromise wound infection pathogenesis.
 Bancroftian filariasis is a mosquito-borne parasitic disease that affects approximately 100 million persons worldwide . It is estimated that 40 million persons suffer from the chronic disfiguring manifestations of this disease, including 27 million men with testicular hydrocele, lymph scrotum, or elephantiasis of the scrotum . The genital pathology caused by bancroftosis is impressively debilitating and economically punishing for huge numbers of adult males throughout endemic countries. There is consensus that hydrocele is the most frequent clinical manifestation of bancroftian filariasis. On the other hand, few systematic studies of the prevalence or incidence of hydrocele in temperate climates have been published. In spite of this, there appears to be a difference between the hydrocele prevalence in temperate countries and tropical and subtropical ones. In locations where bancroftian filariasis is highly endemic, up to 40% of adult males are reported to have testicular hydrocele. With exception of its posterior aspect, the testicle is covered by the tunica vaginalis formed by two layers. The visceral layer and parietal layer are in direct contact with the testis and the scrotum wall, respectively. Both layers have secretory ability and only the parietal layer has resorption property. Between the layers there is a space called vaginal cavity. The balance of secretory and absorptive functions of these layers results in a small volume (0.5 to 2.0 mL) of straw-colored fluid in this cavity. Outside of congenital hydrocele, the general mechanism accepted for abnormal chronic accumulation of fluid in the vaginal cavity, known as acquired hydrocele, irrespective of the etiology, is an unbalanced process between fluid production by the mesothelial cells of the inner surface of the tunica vaginalis and fluid absorption by the draining lymphatic vessels of the parietal layer. Surgery using different techniques is the standard treatment form for chronic hydrocele, regardless of the etiology, and the rationale for its repair is to expose, permanently, the secretory surface of tunica vaginalis to the absorbing surface of scrotal wall. In Greater Recife, northeastern Brazil, a bancroftian filariasis endemic area, the prevalence of acquired hydrocele in the adult male population is high, and hydrocelectomy represents a commonly performed procedure in public hospitals. At these hospitals, the surgeons' preference is for surgical techniques in which the hydrocele sac is opened, everted with or without partial resection of the sac, and the edges sutured behind the testis (J. Norões, personal communication). The purpose of this study is to evaluate the occurrence of lymphangiectasia in scrotal contents, the morphology and consistency of the testicles, and hydrocele recurrence using the complete excision of tunica vaginalis in hydrocele patients living in a bancroftian filariasis endemic area.
 Trichinella spiralis is a zoonotic parasite that causes trichinellosis, a disease that has been identified on all continents except Antarctica. During chronic infection, T. spiralis larvae infect skeletal myofibres, severely disrupting their differentiation state. In this study, an activity-based probe was used to identify deubiquitinating enzyme (DUB) activity in lysate of T. spiralis L1 larvae. Results were analyzed by immuno-blot and immuno-precipitation, identifying a number of potential DUBs. Immuno-precipitated proteins were subjected to LC/MS/MS, yielding peptides with sequence homology to 5 conserved human DUBs: UCH-L5, UCH-L3, HAUSP, OTU 6B and Ataxin-3. The predicted gene encoding the putative UCH-L5 homologue, TsUCH37, was cloned and recombinant protein was expressed and purified. The deubiquitinating activity of this enzyme was verified by Ub-AMC assay. Co-precipitation of recombinant TsUCH37 showed that the protein associates with putative T. spiralis proteasome components, including the yeast Rpn13 homologue ADRM1. In addition, the UCH inhibitor LDN-57444 exhibited specific inhibition of recombinant TsUCH37 and reduced the viability of cultured L1 larvae. This study reports the identification of the first T. spiralis DUB, a cysteine protease that is putatively orthologous to the human protein, hUCH-L5. Results suggest that the interaction of this protein with the proteasome has been conserved throughout evolution. We show potential for the use of inhibitor compounds to elucidate the role of UCH enzymes in T. spiralis infection and their investigation as therapeutic targets for trichinellosis.
 The cysteine protease cruzipain is a validated target for therapeutic intervention in the treatment of Chagas disease, which is caused by the protozoan parasite T . cruzi . In this study, three nitrile-based cysteine protease inhibitors based on two scaffolds known to be associated with cathepsin K inhibition were tested for their anti-trypanosomal activity against the CL Brener strain of T . cruzi. The two compounds showing the greatest potency against the trypanosome were characterized by EC50 values that were an order of magnitude lower than the corresponding Ki values measured against cruzain, a recombinant form of cruzipain, in an enzyme inhibition assay. This implies that the anti-trypanosomal activity of these two compounds may not be explained only by the inhibition of the cruzain enzyme, thereby triggering a putative polypharmacological profile towards cysteine proteases.
 Maize is one of the most important cereal crops in the world, and its genome is being sequenced to better understand its genetic and evolutionary makeup. To do this, a sequence-ready fingerprinted contig-based physical map was constructed that covers 93.5% of the genome and is anchored to the genetic map. The map contains 25,908 genic markers that enabled the alignment of nearly 73% of the anchored maize genome to the rice genome. Inversions account for the majority of chromosome structural variations during subsequent maize diploidization. Reconstructing the paleoethnobotany of the maize genome indicates that the progenitors of modern maize contained ten chromosomes. This physical map will be a valuable resource for the ongoing maize genome sequencing project and for comparative genomics studies across the cereals.
 Prions are the proteinaceous infectious agents responsible for Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathies (TSEs), a group of fatal neurodegenerative disorders. Sporadic TSEs occur worldwide with an approximate frequency of 1 new case per million people each year. Molecularly, it is thought that sporadic TSEs arise from the low frequency spontaneous misfolding of the prion protein which then propagates to other PrPC molecules in a manner similar as in the infectious cases. In this study, we developed a new method to mimic an early event in the etiology of sporadic disease by attempting de novo generation of infectious PrPSc in vitro. Under standard PMCA conditions, and taking precautions to avoid cross-contamination, de novo generation of PrPSc was never observed, supporting the use of the technology for diagnostic applications. However, we report that PMCA can be modified to generate PrPSc in the absence of pre-existing PrPSc in different animal species at a low and variable rate. De novo generated PrPSc was infectious when inoculated into wild type hamsters, producing a new disease phenotype with unique clinical, neuropathological and biochemical features. Our findings represent additional evidence in support of the prion hypothesis and provide a simple model to study the mechanism of sporadic prion disease. The findings also suggest that prion diversity is not restricted to those currently known and that likely new forms of infectious protein foldings may be produced, resulting in novel disease phenotypes.
 We present a novel neurally based model for estimating angular velocity ( AV ) in the bee brain, capable of quantitatively reproducing experimental observations of visual odometry and corridor-centering in free-flying honeybees. The model is fitted using electrophysiological data and tested using behavioural data. Based on our model, we suggest that the AV response can be considered as an evolutionary extension to the optomotor response. The detector is tested behaviourally in silico with the corridor-centering paradigm, where bees navigate down a corridor with gratings on the walls. When combined with an existing flight control algorithm, the detector reproduces the invariance of the average flight path to the spatial frequency and contrast of the gratings, including deviations from perfect centering behaviour as found in the real bee’s behaviour. In addition, the summed response of the detector to a unit distance movement along the corridor is constant for a large range of grating spatial frequencies, demonstrating that the detector can be used as a visual odometer.
The study reports on a long-term follow-up of a cohort of 50 human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) patients from the Ivory Coast. The study found that 11 patients refused treatment after their initial diagnosis. In 10 out of 11 subjects who continued to refuse treatment despite repeated visits, parasite clearance was observed using both microscopy and polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Most of these subjects also displayed decreasing serological responses, becoming progressively negative to trypanosome variable antigens. Hence, in addition to the “classic” lethal outcome of HAT, the study shows that alternative natural progressions of HAT may occur: progression to an apparently aparasitaemic and asymptomatic infection associated with strong long-lasting serological responses and progression to an apparently spontaneous resolution of infection associated with a progressive drop in antibody titres as observed in treated cases. The study demonstrates that a number of subjects display such infection courses. From the authors' point of view, recognizing that trypanotolerance exists in humans is a major step forward for future research in the field of HAT.
γ-irradiation is a well-known carcinogen that causes DNA damage and mutations. However, it is not clear how these mutations contribute to cancer development. In this study, the authors found that loss of the tumor suppressor gene p53 confers a survival advantage following γ-irradiation in short-term survival assays. They also found that p53 null hematopoietic cells are resistant to γ-irradiation-induced death and loss of clonogenic potential. However, the authors found that short-term resistance to genotoxic stress conferred by p53 mutation often does not correlate with long-term survival. The authors also found that irradiation dramatically accelerates tumorigenesis in p53 heterozygous adult mice. They suggest that loss of p53 function may be selected for following irradiation. The authors conclude that the carcinogenic action of γ-irradiation might involve both mutagenesis and selection for p53 loss.
 Schistosoma mansoni is a parasite that causes schistosomiasis, a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite produces a serine protease inhibitor called SmKI-1, which has been shown to have anti-inflammatory properties. In this study, the authors investigated the role of SmKI-1 in parasite development and its ability to regulate different models of inflammatory diseases. They found that SmKI-1 inhibits neutrophil migration and function, and that it has the ability to bind to elastase, a protease that is involved in inflammation. The authors also demonstrated that SmKI-1 is essential for parasite survival in vitro and in vivo. Overall, the study suggests that SmKI-1 could be a promising therapeutic molecule for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.
 Membrane proteins are essential for many cellular functions and are involved in many diseases. However, they are difficult to study because they are embedded in the cell membrane. To overcome this problem, researchers have developed methods to predict the structure of membrane proteins from their amino acid sequence. These methods are based on the idea that similar proteins have similar structures. However, membrane proteins have unique features that make them difficult to predict. To address this problem, researchers have developed a new method that uses a combination of different techniques to predict the structure of membrane proteins. This method has been tested on several different membrane proteins and has been shown to be very accurate. This method should be useful for predicting the structure of many different membrane proteins, which could help researchers understand how these proteins work and how they are involved in diseases.
 Listeria monocytogenes is a foodborne pathogen that causes listeriosis, a rare but serious disease. In this study, researchers used human hepatocytes and trophoblast cells to study the behavior of L. monocytogenes during a long-term infection. They found that bacteria cease to polymerize actin and are enclosed in vacuoles after the actin-dependent motility phase. This phenotypic switch is correlated with a decreased expression of ActA at the bacterial surface. In addition, ΔactA mutants enter a viable but non-culturable (VBNC) state during long-term infection. The formation of LisCVs could potentially enable the persistence of this pathogen in epithelial tissues.
 This study presents a neuromechanistic model of auditory streaming that incorporates sensory feature dependent inputs and neuronal competition to predict the dynamics of alternating percepts in long-term auditory streaming. The model is based on the idea that the initial perceptual phase is followed by a series of irregular alternations between segregated and integrated percepts. The model is constrained by experimental data from a study that manipulated the frequency difference between tones in an ABA-triplet paradigm. The model predicts that the duration of the dominant percept is affected more by the frequency difference between tones than by the presentation rate. The study confirms this prediction and uses the behavioral data to further constrain and improve the model. The model provides a platform for studying other stimulus conditions and the effects of context and volition.
 Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic flatworm that causes schistosomiasis, a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The immune response to S. mansoni infection is characterized by a strong Th2 response, which is thought to be protective against reinfection. However, the specific antigens that trigger this response are not well understood. In this study, the authors developed a new method for assessing the allergenicity of S. mansoni antigens using a humanized rat basophilic leukemia cell line and wheat germ lysate translation. The method allows for rapid and high-throughput assessment of allergenicity without the need for purification of the translated proteins. The authors demonstrated the utility of the method by assessing the allergenicity of known S. mansoni allergens and identifying new allergens. The study provides a valuable tool for the development of safe and effective vaccines against S. mansoni.
 We here characterize the effects that divergence in the TE profile between parents has on offspring in the Drosophila virilis syndrome of hybrid dysgenesis. We show that divergence in the TE landscape is associated with persisting differences in germline TE expression when comparing genetically identical females of reciprocal crosses and these differences are transmitted to the next generation. Moreover, chronic and persisting TE expression coincides with increased levels of genic piRNAs associated with reduced gene expression. Combined with these effects, we further demonstrate that gene expression is idiosyncratically influenced by differences in the genic piRNA profile of the parents that arise through polymorphic TE insertions. Overall, these results support a model in which early germline events in dysgenesis establish a chronic, stable state of both TE and gene expression in the germline that is maintained through adulthood and transmitted to the next generation. This work demonstrates that divergence in the TE profile is associated with diverse piRNA-mediated transgenerational effects on gene expression within populations.
 Fragile X Tremor Ataxia Syndrome ( FXTAS ) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by expansion of a CGG trinucleotide repeat in the 5′UTR of the fragile X syndrome ( FXS ) gene , FMR1 . The expanded CGG repeat is thought to induce toxicity as RNA , and in FXTAS patients mRNA levels for FMR1 are markedly increased . Despite the critical role of FMR1 mRNA in disease pathogenesis , the basis for the increase in FMR1 mRNA expression is unknown . Here we show that overexpressing any of three histone deacetylases ( HDACs 3 , 6 , or 11 ) suppresses CGG repeat–induced neurodegeneration in a Drosophila model of FXTAS . This suppression results from selective transcriptional repression of the CGG repeat–containing transgene . These findings led us to evaluate the acetylation state of histones at the human FMR1 locus . In patient-derived lymphoblasts and fibroblasts , we determined by chromatin immunoprecipitation that there is increased acetylation of histones at the FMR1 locus in pre-mutation carriers compared to control or FXS derived cell lines . These epigenetic changes correlate with elevated FMR1 mRNA expression in pre-mutation carrier cell lines . Consistent with this finding , histone acetyltransferase ( HAT ) inhibitors repress FMR1 mRNA expression to control levels in pre-mutation carrier cell lines and extend lifespan in CGG repeat–expressing Drosophila . These findings support a disease model whereby the CGG repeat expansion in FXTAS promotes chromatin remodeling in cis , which in turn increases expression of the toxic FMR1 mRNA . Moreover , these results provide proof of principle that HAT inhibitors or HDAC activators might be used to selectively repress transcription at the FMR1 locus .
The immune system plays a crucial role in protecting the body from infections. However, during chronic infections, the immune system can become exhausted, leading to the development of immunopathology. In this study, researchers examined the impact of MHC heterogeneity versus non-MHC host genetics on the development of chronic viral infection. They found that increased MHC diversity allowed for a broader CD8 T cell response, which was able to more rapidly control persistent viral infection. However, F1 mice expressing a H-2bxd haplotype on different genetic backgrounds exhibited differences in both CD8 T cell exhaustion and CD4 T cell subset distribution, resulting in differences in viral control and disease. Unexpectedly, H-2bxd mice on a C57BL background succumbed to LCMV Cl-13 infection in a T-cell- and IFN-γ-dependent manner. These findings suggest that both MHC haplotype and genetic background together influence host resistance to CD8 T cell exhaustion and disease susceptibility following LCMV Cl-13 infection.
 Anthrax is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis. It is endemic in many countries, including China, where it is primarily found in rural areas. In this study, the authors analyzed the genetic characteristics of B. anthracis strains isolated from anthrax outbreaks in northwestern China from 1990 to 2016. They used two methods, canonical single-nucleotide polymorphism (canSNP) analysis and multilocus variable-number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA), to analyze the strains. The authors found that five sublineages/subgroups of B. anthracis were present in northwestern China, including A . Br . 001/002, A . Br . Vollum, A . Br . Aust94, A . Br . Ames and A . Br . 008/009. They also found that the geographical distribution of B. anthracis populations in northwestern China was gradually becoming balanced. This study provides important information for the prevention and control of anthrax in China.
 The human intestinal microbiota is a complex community of microorganisms that plays a crucial role in maintaining human health. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiota influences host health are not well understood. In this study, we used a mouse model of intestinal inflammation to investigate the role of the microbiota in regulating host immunity. We found that the microbiota modulates host immunity by altering the expression of genes involved in immune signaling pathways.
